PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles (from 153 citizens), Mr Ronaldson (from 29 citizens) and Mr Taylor (from 10 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

PETITION.PARA: World-wide, people are aware that important natural resources, such as trees, soil, pure air, water, and our Earth's protective ozone layer—all vital to life and human livelihood—have been dangerously depleted.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore urge that the Australian Parliament will:

PETITION.PARA: Let Australia lead the way and legislate to implement the Earth Repair Charter which is a practical solution-strategy to help rectify humanity's environmental, social and economic imbalances, towards achieving just, sustainable and peaceful, local and global communities.

PARA.TAB: The Earth Repair Charter's Objectives (In Summary):

PETITION.PARA: Implement an Earth Repair Action decade;
Cooperate in peace for the environment;
Protect our remaining natural heritage;
Support the world's indigenous people;
Recognise interconnectedness of all life;
Use permaculture to end world hunger;
Cultivate a `sense of humus' for soils;
Acquire vital immunity efficiency;
Educate for and practise healthy living;
Unite humanity in a common purpose.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Costello (from 18 citizens) and Mr Dodd (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Access
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: 1.That we the undersigned citizens wish to signify our strong support for everyone in the community having access to quality healthcare services when they need them.
2.That we believe because people are being discouraged from providing for their own healthcare that not everyone has equal access to quality healthcare services.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

PETITION.PARA: Ensure that the Federal Government provides tax credits or rebates to encourage people to have private healthcare funding where they can afford it, so that all Australians will have equal access to quality healthcare.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Mack (from 513,445 citizens) and Mr Allan Morris (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that certain persons wish to change the National Flag of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request that no change to the National Flag of Australia be made without a full referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Refugees: Port Hedland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble undersigned citizens earnestly pray, that because of the uncertain situation existing in Vietnam and Cambodia it could be cruel and unjust to repatriate those presently held in detention in Port Hedland and other places, who are rejected as being "refugees".

PARA.TAB: That they be given the alternate status of "Domestic Temporary Resident" for a period of two years.
That such a status be granted if sponsored by other Australian individuals or groups, with the guarantee of housing these people for the term of their temporary residency.
That those who are granted such a status be allowed to move freely about the Country, accept work and do skills training.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Organochlorine Pesticides
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House:
That we understand that the organochlorine pesticides heptachlor and aldrin have been banned or restricted for health and/or environmental concerns in 34 and 41 nations overseas (respectively).
They are still widely used in Australia for termite control under and around buildings and homes.

As effective non-chemical alternatives are becoming available for the control of termites, we fail to see why Australians and their environment should tolerate these toxic, persistent and bioaccumulative pesticides any longer.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House takes immediate steps to ban all uses of the organochlorine pesticides, particularly for urban termite control.

PETITION.TITLE: Genetic Engineering and Cloning
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: We citizens of Australia and custodians of the Earth draw to the attention of the House, our concern at the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. Along with the unknown consequences to the Earth's natural life forms and environment, in order for Individuals and Multi National Companies to patent and own the food resources of the world.

We request you to pass laws prohibiting the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. We want you to protect Humanity from the patenting and owning, by Individuals and large Corporate Bodies, of unnatural life forms.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Asia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that:
the Australian Broadcasting Corporation intends to transmit television programs into Asia.
apart from an initial grant from the Government it is intended to finance this venture by the introduction of corporate sponsorship.
the Government intends to alter existing broadcasting legislation to allow this to be done.

this course of action would set a precedent which, in our view, would introduce pressures of corporate funding into the ABC and endanger the independence of our national broadcaster in its vital role as Australia's main disseminator of news and information at a time of unprecedented concentration of media ownership in this country.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House either
to ensure that the proposed Asian service be wholly funded by Government
OR that the proposed Asian service not commence until Government funds are available.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Mid-North Coast
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the fact that we are not able to receive SBS TV on the Mid North Coast of N.S.W. Your petitioners therefore request the House to take action to provide SBS TV facilities in the Mid North Coast area in as quick a time span as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Tariffs and Consumer Taxes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: We, the citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House that we who have signed ask all parties, Labour, Liberal, Democrats and Nationals that your petitioners dutifully pray, to stop the importation of over one billion dollars worth of products from overseas (per month) and that to freeze and increase the levels of Australian workers input to all products sold in Australia, for example: cars, trucks, textile, clothing, footwear, white goods, food products etc. Also no new taxes on their products which will hit all companies and workers in Australia and will not be beneficial to this great country or its people. We therefore pray for a referendum on tariffs and consumer taxes.
Before the next election 1992/93 and before being passed in Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Migraine Drug, Sumitriptan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Ballarat draws to the attention of the House that hundreds of migraine sufferers have been denied easy access to a new effective and safe migraine treatment known as Sumitriptan.

This treatment, which has been approved by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, has been rejected for inclusion on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. The tablets cost about $30 each and consequently will be out of reach for most sufferers resulting in migraine sufferers enduring unnecessary pain and inactivity. The drug is widely used overseas, approved in at least 23 countries and has an 80 per cent success rate.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take urgent steps to ensure that Sumitriptan is listed on the PBS.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
(1)We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
(2)We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tariffs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House

that with more than 10 per cent of Australians out of work, the concept of a level playing field and zero tariffs is rejected by Australian families who can see no evidence of benefit but substantial losses from the arguments put by economic rationalists.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to

act to ensure that Australia maintains a viable processing industry based on our rural industries and that tariffs remain in place as long as other nations use non-tariff measures, tariff protection, etc.;
stop imports of goods that are supported by subsidies and other non-tariff or dumping measures to Australia; and
restore profitability to our farms and factories, employment opportunities to our citizens and to provide a future for our youth.

PETITION.TITLE: Tariffs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House

PETITION.PARA: that with more than 10 per cent of Australians out of work, the concept of a level playing field and zero tariffs is rejected by Australian families who can see no evidence of benefit but substantial losses from the arguments put by economic rationalists.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request the House to

act to ensure that Australia maintains a viable processing industry based on our rural industries and that tariffs remain in place as long as other nations use non-tariff measures, tariff protection, etc;
stop imports of goods that are supported by subsidies and other non-tariff or dumping measures to Australia; and
protect Australians and ensure secure employment for Australian families in industries producing goods for the Australian market.

PETITION.TITLE: Tariffs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House—

PETITION.PARA: that with more than ten per cent of Australians unable to obtain useful, paid employment, the concepts of the level playing field and zero tariffs are rejected because they produce substantial losses and provide no benefits, despite wordy defence of them by economic rationalists.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore urge the House to act to ensure that Australia:-

PETITION.PARA: maintains processing industries based on our well-established rural industries;
retains protective tariffs while any other nation with which we trade uses such or similar measures to provide for its own protection;
prevents imports into Australia of goods or services subsidised, dumped or supported by any non-tariff measures;
restores profitability for Australia's farms and factories; and
provides valuable developmental employment opportunities for all Australians needing them, particularly our youth.

PETITION.TITLE: Nambour TAFE College
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the support of the residents of the Sunshine Coast to have the new campus for the Queensland University of Technology on the Sunshine Coast situated at Nambour such campus to share the site and facilities presently enjoyed by the Nambour T.A.F.E. College.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Government to consider the wishes of the petitioners as representatives of the residents of the area and to fund the proposed university at the above site.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House our strongest support for the existing National Flag.
The Australian National Flag is the most important symbol of the Australian nation and our national unity, and has evoked deep feelings of honour and respect for many generations of Australians.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to preserve our current Australian National Flag and to ensure that its design is not changed without the support of a referendum carried by the majority of Australians in the majority of States.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of the undersigned residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House the precarious position of Australia's independent magazine publishers due to the recent decision by Australia Post to abolish the Registered Publications scheme and cause a rise of between 78.5% and 223.5% in postal charges (depending on weight and destination) for subscriber magazines over an 18 month period. For example, to mail a 300g magazine cost 47 cents in August 1990 under the Registered Publications scheme. It now costs up to $1.52.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners pray that the House, as a matter of urgency:

PETITION.PARA: (a)Takes action to ensure that the registered publications service is saved.
(b)Ensures that such discriminatory eligibility criteria for registered publications as cover price ceilings are forbidden, placing all Australian magazines on an equal footing.

(c)Removes the constant threat of crippling prices rises from the independent publishing industry by ensuring that postal rate increases for magazines are set at 50% of the consumer price index commencing retrospectively at January 1, 1990.
(d)Takes action to ban discriminatory price loadings for interstate and country subscribers, giving all Australians equal access to magazines.

(e)Protects diversity of media ownership in Australia as a mainstay of our democracy by legislating the maintenance of the registered publications service as a community service obligation of Australia Post.

(f)Ensures that all future decisions affecting the carriage of magazines by Australia Post are made in conjunction with a publishing industry committee representing both non-profit and independent publishers to ensure that the best features of both registered publications and print post are maintained.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Malaysia from 24 June to 2 July 1992. I am delighted to table the report. Although some time has elapsed since the visit, most of the observations contained in the report remain very current. Regrettably, not all of the participants in the delegation are currently members of parliament and some of the contributors cannot be here for the tabling of the report today. Of those who are absent, I single out the deputy leader of the delegation, Mr Bruce Cowan, who retired as the member for Lyne on 13 March. Having known Bruce in both the New South Wales and Federal parliaments, I have always found him to be a very amiable companion. Travelling together only enhanced my view of him. He was at all times most pleasant and very constructive—a true gentleman in the finest sense of the word.

PARA.TAB: That aside, I would like to thank all the members of the delegation for their contribution. Having myself participated in only the Malaysian leg of a three-country tour, I was somewhat fresher than the other delegates, who looked a little drained on our first meeting in Kuala Lumpur. Nevertheless, we all warmed to the occasion and enjoyed what was a fascinating and successful visit. The visit could not have been so successful without the efforts of Frank Murray and all the staff of the Australian High Commission in Kuala Lumpur. I would like to place on the record my appreciation of their efforts both before and during the visit.

It is fair to say that in the period between the visits of the 1988 and 1992 delegations the High Commission had to manage a very difficult period in the bilateral relationship. As the focal point of government efforts to both articulate Australia's position and return relations to an even keel, theirs was not always a comfortable or enjoyable task. Nevertheless, what was and always has been a solid bilateral relationship was very much on a secure footing by the time of our arrival in June 1992. Indeed, the delegation's visit was symbolic of the full rapprochement which had been achieved in the preceding year or so.

The solid level of the relationship was underlined by the high-level access that the delegation was accorded. In addition to being received by the President of the Senate, the delegation met with the Ministers for Foreign Affairs, Defence, Justice and Finance. These meetings gave the delegation a feel for the Malaysian priorities and policy perceptions. While much is made of the differences which periodically surface, there remains a strong degree of shared outlook which stems from our joint status as middle ranking Commonwealth Asian-Pacific powers. The strength of the bilateral relationship has been forged on our close defence, five-power and educational ties. However, this is increasingly being complemented by growing economic linkage.

At the time of our visit figures were released showing that Australia had the highest foreign investment in Malaysia for the first quarter of 1992. Although a large investment by BHP contributed greatly to this, it was evidence of the growing importance of Australian capital to Malaysia's impressive eight per cent per annum economic growth. If trade and investment are to continue their rapid growth, it will depend to a significant degree on there being an open and liberal trading regime in the area. It was plain from our discussions that Malaysia and Australia shared the same view on this, although there is some debate about the most appropriate vehicle to guarantee open regional trade. By encouraging more people to people contact, growing trade and investment are helping to bring our countries together in a way generations of Malaysian students studying in Australia have in the past. Indeed, the two developments are complementary, as Australian investors can find a rich source of contacts and expertise in the ranks of former Malaysian students in Australia. This is boosted by the strong English language tradition and the impressive infrastructure which has quickly been developed.

Culturally, the delegation witnessed positive developments in the relationship, prominent amongst them an exhibition of Kuruwarri ancestral art at the Selangor State Museum in Shah Alam. For my part, that was one of the highlights of the visit. What was also very encouraging was the very positive reception from our hosts to the idea of having more leadership and cultural exchanges, in particular a young leaders exchange. Such contact can only enhance future understandings.

The delegation was left in no doubt that now and in the future the media will have an important role to play in the bilateral relationship. Having been a source of friction at times, the media could also promote greater awareness of each other's societies. It would be helpful, I think, to the process of understanding if an Australian media organisation—at least one and hopefully more—had a permanent presence in KL; a permanent presence exhibiting the right mix of cultural sensitivity and commitment to freedom of expression. In the absence of a permanent presence, short-term journalistic exchanges and working visits with access to the Malaysian Government would be worth promoting.

I will leave it to my colleague the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), to give his view of what I regarded as a very successful visit. I thank him for his support in the delegation. In summing up my overall impression, I will simply say that it was one of a relationship on the upswing, with enormous potential for economic, cultural and political expansion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not duplicate many of the points that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) has just made but I certainly echo his comments. I would like to support his comments about Bruce Cowan, and also to join those with similar comments about another member of the delegation, Lloyd O'Neil, the former member for Grey, who also retired from the Parliament at the last election.

PARA.TAB: My last personal exposure to Malaysia was in the 1950s, when I was there as a young serviceman during the communist insurgency period. As honourable members may well imagine, that country has changed out of all recognition in the intervening 35 years, which may indicate why I have a few grey hairs. I am not going to go through the detail of the report, but there are a few key things that we need to take on board as Australians in our relationship with Malaysia.

The first point I make is about education. We have some 10,000-odd Malaysian students coming to our universities in this country. Right across Malaysia it was made very clear to us by our own staff there and the Malaysian Government and individuals that there is an urgent need for us to provide more places. That does two things: it provides more cash for this country, if we can create those places, but the real benefit is in the longer term, because many of the future leaders of that country will come from that group who go to university. Rather than have them going off to America or the UK or somewhere like that and learning the culture there and making contacts with the future leaders of those countries, they really ought to be doing it here.

In Butterworth we had a comprehensive briefing on the five-power defence arrangements It was disappointing that the schedule could not be arranged so that we could meet the Australian service personnel but, again, it is an area where there is plenty of opportunity for future Australian cooperation with Malaysia and for enhancement of our relationships with that country.

On the subject of the Australian media, it was made very clear on a number of occasions that no Australian media organisation has a presence in Malaysia. Of course, our media have been the source of some past problems between the two countries. It seems to me that if the media understood some of the Malaysian environment a bit better some of those problems may not have been so difficult. I am not suggesting that the media need to be stifled, but I do believe that, if they were better informed by having an on the ground presence, we might find that some of those difficulties would not occur in the future.

As the coalition's representative on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and as a member in the last Parliament of the House of Representatives Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, I was particularly pleased to attend the exhibition of Aboriginal art at the Selangor State Museum.

In economic matters, the overwhelming impression is one of very competent planning. In Kuala Lumpur there is a national planning organisation; each of the States has a State planning organisation. At Malacca we visited an Australian company, Ansell International. We are grateful to the people there for their hosting of us. It is important to note that that company is not there just for cheap labour but because the country has a more progressive attitude to business planning. There are tax incentives; there are all sorts of land opportunities there. The Australian businesses go there for very positive reasons, so we are competing against that in this country and need to be aware of it.

There are considerable environmental problems in Malaysia, and we have the skills and expertise to help, to cooperate and develop our businesses there.In Penang there are some lessons for Australia about incentives and quick decisions. Businesses there have a one-stop shop approach. Increasingly, they are moving away from that cheap labour-intensive area into more high-tech areas. Perhaps there is also a lesson in terms of a new international airport, which in Malaysia has been planned, approved and is off and running, whilst we are still talking about one.

We visited a refugee camp where some of the children had been born and had lived for eight years. We should not forget that there are still refugees in that country—from Vietnam in particular—who need to be looked after. One of our number, Senator Chamarette, paid a visit to Michael McAuliffe, an Australian under sentence of death, and we raised with the Government our concerns with regard to the death penalty.

I echo the thanks to Frank Murray, the High Commissioner, and his staff and to Peter Hicks, the secretary of the delegation. Finally, I stress that Malaysia has the same size population as Australia. It has made tremendous progress in the last 30 years, certainly coming off a lower base, but it seems to me that it is a good example of what national discipline and dedication can achieve. Perhaps we should take note from that lesson.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Republic of Korea and Pakistan

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Republic of Korea and Pakistan from 10 to 23 June 1992. In case my colleagues think I spend my life travelling, let me say that this trip was actually part of the trip to Malaysia that I spoke on before. We went to Korea and Pakistan and then the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), who spoke previously, joined us for the Malaysian leg of the trip. The leader of the delegation was Lloyd O'Neil, who is no longer in the Parliament. The deputy was Bruce Cowan, the previous member for Lyne, who is also no longer in the Parliament. Senator Chamarette joined us, as did my colleague the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman), who will speak after me this morning.

PARA.TAB: It was my first visit to Korea, and it was a very impressive exercise. Korea is Australia's third most important export market, mostly in bulk commodities, and therefore this country nurses its relationship with Korea very carefully. Australian Ministers make frequent visits to that country, and vice versa. The relationship between Australia and Korea is developing in important new areas, including science and technology developments and increases in tourism, both to and from Australia.

However, there are a number of problems in the relationship. The phrase `supply diversification' had not actually registered with me very much before I went to Korea. Supply diversification means that, even if we can supply all of the iron ore that Koreans need at the best price in the world, they are still not going to buy it all from us. They might, for example, buy a third from us, a third from a second country and a third from another country. The Koreans do that for three reasons: firstly, to ensure that they have competition; secondly, if there are any industrial relations problems or whatever here, it means that they have continuity of supply; and, thirdly and perhaps more importantly, it enables them to keep the downward price pressure on the product.

We also raised questions of market liberalisation, particularly for beef and rice. We can produce rice much more efficiently than they can there. I have to report that, in real world terms, we got nowhere. The Koreans have a political lobby and have, I think, very little intention of moving on those aspects.

They did express a number of concerns about the proposed Japanese peacekeeping operations. The reasons for that concern are historical. Over the last 500 or 600 years the Japanese have invaded Korea on a number of occasions. The thought that the Japanese might be sending some troops overseas, for whatever purpose, certainly produces heartburn in most Koreans.

We also had the opportunity to visit the demilitarised zone between North and South Korea. Of course, reunification is a major issue and has been for a long time. We got the very clear impression that reunification is not a question of if, but of when and how. I think there has been a slight cooling of their ardour in that respect since they have seen the impact on the German economy of the reunification of Germany. Whilst South Korea is going very well in economic terms, North Korea is certainly not, and I think the South Koreans have learnt a couple of salutary lessons about the potential damage it could do to their economy when reunification occurs.

We visited the Pohang Iron and Steel Corporation in the south of the country. I have visited steelworks in this country and in one or two other parts of the world, and I found visiting this Korean steelworks to be a very interesting experience indeed. That visit is reported in the delegation's report as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: A feature of the Delegation's visit to South Korea was the opportunity to meet with POSCO —
that is the Pohang Iron and Steel Corporation—

representatives and inspect its operations. POSCO is Australia's single most important customer in South Korea purchasing $500 million worth of coal and iron ore annually. This represents about 17 per cent of Australia's total exports to South Korea.
South Korea's steel industry was established with technical assistance from Australia. Initially POSCO was a government owned enterprise but now private enterprise is a significant shareholder.

POSCO's physical operations were impressive not only in scale but also in their standard of technical efficiency. One particularly commendable aspect is the high priority given to the environmental impact of the company's operations through a system of emission monitoring and control.

In fact, POSCO's operations and a major tourist activity are almost collocated and it is hard to pick the difference. We walked around that steelworks wearing white gloves, touching everything in sight, and when we gave back the gloves they were as white as when we put them on. It was a very impressive situation. The Korean record on human rights was not as impressive. Everywhere we went there were riot troops on the streets and, of course, Amnesty International is still reporting concerns in that country.

PARA.TAB: There are tremendous environmental problems in Korea. In Seoul one cannot see very far when one gets up in the morning, even if one is in a high-rise hotel, because of the pollution. Also, the traffic is quite appalling. That is part of the cost of Korea's economic progress and Koreans are beginning to start to take some notice of it.

I would certainly like to thank our hosts in Korea. I thank Mr Gribble, the Australian Ambassador, and his staff. I thank also the Australian Consul in Pusan, the management of POSCO and all those who helped in planning the trip.

I would like to turn now to the Pakistan leg of the visit. I last stopped off in Pakistan about 35 years ago. I did not expect to be in this House talking about that visit. During the trip Mr O'Neill and Mr Cowan, who are no longer with us, were presented with some local costumes. They were going to come into this chamber to present this report wearing the local costumes. I have to tell the House that they have now gone and taken the costumes with them so I could not provide that little bit of local colour for this morning's occasion.

This was the first Australian parliamentary delegation to visit Pakistan. We received a very warm reception but I have to say—and honourable members will have gathered this from the news this morning—that security is a big issue in that country. Everywhere we went, guns were evident. The streets had to be closed for our convoy. We went to Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad and Peshawar, and we visited the Khyber Pass.

In addition to meeting various Ministers, officials and business people, we had meetings with Benazir Bhutto and with some civil rights groups. We talked to a number of groups about the treatment of women in that country—which I have to say, in our terms, leaves an incredible amount to be desired.

We received a lot of press coverage. There are a number of difficult issues there. There is the conflict with India over Kashmir, which is the reason why Pakistan states that it requires a nuclear capability. Another effect, in terms of the dispute with India over Kashmir, is that it is the justification for spending incredible amounts of money on defence. A very high proportion of the national budget, in a very poor country, is spent on defence.

Afghanistan has been a problem that has resulted in many refugees entering Pakistan. When we visited the Khyber Pass we watched the refugees starting to go back to Afghanistan at the rate of 7,000 a day. They were living in quite appalling conditions. We visited a refugee camp in Peshawar. There were 200,000 people in just one of dozens and dozens of camps around the country. The countryside has been stripped bare by the inhabitants of those camps in their search for firewood. Diet and hygiene are at very basic levels. Pakistan is doing its best to cope with those issues but really it is an appalling situation.

On broader issues, the break-up of the former Soviet Union, right on the border of Pakistan, is raising concerns because of the fear of the emergence of old tensions in some of the smaller countries that are now emerging there.

Pakistan certainly needs more aid if it is to deal with a number of incredible problems. One is the environment. Only four per cent of the forestry cover is left and that, of course, means that the soil is just blowing away. The country has tremendous water pollution problems as well. The population of 135 million is increasing at an amazing rate. It is overwhelmingly young and, of course, where there is a young and aggressive population that is not educated and very poor, there is the potential for serious problems to develop in the future.

In the education area, the literacy rate is only 25 per cent. There is a 64 per cent attendance rate at primary school, 24 per cent at secondary school, and only 2 per cent of the population receive tertiary education. It seems to me that that is another area where Australia could look to provide aid in the future.
In terms of human rights I would just like to read one small paragraph from our report. We have said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the Delegation's view that the human rights situation in Pakistan remains quite unsatisfactory on many fronts. Specific matters brought to the attention of the Delegation include the use by police of fictitious and old First Information Reports (FIRs) to initiate arrests, killings by security personnel, women averaging at least two years in prison before their cases go to court and the rape of female activists in police stations and polling stations.

There really is quite a bad record there. We visited our mine clearance training personnel, who are engaged on very hazardous work. We recognise that they are there and compliment them on the fine work they are doing.

PARA.TAB: I would certainly like to thank our hosts in that country. I would like to thank Roy Clogstromm, the acting High Commissioner, and his staff; the Korean and Pakistan representatives in this country who helped plan our visits; and Peter Hicks, the secretary to the delegation. In conclusion, in both of the countries that we went to, we had a warm reception. Pakistan, in particular, is a country of incredible problems. By comparison, we are very much the lucky country. When one visits a place like that and comes back here, one very much appreciates being an Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been fortunate in my short time here—10 years, in fact—in that I have visited South Korea on no fewer than four occasions: two on official delegations and, of course, two with my wife, Jenny, as a private visitor. It absolutely astounds the eye to see the industrialisation that has occurred between the visits. The country can be very proud of its short history, as it has produced such an astounding industrial empire in that time.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, I should have spoken to my colleague the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) before this debate on the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Republic of Korea and Pakistan, because almost word for word he has said what I was about to say. So now I have to pick bits and pieces out of the report

With the tolerance of the House, I will do the best I can in the short period of time allocated to me. The relations between Australia and South Korea have been cemented by the number of visits that have been made to that country by our Ministers. I am sure that under this Labor Government the continued flow of Ministers to Korea—and, of course, Ministers from Korea to this country—will only cement the relationships much further.

The visit some 12 or 18 months ago by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) was one of the best visits made in the last three or four years. She is a very good ambassador for Australia when she goes overseas, as is every one of our Ministers—and also you, Mr Speaker, as you make the trips that will be accorded to you over the next many years. I know—even when I leave the Parliament after the next election; this is my last term—that the future Labor governments of this country, for the next 20 years or so, will cement relationships with all of the countries that the Speaker visits.

Tourism was mentioned by the honourable member for Aston. Tourism is going to be one of the biggest things that happens to this country. I remember John Brown speaking about it on numerous occasions when he was a Minister in the previous Government. Tourism has proven, over the short period since he left, to be one of the big moneymakers for this country. The tourists from this country going to other countries are helping their national coffers with the Australian dollar, which has always been around US$0.70. I look forward to going back to South Korea. I will make one more tour privately in the next couple of years, assuming that I am still here with my feet on the ground.

I also refer to the visit to the steelworks, as was mentioned by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Aston. The leader at the time, Lloyd O'Neil, was my brother in politics, I claimed. He was an old metal worker from the Iron Triangle—a welder by trade and profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good member.

—Yes, a very good member. He is sadly missed in this Parliament. The thing that stood out was the fact that we could walk around the entire steelworks and put our hands wherever we liked, and the white gloves which had been supplied were still white when we handed them back. When we were taken to lunch in the offices of the steelworks, they were really not any cleaner than almost the rest of the works. The steelworks' association with its work force and with the families that live in and around the area is absolutely astounding. There could be some lessons to be learned by our steelworks—in the Newcastle area and on the Illawarra coast—that would bring them into line with the modernisation of steelworks.

PARA.TAB: As also previously stated, the technical knowledge for that steelworks was supplied, certainly in parts, by the management of our own steelworks. That is something we should be grateful for. We have the technology and we have shown another country in the world that it can do it. I just thank Peter Hicks and the rest of the members of the delegation for the courtesy and help they showed me and my wife during the visit.
Bill presented by Mr Ruddock, and read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in your absence from the chair yesterday, I did congratulate you through your Deputy. I will not do so again, but I do present the Social Security Amendment (Listed Securities) Bill 1993 and the explanatory memorandum to it. The coalition made a commitment last year to review the Government's proposal to treat unrealised capital gains on listed shares held by pensioners and other beneficiaries as income. That was a commitment we made after very wide consultation with interested groups. Particularly in the context of during the election and afterwards, we in the Opposition decided to repeal this section of legislation that had previously been enacted; and this Bill seeks to do just that.

PARA.TAB: In the six months since the Government brought in legislation amending the Social Security Act to provide for the treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners and other beneficiaries as income, there has been a great deal of evidence now made available that the schema that the Government has proposed is unlikely to realise its objective. We know from the department that there is something in the order of 81,000 pensioners who hold shares and, of these, 60,000 are expected to be affected by this measure. The Government has suggested that, in relation to those 60,000 pensioners, there will be an average reduction of about $1,100 a year. That is the very reason that they expect to save $61 million.

On questioning the Department of Social Security in relation to that matter, what has become very clear is that it made no assumptions whatever about the impact that these proposals would have upon the behaviour of pensioners. I think every honourable member ought to be concerned about this provision. It will affect something in the order, on average—some will have more, others will have less—of 400 beneficiaries or 400 pensioners in each electorate. It is not a small matter: it is a major matter—400 pensioners, on average, in every electorate around Australia. It is going to be a large number of people affected by this particular proposal. It will reduce their income very significantly, on the Government's estimates.

Of course, what we know from all the publicity that has been associated with this is that not only are people being counselled and advised to change their behaviour, but that is exactly what they will do. The Government made no assumptions whatever about changing behaviour in its calculations. In other words, the $61 million that it expects to save will not be a saving at all. One situation I have likened it to is the Government's proposals to impose a sales tax on luxury motor vehicles. It expected to raise a great deal of money from that proposal. It took no account of changed behaviour: people stopped buying luxury motor vehicles and, of course, there were no savings at all, and in the end the Government had to walk away from the particular proposal.

It is nonsense to think that in the discipline of economics people can make judgments about saving large sums of money without taking into account changed behaviour and behavioural aspects. Senator Richardson, in the other place, where a similar Bill has been introduced, endeavoured to undermine our approach in relation to this matter by suggesting it was going to have minimal impact, and that it was only very wealthy pensioners with shareholdings in excess of $100,000 who would be affected by this proposal. He is deluding himself if he thinks that is the case, and honourable members opposite are like lemmings if they think that those arguments hold any validity. The fact is that the particular proposals that the Government has advanced will not achieve the planned outcome, as they are fundamentally flawed.

The proposals are harsh and unconscionable in the way in which they create new inequities. People will be able to move their investments in shares to other non-capital gains affected property, such as caravans, holiday houses and other collectables. The Government's proposals will undermine the certainty of investment decisions that pensioners might be able to take and will result in less investment in Australia by people who are often in a better position to undertake investments. In other words, the proposals are flawed.
This Bill is one deserving of support from this House and I hope that government members will see fit to come on board and ensure that it is enacted.
Bill read a first time.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—In accordance with standing order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)expresses its concern at the suffering of the Somali people and at the breakdown of Government, civil administration and law and order as a result of internal warfare;
(2)expresses its congratulations and appreciation of the Australian troops in Somalia for their outstanding contribution towards peacemaking in Somalia; and
(3)acknowledges the tremendous support of the people of Australia for the serving men and women of the Australian Defence Force in Somalia.

I wish to thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for allowing me, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), Senator MacGibbon and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) to travel to Somalia to witness at first-hand the conditions in that country and the operations of the Australian troops. I express my sorrow that in the middle of the trip Mr Halverson's mother passed away and that a present illness prevents him from speaking on this motion, which I know he would be only too happy to support.

PARA.TAB: I also thank Major John Withers, our escort officer, who did an outstanding job in shepherding the politicians and two journalists, Ian McPhedran from the Canberra Times and Max Blenkin from AAP, who accompanied us.

The United Nations has had 26 peacekeeping operations and Australia has so far participated in 17 of them. I believe that the Australian Defence Force is doing Australia proud in this new area of activity and nowhere more so than in Somalia. No TV clip or newspaper report adequately prepares one for what is seen. It is a level of destruction that I have not witnessed before and, more sadly, it is not the result of natural causes but is man-made.

The best analogy I can give with respect to Baidoa is for us to imagine our own suburbs with every house destroyed; if walls are left standing, anything of value within them has been removed. But the destruction is not just of the houses; it applies to the schools, the courts, the orphanages and to any public infrastructure.

We travelled through Mogadishu. It is a city of one million people and conditions were the same there. To give the House a feeling of what it was like when the Australians arrived at Baidoa—a city of some 25,000 people—every day 300 people were dying on the streets from either gunshot wounds or famine. Of course, all this has changed.

I particularly pay tribute to the commander of the Australian operations in Somalia, Colonel Bill Mellor, to Lieutenant-Colonel Dave Hurley in Baidoa, and to the captain of HMAS Tobruk, Captain Kevin Taylor, as well as to all their serving men and women—they are doing an outstanding job.

Honourable members may recall that the mission of the Australian troops was to ensure the safety of the non-government organisations and the delivery of food to starving people. Certainly they have done that and they have done it exceedingly well, but they have done much more than that: they have been able to provide security within Baidoa and its surrounds. They have liaised with the local population very well and everywhere we went and were recognised as Australians, we were greeted by men, by women and by children. It was very easy to see that Australians were there because I must say that occasionally one of the children would greet us with a very colloquial Australian expression which they could have only learnt from Australian troops. They were held in the highest possible regard by the population.

It did not matter whom we talked to in Somalia, whether it was the commanding general of UNOSOM, General Bir from Turkey, or the head of the UNITAF forces, General Johnston from the United States, who was second in command in the Gulf—they praised the activities of the Australian troops in Somalia and the way they had gone about securing their area of operations. Indeed, they often said it was a model from which other countries had much to learn. When we spoke to elders in Baidoa or when we spoke to them in Audidilly or when we travelled to Berakaba, the consistent theme that came to us was what a terrific job the Australians had done but, please, can they stay. Of course, it was a decision of the Government, fully supported by the Opposition, that this be a one-term tour of duty of 17 weeks, which I might say is now drawing to its conclusion, and that there would be no replacement troops from Australia. As I say, they have done their jobs extremely well.

I must also tell the House that we were privileged to visit some of the non-government organisations in Baidoa, and in particular Care Australia. Whilst the Australian troops have done a tremendous job, I think everyone would agree with me that the non-government organisations at times have acted quite courageously in their operations. It is a point of sadness for us, I think, that at the time the Australian troops are withdrawing, so too is Care Australia.

I talked about the level of destruction. I suppose we were privileged when we were there because we were told that conditions had improved so much and the physical conditions of the areas we had seen had improved so much. But I would like to make two comments about the United Nations. One recurring theme we heard over there was that the United Nations had initially been very slow to move. If that is well founded, the Somalian people have paid an awful price. For us parliamentarians travelling there, there was a frustration that, given the relative security, there was little sign of reconstruction. Given that the Australians had moved with speed to secure an outstanding level of security, the slowness in the reconstruction of Somalia is a matter of concern.

I would also like to say that, even though the cooks always get a bad time, by using American rations and Australian rations they were able to have in Baidoa the best mess, by all accounts, in the whole of Somalia. They were operating 24 hours a day and, of course, also volunteering for their stints of security duties. To my American friends I would just like to pass an observation that generally I think the relationship between Australia and America is outstandingly good, but this could become threatened if ever they want to extend their MREs—meals ready to eat—to the rest of the world. They are singularly awful.

I would make a couple of suggestions to the lessons-learnt team that went across with us. Firstly, fresh food, even occasionally, would have made a big improvement to the severe conditions under which our serving men and women were working. Secondly, the absence of helicopters was puzzling, to say the least. In the type of operations that were being conducted in Somalia, helicopters would have given them speed and would have been a force multiplier. If they are not appropriate in Somalia, one wonders how they can be justified in limited contingencies in Australia.

Thirdly, I think it is probably appropriate to revisit the issue of whether Australia needs Galaxies. The Hercules—and I will mention that in a minute—have a capacity, I think, for about six pallets, whereas the Galaxies have a capacity for something like 26. When we want to move significant numbers of men and women and equipment—as we did in this battalion group—having that larger capacity and then being able to disperse cargo with the Hercules seems to me to make sense. But I am sure that the lessons learnt team will take all those comments into account.

One thing I cannot thank Senator Robert Ray for was the mode of transport. It took us three days to get to Somalia and three days to get back, and the 13-hour leg from Cocos to Richmond was unendurable, particularly given that the heater had broken down. In conclusion, I would like to thank all the members of the delegation. I would like to thank all the serving men and women and the people that we met in Baidoa for their kindness and generosity. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a pleasure this morning to provide strong bipartisan support to this motion by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price). Having spoken to the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) yesterday, I know he would like to have been here but I am sure he is not going to disagree with anything that the honourable member for Chifley, following speakers and I say.

PARA.TAB: There is little doubt about three things: firstly, the tragedy that was and is Somalia; secondly, the professionalism of the Australian Defence Force in that country; and, thirdly, the strong national support for our international efforts in that direction.

The first question that we should all be asking ourselves this morning is: why did Australia do what it did? It is perhaps worth reminding the House of some of the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the tragedy, in his statement on 17 December last year. I will read some excerpts from that statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the end of the dictatorial rule . . . in January 1991, the political and economic institutions in Somalia have disintegrated. Fighting between shifting factional coalitions has compounded the effects of years of economic mismanagement and drought, and led to starvation and political anarchy on a massive scale.

Famine and clan warfare have so far taken the lives of an estimated quarter of a million Somalis. About two million people, or a third of Somalia's pre-war population, are still at risk of starvation.
The Prime Minister went on:

A response was attempted in April this year when the United Nations Security Council—through Resolution 751—established a peacekeeping operation, UNOSOM, to maintain a ceasefire, to promote a political settlement and to provide urgent humanitarian assistance. But UNOSOM was slow to get under way and was not structured adequately to deal with the problems it faced.
He went on to say:

The world was appalled to see Somalis continuing to starve while food donated by the international community was plundered by armed gangs or remained in warehouses because safe passage could not be guaranteed. Violence and extortion continued unabated and those UN troops who did arrive in Somalia found themselves confronted by lack of cooperation and hamstrung by their restrictive rules of engagement.

It was against this bleak background that President Bush made his ground-breaking offer to provide substantial US troops to a new international coalition of forces that would enforce peace in Somalia, not simply try to keep it. The world community, and specifically the United Nations Security Council, welcomed the President's offer and sanctioned Operation Restore Hope through Resolution 794 on 3 December. Member states were invited by the United Nations to contribute to a multinational force.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has decided—in response to resolution 794 and at the invitation also of the United States—to make a large-scale commitment of Australian forces to Operation Restore Hope.

The operation is intended to create a secure environment for the provision of humanitarian relief in Somalia. . . The United Nations has never before sanctioned intervention on such a scale in the internal affairs of a member state for humanitarian purposes.

It is imperative that Operation Restore Hope succeed, not only to help the people of Somalia, but also as a demonstration that the international community, through the United Nations, is capable of responding promptly and effectively to a crisis of this scale.
He finished by saying:

Our contingent will total about 900 personnel, including four rifle companies from 1st Battalion, a reduced squadron of about 30 armoured personnel carriers, and logistic and engineer support elements.

I suppose the second question this morning that we should ask is: how successful have we been in our contribution? I think the degree to which we have been successful is best encapsulated in an article in the Canberra Times on 20 April by Ian McPhedran headed `Troops help to secure a future for Baidoa'. The article reads:

Baidoa—200km inland from Mogadishu—is slowly but surely returning from the dead, thanks to the vigilance of the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment and other Australian personnel working in the ravaged region.
More than 300 people a day were dying in Baidoa last August, victims of famine, disease or violence in a lawless land laid waste by mother nature and clan rivalry.
Today Baidoa—and the 17,000 sq km around the town which is under Australian control—is essentially secure and the people are getting on with the task of rebuilding their lives.

The acting team leader for Care Australia in Baidoa, Anne Morris, said that without the Australian troops the clans and their notorious "technicals"—open vehicles with heavy weapons mounted on them—would still reign in Baidoa.
Without the army to escort aid convoys into the villages, the anarchy that we witnessed here from last August would still be on, and the people still dying in their thousands.
Ms Morris went on to say:
. . . the region had been transformed from the city of death to the city of life, thanks largely to the Australian forces.
She said the Somali people did not want the Australians to leave the area next month but she was certain the French—who will take over from the Australians—would be in no mood to let security drop.

I think the final question, and perhaps the most important question, is: what about Somalia's future? Again, I think this was very well covered in an article in the Australian on 3 March, entitled `Mission Improbable' by Cameron Stewart, in which he said, in part:

The initial task of the troops—to ensure safe delivery of food aid to a country where 300,000 have died from two years of famine and war—has been a remarkable success. But it contrasts starkly with the lack of progress towards establishing the structures for long-term stability.
The message from most ordinary Somalis is blunt: if the soldiers leave, the country will again descend into chaos.
He finished the article by referring to some British explorers in the country last century. He concluded:

More than a century later, Speke's description is still accurate and underpins the fact that Somalia's problems will not be solved by a short-term international food blitz. They are ingrained in a complex cultural tradition which will test the patience, fairness and resolve of the West for longer than it may wish.

I have little doubt that Australia will continue to exercise its mind on this international quandary. I would like to finish by paying tribute to a number of people and to a number of organisations. Firstly, I would like to pay tribute to the United Nations for its foresight and its commitment to the plight of a tragic people and also to its ongoing dedication to peacekeeping operations around the world.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I would like to pay tribute to the Australian people, without whose strong support this humanitarian effort would not have been possible. I would like to pay tribute to both sides of this House whose bipartisan support ensured that commitment.

Fourthly, I would like to pay tribute, of course, to the Australian Defence Force in general: to the Army, Navy and Air Force elements, and to 1RAR and its supporting elements in particular. I also mention 1RAR's commander, Lieutenant-Colonel David Hurley, and the force commander, Colonel Bill Mellor. I want to pay tribute to the professionalism of all of them, and to their ability to get a job done without any fuss—not only in military terms, but beyond—in particular, in the restoration of justice to the area of Baidoa. Finally, I would like to pay tribute to the non-government aid agencies, without whom this humanitarian effort and many others around the world would not have been the success that they clearly are. I salute all concerned in once again coming to grips with this, yet another example of man's inhumanity to man. All of us should be very proud of their collective efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the members of the delegation, I recently had the privilege of travelling to Somalia with the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) and Senator David MacGibbon. I must say at the outset that the experience of seeing a country totally destroyed and the level that the people had been reduced to was something which I do not wish to see ever again. At the same time, I feel it was also an experience to see how so many other countries of the world could actually come together to restore hope to the country of Somalia—and restore hope they have indeed done. Just a few weeks ago, CARE Australia's acting leader in Baidoa, Ms Anne Morris, pointed out the huge changes which have occurred there, going from a situation where some 200 to 300 people were dying per day to a situation where essentially the people were no longer starving and, in fact, were in quite reasonable health.

PARA.TAB: In paying tribute to the Australian forces in their efforts in Somalia, we must, as the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) pointed out, also thank honourable members on both sides of the House and also members of the Australian population for supporting this operation. The United Nations needs to take on board the need to move more quickly to ensure that it has the resources and the capabilities of ensuring that such a thing never happens to another country again. There are a number of learning experiences or situations in Somalia which I must relate in the short time that I have. In doing that, I would like to feel that I can show honourable members in some brief way how hope has been restored to the Somalian population, in particular in the Baidoa HRS—the humanitarian relief sector—that the Australian forces are responsible for.

I saw this hope at first hand while visiting an orphanage in Baidoa. Dr Mohomoud Iman, the director of that orphanage, was most grateful for the Australian operation and the way that the Australian forces have conducted themselves, and particularly for the way CARE Australia was providing food. Going to the orphanage, where some 900 children gave us a rousing welcome, was a privilege and an experience which was very moving to all members of the delegation. Evidence of hope being restored was the fact that, although there were still a large number of refugees around the city, the numbers of refugees had been actually reduced to some one-tenth of what they had been just a few months previously. The fact that they were able to move back out into the outlying country areas was indicative of the security of those areas and of how the Australian troops were operating.

As well as that, when we were visiting the village of Buurhakba, our interpreter, Ali Haji Mucktar, pointed out to me that in the village markets the people were working on building farm equipment—hoes and the like—rather than producing weapons such as bayonets. They had changed; they had seen the way forward and they were moving towards that, and there was much evidence that the people did see light at the end of the tunnel. As the honourable member for Chifley pointed out, there was also the evidence of people coming up to us in the streets and in the villages, expressing their gratitude for what the Australians have done, whether it was in the vernacular or just a simple thankyou.

I thank Major John Withers, the escort officer for the delegation, for the great job that he did. I certainly appreciated it. I also want to mention the village elder in Baidoa, a gentlemanly 83-year-old called Mulak Muktar Malar Hassan who, as the village chief, expressed his appreciation for what the Australian troops achieved in the area. He and the village people cooperated because they could see the way forward. They were confident enough to support the Australian troops who were helping to establish the local constabulary to help maintain order. We also picked up the fact that the Australian troops had gone on some degree of mission creep, which is the term the honourable member for Chifley used, in getting that constabulary established to ensure that the security of the area will be maintained after the Australian troops withdraw. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion put forward so ably by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), supported by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) and the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor). I was not a member of the delegation. I understand that my colleague, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), who is not well at the moment, certainly would have added to the words of the other parliamentarians and made his own personal observations.

PARA.TAB: As a new member of Parliament, in the 37th Parliament of the Commonwealth, I would like to say that new members thank the honourable members of the previous Parliament for their participation on a bipartisan basis to support the United Nations in what was a very important mission. As new members, we all hope that there will not be many dangerous occasions such as this which Australians will be called upon to participate in. We certainly hope, however, that the example of our colleagues in the last Parliament will be one that we will be up to supporting, so that we can ensure that this Parliament always adopts a bipartisan approach to helping people in the world who suffer at the hands of despots, criminals and the dictators who have caused havoc to so many innocent people.

Last night I was honoured to be a guest, along with the Deputy Speaker and many other parliamentarians, of the Chief of the General Staff, Lieutenant General Grey, at the Army officers mess in Canberra. I was struck by the photographs on the wall that depicted some of the activities of our magnificent armed forces in Somalia. I pay tribute to the skill of those photographers who managed to depict, in a way that no words from me could ever adequately equal, the contribution of our armed forces in Somalia. I hope that those photographs, perhaps with the cooperation of the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, may soon be placed on display in Parliament House to complement the motion of the honourable member for Chifley.

The photographs were taken by Warrant Officer 1 Barry Buckley, Warrant Officer 2 Terry Dex and Corporal Gary Ramage. Those photographs are a marvellous record for Australia's history and for the world's history of how a peacekeeping armed force from a democracy such as Australia can make an enormous impact on people in a relatively short time. The most graphic photograph for me was one of a heavily armed and fully kitted soldier of the Australian 1st Battalion holding the hand of a small Somali child.

That photograph tells a wonderful story and reflects the tribute that I would like to make to the skill of our men and women in Somalia who carried out their mission with skill and professionalism, who achieved their objectives, and who also gained the respect of the people of Somalia. We can only solve the problems of this world if we have respect for each other. The Australian soldiers, in my view, have made a marvellous contribution in that area.

I would like also to briefly pay tribute to the United Nations for its resolve. Whilst the implementation of the programs were slowed down by the debates that took place, with the support and the initiative of President Bush of the United States action was taken that was effective.
I do worry, as other members do, that with the return of our soldiers the mission and the achievements of these United Nations efforts may be diminished. I hope that will not occur. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes the Treasurer's post-election announcement that the Government was under no obligation to keep its promise to remove all pensioners from the tax system by 1995;
(2)notes, in stark contrast, that Labor's official election platform stated that it was working on the details of implementing its commitment to remove all pensioners from the tax system by 1995;

(3)notes, that despite the Treasurer's claims, a senior cabinet minister was distributing fliers in his electorate during the last two weeks of the campaign pledging that Labor would remove all age and service pensioners from the tax system by 1995; and
(4)condemns the Government for misleading the Australian public in such an outrageous fashion by campaigning under the false pretence of a promise that it never had any intention of keeping.

I would like to recall the form of that motion because the words actually speak very much for themselves. They ought to be indelibly etched in the minds of every member who is going to contribute to this debate, every person listening, and every person reading the Hansard. It is a measure of this Government's cynicism that a motion of this sort is required at the beginning of a new Parliament.

PARA.TAB: On what evidence do I advance that motion? The evidence is in this form. The Australian Labor Party presented its policies at Bankstown on 24 February 1993 under a platform statement of `Advancing Australia. Building on strength'. Coupled with the formal announcements they distributed widely this document entitled The Australian Labor Party. Election 1993. Policies for older Australians. That was the document and it was distributed widely by every Labor member and candidate seeking election to the Parliament. On page 5 under the heading Tax Reform, it had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's commitment to removing all age and service pensioners from the tax system by 1995 will benefit pensioners paid at the part rate as well as providing some assistance to retirees with incomes beyond the pension cut out point.
Labor is working on the details of implementing this proposal . . .

This proposal was part of the Labor Party's promise, part of its commitment to the Australian people, and it took that up in the way I will describe to the House. A senior Minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) distributed a document entitled `Labor pledges new benefits for senior citizens'—a heading in capital letters. Then it said:
Remove all age and service pensioners from Tax System by 1995.

He also offered some comments in relation to fringe benefits, the next issue upon which the Government will walk away from its commitments. The fact is that at that policy launch, with those statements, Labor Ministers were secretly working out how they could walk away from that promise immediately after the election, and walk away from the promise they did.

PARA.TAB: Let us understand the enormity of what they have done. They knew the commitment that they were making; they understood it. They understood it better than anybody else because they knew what it would cost, they knew all of the implications of having to implement such a policy commitment.
My colleague Senator Patterson asked the Minister representing the Treasurer in the other House, then Senator Button, a series of questions on notice on 4 August 1992. She asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What is the estimated impact on Government revenue of the commitment to remove all full and part-rate pensioners from the tax system by 1995.

She asked him what it would cost. You know the way these things are done, do you not, Mr Deputy Speaker? The question is asked of the Minister's representative in the other House and the representative writes to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and says, `How do I answer this question? It is a difficult one. How do I answer it, Treasurer?'. Senator Patterson went on:
What is the Government's best estimate of the number of pensioners who are now paying tax who will be removed from the tax system as a result of this commitment.
Does the Government intend to outline to Parliament and to the Australian public prior to the next federal election how it intends to meet this commitment, including how it will be funded.

How will the Government ensure that retirees whose incomes only marginally exceed the part-rate pension income threshold are not comparatively disadvantaged if the Government implements its commitment to remove all pensioners from the tax system by 1995.
What changes to the pension assets test and tax system does the Government envisage . . .
She asked further questions:

If the Government implements its commitment to remove all pensioners . . . what will be the difference in the tax paid by a pensioner with income $1 below the part-rate pension income threshold and a non-pensioner with an equivalent income.
Does the Government also intend to remove from the tax system those retirees who make the choice not to claim the age pension although they meet all the requirements of the income and assets tests.
These were very proper questions. Senator Button answered them: what did he have to say? He confirmed the promise. He said:

In the 1989-90 Budget it was announced that age and service pensioners, both full rate and part rate, would be removed from the taxation system by 1995 in the context of removing disincentives to individuals undertaking retirement savings and encouraging greater self provision in retirement. The cost of the reforms for the aged announced in the April 1989 economic statement and the 1989-90 Budget—including the 1995 commitment—was put at over $1 billion.

So the Treasurer, through Senator Button, told the Senate, `This commitment involves a cost to revenue of over $1 billion', and yet the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy went to the Australian people with a specific pledge on the Labor Party's commitment to remove all age and service pensioners from the tax system, and told them it was working on details. These disgraceful flyers were put out that suggested to people that they would be removed from the tax system, and yet three weeks after the election—three weeks after that confirmation—the Treasurer of this country, said, `It was certainly not an undertaking we have renewed and I don't feel under any obligation to follow through with it'.

PARA.TAB: That is the greatest backflip that we have ever seen. These people were consummate liars. They went to the Australian people—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Could you ask the honourable member to withdraw that description?

—If people take offence at being described as having misled the Australian people by using one set of words and walking away from them when they knew the commitment, of course I will withdraw out of respect for the House.
—I would remind the honourable member for Berowra that the word is unparliamentary.

—The fact is that this was the most disgraceful backflip that we have ever seen. They were all there. We saw the photographs of them, parading around Bankstown with this promise clearly made, knowing it would have cost over $1 billion. If it were a matter of going out to the Australian people and making promises of over $1 billion that could not be honoured, we could have done the same thing, but we did not. We treated the Australian people with honesty and integrity, but these people lied their way by affirming a promise that had been made over and over again and then walking away from it.
