I cannot imagine any more gross way of distorting and manipulating the most vulnerable people in Australia than by making promises and commitments to them and walking away from them immediately an election is over. (Time expired)
—Is the motion seconded?
—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) has been talking about backflips. It is really interesting to hear opposition members speaking about backflips when we see what was in Fightback and how the whole Fightback package has been rejected by the people of Australia. The Opposition has really done a backflip on every policy it ever had, if there ever were any policies. When honourable members opposite come into this place today and rave on about the Government's policies for pensioners and talk about backflips, I remind them that they are the ones who have done the backflips.

PARA.TAB: I am particularly pleased to have the opportunity to respond to the motion of the honourable member for Berowra because I think that pensioners in Australia really said on 13 March what they felt about the Opposition's policies and why they preferred to stay with the Keating Labor Government, and rightly so. Pensioners will benefit from the policy of the Government for all older Australians which was announced in February, which the honourable member opposite has referred to. They will benefit because thousands of part pensioners and retirees throughout Australia will be better off through the new deal for older people announced in the Prime Minister's policy launch. It is true that certain aspects of the policy document are under review since the election, but the package as a whole offers much for pensioners and retirees throughout Australia.

In the policy it was announced that there would be an easing of the assets test for pensioners from September 1993 and that the Government would also introduce a senior health card for all part pensioners, extending eligibility for concessional pharmaceuticals and hearing aids. All pensioners and health card holders will be eligible for free dental care. Easing the assets test means that the new cut-out points for part pensioners will be $218,000 for single home owners, $299,000 for single non-home owners, $335,500 for married home owners and $416,000 for married non-home owners. In addition, the Government is increasing the amount paid to part pensioners. For example, a single retiree with assets of $150,000 on top of the family home will now receive a pension of $100 per week, an increase of $19. I am pleased to see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Lindsay) at the table. He is in a position to respond in support of the Government's initiatives.

These changes mean that the older people will have a higher standard of living and more money for the necessities of life. The Government's senior health card will give low income non-pensioner retirees access to concessional pharmaceuticals and hearing aids as well. In the past, eligibility for concessional pharmaceuticals and hearing aids was limited to pensioners. Labor's initiatives mean all retirees with incomes less than $18,736 for singles, and $31,294 for couples, will be eligible for concessional pharmaceuticals as well.

In addition to these initiatives which will be of great assistance to many older Australians, as part of the seventh accord between the Government and the ACTU, the Government has agreed that unemployed people aged 60 and over and who have been unemployed for 12 months or more will qualify for a provisional age pension. That is the great initiative. This means that from 1 July this year unemployed people over 60, now about 20,000 nationally, will have the option of continuing to seek work and receive unemployment payments or to transfer to a provisional age pension. If these people chose the pension option, many of them will also benefit from the more generous pension income and assets tests. The provisional pension will be introduced from 1 July this year.

Apart from the recent initiatives for pensioners and older Australians, the Labor Government has done a great deal to assist pensioners. This Government has lifted the age pension to over 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, and has indexed the age pension in order to compensate for inflation. We are now in the process of extending fringe benefits to all pensioners, as well as providing all older Australians with universal health insurance as part of this Government's commitment to social justice for the aged.

When honourable members opposite start talking about this Government's policies for the aged, it is instructive to take a look at the age care policies taken into the election by honourable members opposite. First off, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) promised to slug every pensioner and senior citizen with a 15 per cent consumption tax on most goods and every service that they used. The imposition of such a tax would have made it very difficult for some pensioners to actually survive.

Of course, the Leader of the Opposition tried to tempt the elderly with a fistful of dollars, which he promised would compensate them for the increased cost of living under a GST. However, the $6 billion hole in the Fightback package's arithmetic made such promises by the Opposition absolutely worthless.

The introduction of a GST would have had the inevitable effect of increasing prices, pushing up inflation and would have affected people on low and fixed incomes—such as pensioners and retirees—much more than it would the wealthy. The spending power of people on fixed incomes, such as our pensioners, would have declined dramatically under the policies of honourable members opposite. Even on the coalition's own estimates, a consumption tax would have increased inflation by 4.7 per cent, while the independent Treasury analysis found that Fightback would have increased inflation by up to 6 per cent.

The Leader of the Opposition's proposed income tax cuts would have done little for people on pensions and retirees—who do not actually pay tax anyway but who would now have had to pay tax under that proposal—and they would have had to reduce the value of their savings by whatever the increased inflation rate turned out to be.

Even the cost of dying, of course, would have increased under the policies of honourable members opposite. Cemetery plots, coffins, cremations, flowers, and even funeral services themselves would all have increased in price if a GST had been introduced as a result of the last federal election. But the Australian people were too smart for honourable members opposite, that is for sure. The then shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), admitted as much.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't he get the boot quick!
—That is right. He was a scapegoat. The honourable member for Flinders actually admitted as much during an interview on Brisbane radio station 4QR, during an interview on 11 June last year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Under us, as you go down to be buried, you will be buried at 26 cents a litre cheaper, fuel costs, as we are going to abolish the fuel tax. So, yes, there (will be) a tax on burials, on funerals, but there's an existing tax so it won't be a 15% increase.

The honourable member for Flinders admitted that the cost of dying would go up—but not necessarily by 15 per cent. Of course, the GST was a much broader tax than just a tax on goods. Basic services, such as electricity, gas, telephone and water accounts, cleaning, Meals on Wheels, hairdressing, garbage collection and car repairs would all have cost more if a GST had been introduced and it would have hit our pensioner population quite severely.

PARA.TAB: In contrast to the Government's efforts to extend fringe benefits to all pensioners, pensioner rebates on electricity, phone, gas, water and rates—most are administered by State and local governments—would all have been in jeopardy under the coalition's Fightback proposals. It has been a good thing for Australia that they have been thrown out. The coalition's policies did not make any allowances for these rebates to increase to match the price increases which would have occurred as a result of a GST. The cost of the Commonwealth compensating the States for these rebates was not even in the calculations on which the GST package was based. Because of the funding cuts to the States that were proposed in Fightback, it would have been extremely unlikely any compensation would have been provided.

So before honourable members opposite get up in this place to criticise the Government's policies for older Australians, they should look seriously at the implications of their own policies for pensioners and retirees. Over the 10 years of the Labor Government, we have had a very strong commitment to our pensioner population and I know we will continue to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I thank the honourable member for Moreton for offering support there because I know of his very strong commitment to pensioners in his electorate.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt at all that the criticisms put by those opposite today have little credibility. All of their policies have been thrown out by the Australian people, and rightly so. Really, instead of getting up here and criticising us, they should go back to the drawing board and draw up some policies and work a little bit closer with the Government to come up with some proposals that will really assist our age pensioner population.

Our aged people certainly deserve a better deal than what has been proposed by those opposite. Those opposite obviously do not have a great commitment to our aged people—people on lower incomes. I believe our pensioners, in light of what they have contributed to Australia over many years, always should be looked after and looked after well. I am very pleased that we, as a government, have done that over the last 10 years and I know we will continue to do so in the future. It is important that people in their retirement are looked after well.

The recent initiative, where fringe benefits are now going to be extended to all people—even those on part age pensions—is extremely good. It is those fringe benefits that people really like to have as a security blanket to ensure that they have good health care and the like—to ensure that they have some quality of life in their old age. It is all about social justice. That is what we are about on this side of the Parliament, unlike those opposite. I reject the proposals put here by the honourable member for Berowra. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion put forward by the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock). Very clearly, the Keating Labor Government has refined the technique of the disposable election promise. For years, this Government has blatantly sought to buy the votes of pensioners with its pledge that by 1995 no pensioner will pay tax. It really had a rather good ring to it—almost as good as the one about no child living in poverty by 1990.

PARA.TAB: We should have been warned. Now that an election has been won, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) could not wait to get out and announce that the Government is no longer obliged to keep its promise. I must emphasise that this was not some off-the-cuff statement made in the heat of a campaign; it was a commitment that had been made and reiterated over several years. That was then reinforced at the last election.

There may be a great deal of argument to the effect that some pensioners can afford to pay a certain amount of tax and should not have been given this blanket promise. That is an arguable point. Indeed, it was described as drawing an unfair distinction between retired Australians in receipt of age pensions and those living entirely on private income who were offered no such relief. But then, that is a hallmark of the Labor Government. It has done nothing but bring in policies that have been divisive.

The promise was made to the pensioners of Australia that by 1995 no pensioner would pay tax. That promise was made. Senator Walsh stated on ABC radio, within a fortnight of the election, that the Government should break its promise to pensioners. At least Senator Walsh displays some intellectual consistency. He has argued that the pledge was irresponsible—that it should never have been made—and he declined to serve any longer in a Cabinet that continually placed electoral advantage ahead of fiscal probity.

We can see that this Government takes its former colleague's advice selectively. It ignores him when it proclaims that all pensioners will be removed from the tax system and that Australia can afford the change, but it unhesitatingly takes the cynical course of repudiating the pledge when pensioner votes are no longer needed.

We are not going to restore public confidence in the political process as long as the Labor Government treats the electors with such contempt, telling us, in effect, that the ditching of the pre-election pledge is a standard political practice. I hope neither the Treasurer nor his colleagues ever have the gall to lament that Australians are cynical about politics and that the voters feel alienated from the political process.

It would be interesting to hear from the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), who on Tuesday stood in this House and castigated the Western Australian Government for failing to fulfil an election promise. I hope I have the chance to address that issue this evening. He apparently believes that there is another rule for Labor governments, particularly Treasurers who cannot even argue that they were unaware of the exact situation when they made the promise. We are talking about a tax promise made from the Treasury benches, with the benefit of Treasury advice, not a promise made from Opposition whose members are not in receipt of the full facts.

It is particularly outrageous that this disposable promise has been made at the expense of elderly Australians who worry a great deal about maintaining living standards and paying tax. A government that uses them in this way and inflicts a discriminatory tax on that five per cent of age pensioners who have the temerity to own shares in listed Australian companies lacks all compassion as well as integrity. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)calls for the complete elimination of chemical weapons from the Earth as chemical weapons are hideous instruments of warfare and mass destruction which have caused unimaginable suffering to soldiers and civilians alike;

(2)welcomes the Chemical Weapons Convention as an historic human achievement, outlawing the very existence—the development, production, retention, transfer and use—of an entire category of weapons of mass destruction and providing the most comprehensive multilateral system of verification ever undertaken;

(3)congratulates the Australian Government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs for their significant contribution in expediting the finalisation of the Chemical Weapons Convention enabling it to be signed in Paris in January 1993;
(4)urges the Australian Government to ratify the Convention as soon as possible and to use its diplomatic efforts to ensure all other countries in our region sign and ratify the Convention; and

(5)pledges to work for the full and proper implementation of the Convention by our Government and industry and adequate financial backing by our Government to enable the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons to carry out its designated functions to deter violations and promote compliance with the Convention.

We all come into this place with different backgrounds, experiences, philosophies and values. But there is one common thread that binds all of us and motivates our participation in our nation's political process, and that is our desire to make this a safer and better place for our children and our grandchildren. We may have differing views about how to achieve this aim and a variety of methods to implement those views, but that fundamental objective is shared by us all in this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: No one issue is more crucial to that objective than the question of peace. If we cannot live together in peace, express our differences without recourse to violence or coexist in harmony, none of our other activities really ever amount to much. There continues to be ample evidence of this basic truth in a number of places around our planet. The senseless violence, destruction and death that are occurring in Bosnia, Cambodia, South Africa, Northern Ireland, Georgia and elsewhere are a continuing example of the total folly of war.

Our world will continue to be a violent and frightening place while we maintain our practice of spending more of our income on weapons and on armies than on health, education, housing or community services. It is for this reason that the process of disarmament is crucial if we are to make any progress on our objective of making this a safer world.

Chemical weapons are the most abhorrent form of warfare that man has inflicted on this planet, if we wish to differentiate between the various evil ways our species has devised to kill each other. These poisonous weapons have terrified soldiers and civilians alike since they were first developed and used in their modern form last century. Some 1.3 million casualties and 100,000 fatalities resulted from the use of poisonous gas in World War I.

More recently, the world witnessed with horror the use of these weapons by the Iraqi Government against its own people living along the border with Iran during the Iran-Iraq war. Millions of tonnes of chemical weapons are currently stockpiled in the armouries of nations around the world. I think the scientists who devise these evil creations and the military and political leaders who authorise their production and, even worse, their use are guilty of massive crimes against humanity. Scientists have a great deal to answer for in their development of such devices.

On 13 January this year, the representatives of 130 nations of the world gathered in Paris to dedicate themselves to the complete elimination of chemical weapons from the face of the earth. It had taken 24 years of negotiation to reach agreement on the chemical weapons convention. The conference on disarmament in Geneva had faced many difficulties in arriving at the process and structure to achieve agreement. If it had not been for the timely and significant contribution of the Australian delegation, the conference may still be debating the details. Our nation can be proud that once again we have played an important part in achieving world peace and furthering the cause of disarmament. Congratulations are due to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and his disarmament negotiators for their outstanding efforts.

The most significant feature of the chemical weapons convention is that it is the first treaty to seek to abolish an entire category of weapons of mass destruction. Of equal importance is the fact that it establishes a comprehensive verification process ensuring compliance. This treaty requires, for the first time in history, that signatories enact penal legislation which makes it a violation of national law to engage in activities prohibited by an international treaty.

The CWC makes no distinction in the treatment of possessors and non-possessors, requiring all signatories to destroy their stockpiles and chemical weapons production facilities and to agree not to produce or acquire chemical weapons. The verification regime is the most intrusive ever produced in a multilateral arms control agreement. Thousands of facilities will be subject to inspection. Inspectors will have the right to perform challenge inspections without right of refusal at any site about which suspicion has been raised. This includes private chemical companies which may be producing components which by themselves are innocent, but which when combined make a lethal mix.

Parliamentarians have a special role to play in fulfilling the objectives of the chemical weapons convention. Our task is to ensure that this treaty is ratified and that domestic legislation is enacted to facilitate inspections and prohibit violations of the treaty within our country and region. Parliamentarians can utilise the special relationships that we build with our colleagues in other parliaments around the world to ensure that this convention is ratified and implemented in all nations.

I belong to an extra-parliamentary organisation called Parliamentarians for Global Action. There are 36 members of that group in this Parliament, and I acknowledge the fact that the seconder of this motion, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), is also a member of Parliamentarians for Global Action. Our 36 members are part of a group of over 890 parliamentarians from another 65 parliaments around the world who belong to PGA. Through parliamentary debate and action, we seek to advance the cause of peace and disarmament, democracy, human rights, economic equity and sustainable development. I am pleased to advise members that PGA has played a very important role in assisting in the successful negotiations for the chemical weapons convention.

The PGA secretariat in New York, along with our parliamentarian executive members, has engaged in extensive lobbying and negotiations in the United Nations and with national governments across the globe to expedite the finalisation, signing and ratification of the chemical weapons convention. PGA is an activist, progressive, multi-party organisation, which crosses political boundaries and contributes significantly to the realisation of principles and policies of global significance.

Australia has continued to play a very important role in advancing the chemical weapons convention. In late March this year, Australia hosted the fourth regional seminar against chemical weapons in Sydney. Representatives from 24 Asia-Pacific countries attended the seminar, held to promote strong regional support for the achievement and implementation of the chemical weapons convention. Australia and the Asia-Pacific region are participating actively in the development of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons. This organisation will be responsible for developing and undertaking detailed procedures in implementing the terms of the convention.

The motion before the House today reflects the tremendous historic and human significance of the chemical weapons convention. As representatives of the citizens of our nation, we as parliamentarians have the responsibility to ensure its complete achievement. Only through such positive actions can we realise our common purpose in this place: to advance the cause of peace and to leave a better place for our children and our grandchildren. I hope that the motion achieves the support of both sides of this House, as I know it reflects the common objectives and common goals that all of us have regarding our purpose in this place. I commend the motion to the House.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I have no particular problem with this motion. I am sorry that I was not in the House to hear the remarks of the motion's mover, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), but unfortunately I was delayed at a meeting. I think that this motion to a great extent is a motherhood-type one. It gives the Government a bit of a pat on the back for doing something that very few people, except for some extreme warmongers, would have any reason to object to. However, to put that in context, one wonders in broad terms about the effect of these conventions. The Government does from time to time—in fact, I think quite regularly—sign various conventions. In a broad context, that raises a question about what the process should be for the signing of those conventions and I think there is some valid concern about the processes involved.

PARA.TAB: Conventions have been signed by this Government—or by the previous Government, in fact—that a significant number of people may have had concerns about. Although discussion of those is not particularly relevant today, one that particularly comes to mind that puts this whole issue on the agenda is the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. I do not want to recanvass those issues, but at the time it did raise questions about the process. I believe that the position that we take on this side of the House in respect of conventions broadly is that they ought to be a matter of debate in the Parliament, and that the Parliament ought to give consideration to whether conventions are acceded to or not.In that respect, I believe there is a danger in giving the Government—that effectively means the Executive of the Government—the power, as it has now, to sign such conventions. But that is not to say that this convention is not worth while.

Another concern I have generally about conventions is that the good people sign them and the bad people do not, and we have seen plenty of evidence for that concern. Whilst it might give us a nice, warm feeling this morning to be able to say that Australia has signed this convention that it wants to eliminate all chemical weapons, that is motherhood. It gives us a nice feeling, and it gives other like-minded civilised nations a nice feeling.

What do we do about the baddies? What do we do about Saddam Hussein? In that instance, at least, I suppose we saw some preparedness of the world community via the United Nations to intervene and to take action on an ongoing basis. But even there the methodology becomes flawed because apparently he has been quite able to make it very difficult for the United Nations to enforce its resolutions. Ultimately, the question that comes to my mind in this context is: what is the point of the exercise? I am sorry if the honourable member answered that question; I did not hear him. I hope the point is something other than giving us the good feeling that we are standing up and saying something good. We might well sign a convention that will prevent whaling or prevent the killing of dolphins through driftnets, or whatever, but there is always someone who does not sign, who does not agree and who does not abide by that particular convention.

I suppose the highest profile conventions in existence at the moment are the so-called Geneva conventions. I assume that most countries have agreed to the Geneva conventions which largely govern the conduct of war. That is an interesting exercise in itself, that we should in times of peace agree that, if we are going to have a war, we should conduct it within certain bounds. That is not difficult to do when we are getting on well with our neighbours. We can sit down and agree to what amounts to a convention and it can have the imprimatur of the United Nations. For instance, we could agree on a whole range of issues, such as when we capture prisoners. We could agree not to torture them and to feed them properly. Those Geneva conventions go into great detail not only on the treatment of prisoners but on a whole range of other very important issues. But in very many cases, when the crunch comes, they are thrown out the window.

I have been very closely involved with the Prisoner of War Association in this country. I am the patron of the Gold Coast branch of the Queensland Prisoner of War Association. Having been a serviceman myself, I am naturally very sympathetic to the plight of prisoners of war. I have read a lot and I commend to all honourable members some of the books that have been written about the treatment of Australian prisoners of war by the Japanese. This has become even more of an issue for me now than it ever was, having read a lot of the documentary evidence on what actually happened to Australians, British servicemen, Dutch servicemen and Thai nationals, and others, on that infamous Burma-Thai railway. In this instance, there was no attempt at propriety nor subscription to any convention.

Over 8,000 Australian servicemen died in captivity and they died because they were maltreated. They became ill and they were not given medicine. They were never fed properly and, on reading these books, the descriptions of the sorts of meals that they had would bring tears to one's eyes. They were made to work in terrible conditions when they were desperately ill; some of them were even unable to stand up. Their tormenters said, `We want a hundred men to work on this particular part of the railway today' and the hundred best able to work were chosen, despite the fact that many of them were ill.

It is an issue I want to pursue in this Parliament and I have made a call in this place as recently as yesterday. I want the Australian Government to get serious with the Japanese Government about reparations for POWs who are still alive today. In the twilight years of their lives many of them are still suffering and that is understandable. They spent 3 1/2 years in captivity in the most horrific conditions, not only weather conditions but also every other imaginable sort of condition.

I want the Government—I know it is an embarrassment to it—to push this issue. I want it to push the matter through the United Nations. If we are serious about the United Nations and a new world order and what can be achieved by agreeing to these sorts of conventions, then we can surely take the matter of reparations for POWs to the United Nations.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when he talks to his Japanese counterpart, should be prepared to put this on the agenda. I know it is a tough issue. It is certainly offensive to the Japanese. I have remarked in this place on more than one occasion that we have never actually received an apology from the Japanese Government, other than in the most perfunctory of terms, for what the Japanese did to relatives of yours and mine during the Second World War. They have certainly never paid reparations.

The remaining POWs, of course, are now getting old. They are elderly, they are still suffering and they have never received a cent for the 3 1/2 years of deprivation and torture and ill treatment that they suffered as prisoners of war.

I make those remarks because there can be no objection to the honourable member's motion. It has my support; it would have the support of every civilised person who heard him talk about it. We must eliminate chemical weapons; we must eliminate nuclear weapons. Ultimately, of course, the execution is much more difficult than the actual process of talking about it. Of course, it also raises the issue of how we control the people who do not want to comply with these conventions and, indeed, how one ensures that they are applied in the time of war as opposed to the time of peace. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to second this motion which has been moved so well by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). He referred to the fact that he and I are two of 36 members of this Parliament who are members of Parliamentarians for Global Action. I would like to emphasise that Parliamentarians for Global Action in this Parliament, as in most parliaments throughout the world which have representatives of that organisation, includes members of all political groupings within this Parliament—Labor, Liberal, National, Democrats, and Greens. It is representative of what I believe are some of the higher aspirations of the human character expressed by representatives in institutions of this kind.

PARA.TAB: I was pleased to hear that the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), speaking on his own behalf and on behalf of his colleagues, indicated quite correctly that no civilised person could be opposed to a proposition of this kind. He said that he felt that it was a motherhood motion. I do not believe that it is. There is a very positive, practical element to it. What we do in even raising this question in the Parliament on private members' day is to assert as well the rights of individual members of this Parliament to make an individual and collective statement about the principles that they want to represent while they are in this place.

It is a statement that we believe should not be left to leading members of government, to Ministers for foreign affairs, to Prime Ministers, to presidents or to representatives who sit in the United Nations. We believe that ordinary representatives of constituencies have a right and a responsibility to express their concerns. In doing that we emphasise to this Government that we want it in the shortest period of time to ratify the convention. We have already signed it. We were one of those nations in Paris in January of this year that signed the convention.

It now remains for us to ratify it—and ratify it we will, later this year after the practical legislative enabling arrangements have been made. We will then urge at least 65 countries of the world to ratify it as well. When 65 countries of the world have ratified it, it will then represent a world adoption of the United Nations convention and become part of the international rule of law, with the expectation and the requirement that countries throughout the world will honour it. If they fail to honour it, then there will be measures which the United Nations in its own judgment will be able to adopt to ensure that it is honoured, enforced and carried out.

Both the honourable member for Moreton and the honourable member for McPherson referred to the fact that chemical weapons are among the most horrific instruments of slaughter, destruction and death that we can think of. But there is something absurd and something a little unreal—even in a motion of this kind which I applaud and which I am privileged to second—about talking about civilising the process of war. For God's sake! Is there a humane way to destroy human achievements? Is there a humane and decent way to kill? For God's sake, what are we talking about!

This is a simple statement from this chamber within this Parliament about how we want this Government to respond and how we want the people of the world and the representatives of the world in legislatures of this kind to respond in a similar way. At least it is a statement made in the form of those statements of humanity that we might be expected to express. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to read a piece of poetry:

SPEECH.PARA: Gas! Gas! Quick boys, boys! An ecstasy of fumbling,
Fitting the clumsy helmets just in time;
But someone still was yelling out and stumbling
And floundering like a man in fire or lime . . .
Dim through the misty panes and thick green light,
As under a green sea, I saw him drowning.
In all my dreams, before my helpless sight, He plunges at me
guttering, choking, drowning.
If in some smothering dreams you too could pace
Behind the wagon we flung him in,
And watch the white eyes writhing in his face,
His hanging face, like a devil's sick of sin;
If you could hear at every jolt, the blood
Come gargling from the froth-corrupted lungs,
Obscene as cancer, bitter as the cud. . .
Wilfred Owen, a very famous poet of World War I, described there graphically the effects of a chemical attack during that particular war.

PARA.TAB: Chemical warfare has been with us for years. Between the years 431BC and 404BC, the Spartans threw burning mixtures of sulfur and pitch over the walls in the sieges of two Athenian cities, which produced fires that asphyxiated the occupants. In the Middle Ages, Genghis Khan shot huge balls of burning pitch and sulfur into cities as a standard part of his attack. In 1812, Thomas Cochrane, a British naval officer, proposed the burning of ships filled with sulfur to drive Napoleon's forces from fortifications around French ports.

During the Crimean War, a British chemist suggested two interesting new munitions. One was a hollow shell, filled with a solution of phosphorous, which would break open on impact, exposing the phosphorous to the air and thus causing fires and blinding smoke. He also suggested a brittle shell, filled with a compound which would burn, that could be used against Russian ships. In that particular instance, those two ideas were rejected by the British War Department. During the American Civil War, both sides either proposed or used chemicals as weapons. In 1905, in the Russo-Japanese War, the Japanese were said to have pushed burning rags soaked with arsenic compounds into Russian trenches.

There are interesting conclusions to be drawn from that period before World War I: firstly, chemical weapons played a sometimes decisive role even before the birth of Christ and, secondly, the use of chemicals—with the exception of sulfur, which had been mined for about 1,000 years—was limited only by technology. But it is also interesting that it was seen as immoral long before the large-scale use of chemical weapons in World War I.

Of course, their large-scale use in World War I produced some horrific results, some of which were described in the words of Wilfred Owen earlier. In one particular attack there were 15,000 casualties from the release of chlorine gas in the first stages of gas warfare in the First World War. We saw the use by the Germans of mustard gas—first introduced on 12 July 1917 and delivered in liquid form by artillery shells. The extent of its use is indicated by the fact that, in the 10 days following the introduction of that gas, they fired one million shells at the Allies and gave themselves an advantage—in fact, almost a monopoly—on chemical weapons for over a year. The potency of those weapons was such that lethal amounts of mustard gas were still being discovered in the Verdun area in France up to the late 1970s.

We have seen all the way through the 20th century the use of chemical weapons in horrific and significant ways as part of warfare. The interesting conclusion that supports the intent of the motion of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) is that the use of chemical weapons is on the rise. In the first 20 years after World War II there were no significant confirmed uses of lethal chemical weapons. In the second 20 years there were four to five confirmed uses, including the first military uses of chemical warfare and, for the first time, a two-sided war in which both sides used chemical weapons against each other.

In concluding my address I point out that history has shown conclusively that in order to prevent the use of what are the most horrific types of weapons available in the armoury one has to resort in the end to the convention of the banning of that use.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)acknowledges the extreme hardship now being faced by many hundreds of farming and other families and individuals in rural and regional Australia, as a result of falling and in some cases disastrous commodity prices, exacerbated by the spread of drought conditions in areas of Queensland and New South Wales;

(2)considers that the availability of basic financial support to such families and individuals is restricted by asset tests which do not allow for the realities of the severe downturn in incomes for farmers and associated self-employed persons;
(3)calls on the Government to act on these matters as a matter of urgency; and

(4)notes that the Government has removed the assets test for recipients of Farm Household Support and urges it to extend this liberalisation of the assets test to other areas to address the hardship faced by farming and other families and individuals in rural and regional Australia.

It is interesting to have just listened to the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) describing the effects of war, particularly the First World War, and to realise that few in this House, in this capital city and within the cities of Australia would realise that that same type of devastation, that same type of war, is now being perpetrated within the rural and country areas of Australia. I cannot start to describe the amount of devastation that exists in these areas because of the continuing drought and the consequent lowering of commodity prices. In many respects the human aspect is as grim as was portrayed in the poem from which he read.

PARA.TAB: In this Parliament and within the capital of Australia we are unappreciative of the depths of the despair and the tragedy out there. There is a feeling that people are not concerned about that tragedy in others. As we debate, in its turn, the republic or a constitutional monarchy we must acknowledge that any system that we have should be based on fairness and equity to all Australians. I am suggesting that there is no fairness or equity when people who are secure in a nine to five job cannot concern themselves with the tragedy that is going on out there. When we can find funds from this Parliament to pay for eminent people's committees to look at the republic or spend $168 million on new headquarters for the Department of Foreign Affairs or perhaps pay $200,000 for a barbecue area for public servants here, we do not understand the depths of the despair that is out there. It is on this subject that I wish to speak today on a purely non-political basis.

For those honourable members who might have heard some of the Easter messages, one of the most telling was one about members of the Rotary club of Charleville who were distributing funds to provide boots for people so that they could go out and work their properties. They were also distributing food packages to those people who for generations have taken pride in being farmers.

We also have the situation—and I have seen it within my own electorate—where women and children are being called upon to handle jobs on farms while there are people within the same area who are on the dole and who are sitting back and not helping to relieve that situation.I have seen in my own constituency a farmer who has committed his life's savings—his superannuation funds and his retirement funds—to maintaining his property now suffering because the property is in the grip of drought. Families who have farmed their properties for three generations are seeing the value of their properties falling away and as a result they are suffering a loss of pride. They see themselves as being failures. This is the tragedy.

There is also the economic tragedy. We have heard quite a lot about the plight of the graziers as far as wool is concerned. Export values are diminishing. Commodity prices are dropping right off and as a result there is a deficit in the balance of trade. How much of that is caused by the drought? How much of that is caused by the fact that rural industries and primary industries in Australia cannot contribute because of the circumstances?

We are talking also in terms of the human problems. In his maiden speech the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) referred to those people who have taken their own lives. He related one instance. I can relate another. Within my own constituency a farmer who was in the depths of the recession, when faced with trying to save his breeders, went out and shot the calves from those breeders so that the breeders could stay alive. He then used the revolver on himself. I think that is probably the most telling example that I can give.

We find that these people have few cash reserves. What they need more than anything else is assistance from people like us, not sympathy. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has said that there is a partnership required. I agree wholeheartedly with him. Only a partnership will get us out of this situation. We need a partnership to help control the financial hardship and the human hardship that the farmers are going through and we also need a partnership for recovery.

In the resolution we mention that there are ways that the Government can help. I will just mention a few of the ways it could help. If the Government chose to recognise drought as a natural disaster, that would be of tremendous help. That would bring relief to where it is required. There is need for financial help and while the RAS scheme does give it, it does not give it in the most meaningful way to enable these people to keep going.

For instance, on the farm there are certain fixed expenses. There are certain expenses that are necessary to keep the crops and livestock going. Take piping as an example. Assistance with piping to get water to a destination would help. Also, the cost of agistment is going up to about two to three times what it was before. I believe there has to be some realisation that if we are going to keep the breeding stock alive then there has to be help with agistment.

The interest subsidy is all very fine but it is not helping in the manner in which it could be. In the matter of personal funding, it is interesting that the RAS is only of assistance to those people who are leaving their properties. I believe that the worst thing we can do is say that the inevitable consequence of this drought and the downturn in commodity prices is for people to have to leave the land.
The Minister for Primary Industry in Queensland can say that 30 per cent of farmers have to go because they are no longer efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a shame. There are no longer white shoe brigade farmers. There are no longer Pitt Street farmers. Those farmers remaining are the people who for generations knew nothing else other than farming and they are very good farmers. We have to do more than use the RAS scheme to direct farmers off the land.

PARA.TAB: Within the motion we mention the need to look at the assets test on the ways in which assistance can be given. Household support is already excluded from the assets test, but there are other things that need to be looked at, particularly Austudy. I understand that during the course of the last election the Minister mentioned the lifting of the assets test on the isolated children's allowance. These are ways in which the Government can move right now to provide some help in that regard.

The partnership also should involve the commercial people who run the financial affairs and assist in the consultation. Perhaps the Government might be able to assist the bankers in restructuring the loans—and I think it has tried to do that. There are inevitable problems when someone has shrinking security. I saw this in the banking inquiry at Charleville where a State instrumentality, the QIDC, was blackmailing an individual to supply more off-farm assets as security so that that person could stay on the farm. It is absolutely criminal when it is a government department that is doing that.

The bankers have to recognise that they have to share the losses in that diminishing security. The Government has already provided that by way of a partial write-off of bad debts so far as income tax is concerned. I believe it is time the bankers got off their seats in their offices and went out on the properties to see what is really happening. I suggest accountants could do that too. The professional people should not lock themselves in airconditioned comfort; they should be out there looking at what is actually happening.

In Queensland, the DPI inspectors were told that they were to make their assessments from the desks in their offices. It is not going to help the person who has just shot himself to know that we do not appreciate what the problems are. We have to make sure that there is a partnership operating. We have to accept the losses, as these people themselves are accepting the losses. We have to understand that the prime objective of these people is to stay on the land.

The Government can help in the ways which I have indicated. The counsellors who advise these people should be out talking to them about what is happening. People in Parliament must appreciate the depth of the tragedy, not only for these farmers but also for the economy of Australia. I hope that through this motion we can all pull together to achieve the desired end. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has already acknowledged the extreme hardship faced by our rural community as a result of falling commodity prices and drought. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) mentioned those aspects as being pertinent to the present situation facing farmers across Australia, and particularly the farmers in western Queensland and north-west New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The rural crisis is complex. The Commonwealth has recognised that it requires an intelligent and multi-pronged approach. In recognition of this, the Commonwealth has implemented an integrated package of policies for rural Australia. These policies are pushing along the process of structural change and rural development, while at the same time they acknowledge the difficult times that face the farmers.

The centrepiece of the policy is the rural adjustment scheme. That scheme contains exceptional circumstances provisions to increase support to farmers in times of difficulty, as in the current drought crisis in Queensland and in my own State of New South Wales. It should also be noted that in New South Wales the State government, including its honourable members from the National Party, has failed to support the 100 per cent interest subsidy which the Commonwealth has said it is ready to offer to and support farmers with.

The New South Wales Government has, at this time, only agreed to an 80 per cent interest subsidy. This should give the honourable member for Dawson something to think about. The exceptional circumstances provisions recognise that farmers need support through difficult circumstances and that otherwise productive farmers could be forced to leave their farms and so weaken the prospects of the industry to recover in the future.

Consequently, in times of exceptional circumstances, special interest subsidies of 100 per cent may be provided to farmers. This funding is available immediately. Further, the cap on the level of assistance payable to applicants under the exceptional circumstances provisions of the rural adjustment scheme has been lifted from $30,000 to $50,000, with further changes being subject to review of the rural adjustment scheme administrative arrangements. I anticipate that this will free up the rural adjustment scheme authorities to deliver the optimum level of assistance. In some cases this may be less than the 100 per cent interest subsidy which should be available now.

The rural adjustment scheme has also been revised to achieve effective structural adjustment of farmer enterprises. It is a long-term view and not a knee-jerk response. The scheme aims to encourage better financial and technical performance in an industry responsive to market signals. The National Farmers Federation President, Graham Blight, has welcomed the $50.6 million drought and wool package. Mr Blight has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Invoking the `exceptional circumstances' provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme to assist farmers is a welcome step as it allows them to prove viability over a longer period. However, the onus is now on the States to match the Commonwealth contribution under the RAS so that assistance is available to farmers immediately.

That was on 28 April. Today the honourable member for Dawson's National Party colleagues in New South Wales have still failed to deliver that 100 per cent subsidy from the New South Wales Government, and I hardly think that under these circumstances the honourable member for Dawson should be trying to play a role as some sort of champion of the bush.

PARA.TAB: In contrast, the Commonwealth, as well as offering exceptional circumstances subsidies of 100 per cent, has in place incentives for enhancing productivity by way of the 50 per cent interest subsidies. Farmers are also able to obtain grants to improve skills and assist with appraising their farm businesses. Support is also available via re-establishment grants to those farmers who do wish to leave the farm sector. The farm household support scheme provides farmers who are unable to get commercial finance with support to meet day-to-day family expenses.

The national drought policy contains a series of initiatives which provide an integrated—and I emphasise the word `integrated'—approach and not a scatter gun approach to land management and financial security, by incorporating policies for risk management, financial assistance, research and development, resource management, and education and training. What the Government clearly recognises is that the urgency of the rural crisis is being responded to, but it is not without some historic parallels. As a government, it sees that there is a need for a coordinated and far-sighted approach which responds to urgent current needs while looking to the future and certainly reducing the chances of such crises recurring.

I do feel, from the comments made by the honourable member for Dawson so far, that probably what he is suggesting is that he would like a rural policy which is based a little bit on a kick to kick approach rather than on an approach which is looking towards the long-term future. This Government clearly recognises that that is the way to go. As part of the Government's response to the rural crisis, income equalisation deposits have been designed to provide tax linked incentives for primary producers. These will allow them to build financial reserves for use during downturns, including farm management bonds which have been introduced specifically for use during periods of hardship due to natural or market events.

The circumstances at the moment are certainly a combination of both natural and market events. Neither of those are situations which we can control, but it is imperative that we are able to put in place the packages of assistance which enable farmers not just to be begrudgingly dependent on government assistance all the time but to be able to put in place a situation where they can, with dignity, provide for their future and allow for those exceptional circumstances which are beyond the control of either governments or farmers themselves.

The farmers I have met with want this sort of support and the National Farmers Federation does not want a short-sighted welfare approach to the rural crisis. The primary producers that I have spoken to certainly want assistance like that offered through the tax concessions for things like land care programs that reduce the effect of recurrent prolonged drought and reduce the impact of any sort of drought.

I agree with the honourable member for Dawson. He made comments to the effect that we need to provide packages which will take care of natural disasters—I think that is how he referred to them—because they are so recurrent and so prolonged in Australia. We have to have in place things such as the IEDs, which enable farmers to provide for the occurrence of drought because it is so much a part of the farming scene in the north of Queensland, mid-Queensland and even in the southern parts of Australia. I notice that just recently assistance has had to be provided in parts of South Australia for the very opposite—the damaging effects of too much rain.

Primary producers also want the national property management planning campaign to get under way. It aims to improve the skills of land-holders in elements of property and financial risk planning. The rural business development programs provide help to rural communities to improve marketing and business skills. A range of programs help the whole community. They encourage innovative ideas and international competitiveness. They do not seek to cocoon—if I may use that term—our regional and rural communities. Despite what the honourable member for Dawson seems to believe, these communities want opportunities and incentives to actively turn around their current circumstances and to move into the future positively and with confidence of success.

One of the examples of this far-sightedness that I would put to the House is the telecentre program. One of these operates in my electorate and it gives the community access to computer skills training and to modern communications developments that are essential for a business to become competitive. While I take on board the comments of the honourable member for Braithwaite—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Dawson.
—Sorry, I mean the honourable member for Dawson—
—The member for Braithwaite is good.

—Not yet. I take on board the comments of the honourable member for Dawson that the traditional farmers and those who have farmed for many generations generally know that way of life only. We also have to accept that they do tend to keep up with the modern developments in their industry, and this way of providing information and assistance to farmers is to be applauded.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has just recently found out himself that there is an unfortunate lack of understanding among rural producers about the level of help available to them. I would warn the honourable member for Dawson that too much beating about the bush and assuring farmers that it is all the Government's fault does tend to preclude them from realising what assistance provided by this Government is available to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any need for me to bring to the House's attention the serious plight facing rural producers and the people dependent on them. Many farmers are experiencing the toughest time since they started on the land, whether they be in their 50s, 60s, 70s or even 80s, which some of them are.

PARA.TAB: Low commodity prices have been exacerbated by record high interest rates and, while the Government takes credit for today's lower interest rates, they are still amongst the highest comparable interest rates in the world. However, the aftershocks of the Government's previous scorched earth policy of record high interest rates are still being felt by farmers, many of whom have had to leave the land because of that policy.

On top of that they have the falling commodity prices, particularly in the wool industry, in the citrus industry in my electorate, and in a number of other industries. On top of that again, there is drought in western Queensland and in northern New South Wales. This has badly affected the rural sector, and we will find it affecting the economy of this nation. The Government, although it has a massive Budget deficit, will find that the deficit will get even worse, particularly because of the problems we are facing in our rural sector.

I was pleased to see the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) visit Queensland. He would know now just how serious drought can be. I hope that he will bring back to his Government the message that severe drought is indeed a natural disaster and that it is not only farmers who lose out in time of drought; as I said before, it is the entire Australian economy.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural Resource Economics—a part of the Minister's own portfolio—in its September quarterly forecast told us that, on average, farm businesses in Australia will lose $26,000 in 1992-93; the figure for last year was a loss of $29,000; and the year before it was $24,000. This means that an average farmer loses $79,000 in a three-year period, and I believe that in the wool industry the loss is even worse.

One of the things we have to look at—and this is what this motion is all about—is the assets test as applied to farmers and farming families. The assets test cannot be applied in the same way as it is to other situations. The Government's removal of the assets test for farm household support is to be welcomed, but it must go further in assisting farming families.

Many, if not most, farmers are asset rich and income poor. Assets are virtually worthless unless they are producing an income. The notion that farmers should sell up and leave and turn their assets into liquidity is ludicrous, given that farm property values are extremely low. The extremely depressed rural property market would work against people trying to sell their properties, even if they wanted to.

Farmers are in a catch-22 situation: they cannot afford to work the farm and they cannot afford to leave it. Many farmers in my electorate of Riverina are above the average age of 57, which in itself is an indictment of the fact that young people cannot afford a farm. So the older farmers keep going because they cannot leave the farm, and young people cannot afford to go onto a farm.

I remember going to a small property in the irrigation area, where I had a friend of Italian heritage. He was very upset, talking to me in tears because his son had come home. He had been educated and, as we know, the Italian heritage is that they work hard for their families so that they can give them something. The young man said, `Dad, I am educated now. I hope you are not working from daylight until dark for me, because there is no way I am taking on this lifestyle to make a living. I do not want to have to put up with drought and with the costs that are added on to me. I am going to work for the Government'. So he is working for the Government and his father is devastated.

The Government must seriously consider the coalition's policy of abolishing the assets test on pensions for those farmers wishing to retire on the family farm. I know of one gentleman from my electorate, aged 75, who cannot retire because he cannot get a pension to live on. He cannot sell the farm, as I said before, because the values have dropped.

The Austudy assets test must also be removed for those families in rural areas who are undergoing economic hardship. It is very difficult in these times for those people to educate their children. The Government should also consider abolishing the assets test on a range of other benefits, including all rural education allowances. We have a problem in the bush. The Government must look at the assets test because the situation is different for those on the land.

I turn finally to income equalisation deposits. They should be an important method of stabilising farm incomes through drought, floods, crop failure and falls in commodity prices. If we had the old IED scheme that was introduced by the coalition, in particular by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), we would have had farmers in a much better situation today to face these high interest rates, drought and the fall in commodity prices.

I support the motion which calls for the Government to act on these matters as a matter of urgency and ask for a deeper empathy with the plight of rural people in these harsh times. It was said that a partnership is required. We must get together. It is not `them and us'. These people have supported the nation and we must now support them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very serious subject and I commend the speakers from the Opposition—the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks)—because I think they have a genuine concern for farming communities. I do not think that they are trying to play it politically and I appreciate the ideas of partnership and working together on this. Also, the words that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) spoke on this subject showed a genuine concern.

PARA.TAB: All of us who have a knowledge of rural communities and country areas—and that would include you, Mr Deputy Speaker—understand that things are very tough out there. Some of the areas that have been hit by drought conditions are being described as the worst drought areas since settlement. There can be no doubt that there is extreme hardship being suffered by many of those people and families in those areas.

The motion for the acknowledgment of that hardship by this House should be recognised. I have been to some of those areas and there is ample evidence that hardship exists. But even in areas where the drought has not been so severe, many are having a difficult time because of the low world commodity prices and the effects of the rural recession. It is especially so for woolgrowers, as some of them have struggled through the last three or four years with continuing drought, low prices, recession and earlier high interest rates. Some of them have had all of those things at the same time. The hardship has been extremely severe. The Government does recognise that and acknowledges those difficulties. On 11 May, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) stated that he acknowledged the major problems facing rural Australia.

The Government has been doing, and is doing, more than just expressing concern at these problems. We have allocated additional funding for the RAS—an extra $150 million in the last two years. We have introduced the exceptional circumstances provisions of around $50 million to deal with the long-term drought and to assist woolgrowers. We have allowed special access to the Job Search allowance for farmers. We have increased the RAS exit grant to $45,000; we have extended the farm household scheme; we have given additional support for the education of isolated children; we have given additional allowances under Austudy; and we have attempted to work with the banks to improve the deals that they get for farmers.

We have done those things, but that is not to say that more should not be done and that we should not be looking at other things—perhaps some of the things that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) mentions in his motion. The Government will continue to examine closely the situation in rural Australia and, I hope, offer further real assistance where it can effectively do so.

One of the matters that have come to my notice is that many people in rural areas—those people affected by the worst parts of those hardships—are not aware of some of the benefits that are available. That was, I think, identified by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), when he went to south-east Queensland recently. It was also identified by Graham Blight, in his address the other day, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major problems in this respect is that many farmers do not know what kind of support is available.

He says that the NFF and the Minister's office will cooperate to provide services for getting that information out. Perhaps we, as members of parliament from rural areas, have not been getting that information out as well as we might have done. We have available to us the local press and local media to get that information out, and we should make a real effort to tell all farmers what sort of assistance is available, because that is identified not only by us but by the NFF as one of the problems with the assistance that is now available. (Time expired)
