DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY ON THE ECONOMY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in view of Australia's intractable high unemployment and high current account deficit, this House urges the Government to establish a National Commission of Inquiry on the Economy to report within a year on the new policies required to simultaneously rapidly increase employment and reduce the current account deficit while maintaining low inflation, improving equity and ensuring environmental security.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is at a watershed. We have two intractable economic problems which the policies of the 1980s have failed to resolve: high unemployment and a high current account deficit. As well, the policies of the 1980s have increased inequity, through the growth of high income and of the wealth and power of a relatively small proportion of the population. The quality and accessibility of some important community services have been reduced by cuts in government spending, and a serious aftermath of the excesses of private entrepreneurs during the 1980s has been a loss of confidence in the probity, ethics and judgment of the Australian business community, both here and internationally.

PARA.TAB: Yet there were also demonstrable benefits from the policies of the 1980s which now provide a firm basis for a refocused economic strategy. Firstly, Australia's inflation rate of about one per cent is amongst the lowest in Western countries, and continues here at the lowest level it has been for several decades. Secondly, Australia's public debt is amongst the lowest of comparable countries, a fact which is not recognised by many economic analysts. Thirdly, an economic recovery is under way. Australia is expecting to grow faster than all but a couple of Western countries during 1993.

Other achievements during the last decade have included the remarkable growth in public sector productivity of over four per cent a year, which the Opposition often does not recognise; the efficiency of the social security system in targeting deprivation; and the exploding interest in education and training in schools, institutes of technology and universities. These achievements are, in part, the obverse side of the problems.

However, a central issue remains, which is that many of the Government's economic advisers have been preoccupied with reducing inflation rather than unemployment and with improving efficiency rather than equity. For example, many economists perceive a trade-off between inflation and unemployment. Although both are regarded as problems, many economists would argue that achieving and maintaining low inflation should have a priority. `Inflation first' is their slogan. A low inflation rate is certainly desirable, for it increases Australia's international competitiveness and improves economic security. Yet moderate inflation and unemployment are hardly equivalent evils. Inflation is only about the value of money, yet unemployment marginalises and stigmatises people, destroying their economic security and their self-respect.

Many economists, particularly monetarists, solemnly talked during the 1980s about the `natural rate of unemployment'—one of the most vicious euphemisms ever coined, as the past president of the Economic Associations of America wrote recently. Our own Treasury has used the inhuman term `over-full employment' meaning that while there was still unemployment inflationary pressure was increasing. Such word games demonstrate the dehumanisation of much economic analysis.

The way out of this conflict is to emphasise the twin goals of reduction of both unemployment and inflation. It is not beyond the wit of competent economists to design policies which simultaneously increase employment and reduce inflation. That is the main goal of the accord, which has contributed directly and effectively to achieving both goals.

Australia's circumstances require that economic policy be refocused. There has been a strong public reaction against the misjudgments of the economic fundamentalists. There is a widespread hunger for a balanced approach which would offer realistic hope of growth of employment and equity, as well as of low inflation and improving efficiency, of environmental responsibility as well as of economic development. The Government is firmly committed to those complex goals and it must therefore be prepared to seek policies which would include more active intervention. In that context there would be great value in a national commission of inquiry into the economy.

The outcome of such an inquiry could well be a statement akin to the 1945 white paper on full employment, but the process of preparation would be vital to the effectiveness of the outcome. An internal Public Service review would be inadequate, because much the same people who advised on the policies of the 1980s would prepare the papers. The Vernon committee or the Coombs royal commission would provide much better models because they involved commissioners with a wide range of experience drawn from all major parts of the economy. That is a somewhat different approach from that envisaged by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, though the rationale is similar.

A five-person commission would be appropriate, drawn from business, unions, academia, the Public Service and other community groups. Such an inquiry could be established immediately. The commission could be given a year to report and the support of a secretariat of about 20 professional officers. The terms of reference for the commission should begin with the Government's commitment to full employment and lower inflation, to improving equity and efficiency and to environmental security as well as economic development, and include references to each of the areas of policy and practice which make an impact on economic activity and employment: fiscal, monetary and incomes policy, the international economy, industry policy, education, training and immigration, industry structure, work and employment practices, labour market programs, income support and so on.

Inquiries sometimes cause cynicism among people who say, `The Government is only deferring the problems'. The point is, however, that there are no panaceas for resolving our intractable economic problems. No-one on either side of this House, or in any part of the community, has the whole answer. Hundreds of new minor and major policy and program initiatives and changes in business and union practice are required, and that was recognised by the Government in the Governor-General's speech when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we also acknowledge that new policies and practices may have to be developed.

That is certainly true. Without new policies and practices we will still have high unemployment by the end of the decade. Both new processes of policy formation and new approaches are necessary. In this situation, a broad based inquiry, drawing on the most rigorous intellectual analysis and empirical research by able people, committed to the goals of full employment as well as to the goals of lower inflation and to improving equity as well as efficiency, could make a major contribution to effectively redirecting Australian economic strategy.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Government should not wait until the report of this commission is received before taking initiatives. Fresh additional policies are required immediately. I will conclude by suggesting a couple. In October 1991, I tabled a parliamentary report on Australia's current account deficit and overseas debt and, in July last year, I released a report of an employment task force entitled `Maximising employment'. Some of the proposals in those reports have already been implemented, including fiscal stimulus, a new job creation scheme operating on local infrastructure, a fall in interest rates and the exchange rate, and the expansion of targeted training programs for young people.

Other proposals are still relevant. For example, there is scope for a further expansion of public outlays targeted in ways which would increase national productivity, output and exports. These include areas such as infrastructure, education and training, research and development, structural adjustment and international marketing assistance. Further increases in funding for institutes of technology, universities and schools, for railways, roads and ports, as well as for hospitals and public housing would serve the double purpose of improving the efficiency of the national infrastructure and of improving skills in human wellbeing as well as stimulating economic activity.

Income restraint should be maintained and extended to non-wage incomes through implementation of the strength and competition policy and by using progressive tax policies. An active industry based policy should be developed to promote exports and import replacement with emphasis on regional userproducer links.

Many other possibilities are appropriate but to summarise: the central requirements for addressing unemployment and the current account deficit are a more balanced approach to both ends and means. This would allow a more active role for the Government free of the artificial ideological constraints of the 1980s. Our society will be more secure and attractive if it is also more equitable and humane.(Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—Unfortunately, I will not be able to support the motion of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). It must be said that I do support his objectives of low inflation and high levels of employment or conversely low levels of unemployment. There is no question that, in a historical context, we need to once again return Australia to those halcyon days of the past when we lived in a time of low inflation and virtually no unemployment whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that, instead of another commission or another inquiry, basically we know what needs to be done. We know what needs to be done and yet this Government—those on the Government side of this place—lack the political will to get on with the job. While he talks in very positive context about the so-called benefits of the accord, I remind the honourable member for Fraser that this stitched-up deal between a Labor government and the trade unions in Australia has really brought undone the basis of our whole economy. This is the first thing that needs to be addressed.

It is to the Government's credit—and I have said this on many occasions—and the credit of the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that when he was Treasurer he did help us to deregulate the banks and to deregulate the dollar so that our dollar now floats in an international context. But in a historical context Australia grew up with great wealth generated out of our mines and on our farms—off the backs of the sheep, if you will. In order to try to diversify our exports, diversify what Australians did, we then used that income to build a huge wall of protection around our country. That wall of protection not only cost Australians dearly, as we now know, but also set in train a set of attitudes and a whole set of formalised systems—including, notably, our industrial relations system being highly centralised and highly cosseted as it is. So for year after year after year we increased protection for industry because the unions said they needed a wage increase, and then we increased wages because we had increased the cost to Australians of the products that we had so protected.

Now we are caught in this time warp where we know what needs to be done. We know that we need to deregulate the labour market as we have deregulated the financial market. We know that Australian industry, in order to be competitive, has got to be released from the constraints of centralism and released from the constraints of the union bureaucracy determining, in the largest sense, how people work, what they are paid and how they participate in the working life of our economy. I have no doubt that if we truly deregulate our labour market, if we attack some of our real infrastructure problems—like the cost of electricity supply, the cost of water and the cost of transport both on land and, significantly, at sea—if we allow our industry to be competitive and if at the same time we offer industry some encouragement to invest in productive capacity, then perhaps once again we will start to build the industry infrastructure which today we know is falling.

Investment in new productive capacity is falling, and that means that this recovery which the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) says is emerging may not in fact emerge at all. I fear that as we further eliminate tariffs, without allowing industry some advantage on the other side for giving up this protection, we will in fact lose more and more industry, some of it to bankruptcies and some of it overseas. We will never solve the problem of low inflation and high employment until we have productive enterprise. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that the previous speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), took such a narrow and simplistic view on the Australian economy. The conclusion from his position is that the way to solve the problem is to reduce Australian wages. That is basically what he is talking about, turning us into not a low wage country but an ultra low wage country. Unfortunately, he has missed the richness of this motion before the House. What the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) has put forward is a matter of extreme substance, not some trivial, simplistic notion that you can solve our economic problems easily.

PARA.TAB: To understand its depth, one really has to go back over time and look at what has been happening in Australia in the sense that we, with the rest of the world, have moved slowly. Things have changed slowly, and one can go back and measure those changes over hundreds of years and see minor changes in language, in technology, in science and medicine. But in the last 30 years there has been a dramatic change in the rate of change and the whole world has suddenly started to learn much faster.

There has been a massive change in production technology. It took us thousands of years to develop production lines like the Ford production line. It has taken us virtually decades to automate those lines. The development of computers took 50 years to get to transistors and five to 10 years to get to integrated circuits. The miniaturisation, computerisation and automation of our means of production is transforming the fabric of modern economies so fast that most people do not see what is happening and cannot see the results. It is transforming so fast that we can no longer measure it and, because we cannot measure it, we cannot predict it.

Some time ago a parliamentary inquiry took evidence from representatives of the Bureau of Statistics about how they measure investment. It transpired that leasing by businesses is not regarded as investment. So all those companies that are leasing equipment are not investing because leasing is part of finance; it is not part of investment.

The national accounts figures are a good example. That famous and historic occasion in December 1991 when the national accounts figures for September were negative had an enormous effect on how businesses and the community perceived that Australia was going. People made a lot of decisions based on those figures. Three months later those figures were revised to become positive. In other words, in reporting on the September quarter the Bureau of Statistics had made a report which was in fact wrong, and that was corrected four months later. So until those corrections were made, people were making judgments about what to do, and they were making the wrong judgments.

We need to transform dramatically our capacity to understand our economy. We drastically need to transform our capacity to predict our economy. When things change slowly it is easy to predict. When things change quickly it is hard to predict. We are using instruments of prediction and analysis which date back to 20 years ago. Those instruments were terrific for understanding our economy 20 years ago. The danger is that in 20 years time we will have instruments that predict today's economy very well.

Unless we understand that and understand the methodologies, we will be trapped in a situation where we have very little control over our future. The fact is that predictions can be self-fulfilling. If we say we are in recession, and we tell the whole world we are in recession, and we tell ourselves we are in recession, then to some degree we automatically are in recession.

This does not just apply to Australia. At the beginning of last year in America and Europe President George Bush and Prime Minister John Major were being given similar advice about their economies. I was in Europe early last year. I talked to French parliamentarians and French bureaucrats about their advice, and the advice they were getting was very similar to the advice we were being given in Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a worthwhile initiative and I am pleased to comment on it. I have listened very carefully to the comments made by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) and the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), but I feel that the recommendation that has been put forward is more noble than practical. I am surprised that this suggestion is coming from the government benches. This nation is indeed in a terrible mess. There is no doubt about that. The Government must accept full responsibility for that mess.

PARA.TAB: I have wondered for a long time whether honourable members on the other side of this House really have any idea of the enormous amount of anxiety, personal tragedy and misery that is out there in the real world. I am reassured by the comments of the two honourable members opposite. I commended them. However, I do not share their optimism with respect to future growth. Their optimism is not shared by the authors of articles in the Australian Financial Review today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The grievance that I wish to put before the House today is one that has been raised, at least in part, by me earlier this week. I wish to place on the record, very briefly, that the subject about which I am going to speak was raised in a spurious way in the Queensland Parliament yesterday by the Queensland State Treasurer. I state to the House that I do not intend to respond at the moment to Mr de Lacy's allegations. I am hoping that I shall get the opportunity when 90-second statements occur later today to make a statement in response to the allegations Mr de Lacy made about me yesterday.

PARA.TAB: However, at this stage Mr De Lacy and his views are only a sideshow. The central issue is one of national security. On Monday I asked a question of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) relating to the activities of a Japanese crime boss in Australia. The Prime Minister made an undertaking which I shall refer to in a few minutes.

Yesterday, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, as the Minister representing the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), had this matter raised by way of a question to him from a Queensland senator. In reply, amongst other things, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Justice has sought advice from the commissioner of the Australian Federal Police in respect of this issue. As a consequence of that advice, I am advised that the AFP has in fact been monitoring Japanese organised crime trends and activities for a number of years.
Further on in his reply, when responding as the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, he made the statement:

There has been media speculation in recent days, particularly in Queensland. That speculation has named specific persons. . . I have asked my department, the immigration department, to investigate the allegations as they affect immigration laws.

Yesterday's attempt in the Senate by the Minister to answer my question to the Prime Minister and to draw away some of the attention being paid to this subject has raised far more questions than it answered. It now transpires, according to information in the Minister's answer, that the Japanese crime boss whom I referred to earlier this week holds a multiple entry visa. The Minister said:
That visa, I am informed, was issued at a time when he had no criminal record.

Obviously, when his department gave him that advice it was hoping that the Minister had not read my speech, because it outlined how it could happen that a criminal from Japan would not appear to have a criminal record, at least, not before March of this year, which was when the relevant Japanese law was changed. The facts are that Masaru Takumi has twice been issued with a multiple entry visa into Australia. One was issued for four years in 1987. His present visa was issued for four years in 1991—it is obviously a renewal of the 1987 visa—and does not expire until December 1995.

PARA.TAB: Presumably this is a multiple entry business visa, although the Minister did not actually say that in his answer. So for the last six years one of the world's leading crime figures has held a multiple entry visa for Australia and has travelled here at will under that visa. Presumably, six years ago he made claims as to having certain business interests in this country. We must be urgently told what those claims were. What are Mr Takumi's business interests in Australia? Time does not permit me to reiterate the sorts of business interests that his branch of the Yakuza—the Yamaguchi-Gumi gang—pursues, but there are thousands of seemingly legitimate businesses operated by his gang. How many of them is he pursuing here in Australia?

I made reference to the fact that the home that Takumi has bought on the Gold Coast, in my electorate, was purchased by a business called Takumi Enterprises Pty Ltd. He remarried in June 1991, I note for the record. The two shareholders in this company are he and the woman he married in June 1991. If he received a business visa in 1987—that is, before he married this co-shareholder—what other businesses, besides Takumi Enterprises Pty Ltd, does this man have in Australia?

We must urgently have all this information put before us, and it is the business of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to be seeking that information. It is not just a matter for the Minister for Justice with his responsibility for the Australian Federal Police. It is not just the business of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, with his responsibility for issuing visas. It is also very much the responsibility of the Treasurer.

I reiterate that the reason, however, that I directed last Monday's question to the Prime Minister, calling on him to answer the allegations about Takumi, is that this is a matter of utmost urgency, with implications for Australia's national security. It relates not only to the general question of the administration of government in Australia across several portfolios but also specifically to the central role of the Australian Federal Police and its responsibilities for protecting our security.

I find it very poor indeed that yesterday—five days after the front page Courier-Mail article made its allegations about Masaru Takumi—the best the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs could say is that he has called for a report, and that he could only give us sketchy, basic information. He should have urgently been seeking it after Saturday's Courier-Mail story, not after I raised the matter here on Monday. Even so, two days after my question and my speech, he still does not have anything to tell us. I reiterate here an extract from Saturday's Courier-Mail article:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal Police yesterday—
that is, last Friday, 7 May 1993—
confirmed they were aware of Takumi's penthouse purchase and his frequent visits to the Gold Coast but would not comment further.
The article then quotes the federal police:

`The Australian Federal Police does not talk about its intelligence activities in relation to the Yakuza or any ethnic organised crime group which may or may not be operating in Australia', a spokesman said.

This is an official statement from the Australian Federal Police, presumably following on from the other comments of confirmation that had been made. It is confirmation that the AFP has been aware of the activities of this man on the Gold Coast.

PARA.TAB: I ask two central questions. If the Australian Federal Police was aware of his activities, why did it not inform the department of immigration earlier? If it did, why was this man's visa not cancelled forthwith? Why is it today still valid? Why is it that he could be arriving at any of our international airports today and be allowed through immigration with impunity, with a right to be here? What is happening in the administration of the security of this country?

I turn very briefly to the matter of the Foreign Investment Review Board, because I have only a short time left to speak on this matter. The Treasurer, as I said, must make a full statement about the FIRB approval of Takumi's property purchase. I cannot repeat here the grounds available for approval of purchase of private property by a foreign national, but they are all listed in my speech of Monday.

Now it appears that this man has had business activities here since 1987. Not only has the Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Department not done anything about his visa for six years, but the Foreign Investment Review Board also has had a potential involvement for the past six years. What checks has FIRB made on the actual business activities of this man? What information can it give us, through the Treasurer—and hopefully also through the Prime Minister—about what his activities have been? What has he claimed? Does he claim business activities other than Takumi Enterprises Pty Ltd? What are all of his companies' activities in this country, if in fact he has more than one company? Whether it is one or more, we must be told in this place the names of the directors of all of those companies, because we are informed in the Courier-Mail article that there is an Australian involvement in Takumi Enterprises Pty Ltd.

The same questions must be asked of the AFP as must be asked of the FIRB. Why have Takumi's activities not been reported to relevant government authorities? Whilst, as I said, Mr de Lacy has attempted to draw attention to himself, what is really central to this matter is the role of the Australian Federal Police. In theory, critical information should have been flowing from it to all these other government departments. If it has, why has action not been taken in those departments? If it has not flowed, we must know with great urgency the reasons and the facts behind that non-flow of information about one of the world's leading criminals and his activities in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue some remarks I have been making about aspects of superannuation policy which now come under my area of responsibility in the Government. However, first I want to pick up and counter some criticisms by the Opposition relating to some recent speeches I have made on the question of superannuation.

PARA.TAB: There is a perception in the coalition parties that the benefits accruing to workers under the superannuation guarantee system will not be enough to fund a decent standard of living for Australians in retirement. The conventional wisdom on that right now is that, yes, contributions of only three to five per cent of wages are not sufficient to build up a decent nest egg. But honourable members need to remember that under our system employer contributions are set to rise, over the next few years, from that level to nine per cent of employee ordinary time earnings.

In short, everyone knows that the current contributions are not sufficient, but what we have done through our policy is to set in legislation the rate at which the contributions will rise and become sufficient. What the Government has not done—and what our opponents apparently would like to do—is subject our retirement incomes policy to the vagaries of the Opposition's industrial relations policy, which is pretty much a dog-eat-dog situation.

The Opposition has also, of course, relied on the notion of a faulty system of incentives that are meant to induce Australians to put away for their own retirement, a system which we well know, and the superannuation industry knows, would simply be insufficient; people would not put away and make sufficient provision for their own retirement. It is important that we have a schedule whereby we raise the rate of contributions over a number of years to a level which we all agree is sufficient for a decent income in retirement.

We know, and so should our opponents, that when we introduce a scheme with such importance as the superannuation guarantee we need to make gradual changes. That is why the contribution rates will rise over a considerable number of years. We know that contribution rates must be in the vicinity of about 12 per cent of average weekly earnings, but we have ensured that we do not make that levy all at one time on the business community: we have already announced that we will reach that percentage by the end of the century. The contributions from employers will reach nine per cent and then the question of a three per cent contribution on the part of employees will have to be raised and no doubt will be worked through.

I was reading in a recent article by David Wise some interesting trends and facts about the American retirement income scenario. He noted that 64 million people in the United States work in almost two-thirds of all commercial organisations which do not offer any kind of superannuation contributions. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: For the majority of these workers, the social security system is the only hope for succour and security in their retirement years.
Interestingly, for the job growth that Australia will experience in the next few years, he said:
The trends in the economy towards job-creation by smaller firms which are outside of the collective bargaining system will only exacerbate the current decline in private pension fund coverage.

All honourable members should breathe a collective sigh of relief that Australia has such a well-developed and mature retirement incomes policy. One only has to look at the open hostility of the small business community and basically the employer groups to the advent of both award based superannuation and the superannuation guarantee charge scheme to guess where we would now be if a Liberal government had been elected in March this year.

PARA.TAB: The other refrain that we hear often involves the effect of excessive fees and charges being levied against those taking out superannuation. I am happy to say and to announce today that the fees, charges, commissions and their disclosures, both in life insurance and superannuation products, will be one of my priorities in my period as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer.

Just recently one of the honourable members opposite suggested that these fees were a substantial drain on retirement savings. I might say to that person in reply that rather than throw up my hands and suggest that this is too difficult an area to tackle, what I will be proposing is that we will not allow high transaction fees to frustrate government policy in this area. To that end I look forward to the challenge of creating a situation where by careful scrutiny by the Government and by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and by the forces of competition that we can enhance in the market, the cost of private superannuation will be forced down.

I note that earlier this year Senator Sherry, the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, tabled some documents showing the growth in industry funds prior to the introduction of the superannuation guarantee levy. I would hope soon to be able to table some more up to date figures on the growth of low cost industry funds.

I might now turn to another subject that I have an interest in, national accounting for resource depletion. I have an interest in that for a couple of reasons. Firstly, the Australian Bureau of Statistics comes within my purview as Parliamentary Secretary. Secondly, as an old geographer I have kept up an interest in environmental issues.
I note with interest the report in the Australian of 29 April where the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Ros Kelly) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia should consider including environmental damage and the depletion of national resources in its calculations of national income.

This follows from similar moves that are now occurring in the United States. Support for such moves comes from the Vice-President of the United States, Al Gore, who wrote in October 1992 when he was still Senator Gore, that he noted that the man-delivered impacts on the environment were not adequately factored into the decision making equation. He said:

The bad things economists want to ignore while they measure the good things are often said to be too difficult to integrate into their calculations. . . . The bad things are simply defined away as external to the process and called externalities. This habit of using an arbitrary definition to exclude inconvenient facts from the calculation of what is good and what is bad is a form of dishonesty.

PARA.TAB: The work of the noted American Robert Repetto of the World Resources Institute in Washington DC is enlightening here. He notes that both classical and Keynesian economists are caught up in measuring factors like consumption and savings and investment and so on and he goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The difference in treatment of natural resources and other tangible assets provides false signals to both economists and politicians. It reinforces a false dichotomy between the economy and the environment that leads them to ignore or destroy the latter in the name of development.

PARA.TAB: These developments have already excited the curiosity of some Australians and to this end I note the work of Mr Young of the CSIRO in Canberra. In May 1991 Mr Young extrapolated the Repetto approach to the Australian landscape and did some work on a conceptual framework for accountants that describes the costs and benefits of agricultural land use in the Murray-Darling Basin. I note that he also has completed some work at a macro level looking at renewable resource depletion and the valuation of mineral stocks and their effect on the GDP.

I mention these points because the issue has now been raised by Mrs Kelly. I seek to have discussions with the ABS and Mrs Kelly on the question. I think it is a very difficult one even to conceptualise, but it is one that we have to think about. We have to have the ABS do some work on it and see if we cannot incorporate these measures of natural resource depletion as part of our national accounting system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 35th and 36th parliaments I have reminded the House, and now I remind the 37th Parliament, of one of the worst disasters in the peacetime history of the Royal Australian Navy and of this nation. Many honourable members will recognise that I speak of the collision in February 1964 between the destroyer HMAS Voyager and the aircraft carrier, and flagship at that time, HMAS Melbourne off Jervis Bay, claiming 82 lives.

PARA.TAB: For five years, both in this place and outside, I have supported the compensation case for some 80 survivors of that tragedy through to a successful High Court, supposedly precedent setting, action for one of them in 1990, the so-called Verwayen case. Although that gentleman's claim has now been settled, regrettably many other survivors and their families still bear indelible scars: scars of psychological trauma, of persistent nervous shock, of domestic instability, of financial strain and, very importantly in this parliamentary setting, of misplaced confidence in a government which espouses social justice but a government which demonstrably until today—and I have to say `until today'—has failed to put its money where its mouth is and has failed to live up to its compassionate rhetoric in this instance.
To illustrate, I refer the House to an editorial entitled `Justice at Last' in the Brisbane Courier-Mail in September 1990, which stated in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The view that the Commonwealth has behaved with despicable bureaucratic self-interest in the Voyager case would result in very little argument in the general community. The High Court ruling paving the way for compensation claims by the survivors of that horrific 1964 naval accident, is a signal victory for social justice.
It went on to say:

The Commonwealth long denied liability for compensation. Mr Hawke's first Government lifted the statute of limitations on the case in 1985, then slammed the door in 1986 when it found there might be substantial compensation claims in the offing.

The Verwayen judgment supposedly means that the Commonwealth, as an employer of people paid to defend the country, cannot claim exemption from civil compensation if they come to harm in the course of their natural or normal duties, the so-called combat defence. This is not only an important precedent but also is a simple reflection of elementary justice, albeit achieved for Mr Verwayen only after a tortuous confrontation with the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: I regret to say that the path to justice for the remaining survivors continues to be obstructed at every turn by the Commonwealth, although I am more optimistic as the result of the initiatives by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) a couple of hours ago. Since 1986, Ministers have relied on legalistic jingoism in each individual case. Squirm as they may about their rationale, Ministers know that the bottom line for the Commonwealth is a total compensation bill of about $30 million. In other words, unnecessary and costly legal argument has been used to cloud the real issue of reluctance to satisfy such a substantial budgetary outlay.
I refer the Attorney-General in particular to page 45 of Mr Justice Coldrey's 1992 judgment in one of these cases, the Clark case, where he said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: It would of course, have been open to the defendant—
in this case, the Commonwealth—
if it lost the Verwayen case—
which indeed it did—

to withdraw its defences against all remaining Voyager claimants on the basis of consistency towards an otherwise homogeneous class of persons and in order to prevent any perception of discrimination and injustice.

Late last month, the Full Court of the Victorian Supreme Court dismissed an appeal by the Commonwealth against an $800,000 damages claim in the Clark case. Mr Justice Ormiston said, in part, that the Commonwealth could not rely on the combat defence or indeed on the statute of limitations.

PARA.TAB: I simply say to the Attorney-General today that enough is enough. Forget the historical differences. Why continue to prolong the judicial processes when the results are inevitable, and why not make a settlement to each of the survivors along the lines of the Justice Coldrey suggestion. As Mr Clark's solicitor, Jim Taylor, said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: For goodness sake, I hope that our Government realises that the umpire has made a decision. Let us abide by it.

That said, today's statement by the Commonwealth in the Supreme Court of Victoria appears to be moving along those quasi class action lines. On that point I seek leave to table a copy of the Commonwealth statement. I have cleared it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much. The 1992 book about the Voyager sinking by the historian Tom Frame, Where Fate Calls, should be a salutary reminder to the people of Australia, to the Royal Australian Navy, to Federal governments of all party political hues and to this Government in particular. No-one wants a witch-hunt after 30 years. However, it remains a national tragedy that the public at large and the families of the 82 men who died may never have the undisputed truth. That said, what the people of Australia should understand today is the degree of intransigence by the present Government on the compensation claims of the survivors, many of whom are physical and mental wrecks.

PARA.TAB: The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) may recall that, last Monday in this place, I sought assurances from him that he would ensure, in conjunction with his Defence and Finance ministerial colleagues, that all outstanding Voyager compensation claims are settled by the Commonwealth in the life of this Parliament. At the time, and informally since, he has given me assurances that we could expect a positive response by today. To the Attorney-General's credit he has honoured that undertaking with today's positive initiative in the courts.

The Attorney-General's credibility, of course, has been and will continue to be an issue. He has a lot to live down, both politically and professionally, as a result of his unconventional appointment by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) prior to the 17 April Dickson by-election. I am hopeful that his Cabinet advisings earlier this week and today's change of legal tack by the Government will provide substantive early results for the survivors, ensuring that those who perished nearly 30 years ago will at long last rest in peace and that those who survived can pick up the shattered remnants of their lives. As a survivor, Mr Clark, said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth just seems to be able to print its own money. We're broke and we're desperate.

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding today's commendable developments, which will need to be kept under close review, I implore the Attorney-General, as indeed I would any reasonable person, to ensure that, for God's sake, we show some unqualified compassion and get the issue settled without further delays for these people before more join the suicide ranks of some of their colleagues. Near enough is simply not good enough when it comes to people's lives. The ball remains in the Attorney-General's court; it is imperative that he take it up and that he score a quick and decisive goal in the national interest for 80 desperate people.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the grievance debate to inform the House about an issue that has been a particular concern in my electorate over the last few weeks; that is, the health of my community. The Governor-General mentioned in his address to the Parliament last week that our Government plans to work with State governments and the private sector to achieve efficiency gains and better access to health services while reducing waiting lists in main surgical areas. This to me was extremely encouraging news.

PARA.TAB: However, I am very disturbed that I received a letter from a constituent recently whose 19-year-old son has had a distressing experience with our health system in New South Wales. His access to local health services was impaired, to say the least. My constituent stated to me that her son had been experiencing very high fevers, vomiting and severe headaches for over a week. He was told on three separate occasions by doctors coming to the home to treat him during that time that he had glandular fever.

By the end of that week of treatment he was so ill and his mother become so frustrated that she immediately put him in her car and rushed him to Westmead Hospital, which, I might add, is a major teaching hospital in the western region of Sydney. There she was told that there was something like a three-hour waiting period in casualty. She appealed to the sister in charge,`He is very ill. Could he at least lie down?'. She said, `No, you will have to wait your turn'. She was then questioned about her address; when my constituent said she lived in Yennora, which is part of my electorate, she was asked by the sister on duty why she did not go to the smaller local hospital at Fairfield, which the sister said was closer, and told that she should not have brought her son to Westmead in the first place.

I was particularly shocked to read about this because I have always believed that it is the right of all people to be able to go to any public hospital for emergency assistance, no matter where they live. I might add that, geographically, that person lives a lot closer to Westmead Hospital than Fairfield Hospital.

My constituent's son was deteriorating rapidly and, rather than take him straight to Fairfield Hospital, she drove to a medical centre in Merrylands which was much closer. The doctors there were extremely concerned about the treatment Westmead Hospital had given my constituent's son because they were sure he had meningitis. The doctors at the medical centre then organised immediate transfer for the son to Fairfield Hospital. Doctors at Fairfield Hospital agreed that he may have meningitis and they decided that he would have to go—wait for it!—back to Westmead Hospital, or to Liverpool Hospital, for further tests. By this stage my constituent was so distressed by her son's illness and treatment and the condition he was then in that she said, `We will not go to Westmead'. So the hospital then sent him to Liverpool Hospital for further tests.

The tests confirmed that her son did have viral meningitis, which is an extremely serious disease that affects the brain. I have requested a full investigation, on behalf of my constituent, of her experience at Westmead Hospital. I should state that Westmead is a teaching hospital which I have always been very proud of since relocating in the western region of Sydney. I hope that the result of the investigation will prevail upon all concerned so that we do not see a recurrence of what I believe has been a dreadful situation for my constituent to bear. Her son, I might add, has been left with permanent damage.

Unfortunately, meningitis is a disease which is increasing in incidence within our community. Young children are particularly susceptible to it. The symptoms progress very quickly and, over a period of hours, a child's health can deteriorate so rapidly that it is vital for that child to be immediately hospitalised.

Bacterial meningitis, as opposed to the viral meningitis which my 19-year-old constituent was diagnosed with, is commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type B, or HIB, which is a strain of the influenza virus which is now affecting around 700 Australian children each year, with some 10 to 20 of those affected children dying from the disease, and a similar number now suffering from permanent long-term scarring. The peak incidence of the disease is in children between the ages of six and 12 months, and about 40 per cent of those cases now occur in children before the age of 18 months.

The Federal Government, I am very pleased to hear, has announced that a special interim arrangement has now been put in place to allow parents of eligible children to claim a refund on any expenditure they may have had in recent months with regard to the HIB vaccine. There are currently four vaccines approved for use in Australia, but only one is approved for use in children over 18 months. The other three are administered when the children are two, four and 12 months old for the three-dose vaccine, and two, four, six and 18 months old for the four-dose vaccine.

The parents of babies born on or after 1 February 1993, who have purchased that vaccine on or after 1 April 1993, will be eligible, I am pleased to say, for reimbursement of up to $35.50 per dose of the HIB vaccine provided by a pharmacist, medical practitioner or the local council. Proof of purchase will be required, including the name of vaccine and the date on which it was bought, as well as a declaration of out-of-pocket expenses that will also be required to obtain that refund. Parents can now make that claim through their local Medicare office, and special HIB claim forms have now been made available at these offices.

The national HIB immunisation program was agreed as a cooperative program between the Commonwealth and the States in 1992. Under that arrangement, the Commonwealth will now supply the vaccine to the States following a national tender which, fortunately, closes in mid-May. The full program will commence on 1 July 1993. The Commonwealth Government will provide the funds to the States and the Territories so that that precious vaccine can be made available to our medical practitioners and, in particular, to our immunisation clinics at no cost to parents of eligible children from that date.The HIB vaccine is the first significant addition to the routine immunisation schedule since the measles vaccine in 1968.

The national program itself aims to vaccinate all children at two months, and several times thereafter, as this has been shown to be the most effective time for vaccination to take place. Older children, much to the concern of some of my constituents, will not be eligible for the funded program, but I am pleased that they will at least have the ability to purchase the vaccine. The health of our community is vital as we are all well aware. Babies are so precious to us all. Our children are our future and I believe that we must do all we can to protect them from illnesses such as meningitis.

I commend our Federal Government on its moves to make the HIB vaccine readily and freely available to parents for their children. I believe this will not only contribute to the general health and to the wellbeing of our society but it will also get the message across to the community at large that we must now take further steps to protect our children.

Recently in my electorate, we have had cases of mothers who did not know that something like this existed. They originally thought that their child was having a reaction to flu or was sick or teething. I believe that, with this awareness and with the immunisation program that is now in place, we will go a long way to avoiding what has been a tragic loss of life which we now know was avoidable.

Most particularly, I am very concerned to receive reports, in a community such as mine, of the calibre of treatment from a major teaching hospital like Westmead—that it could be put in the circumstance where many seriously ill constituents of mine are being placed at a disadvantage. Our community at all times should have the right to emergency treatment, no matter where they go in the public health system. I hope the representations that I have made, on behalf of my constituents, will see the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) fully investigating this particular matter. I believe that in so doing we could prevent in the future an occurrence like this affecting other constituents in other electorates.

I am particularly pleased to commend to the community the availability of a vaccine that has taken a number of years to bring to this country. I plead with many mothers—who have for some time ignored the right of having their children vaccinated—to heed the advice that has now been proven. The only preventive way is to have children vaccinated and to have them done at a very early age with a preference to start the first vaccine, in the multi-vaccine inoculation, at two months of age. I know that many people are saying, `My child has been all right. Why should I now have a second one vaccinated?'. It is not the case; the disease is there. There is a preventive measure which they can take. The cost is no longer the cause for not taking that preventive measure. I appeal to all parents throughout Australia to make it available to their children at a very early age.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure there are many honourable members in this House who wish pay television had never been invented. The Government has presided over one big stuff-up that shows no signs of abating. What interests me is the access of pay television to regional and rural Australia—the forgotten land under this Government. How can regional development seriously proceed in this country when our remote regions are 80 years behind the technological eight ball.

PARA.TAB: In 1911 the first automatic telephone exchange began operating in Sydney. It was not until December 1991 that the last manual exchange was phased out in Wanaaring, New South Wales. It took 80 years for the automatic telephone to reach rural Australia. Bravo!

Let us not allow this Labor Government repeat this disgraceful record with pay television. In order to decentralise our closely knit coastal population, effective communications, transport and education facilities must be available in regional areas. Our country regions have great things to offer major metropolitan centres, including a better quality of life, close community associations, lower cost of living, a lower incidence of industrial disputation and a proximity to the nation's wealth—the land and its resources. However, these things do not stand on their own. They must be backed up with adequate provision of quality of life services.

No-one will happily move from a city location to a region where television services are limited, where untimed local telephone calls are simply mythology, where access to education is restricted, and where public transport is non-existent. Regional development is more than just attracting businesses outside the capital cities. It requires a commitment from all levels of government and the provision of equitable levels of services. Pay television is no exception.

Last year during the debate on the Broadcasting Services Bill, an Opposition amendment was successfully carried to provide for as much of Australia as possible to access pay television. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has conveniently ignored this amendment. His comments during Question Time over the last two days illustrate that he is resigned to the fact that 10 per cent of Australian households will not access the Optus satellite high-performance beam and therefore will not receive pay television. He has stated categorically in Question Time that all but 10 per cent of the Australian population will receive pay television.

However, in advocating the satellite technology and the Optus high-performance beam, the Prime Minister implied that rural Queensland and our provincial cities will access pay television. I have news for the Prime Minister. It is these very areas that represent the 10 per cent of households unable to access the high-performance beam. As a general rule of thumb, the high-performance beam will be accessible to those people living within 200 kilometres of the coast. This would rule out the centres of Wagga, Forbes and Junee, so proudly alluded to by the Prime Minister yesterday.

A rhetorical question posed by the Prime Minister during Question Time yesterday was: Who cares about Forbes and Junee and Wagga or rural Queensland, who cares about our great provincial cities?'. Obviously not this Prime Minister, and obviously not this Labor Government. The Prime Minister's gall to suggest that the National Party was not looking after its interests of regional and rural Australia is seen for the sham that it is.

The 10 per cent of Australian households the Prime Minister is willing to write off in the pay television debate is the 10 per cent of households already ignored by the Labor Government. Their access to community, cultural and sporting activities is already severely limited. In many cases, their current television viewing is restricted to two channels, a commercial network and the ABC. In effect, the Government's actions are widening the gap between the haves and the have-nots. What does the city have? It has 26-odd pay television channels, access to live theatrical and sporting activities, and various other services at people's fingertips. What does regional Australia have? Very little. And if this Government has its way, it will be a long time before regional Australia gets much more than it has today.

What of the amendment to provide for as much of Australia as possible to access pay television? I stress the word `possible'. It is indeed possible for 100 per cent of Australian households to access pay television. The licensee must simply draw from the national beam in addition to the high-performance beam.

A simple calculation based on figures provided by Optus would suggest that the provision of four basic service channels on the high-performance beam will cost the licensee $8.6 million per year. To extend the coverage to include the national beam, and access all Australian households, would cost a further $4.4 million. If that were done, we would have a truly national pay television service. What the Government offers is not a national pay television service.

It has the further benefit of reducing the cost of bringing the free to air services to regional and rural Australia and would also lower the cost to government, because some of these free to air services today are subsidised by the Government. Given that we have established that it is possible for pay television to be provided to 100 per cent of Australian households, what action will the Government take to fulfil the amendment passed, to provide for as much of Australia as possible access to pay television? What provision will the Prime Minister make, in fact what provision will the Labor Party make, to those 10 per cent of households, including those located in Hobart, Darwin and Cairns, unable to access the high performance beam and therefore rendered incapable of receiving pay television?

The Labor Party is clearly in a mess over this pay television debate. The Ministers involved have not handled it well, in fact they have been appalling, and the editorials confirm that comment. The Labor Party has forgotten rural Australians and regional Australians in this pay TV debate. Where regional and rural Australia counts, I challenge the Prime Minister on this issue to either put up or shut up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today relates to the hypocritical attitude of the Opposition in relation to the Government's proposal to treat shares differently as from September 1993 in calculating eligibility for pension purposes. This morning the shadow social security Minister, the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), shed crocodile tears for social security recipients. He introduced a private member's Bill relating to the proposed treatment of shares and later moved a motion with respect to certain matters relating to the taxation system and the social security system.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition originally supported the Bill when it was passed some time last year in both Houses. During the election campaign it said that, if elected to government, it would review it. Now, having lost the election, having been rejected by the Australian people, it seeks to find favour with those who will be affected by these new measures by playing politics with the issue. Those opposite know that in opposition they can say and do whatever they like. They do not have any responsibility to anyone but themselves, and what they are doing is spreading fear and panic amongst the pensioner community for the purpose of scoring cheap political points. It is easy for the honourable member for Berowra to stand at the dispatch box and with righteous indignation criticise the Government for its actions in this area. But would Opposition members have changed their minds on this issue had they found themselves in government after 13 March? Of course they would not have. There is no question about that.
I turn to an article by Christine Wallace in the Australian Financial Review a couple of days ago. It is headed, `Opposition pension Bill at odds with tough fiscal line'. She says:

Inconsistencies have begun to emerge in the fiscal purity of the Hewson Opposition which, while taking a hard line on cutting government spending to fix the Budget deficit, is pushing for a change to policy that could put spending up. The first private member's Bill introduced into the Senate by the Opposition has potential extra spending implications of up to $60 million a year.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to say:

The move is at odds with the tough fiscal line coming from Opposition economic spokesmen, who have repeatedly criticised the Keating Government's $16 billion 1992-93 Budget deficit, urging Labor to cut spending to repair the deficit.

The Opposition parties made it clear in Fightback that they would cut $1 billion from the social security budget. I put it to the House that there is no way that they would have changed these rules, which will save up to some $80 million in one year for an initial setting-up administrative cost of some $350,000. But what do they do? They play politics with the issue and as a result spread fear among our pensioner community as to what is going to happen, or what they consider is going to happen.

PARA.TAB: They join some financial planners who are making an issue in the pensioner community of the same issue, for obvious reasons. I quote from a good article from the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation newsletter, Action Network of May, 1993. It is by Gerard Thomas, who is their policy officer, and it is headed `Changes cause panic'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The share issue has received an unprecedented amount of publicity, causing anxiety around the country, even though it only affected less than five per cent of the total pensioner population.
Commenting on the publicity the issue has received in the popular press, Mr Thomas said:

Industry groups, investment and retirement advisers have been lobbying heavily against the changes. This makes one suspicious and wary about the motives of these people who have a vested interest in maintaining the status quo.
Cautioning pensioners against making panic decisions to dispose of their shares, he urged them to receive financial advice before acting.

PARA.TAB: Here is somebody who actually writes for the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation saying, `Do not be too concerned about it, because the fact is that you may not even be affected'. The reason that we are doing this is that it is simply another device to circumvent the income test provisions of the Social Security Act. The campaign being waged by the Opposition is similar to that waged when the assets test rules were introduced at some time in the early part of the Hawke-Keating governments, and is the same sort of campaign that was later initiated as a result of the deeming proposals.

The reality is that, once they were understood, they were accepted. In the great majority of cases, people were not adversely affected. In the case of the deeming rules, not only were thousands of people not affected adversely, but they in fact ended up with more disposable income than they themselves were aware that they could have. Indeed, over the last couple of weeks, since there has been a lot of publicity about this new treatment of shares, I have received a number of phone calls at my office from pensioners who have been understandably concerned about some of the things said in the publicity. In every case except one, I think, they were not going to be affected.

In terms of managed investments, this is simply extending what we had done with respect to other types of shares, managed investments and that sort of thing. The policy was introduced in 1988, because many investors were using exempt capital growth to obtain good returns on their investments while avoiding the income test. Rather than use those returns to provide for their income needs in retirement, they were able to draw on the age pension to a greater extent than other people who received their returns in other forms, and were able to retain and increase their capital assets. This was clearly unfair. The change in the treatment of shares extends these rules, making the income test even fairer. There is no reason why people who invest directly in the share market should be treated differently from those who invest indirectly through equity-linked managed investments such as equity trusts.

The Government would prefer not to have to take these measures, but sometimes tough decisions have to be made, and as a Government we have a responsibility to ensure that every dollar of the welfare budget is properly targeted. There is no bottomless well of money available to the Government. This measure is not about being unfair. It is not about discriminatory treatment of pensioners who happen to hold shares. What it is about is fairness and consistency in the way that we treat such investments. It is about equity; it is about proper targeting; it is about ensuring that the social security system is used as a needs based system—as a safety net. It is not about being used as a means of supplementing the incomes of people who can, if forced to do so, provide for their own income support by utilising their investments better.

We have in fact isolated some instances where there are pensioners with large shareholdings, some of them in excess of $100,000, who are drawing the full pension. Is it fair to the other 97 per cent of pensioners who will not be affected by this treatment? Is it fair to those, for instance, who have equity trusts or property trusts or insurance bonds or friendly society bonds, who are presently the subject of treatment similar to that proposed for shares? These measures are part of an ongoing commitment by this Government to treat investments more consistently and to improve the equity in the system and remove opportunities to circumvent the income test.

We can come back all the time to the bottom line of this whole argument—the social security system is a needs based system and is there as a safety net. Pensioners should not be fearful of these changes. They should see their financial advisers or, better still, make an appointment to see the financial information service for pensioners, now called the Financial Information Service. It is free and I urge them to take up this opportunity. In many cases they may not even be affected. In other cases, alternative investments may be advisable to ensure that more income is generated from their investments. In many cases, not only will the Australian taxpayer be the winner but also the investors themselves.

Fringe benefits, as I heard you say in a speech this morning, Mr Deputy Speaker, have been extended and some 50 per cent of the pensioners who will be affected by the new share treatment will be the beneficiaries of that. At the moment we are in negotiation with the States. Some of the State governments, such as the Kennett Government and the New South Wales Liberal Government, are making it a little bit tougher for us. What they are about is kicking the pensioners. They are about kicking the people in their own States, and it is a bit harder for us to get them to come on line to extend those fringe benefits that are not ones provided by the Commonwealth.

I urge people in the pensioner community not to be conned by all these things that they are reading. Let them go and see the Financial Information Service, which is a free service of the Department of Social Security. They should have a look at these things first and remember that the social security system is a needs base system. It is a system of a safety net, and that is all it is. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As last week was National Marriage and Family Week, it is appropriate to reflect on some aspects of marriage and family in Australia today. I make these comments in the knowledge also that the United Nations has appointed 1994 as the International Year of the Family.

PARA.TAB: Although the number of marriages in Australia each year is continuing to increase—from fewer than 80,000 in 1960 to of the order of 115,000 this year—the crude marriage rate has declined and, with the exception of females aged 25 to 29 years, first marriage rates have declined sharply. This decline partially reflects a trend in Australia toward marrying later.

There is also a return to the pre-World War II proportions of men and women who will never marry. In 1934, 18 per cent of women turning 35 had not married, but this figure fell to five per cent by 1972. The proportion is expected to increase to about 20 per cent by the end of this decade.

Throughout the 1960s the divorce rate rose to reach four per 1,000 married women, but climbed sharply to 19 per 1,000 in 1976 following the introduction of the Family Law Act. By 1979 the rate had fallen to 11 divorces per 1,000 married females and has since remained at about that level.

Over the 20 years there has been a marked change in the pattern of divorces with respect to the duration of marriage. Prior to 1976, about 10 per cent of divorces dissolved marriages of less than five years duration and about 25 per cent dissolved marriages of 20 years or longer. Since then the pattern has changed, with around 20 per cent of divorces occurring to marriages of less than five years duration. Throughout the 1980s, the median duration of marriage has been a little over 10 years. Indeed, 50 per cent of all separations occur within the first seven years of the wedding.

Each year, more than 40,000 marriages in Australia are dissolved. In 1991, the number of divorces represented some 40 per cent of the total number of weddings in Australia that year. It is estimated that in 1990 some 55 per cent of the divorces involved one or more children, that is, some 45,000 children. Since 1975, some 700,000 Australian children have been deprived of the care of one parent for some part of their lives. By the end of the decade, this figure will have reached over one million Australian children.

Prior to the major increase in divorce, the incidence of remarriage was relatively low. In 1971 fewer than 14 per cent of marriages involved remarriage for one or both partners. By 1981, however, this had risen to 32 per cent and it has remained at that level ever since. However, the separation and divorce rate for remarriages is higher, unfortunately, than for first marriages.

These changes are also reflected in the composition of Australian households. Despite claims to the contrary, family households remain the popular norm for Australians. There were 4.2 million families in Australia at the time of the 1986 census. The great majority, 86 per cent, were couple families, 6 per cent of which were de facto couples. Just over half of all couple families had dependent children and, of these, approximately 90 per cent had children aged 14 years or under. The number of one-parent families increased sharply between 1976 and 1981 and more slowly between 1981 and 1986. The slowing of the rate reflects the stabilisation of the divorce rate since the early 1970s. Almost two-thirds of lone parents were either divorced or separated and only about 20 per cent had never married. In 1991, 87 per cent of lone parents were women.

Having said this, I point out that the traditional family of mother, father and at least one child is still the Australian norm. At the time of the census, 75 per cent of households were family households. We can see, when it is looked at from another perspective, that 81 per cent of dependent children lived with married parents in 1986; 12 per cent with a sole parent; 4.7 with a step-parent and 1.7 per cent with parents in a de facto relationship.

This reflection on the changes which have occurred in family life in Australia leads me to some remarks about the provision of marriage education in Australia. The question arises as to what marriage education is, because education about marriage is often confused with marriage counselling. Unlike counselling, which is directed at particular difficulties encountered in a relationship, marriage education is a preventative process to give couples the skills to assist them in dealing with the potential problems which arise in family situations—problems, as I have pointed out, which frequently result in the high levels of marriage breakdown in Australia.

Since 1987-88 the two national peak organisations—namely, the Australian Association for Marriage Education and the Catholic Society for Marriage Education—encouraged by the family services section of the Attorney-General's Department, have worked to develop and expand the provision of marriage education in Australia. This work was largely encouraged by the then head of the Family Services Section back in 1987-88, Mr John Dickie, whose foresight in encouraging the two national organisations ought to be recorded.

There were a number of questions and matters which arose at that time for consideration which subsequent developments show as a pattern which has developed. It was thought at the time that marriage education could provide both an increased quality of relationship and also a preventative strategy against divorce, but there was little hard evidence in support of that proposition. However, if the proposition could be supported by research, then there was a clear need for the development of high standards and appropriate training for marriage education in Australia. Given the substantiation of the argument, a case for increased funding for marriage education was clear.

This proposal led to a number of strategies which have been developed by the national organisations with the encouragement of the department over the past four or five years. The first was the appointment of a national trainer to enhance the standard and performance of marriage educators throughout Australia. The unfortunate aspect with regard to marriage education is that each year only some 10 to 12 per cent of couples marrying in Australia undergo any form of preventative education before their wedding. The appointment of the national trainer has led to an improvement in the training and standard of marriage educators around Australia.

The second part of the strategy was to carry out some research into the effectiveness of marriage education. That research was concluded last year and published in the report, Love, sex and waterskiing—`love, sex and waterskiing' being the description that one of the participants in the survey provided when asked about his idea of marriage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at the one time.

—Not at the one time, as my learned colleague points out. But this is a serious study and one which deserves further consideration and further research. It showed, for example, that 83 per cent of couples reported learning new skills as a result of attending a program; 42 per cent of couples said their ideas about marriage had changed a great deal; a third of couples said their program had raised new issues for themselves; five per cent of couples—this is an important statistic—either cancelled or postponed their wedding after attending a program; 91 per cent of couples reported after attending a program that they would seek professional help if problems arose in their marriage; and nearly 80 per cent of couples rated their program as good or excellent. So this report substantiated the proposition which had been advanced five or six years ago in showing that there is evidence to support the belief that marriage education is indeed an important preventive strategy.

PARA.TAB: Since then, with the encouragement, again, of the department, the Australian Association for Marriage Education has undertaken a pilot publicity program for marriage education under the title `How long before your marriage breaks down?', for which I have a poster. This program, which is being conducted in central Victoria at the present time on radio and television and in the press, will be an important indication as to whether or not publicity can raise that figure of 10 per cent of couples attending the programs.

In conclusion, the two peak bodies, AAME and CSME, working in conjunction with the department, ought to be congratulated and encouraged for what they have achieved over the past few years, and that model of cooperation by all the agencies in the field, through AAME and CSME, is one which no doubt stands as an example for the provision of other services in Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a grievance I wish to present to this House on behalf of a number of constituents who reside in the Federal electorate of McEwen. It concerns the operations of Vic Roads and its management and control of entrepreneurial activities which occur adjacent to the Hume Freeway and other roads.

PARA.TAB: Vic Roads has the total control and management of the freeway system of Victoria, which I might add is funded by this Government. It is fair to say that all of us on this side of the House are very proud of the achievements we have made in putting a decent road network nationally throughout Australia. In fact, for the first time in our history, we now have a sealed road which totally circumscribes this great country of ours—a great Labor achievement, I might add.

So far as Vic Roads is concerned, the Hume Freeway, which runs right through the centre of the electorate of McEwen, is under its total control and management. As one would expect, adjacent to the freeway there are people who run businesses of various kinds who are anxious to profit from the two million-odd vehicles a year which travel from Melbourne to the junction of the Goulburn Valley Highway, where the road then goes up through to the Tocumwal and the Newell freeways. Those two million vehicles, of course, are a major source of potential profit for people who reside adjacent to that freeway.

Unfortunately, Vic Roads takes the view that no-one can have access to that freeway—no-one—except those persons who, through what means I do not know, manage to enter into arrangements with Vic Roads and get a profit back to Vic Roads as a result. As an example, since the freeway system has been built on the Hume—it is almost finished to Wodonga and the border—there is only one service centre presently on that freeway between Melbourne and Albury-Wodonga, and that is at Glenrowan. It is a most garish, monstrous sort of a structure, I might add, with great neon lights and signs. That was done with Vic Roads by entering into an agreement where it takes a fat share of the profit out of it.

Many years before that was built and Vic Roads allowed that to happen, a gentleman called Mr Rick Hill, who lives at Seymour—in fact, he still owns a drive-in theatre adjacent to the new freeway—applied for and got permission through the various planning schemes of the Victorian Government to build a truck stop. He has all of the necessary planning permits, has held them for over eight years—they keep getting extended every couple of years—and all he needs is permission from Vic Roads to access the Hume Freeway, to allow trucks to enter and exit from the freeway onto his proposed development.
