He has the funding, he has the planning permits, he has support—truck people say it is a very good idea—yet consistently now for over eight years Vic Roads has refused him the right to enter or exit the Hume Freeway.

There are other examples of this strange monopoly and anti-entrepreneurial attitude Vic Roads has to its management of the freeway system—a system which we fund and over which we have little management control. Another family, the Plunkett family, just north of Seymour near Avenel, has a vineyard and a delicatessen and restaurant facility adjacent to the freeway. Some months ago the family was putting up signs—not big, garish signs but reasonably sized ones—on the freeway to tell people as they drove along that the facility was there, that they could pop in and buy wonderful Victorian products like pickles and homemade local products, and that there was a vineyard. It produces a very nice chardonnay, and if honourable members are driving past I suggest they pop in and buy a bottle—we all know Victorian wines are great, particularly in the McEwen area.

But then Vic Roads came along demanding that the signs be removed and threatening the Plunketts with prosecution. They are now limited to a smallish sign on their site itself. If travellers are whistling past at 110 kilometres per hour, which, thank God, is now the permissible speed on the freeway—one of the few things the Kennett Government has done that I can agree with—they are past the place before they see the sign.

I find this action an absolute madness. We are trying to encourage people to put dollars into profitable businesses, particularly in rural and provincial areas of Victoria and asking people to have a go, yet one of the major authorities in the State of Victoria, Vic Roads, is doing everything possible to prevent people from accessing two million motor vehicles and their occupants each year.

I find its action illogical and what worries me even more is that one must have some suspicion as to why this is so. Whilst I have no evidence and whilst I am always careful in this House not to use the privileges I have to raise allegations which I cannot substantiate personally, there is a substantial body of opinion in Victoria, among people such as those I have spoken of, that one needs to have a means of encouraging certain people, if I can put it that way, in order to get Vic Roads to do anything, and that concerns me.

It concerns me, firstly, that people are being denied their right to access a public highway; secondly, that Vic Roads will not communicate or talk to people; thirdly, that there are suggestions about it which have been on several programs. I think there was a gentleman from Werribee who publicly said that Vic Roads had given a right to Shell Australia to have sole access to the Princes Highway between Melbourne and Geelong, and yet it denies access to small firms and small entrepreneurs to get access to that freeway.

It concerns me that we do not know. As a candidate, and in the last three years before I came back to this place, I have tried to find out what is going on with Vic Roads; I have tried to find out why people cannot access the freeway. I was supporting Rick Hill even when I was in this place before 1990, and I still cannot get satisfactory reasons from Vic Roads as to why he cannot have access to the Hume freeway.

It is time that this Government, my Government, actually made some inquiries and demanded from Vic Roads why roads funded by us but controlled by Vic Roads are operated in a way which denies reasonable people access to the vehicular traffic which uses them. Even more, I would suggest to this House that the actions of Vic Roads are uncompetitive and probably in breach of the Trade Practices Act. If Vic Roads is going to be the only authority that can say who gets what use out of the vehicular traffic using the freeways, and if it gets a hand in the till and a share of the cake under a joint venture agreement—and only big business is getting the opportunity to do that with Vic Roads—it seems to me that it is in breach of the Trade Practices Act and that it is time there was a major inquiry into this matter. It should be an inquiry which demonstrates to people that we care and through which we actually find out how these statutory authorities operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the Queensland Parliament Treasurer de Lacy attacked me personally following Courier-Mail reports of my speech here on Monday regarding Japanese organised crime figures gambling in Australian casinos. If he wants evidence of this, he does not need to demand it from me. He should ask the Queensland Police Force's Neil Comrie, who, as Queensland's Assistant Police Commissioner for Task Force, which covers intelligence gathering, was quoted in a Gold Coast Bulletin's news story last year as follows:

PARA.TAB: There have been recent instances of Yakuza suspects arriving in Queensland with large amounts of money, and we cannot determine the source of that money . . . .
We are convinced the Yakuza is not coming to the Gold Coast just to gamble in the casinos, although several have been seen doing that in recent months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a matter of considerable importance not only to the people of my electorate of Paterson who live in the Nelson Bay area, but indeed to all Australians. It concerns the future of Point Stephens lighthouse, which is one of a number on the New South Wales coast that are currently owned by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. Changes in the trading patterns of commercial shipping and changes in technology mean that these lights are no longer required by AMSA's navigational aids network.

PARA.TAB: I understand that AMSA has offered the lighthouse and its immediate surrounds to the New South Wales Government. Apparently, discussions are continuing between AMSA and the New South Wales Maritime Services Board on the future operation of the Point Stephens light.

I would point out that the lighthouse and lightkeepers quarters at Point Stephens are listed on the Australian Heritage Commission's register of the National Estate. As such, they are covered by Commonwealth legislation for their protection and preservation. It is vital that, if this property is to be disposed of, the heritage and conservation values of the Port Stephens lighthouse are recognised.

There is very strong local interest in the future of this lighthouse site. I urge the New South Wales Government to take the opportunity to take over this property, not only on behalf of the people of Nelson Bay, but to ensure its proper preservation for the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with over 15,000 registered unemployed in my electorate of Stirling, it is with absolute amazement that I note recent comments from the President of the ACTU, Mr Martin Ferguson, about Australia's unemployment levels. Mr Ferguson has warned that long-term unemployment could reach 500,000. Surprise, surprise! One must ask: has anything changed in the last eight weeks which would suggest this, or did Mr Ferguson realise this fact before the election but keep quiet so that he would not let his mates opposite down by spilling the beans on the truth of their pathetic record?

PARA.TAB: The coalition warned repeatedly before the last election that long-term unemployment was a crisis to be reckoned with. Our policies were aimed at addressing this very severe problem. It is only unfortunate that the power-hungry opportunists opposite saw fit to misrepresent us and our policies simply to buy votes.

It is history now that the Labor Party was elected without any policies. It is still bereft of any idea whatsoever of how to deal with this national tragedy. The Labor Party is now considering higher taxes and new taxes to pay for its ineptitude. Jobs are not created by increasing taxes. People need an incentive to work, and any increase in taxes will only destroy any incentive we have left.

It is high time the Government accepted some responsibility for the one million Australians it has thrown on the scrap heap. It must cut government spending; it must encourage enterprise bargaining; it must reform our tax system; and, finally, it must make decisions for all Australians and not just the ACTU and the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw attention to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning concerning yet another member of the judiciary who shows that he is totally out of touch with the views of the community and particularly those of women. In this case, a 17-year-old girl was raped after being punched and was later stabbed, and this judge gave the perpetrator a lenient sentence because the woman was possibly comatose at the time. It really is about time that the judiciary were aware that for women rape is one of the greatest violations that they can ever experience.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on his statement on women to re-educate the judges, something, I am afraid, that some members on the other side, if the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), is to be believed, do not agree with. We re-educate the police and other community workers in Aboriginal culture, in domestic violence and other things that they need to know about, but the judges, it seems, are exempt. The Opposition spokesman says that they are left to re-educate themselves. I do not agree with him. In fact, I endorse Mike Seccombe of the Sydney Morning Herald, who would like to award him the Guthrie Featherstone award for judicio-political pomposity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the important issue of small businesses in rural communities and the serious conditions that they are experiencing at the moment. I have received correspondence from a constituent in my electorate who wrote to me to ask me to take up the fight on behalf of businesses in those rural areas. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: As a manager of an engineering business in a small country town we are very alarmed at the fact that we are going backwards. We are not alone in our plight, rather, we are like most small businesses in rural areas. We rely almost entirely on the farming community for our livelihood and as they are hurting badly, so are we. We are faced in many situations where the work must be done to keep the equipment going and often we do the work knowing we are going to wait a long time to ever get paid . . .

The serious aspect that he raises is the fact that many farmers are finding it very difficult to maintain their equipment in a safe, working condition. This is a serious matter because, as he wrote, 90 per cent of accidents involving farming equipment are due to poor or in some cases non-existent repairs and maintenance. My correspondent continued:
. . . we support the farmers all the way in their push for assistance in the form of drought relief or interest subsidy . . .

He wrote, however, that the small business people believe that there should be some package of assistance available to small business in rural communities. Regrettably, the Minister for small business—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In my inaugural speech just three days ago, I made specific mention of the quality primary produce that is a developing industry within my electorate. I talked about the importance of trade between Tasmania and the South-East Asian region and said that, as the member for Franklin, I have a responsibility to facilitate that trade.

PARA.TAB: Tasmanians have already welcomed those comments. The media have latched onto my commitment, and so too has primary industry in my electorate. I have been contacted by business leaders in the seafood industry and the apple and pear industry, who are extremely supportive of these moves.

I am aware that I must act upon these commitments as soon as possible. Today I have received statistical information about the people who live in my electorate which shows that 37 per cent of the population in Franklin is earning less than $15,000 a year. This is a very sorry state and it is incumbent upon me to work hard to rectify this situation.

I have already met with a representative from the ABC and discussed the possibility of advertising Tasmanian produce through the ABC's new broadcasting service into the Asia-Pacific region. Obviously, we can produce all the fantastic product we like but, if buyers in the Asia-Pacific region do not know about it, industry will not move forward. I will facilitate a meeting between business groups and the ABC with a view to advertising in that region.

Secondly, I have been in contact with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Sherry, to arrange a visit to the Huon region by the parliamentary standing committee on horticulture. This committee will be able to provide much needed information and contact that should provide further opportunities for the industry. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I presented a petition signed by 513,000 Australians. It is almost certainly the largest petition ever presented to this Parliament. It is not good enough for such a petition to receive the usual fate of a passing mention by the Clerk and then disappear into archives. There should be a change in the practice of the House so that major petitions have to receive a substantial response, a formal response from the Government which allows for a full debate.

PARA.TAB: The petition calls on the Government to provide tax credits or rebates to encourage people to take out private health insurance. The petitioners consider that this will provide equal access to quality health care for all Australians. The petition raises a fundamental issue in respect of Australia's health system and, irrespective of any honourable member's views, over half a million constituents should not be ignored. They have petitioned this Parliament and they should receive a clear and unambiguous response setting out when the Government will implement their wishes or, alternatively, giving the reasons why such a policy is not in the interest of the nation.
The public has a right to put issues on the agenda of its own parliament. To ignore a major petition of this size, making only a token response, is an arrogant insult and a denial of democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on two separate and distinct but welcome developments today. Firstly, I welcome the decision of the Federal Court sitting in Perth today in the case of Irving v Commonwealth. The Federal Court upheld the previous immigration Minister's decision to refuse Irving entry to Australia. I welcome it because it is consistent with the view that we should do everything we can to avoid racism and incitement to racial disharmony and particularly, in this case, anti-semitic activity.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I welcome the release of two new Industry Commission reports which reflect the positive embrace of the new development role of the Industry Commission given by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in May last year. In that statement the Treasurer said that the Government:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will allow the Commission to extend its vision in such a way that it can make a positive contribution to industry development in a low tariff environment.
I agree with the comment in the Australian Financial Review today that this development:
. . . reflects the Treasurer's demand that the commission concentrate on industry development rather than the identification of impediments to performance.
In my first speech I said I agreed with intervention in the economy to support Australian industry. This gives the Government scope to do precisely that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this afternoon we heard a pathetic defence by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) of the Government's decision to include unrealised capital gain on shares in the pension income test. The Parliamentary Secretary would do himself more credit if, instead of trying to justify this decision, he admitted that it had been made because the Government was out of money and had decided to take it out on pensioners. It is just impossible to regard this new measure as being fair. What is fair about including shares in this test but not the capital gain on other assets? What is fair about the Government's decision to introduce deeming provisions to maximise income for pensioners when at the same time it now moves to eliminate one of the areas where pensioners can increase their income and therefore reduce their dependency on the social security system?

PARA.TAB: Surely this country ought to be encouraging people to look after their own needs. It ought to be rewarding those who put aside for their own retirement, and give them an opportunity to live in dignity on the benefits of their own labours. Instead, this Government prefers to make people divest themselves of their assets and then be totally dependent upon the social security system, the taxpayers of Australia, for the rest of their lives. That is an illogical policy and the Government ought to realise the benefits of the private member's Bill proposed on this side of the House and give it wholehearted support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today as a member of Pricewatch in Queensland to appeal for more community volunteers to join this very important organisation. Pricewatch is a monthly survey of 36 basic shopping basket items carried out by volunteer shoppers around the State. It takes on the role of a consumer watchdog where consumers can participate in price surveillance to promote healthy competition amongst supermarkets. Our role is to keep the supermarket chains honest, particularly now as we move out of a recession, because the temptation for the supermarkets will be to profit take and they will do that at the expense of consumers.

PARA.TAB: In the electorate of Lilley, more than a dozen supermarkets are regularly surveyed by a team of volunteers who give their time to record prices. This price surveillance is very important because it brings the community much closer to the Government through a joint exercise. It puts price control on the public agenda because it allows low income people to express their concerns. It will also save them money. It makes consumers aware of the large discrepancies in prices throughout the State and encourages consumers to shop around. Usually, country people pay a lot more for their basic items. Times are tough enough for these people, and they certainly do not need this extra cost. That is why they should shop around. That is why Pricewatch is invaluable, and I appeal for more volunteers to come and join this worthy organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the High Court sent me packing I had been asking honourable members on both sides of the House why they were so addicted to free trade policies and a fictitious level playing field. In this, the 37th, Parliament it seems this addiction is still with us. Many members of the Austrlaian Labor Party continue to take solace in the fact that their tariff policy is marginally better than the Opposition's. The fact that imports have surged as a result of tariff cuts and the abolition of quotas is ignored.

PARA.TAB: Today's unemployment figures reveal that there are fewer people employed than there were last month. Abolishing the oath of allegiance to the Queen will not solve these serious economic problems. The tragic fire in a Bangkok sweatshop should remind honourable members of the exploitative conditions under which many imported goods are made. A fair dinkum industry policy would extend the definition of dumping to include goods made under such exploitative conditions. Under the industrial relations policies of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), many Australian workers could well end up in the same boat.

The recently concluded Spindler parliamentary inquiry into tariffs was unequivocal in recommending import management, the resumption of quotas, a pause in tariff cuts, and the adoption of an interventionist strategic industry policy. In the past two weeks honourable members on both sides of the House have supported policies—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.
—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training explain why 100,000 people have given up looking for work in April?

—Members of the Liberal Party have the hide to come into this place discussing unemployment. They ran in the last election campaign on the proposition that they were going to abolish the CES. The CES is doing a fine job in placing very large numbers of Australians in work—some 460,000 of them last year. Tell me what sorts of numbers would give up looking for work when the body which put 460,000 of them in work last year was abolished.

PARA.TAB: Three months before the last election, members of the Opposition came into this place in a state of total policy confusion. They retracted, but everybody at the back of his mind knew exactly what the Opposition had in mind—a policy which was designed to throw people off the dole after nine months out of work, not by putting them back in work but by putting them under impossible tests. The Liberal Party has the hide to adopt these policies and to come in here—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I draw your attention to standing orders 142 and 145—the first, of course, requiring that a question be put to the Minister on matters for which he is responsible; the second requiring that the answer be relevant to the question. I draw your attention to the definition of relevance in the Macquarie Dictionary which says, `Bearing upon or connected with the matter in hand'.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat!
—I wish to make my point of order, Mr Speaker.
—You have made your point of order. There is no need to debate it.
—No I have not, I have only drawn your attention to the fact—
—You will resume your seat!
—I will resume it, sir, but now I will—
—You will resume your seat!
—Now I will stand on another point of order.
—Do you have another point of order?
—I have another point of order: the Minister had put to him a very succinct question on a very serious matter of unemployment, and he is playing politics with it.
—The Minister was asked a question about unemployment. He will answer the question on unemployment.

—I thought my answer was pretty relevant to the question that was put to me. It is no irrelevancy to deal in the policy environment in which we are dealing with the issue of unemployment to discuss the various options. The honourable gentleman comes to the dispatch box asking me questions on the basis of policies that he thinks are going to deal with the problem, and they will not.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that nobody can take any joy in unemployment figures at the levels and dimensions that we have in this society. We are not Robinson Crusoe in that regard. It is a problem that is confronting all countries with which we like to compare ourselves. The fact of the matter is that we are doing better than most in dealing with it. The Government at least has in place policies which will make a substantial inroad, be a substantial alleviation of unemployment and assist those who are experiencing unemployment back into the work force.

I have had occasion before in Question Time in this place to discuss some of the things that we are doing, and having in mind to do, for the long-term unemployed. That is a problem that is going to be with us for some very considerable time. It was a problem that was with us for some very considerable time after the recession in 1982-83. This will be no different.

The last set of statistics—those that are received from the Department of Social Security—bear out what I had to say the other week: slowly, gradually, the overall level of unemployment is coming down. But at the same time the level of long-term unemployed is rising, suggesting we have a developing, intractable problem in a portion of the labour market. Again, we are not Robinson Crusoe on that. It is a problem being experienced right through Europe and right through the United States. It will require very special attention to be able to deal with it, and the unemployed will get that attention from us. It will not be solved by abolishing the CES, by throwing people off the dole and by cutting back hugely labour market programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Finance advise the House what progress has been achieved regarding the sale of Qantas and Australian Airlines; what further steps are required to complete the sale; and what is the projected timetable for the completion?

—I am pleased to advise the honourable member for Watson that there has been considerable progress this financial year and, although Qantas will not be fully sold this financial year, the sale will be completed next financial year. The progress has involved a number of major features: firstly, the sale of Australian Airlines to Qantas in September for $400 million. That was decided following the very strongly held view of a number of the bidders that there were considerable economies and revenue enhancements possible if the two airlines were united. So the Government decided to put them together by way of a sale of Australian Airlines to Qantas and $400 million was paid for it.

PARA.TAB: Since then major steps have been taken to put the two airlines together in an integrated way, and that has most recently been announced as taking the form of Qantas operating its domestic flights increasingly as Qantas flights rather than Australian Airlines flights with new planes coming in Qantas livery for the domestic operations, the existing ones being repainted, using Qantas uniforms, Qantas flight designations, et cetera.

Secondly, there was recapitalisation of the combined airlines in February of this year and that has meant principally a debt to equity conversion of over $1 billion of government guaranteed debt which could not really be properly left in a privately owned enterprise. That reduced the debt to equity ratio from 84:16, which is very high, to a more commercially acceptable ratio of 70:30. It is projected that over the next few years that will come down to around 60:40.

Thirdly, there was completion of the trade sale of the combined airline in March of this year with 25 per cent of the equity being sold to British Airways for $665 million. Of course, British Airways is a major world airline which has been very successful since it was privatised in the mid-1980s. Its association with Qantas brings considerable additional strength to both airlines and should enhance Qantas's future prospects considerably.

Fourthly, there is the preparation for the float—or the public share offering, to give it its formal name—which will be one of the biggest floats in Australian corporate history, if not the biggest. Virtually all of the steps needed to be taken to proceed with the float have now been completed and this has involved principally a decision to sell up to 10 per cent of the equity in overseas markets, thus taking foreign ownership of Qantas up to the 35 per cent limit set by the Government and put into legislation passed by the Parliament last year.

There was a decision to provide for five per cent of the equity to go to an employee share ownership scheme so that the employees can have shares in the company, which would do much to enhance their incentive to perform. The appointment of lead managers for the domestic and international tranches of the sale has been made. There has also been the appointment of other financial and legal advisers, consultants, advertising agencies and providers of various other technical services required for the float. The contracts for all of these have been finalised or are now in the process of being finalised.

Two major factors remain to be done: firstly, the completion of the refinancing of about $1.3 billion of debt. That is subject to so-called change of ownership clauses. If the ownership is to change, then the debt has to be subject to some refinancing. In turn, that requires that Qantas have an international credit rating. That has almost been achieved and the rating should be available by the end of this month.

The second factor which needs to be decided is when we are actually going to go to the market. We are working towards the timing of the float being in October-November of this year or April-May of next year. We will be technically capable of going in October-November of this year, but whether we do so or not will depend on our assessment of what would be the most propitious timing. A decision to go in October-November would require a final decision to be made in the next couple of months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to reports in today's press that Westpac has revised its growth forecast for 1994 down to 3.5 per cent from 4.2 per cent. Given the Government has stated that four per cent growth is necessary to reduce unemployment, what impact will slower growth than expected have on the Government's assessment of the employment outlook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member knows that when he wants to ask for official predictions on growth rates in the economy he does not direct questions to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training but to the Treasurer or the Prime Minister. If he has not worked that out by now, then it is about time he did work that out in his tactics committee across the frontbench. We do require a level above the level of growth that we have at the moment to start to bring unemployment numbers down, which is no great revelation. That has been stated repeatedly by me, by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer at different times.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to draw any form of excess comfort at all from those figures. They are monthly figures and they bounce about. There is one noteworthy feature, and that is the underlying rate of unemployment. The underlying rate of employment has plateaued. The underlying rate of unemployment has started to come down steadily after a period of some months in which it had effectively plateaued. I do not want to overstate anything about that at all, but at least it is an indication that one of those statistics that is of a slightly more long-term nature is moving in the right direction—not at any sort of speed which we would be cheerful about but at least, for people looking at these figures and feeling excessively depressed, alarmed or cheerful about them, that is one point they can take on board.

Long-term predictions is not an area that anyone wants to get into with any exactitude and is certainly one apparently that anyone on the other side of the House does not wish to get into with any exactitude. I notice in an interview last year with Dr Hewson in the Weekend Australian on what he considered unemployment levels would be, the interviewer asked:

ANSWER.PARA: At what people in your first term do you think you'll start to make inroads into the unemployment rate?

I don't know where we will be. I'll be more than happy to give you the predictions when we get there . . . So OK you don't get any noticeable improvement in the first 12 months in the unemployment rate.
Of course, the unemployment rate has started to improve. The interviewer asked:
But are you prepared to countenance that you might actually see a rise in the unemployment rate in the first 12 months?
Well, I mean I'm happy to tell you that when I know.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the case of Graham Clark, a HMAS Voyager survivor and resident of Sandgate in the electorate of Lilley. Can the Attorney-General tell the House whether the Commonwealth will be seeking special leave to appeal to the High Court in the Clark case.

—Honourable members might recall that, I think on Monday, I was asked by the honourable member for Groom about the HMAS Voyager cases. At that time I indicated that negotiations were going on with a view to the Commonwealth and the solicitors for the HMAS Voyager claimants coming to a resolution of the matter by today where the matters would be mentioned again before the Victorian Supreme Court.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to be able to tell the honourable member that in relation to his constituent, Mr Clark, the Commonwealth has told the Supreme Court that we will not be seeking special leave to appeal. Mr Clark will be paid in accordance with earlier court decisions. In relation to the other HMAS Voyager claims, there are some 19 which the Commonwealth now regards as having been effectively decided by the decision in Clark.

The Clark decision was on the question of estoppel on a particular date where the Commonwealth changed tack in terms of defending these actions. All cases commenced prior to February 1986 will be regarded as settled. The Commonwealth will immediately enter into negotiations in relation to these claims with a view to settling them.

In relation to the other HMAS Voyager claims which the Commonwealth does not consider resolved by the decision in Clark, the Commonwealth will not admit liability. However, in accordance with instructions from the Attorney-General and following discussions of the Cabinet, the Commonwealth Government solicitors will enter into negotiations with the rest of the claimants with a view to reaching a settlement.

If those negotiations do not succeed, the next step will be a process of mediation. We are hopeful, and I think this is a hope shared by the solicitors for the claimants, that that process should see the remaining cases settled. I commend the honourable member for his strong representations in relation to Mr Clark, and of course other members, notably the honourable member for Groom, for their longstanding interest in these matters. It has been a long and difficult case but I do believe now we are at a stage where the Voyager claims can be reasonably settled to the satisfaction of both sides.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to recent changes to the wholesale sales tax system, and I ask: will he give a commitment not to broaden the base of the wholesale sales tax or to increase the rate of the sales tax?

—I mentioned to the honourable member for Mayo earlier that it is the job of the Opposition to speculate—in fact, that is about its only job. I leave him to speculate as much as he likes about whatever he likes.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What progress is being made in improving the exports of Australian wine? Who is responsible for that progress?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I know that he, like many other members in the House, takes a very keen interest in this industry. I am sure the wine industry would like me to convey to members of the House that it appreciates their continued support for the domestic consumption of the product. But it really is in the export dimension of this industry that we have seen enormous progress made. The fact of the matter is that now for every bottle of wine uncorked in this country there is more than another bottle uncorked overseas. Exports now are the equivalent of $280 million a year, which has been a 13-fold increase since 1985.

PARA.TAB: Against that background, I was reminded yesterday, when I spoke to the president of the Winemakers Federation that this industry seems to be doing about as well as my football team at the moment. As for the future, because this is really where the opportunity does present itself, the industry expects that exports will top $1 billion by the turn of this decade. That will require an investment in this country in excess of $1.2 billion in terms of plantings and equipment.

Essentially this has been achieved, and the continuing improvement will occur, against the background of a supportive government environment. But it is important to note that most of this performance goes to the credit of the industry itself because it has been prepared to concentrate upon quality, with an emphasis on marketing into particular countries. In particular, it is promoting the unique quality that this country has in terms of the clean green image associated with food and food-based products.

But it is government programs which the industry has had access to that have assisted the industry in this direction: the export market development grants scheme; the marketing skills program; the innovative agricultural marketing program; and the rural industries business extension services—all supportive of a pro-active export driven growth strategy for the industry. Recently the industry has been the recipient of the international trade enhancement scheme program, a $1.5 million extra payment, and it has also been very appreciative of the successful government efforts to open market access opportunities into Europe over the period of the growth strategy ahead of it. I am sure that, against that background, all honourable members will join with me in acknowledging the outstanding contribution that the wine industry has made to this country's export potential and wish it every success for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, we all hope wine exports continue to grow. I direct my question to the Minister for Communications. Is it not a fact that, in relation to pay TV, the primary footprint of the satellite will not cover most of regional Queensland, most of regional New South Wales, regional South Australia, regional Western Australia, and Tasmania, with there being no coverage at all of the Northern Territory, and that there is no obligation on the satellite licensees to purchase an additional national beam from Optus in order to give coverage to all of Australia, even those living near the Simpson Desert? Will the Minister explain to the House the exact difference between the high performance beam coverage and the national beam coverage?

—Mr Speaker, the Leader of the National Party continues to confuse the coverage of 90 per cent of Australians with the coverage of the beam across the landmass of Australia. To achieve economic viability, the important thing for pay television is to get maximum coverage of the Australian population. Pay television means that people now have the choice of a new television service, for which they will pay, and therefore there must be penetration of the maximum market. That is achieved by compressed digital technology off the satellite, which can be rebroadcast by other methodologies, and that is what will happen in other areas of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Today I was talking to someone in my department who indicated that in the city of Adelaide, for example—where about 4 or 5 repeaters are currently required for normal, free-to-air television—in excess of 20 repeaters would be needed for MDS. The people of Australia do not want a range of towers sticking up all over the place when they can get a very good service by satellite. It does not necessarily mean that MDS is required in those other areas. There are hybrid systems that will give the maximum number of people in Australia pay television, for which they will only pay if they think the service is sufficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Firstly, can the Minister inform the House what factors have contributed to export success for Australian high technology companies? Secondly, can the Minister give the House details of recent export success by a Perth-based company, QPSX Communications?

—I thank the honourable member for Perth for his question. Elaborately transformed manufactures, including telecommunications and information technology, are Australia's fastest growing export sector. The Bureau of Industry Economics has forecast that telecommunications and information industry exports will almost treble to $3 billion during the course of the current decade. The Perth-based company to which the honourable member referred, QPSX Communications Ltd—formed only six years ago as a joint venture between Telecom Australia, the University of Western Australia and a team of electronic engineers—has just sold communications technology to carriers in Britain, Germany and the United States which enable large or complex messages to be sent quickly and securely through public telecommunications systems. The company's exports as a percentage of its overall sales now totals some 50 per cent.

PARA.TAB: QPSX is the type of successful company highlighted by the McKinsey report on emerging exporters. The success of high technology firms, such as this one, depends on factors well beyond the comprehension of the Opposition's zero tariff—I should say `zero imagination'—policy. Central to the success of these companies is leadership.
Dr Hewson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I only have to raise the issue of leadership and, like a big fish, the Leader of the Opposition comes in. In terms of leadership, the Opposition still has its training wheels on.

PARA.TAB: Other issues relating to a company's ability to export successfully include: the pursuit of world class innovation based on research and development, supported through initiatives such as the R&D tax concession, grants and so on; partnerships with leading edge technology consumers—in this instance, Telecom Australia—which provide the credibility and international access so important to emerging exporters; and value. Cost is not the only factor. Value can also be created by marketing, design production, service and quality issues.

Unlike the Opposition, this Government believes in engaging with business. In our view, the business of government is not to put the Government out of business but rather—and I think the success of our emerging exporters shows we are right—to work with business. The honourable member for Goldstein, who is trying to interject, should take the advice of his father who, as quoted in this month's edition of Quadrant, indicated that the Opposition should engage in reading heroic poetry and leave policy formulation for a couple of years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the Minister confirm that the Government's proposals for enterprise bargaining will allow non-union members to deal directly with their employers without union intervention?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I repeat today in the House what I have said publicly before, and that is that the range of measures necessary to encourage enterprise bargaining as the whole basis of our new system of industrial relations is something on which the Government will be consulting closely with industry, trade unions and the community at large during the winter recess with a view to introducing legislation later on this year. As part of that process, I have had the opportunity to meet with the ACTU and a number of unions, and with all sorts of employer organisations and I intend to continue to do so in the course of the next couple of months.

PARA.TAB: One of the questions that has been raised in those discussions is this issue of the non-union sector and the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act, particularly section 134, which of course involved union participation. I have indicated to those who have raised this question that in New South Wales, where there is a system in place which does not involve any union representation, there has not been a great success thus far in pursuing enterprise agreements. Nationally, we now have some 830 agreements covering 700,000 employees. In New South Wales, without unions, we have a handful of agreements covering some 6,800 employees. So I do not think the answer to enterprise bargaining is to say that it is being held up in any way by a failure on the part of the union movement or for representation from unions. Having said that, it is a question which we will be talking about and one which will be addressed in the legislation that I will be recommending to the Cabinet and introducing in this Parliament later on this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recent paper by Dr Steve Dowrick of the ANU? Does the Minister agree with Dr Dowrick that Australia is in danger of having a halfway industrial relations house?

—I thank the honourable member for Reid for his close and continuing interest in industrial relations. As the Government and the ACTU both agreed in accord mark 7, the primary means for future wage determination will be enterprise bargaining. Certainly, the Prime Minister once again emphasised that point in his speech on 21 April last in Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: As we have consistently and persistently made clear, the system of enterprise bargaining that we intend to create will be underpinned with an up-to-date safety net of relevant award provisions to guarantee its integrity and to make sure that those not so well placed in bargaining power are protected. Far from being a halfway house, the system that we are proposing will be the best of both worlds: a system that is tailored to Australia's needs as an open trading nation but also, of course, that is mindful to protect the industrially weak and the low paid.

Of course, that is quite unlike the Opposition's policies which were so emphatically rejected by the Australian population in March and were about making Australia a low pay, low skill country. That was the Opposition's approach, and it is in great contrast with ours which is about flexibility laterally—flexibility upward, not downward—and which involves cooperation and will lead to a highly skilled, high wage work force.

It is worth reminding the House that the policy pursued by the Opposition—and we have not heard too much about it since the election—would have taken Australia down the same path as Victoria, which has individual contracts. Let me tell the House what happened to someone in Victoria last week. An apprentice hairdresser was presented with an individual contract by his employer. It was a case of `take a $100 a week salary cut in a contract or take the sack'. That is the system that those opposite would have operating not only in Victoria but all around Australia. That is the reason why 600,000 people who were formerly under Victorian awards have applied to come under the federal provisions introduced by this Government in this Parliament in December last year.

Even the Opposition's former Minister for Industrial Relations, Ian Macphee, has described that Victorian system—the system of those opposite—as one that is utterly unsatisfactory in fulfilling the economic objectives of the workplace. He is not one of ours; he is one of theirs. What have we seen from the honourable member for Bennelong since the election? We have seen a bit about the flag, a bit about Anzac Day, a bit about the monarchy and a bit about Liberal Party preselections, but we have seen precious little about industrial relations; that is for sure. The only thing he has been prepared to say is that he will not preside over the emasculation of the coalition's industrial relations policy.

I conclude by saying that business needs to be more internationally competitive, and industrial relations is integral to that. That is why we have foreshadowed a new system of industrial relations; one that is aimed at speeding up enterprise bargaining. We have started that consultation and we intend to proceed with legislation later on this year. I say this to Dr Dowrick: I think his paper is a useful contribution, but I do not think it accurately reflects the system that we have in Australia. I do not think it accurately reflects the fact that we are moving from craft unions, and that we have an accord system operating in Australia. The Government's package will build upon our already unique system to give us one that even better serves Australia's needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the Minister to the questions I asked him on Tuesday concerning the rules laid down by the Government for direct funding to higher education institutions under the Higher Education Funding Act. I asked him to assure the House that payments made as a result of determinations between 30 November 1992 and 18 February 1993 were made according to those rules. The Minister informed the House that he would make appropriate inquiries and provide an answer to the questions raised. I ask the Minister whether he has made appropriate inquiries and, if so, whether he is in a position to answer the question.

—I ought to point out to the honourable gentleman and to the House that as far as the universities are concerned nobody has received any funds that they are not entitled to; nobody has received any funds that were not legislated under the Higher Education Funding Act in the course of last year; nobody has received any funds that were not publicly notified that they were going to receive in the material released publicly by the then Minister for Higher Education. So these efforts by the honourable gentleman to try to convey that something untoward has happened are a nonsense. All arrangements for the payment of these funds—as would automatically and sensibly be the case—operate under the delegation of the Minister for Higher Education and are effectively done by the Public Service, not by the Ministers. That is commonsense, and it is a practice that did not begin with us, did it? It is a practice that is longstanding as far as the parliamentary process and administrative processes are concerned.

PARA.TAB: There were some technical irregularities in the way in which the funds were paid. Those technical irregularities do require subsequent determinations and gazettal to fix them up. In the course of going through that there are a variety of practices in this regard that I believe my department needs to change. When I am totally satisfied that we have in place processes to ensure that that technical irregularity will not occur in the future I will be pleased to communicate with the honourable gentleman.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Will the Assistant Treasurer inform the House of the progress towards implementing the superannuation guarantee scheme? In particular, would he advise the House how employers will be aware of their obligations to their employees under the SGC legislation?

—I thank honourable members for the welcome. It is worth reminding the House that the superannuation guarantee scheme is about saving for Australia's future. It also means that in the future we will have a higher retirement income, allowing for a more dignified lifestyle. This is the first full year of the superannuation guarantee charge and many employers are making their contributions on a regular basis. Our concern is for those employers who, for one reason or another, may not be.

PARA.TAB: The Government is concerned that these employers do so before 14 August. To assist those employers to recognise their obligations the Australian Tax Office is undertaking a number of measures, the details of which I have with me, to make sure that they do. Amongst those is a mass media campaign using television and print media—and those television ads are running currently—specifically targeted advertising and trade journals and industry magazines. We are also conducting a direct mailing campaign to over 700,000 employers, which will allow those employers to check whether they have met their obligations.

There is also a special media strategy which has been developed to address employers from non-English speaking backgrounds. It includes advertisements in the press, the SBS English at work program, and briefings for ethnic media and accountants. The tax professionals will be provided with up-to-date information, and the Australian Tax Office is also continuing to operate its hotline service which has handled almost 180,000 calls since March 1992.

The SGC has benefits for Australia and Australians. For Australia it has a critical role in national savings; for Australians it will mean a better standard of living in retirement. For instance, for a person on average weekly earnings, the SGC will in time double the retirement income that person would have had if he or she had relied solely on an aged pension. In conclusion, this is a long-term visionary policy brought in by this Government. I note in contrast that the Opposition does not have a policy or even a spokesperson.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Does the Minister support the commitment given by the newly elected Chairman of the Government's Primary Industry and Resources Committee, the honourable member for Page, to overhaul the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service which he claims has no industry input, charges excessively and, given a proper shake-up of procedure, could save the north coast beef industry millions of dollars a year? If millions of dollars a year can be saved in just one area of Australia, will the Minister ensure that the same approach is adopted throughout Australia, so that the whole industry can benefit?

—I thank the Deputy Leader of the National Party for his question. I can inform the House that I am in accord with the chairman of my Caucus committee, not only on this issue but on many issues. He and I were great campaigners together in the last election. He held his seat by a magnificent result, and after the next election he will hold it by even more.

PARA.TAB: In relation to AQIS, the House may or may not be aware that in the portfolio reallocation I have taken specific responsibility for AQIS. In the past couple of years I have tended to receive all the criticisms concerning AQIS but have not, as such, had the direct responsibility for correcting it.

Further, I pay tribute to my ministerial colleague, the former Minister for Resources when he had carriage of this industry, for introducing some important cost saving measures. The difficulty is that, at the time those cost saving measures were being introduced, the government policy position to move to 100 per cent cost recovery, which that side of the House supports, was being implemented at the same time. So the savings that were being achieved in the industry were also being counter-affected by the increase in the movement to cost charging.

In the last election campaign my ministerial colleague made a commitment to finding something in the order of an additional $20 million in expenditure savings out of AQIS. I hope that we can improve upon that, and it is my intention to do what I can to ensure that not only do we get an efficient industry service but also that the integrity of our meat quality, both for exports and domestic consumption, is maintained. I happen to believe that if we can get the standards right we can see a lot more effective either contracting out or movement to quality assurance programs. In the discussions I have had with the board of management of the meatworks up in Casino with the honourable member for Page, we are very keen to work with industry to find means by which we can get its cost structure down.

The final point I would make is that, looking at the figures the other day, the contribution of the AQIS charge is roughly the equivalent of about two to 2 1/2 per cent of the cost impact in this industry, and I believe that whilst it is an important area on which to concentrate, because there is a transparency associated with AQIS's activities, there are more important areas of industry activity whereby we can get charges and costs down in the industry.

I might remind the House that I achieved that in the last term of government in relation to the cattle transaction levy whereby we took it down from $6.25 to $4. So we are committed to getting cost structures down in the industry. We will do it effectively in the future, and I hope that I am able to report to the House in relation to the success on AQIS in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. In light of the most recent death in custody in Queensland, can the Minister advise the House what progress has been achieved by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments in implementing their commitments in response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his question. As all honourable members would be aware, the honourable member is someone who has a very genuine commitment to issues of social justice, and particularly to social justice for indigenous Australians. As the Minister responsible for coordinating the Commonwealth whole of government response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, and indeed the national response to the royal commission, it has always been my view, and that of the Government, that that response must not be allowed to gather dust on the shelf.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will recall that the Commonwealth response endorsed 338 of 339 royal commission recommendations, and such was the calibre of those responses—endorsed by the ATSIC commissioners and endorsed by the Federal Cabinet—that they were also endorsed unanimously by this House in a resolution last year on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the 1967 referendum. Honourable members will also recall that that response to the royal commission focused on the law and justice issues which occupy some one-half to two-thirds of the royal commission recommendations, and subsequently looked to the underlying issues which go to the very heart of the disproportionate rate of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander imprisonment.

Honourable members will also recall that the Commonwealth commitment was very much one of social justice, and the amount of more than $400 million over a five-year period was a genuine manifestation of the Commonwealth's support for the royal commission recommendations.

Turning to the very heart of the honourable member's question, perhaps more important in the longer term than the Commonwealth, State and Territory responses to the royal commission is the detailed regime of accountability to put into practical effect those royal commission recommendations. I inform the honourable member for Moreton that, at the Commonwealth level, what the Commonwealth promised to do the Commonwealth is doing.

There will be an annual report to the Commonwealth Parliament as a result of work done by an interdepartmental committee which has been brought together by the Prime Minister's own department and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Because of the respect that we have for the institution of the Parliament, that report will be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and will of course be available for public scrutiny.

A further but critical part of that regime of accountability is the appointment of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. That commissioner, who is of course Mr Mick Dodson, will produce an annual report entitled State of the nation which will detail action by the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments to give effect to that royal commission response.

The honourable member asks me, as the federal Minister, to comment on the States and Territories and their progress in implementing the royal commission recommendations. I have to say to the honourable member that the jury is still out on the question of the progress that the States and Territories have made in that regard. As the Commonwealth Minister, I have no direct control over the reporting and monitoring arrangements of State and Territory governments. I can say that at the highest level of those governments there have been strong commitments to give effect to the royal commission recommendations. In the course of the State and Territory monitoring processes, which we hope will model those of the Commonwealth, we expect to see real progress in giving effect to the letter of those State and Territory responses.

In conclusion, I say this to the honourable member—and let me not mince words: the fact is that not only is this an important matter for both sides of the House and the public of Australia but also, in every sense of the word, it is an important matter for the international community. The fact is that the world is watching the progress that our nation makes in giving effect to those royal commission recommendations. I thank the honourable member for his question and I give a commitment to the House that, at the Commonwealth level, we will give full force and effect to the royal commission recommendations and we expect State and Territory governments to do no less.
