INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The disarray of the Government at a time when we are locked into high unemployment and many Australians are giving up hope of ever finding a job.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALKER.NAME: Dr HEWSON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —These two weeks of Parliament were supposed to be the final indignity of the Opposition. They were to be the Government's triumph and in fact they have turned out to be two weeks of turmoil. In just on two months since the Government won the election we have seen it fully exposed on a number of fronts.

PARA.TAB: The Government has been exposed by the facts as our economic circumstances have unfolded quite differently to the impression the Government created in the course of the election campaign. The Government has been exposed on policy where, in a number of areas, it has simply just picked up great slabs of our policy platform that we took to the last election. The generational change that was to take place on the front bench has totally exposed the inadequacy of the Government, and a number of people on the back bench have begun to speak out and expose the Government as well.

Let me begin by looking at the extent to which the Government has been exposed by the facts of our economic circumstances as they have unfolded in just the last couple of months. We should begin with today's unemployment data, which on face value with a fall in the measured unemployment rate might be taken as a welcome improvement, until we look behind the numbers and start to see the full magnitude of the unemployment crisis that has hit Australia in the course of the last few years.

Today's data for April show that something like 75,000 jobs were destroyed in one month and something like 100,000 Australians simply gave up looking for work. In circumstances of what is pretty much still a prolonged recession, at best bumping along the bottom of that recession, 100,000 Australians have decided that it is not worth trying to find a job and have left the labour force in the course of just one month.

When we combine this picture of one month with recent statements by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), that it is not inconceivable that the number of long-term unemployed in Australia, those who have been unemployed for more than a year, could actually rise above 400,000 towards 500,000 people in the course of the next few years, we start to understand the magnitude of our unemployment crisis.

We have also seen a very alarming jump today in youth unemployment, back to one in three of our young people who cannot find a job. In recent days we have seen some very disturbing data on the significantly smaller percentage of graduates this year who have been able to find a job compared with previous years under this Government. But the most disturbing feature of today is surely that 75,000 jobs were destroyed and that 100,000 Australians simply gave up in their search for work.

In recent days we also had data on the balance of payments, which shows the magnitude not only of our current account problem but also of our continually rising debt problem. We saw a balance of payments deficit figure in one month of over $2 billion—a staggering figure; a figure that nobody would have predicted two or three years ago could even have been remotely possible at this stage of the economic cycle.

When we look at the unemployment data and balance of payments data together, we get to see the full extent of the economic crisis that is bedevilling Australia at the present time. In simple terms, as the Government has admitted, we need more than three per cent growth, something approaching four per cent growth, to lower unemployment in a sustainable way. But on the other side, if we get three or four per cent growth, there is a very high probability of a balance of payments crisis. The Government has in fact got us caught in a pincer with nowhere to go. If it gets the growth up, high enough to start to make a dent on unemployment, this country will be hit with a balance of payments crisis, a blow-out in debt, and a further downgrading of our credit standing.

Of course, some of the economic forecasters in the private sector are now starting to reconsider their earlier assessments of Australia's growth potential. Most recently, yesterday Westpac lowered its growth forecasts for 1994, recognising that not only is the problem not being dealt with in Australia but also the world economy is still drifting, and in large part is still in recession. There are some alarming statistics and assessments now emerging in the United States. Many had pinned their hopes on the United States pulling the rest of the world out of this recession, but there is now recognition that growth numbers are being down scaled yet again. So we are still in a period of very flat activity, at best, in Australia. The national accounts for next quarter will be particularly interesting. We will see whether the so-called measured growth in this country is being sustained or whether it has faltered. On the basis of the anecdotal evidence we have seen in recent days, particularly in retail trade and the likely contribution from net exports, there is every possibility that our growth, as measured, has started to slow down and falter in the March quarter.

The Government has been exposed on a number of policy fronts. On industrial relations, we saw the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) at the table today trying to give a description of this Government's emerging concept of enterprise bargaining, which has an eerie similarity to the policy we took to the last election. In fact, in substantial part, it was a direct pinch. We saw the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) on television recently talking about health policy and raising the possibility of tax rebates for people to take out private health insurance; that has an eerie similarity to the policy we took to the last election.

Of course, where has the Government been most decidedly exposed? It has been on tax. If the Government had any mandate from the last election, it was that there should be no new taxes and no tax increases. At this stage, I have taken a count of what we have heard in recent days. We have heard of the possibility of death duties being reinstated, of wealth taxes, taxes on high income earners, the reintroduction of the interest withholding tax—better called a pensioner tax—and a broadening of the wholesale sales tax base to include services, and perhaps, in effect, being a GST. The Government will not call it a goods and services tax but, as my friend the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) keeps reminding me, it will be a giant sales tax. So the Government is working on its own GST.

There is also the possibility of energy taxes, given the balance of power in the Senate these days and the potentially high probability that it will be held by a couple of Greens. We have had the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) campaigning for years on the need to increase the Medicare levy. No new taxes or tax increases is the only mandate the Government has, and I assure those opposite that we will hound them on those tax increases every hour of every day until the next election. Whether the Government puts taxes up directly, or indirectly by forcing the States to do so, we are going to tag the Government with the lot of them.

A lot of other policy areas have been exposed in recent days, but perhaps the most notable has been communications policy—or should I say a total lack of communications policy. The communications policy is a living, breathing document. Every time we turn around, it takes on a different form. In questioning the Ministers in this House and in the other place in the course of the last two weeks, we have seen that they have absolutely no capacity to explain or defend the shambles which has emerged, particularly in relation to pay TV.

As we turn to the exposure of the individuals concerned, this place has become a total farce. The concept of ministerial responsibility under this Government has been totally jettisoned. There is no understanding of what a Minister's role is. There is no acceptance that a Minister carries responsibility for his or her actions, even though a Minister is actually required to sign off under an Act, and in the case of pay TV the Minister did so.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a damning statement the other day when he tried to make it look like he was attacking us. He said that in the days when we were in government Ministers just had pieces of paper stuffed under their noses, signed them without reading them and then hopped into their white cars and ducked off. In my view, he was actually deliberately and knowingly bucketing his ministerial colleague Senator Collins for what has been a disastrous performance in that portfolio.

Not only has Senator Collins been unable to explain how the farce of satellite pay TV emerged, but his counterpart in the House, the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall)—the most inappropriately named Minister in the Government, as he has shown a total failure to communicate anything in the course of the last two weeks—has revealed just how bad this factional system is and what poor products it turns out in terms of Ministers for the front bench of this Government.

What a staggering performance. He never answered any question directly. He stood here on most occasions trying to read a prepared text, irrespective of the question that was asked. Every time one of us got up and asked a question he would start quivering down here and the fellow sitting where the Minister is sitting now, the Prime Minister, started quivering in that chair as well, fearful of what this bloke might say or do when he arrived on the scene.

As the Minister approached the dispatch box we could hear the Prime Minister yelling to him the essence of the answer, but it was not to be absorbed by the Minister. He was hell bent on just delivering the text that had been prepared for him. We tried him in a couple of other areas of ministerial responsibility, areas about which he should have known something. One of my colleagues asked him a question about road funding and his answer was, `I was not expecting that question today but I will get an answer from the Minister and I will give it to you'. Then we asked him another question about regional coverage of television and he did not know about that either; he made the same comment. He said something like, `I was not expecting this question either. I do not know. I will speak to the Minister and I will get you an answer'.

The fact is that he is the Minister responsible. In transport, it might be argued, the other guy has principal responsibility, but for television and communications he is the Minister, so undoubtedly he is now sitting back in his office asking himself the question. If a new program of Faulty Towers were being cast, it would not take long to see who would be playing the role of Manuel, would it? `I know; I do not know; I ask the Minister'—you can just see it coming. Wonderful stuff!

The Minister at the table is another classic example of ministerial incompetence and ministerial failure. In conjunction with the Minister's mate the former Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, now the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), he had a—what was the word the Minister used today?—technical irregularity for making an illegal payment. Is that not right—a technical irregularity for making an illegal payment?

We have had the communications Ministers talking about potential deficiencies, we have had technical irregularities and we have got unintended consequences—all of them expressions designed to cover up one of the most incompetent frontbenches we have seen in many years. If Allan Border were running that lot, he would have a lot to say, and he would say it pretty well when he looked around the team as they went back to the end of the crease.

They are not the only ones. What about Senator Evans who has been unable to explain why he will not meet Mrs Gillespie and why it took him eight months to put in place these extradition proceedings which had been prepared eight months ago? He has been unable to explain it. But he did do one good thing. He did actually say quite openly and honestly, backing up the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), that all tax increases are on the agenda. In the other place, he would not rule out any of them. He was quite happy to contemplate the possibility of any of them, and I am sure in this year's Budget we will see it.

Then there was the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). He has made a great entry into the front bench, has he not? The first utterance, in the Governor-General's speech at the opening of Parliament, was to downgrade and patronise the position of women judges. That was a great entry into the field of the front bench.

The smoothest of all on the front bench, the young up and coming Turk, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths), in a moment of rash honesty on his part—because they are trying to demonstrate to him that the only way they win on that side is through dishonesty—referred to our circumstances as those of the Titanic. That has been a pretty good start. Just look at them: Beddall, Collins, Beazley, Baldwin, Evans, Lavarch, Willis, Dawkins, Griffiths—what a team! In two weeks, you have just about annihilated half the frontbench.

Finally, there are the backbenchers, who are not going to cop this sitting down. They and other members of the Labor Party are starting to speak out to expose more of the secret agenda. We have seen the secret agenda in the republican debate. Premier Goss was out there yesterday talking about abolishing the Senate. We have had Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development talking about the abolition of the States. We have had the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) talking about just about everything. If we focus on it, we see that he wants to change the reserve powers and other things. There is a very large agenda out there. There is the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns), who was rolled in that factional brawl in Queensland and missed out on his front bench spot. He has decided to change the flag on their logo.

There is a secret agenda here that goes way beyond the so-called Head of State in the republican debate. These guys are about changing the basic structure and fabric of Australian government and Australian society. We should have no doubt that others in the course of the next few weeks, as the factional pressures and the consequences of the factional pressures run their course, will start to speak out as well.

Poor old Gary Punch: remember him? He had a deal that he and Brereton would go up together. Brereton is on the front bench and Punch is still on the back bench because of Walker, who is just loved by the left wing faction right now. There are factional divisions which go to the very heart of it. Let us look at the position: the Government is exposed by the facts, exposed on a policy front, exposed by the backbench, and exposed by its own incompetence on the front bench. We might stop and ask ourselves what has changed on the other side? We have had an election, but what has changed? There are a few new ties, a few new dresses and a few new suits but, fundamentally, nothing else. It is just the same old tired lot over there. They have no direction, no policies, no mandate, no sense of direction for Australia, and no capacity to put in place, if it did have them, the policies that are required to deal with our very deep-seated economic circumstances as they have emerged and are still emerging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not bought a new suit since the election so that last epithet cannot possibly apply to me. This is a sad, quiet little canter across the front bench from a man with boldness, with arrogance, with firmness, with decisiveness, with leadership, who said last year:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if people moved to get rid of the GST from the package, they'd have to remove me.
It is the man who said:

I mean, I'm said to be inflexible, well I am, I'm not going to change. I mean the only way to be genuinely compassionate in Australia is to take the hard line and call for the decisions and advocate the right policies.

It has been the source of some mystery for people on this side of the House, and the public in general, why such flamboyantly expressed firm statements of what constitutes quality of leadership in Australian politics, so massively reneged on since the election, see the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) still sitting there—a man who gets up and criticises the Government's policies, policies which are directed at meeting the needs of the Australian population, at the same time as he sits with an $18 billion hole in his policy, as he desperately scrabbles against his backbench, against the National Party, and against other members of his frontbench to hold on to the total picture that he wishes to present of what an alternative Liberal Government would be. He staggers from one crisis to another in the Liberal Party, with his leadership constantly being undermined, yet he stands here and mentions a few odd-ball points and expects that he can mount a case against the Government when the mess on which he sits is putrid, and everybody knows it.

PARA.TAB: I recollect once or twice during the course of Question Time last year that when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was invited by the Leader of the Opposition to go to the polls, he said to the Leader of the Opposition, `No, I shall go to the polls at the normal time'—as indeed he did—`because I wish to do you slowly'. That was the position adopted by the Prime Minister and, indeed, he was good to his word—he did him slowly.

It just came through, as far as I am concerned, at the last possible minute. Nevertheless, the slow doing was done. The difference between the situation then and the situation now, because I think it has been a source of some mystery to us, is why such an utterly discredited leader is still there. He is not discredited by an election loss; they happen to politicians all the time and there is not necessarily any discrediting in an election loss—he is discredited because he has had to abandon everything he has stated firmly, publicly and repeatedly is absolutely essential to the country and, in a mealy-mouthed fashion, he has walked back from what he has said, has participated in no way in his party's debate, and in a humiliating way has tried to explain himself to the press, which has been his lot since the election.

We have an answer to that. The Liberal Party, having heard the Prime Minister, has now decided to do the Leader of the Opposition slowly itself. It said to him, `No, you haven't just lost us an election; you are not going to be allowed to run away from the consequences of losing us an election. What we are going to do is to haul you back into this seat so that we can inflict upon you maximum humiliation. You are going to have to sit there while the National Party, while some of our own backbenchers from Victoria, get up and say your policies on tariffs stink. The fundamental underpinning element of your industrial policy is that you should be taken by the ears and hung out to dry on it.'. That is what some elements of the National Party and those in Victoria are saying to the Leader of the Opposition. That is doing him slowly if ever there was such a thing.

When the shadow Minister for industrial relations, the Manager of Opposition Business in the House (Mr Howard), stood up and said, `Dr Hewson may choose to abandon his policies by the bushel but I will not let him—cowardly backslider that he is—move one inch from the policies that I lay down as far as industrial relations are concerned', he was slowly making his contribution, turning the spit for the Leader of the Opposition.

Then various backbenchers got up and said, `As far as Medicare is concerned, we cannot possibly go into an election campaign again with the policies we have adopted on Medicare. They are too threatening to the bulk of the population. As far as we are concerned, that policy will have to be abandoned'. And the spit continued to be turned slowly by that section of the Opposition backbench.

Only a few weeks ago, the Leader of the Opposition made a perfectly sensible statement—about a matter on which he had not declared himself before the election—when he said, `We are going to have a decent debate in the Liberal Party on the subject of republicanism. I have a mind to head down the road in that direction'. Then one of his frontbenchers, the shadow Minister for finance, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), stood up and said, `No. We will make a decision right now, thank you very much, and we will make it in favour of a monarchy'. And he got to crank the spit, and the Leader of the Opposition continued to turn over slowly.

In an issue of Quadrant, the father of the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) had some advice for members of the Opposition on their activities over the next two years: don't arrive at policies; arrive only at heroic poetry—read heroic poetry. I will give the Leader of the Opposition some heroic poetry—what he resembles—The Ancient Mariner:

SPEECH.PARA: And the many men so beautiful
And they all dead did lie,
And a thousand thousand slimy things
Lived on; and so did I.

That is the Leader of the Opposition's position. I would recommend to him the heroic poetry of The Ancient Mariner—since we are all getting nautical on these matters—so that he can contemplate the many dead men on the side of the Liberal Party and the National Party after the election process. It describes what happens when people abandon what they regard as inflexible policies that must be pursued for the good of the country, and if they are not pursued to that end, the country's interests cannot be served. It indicates that, at least as far as the Leader of the Opposition considers himself situated somewhere in the political spectrum, he would definitely see himself among the living, with a thousand thousand slimy things beneath him. The thousand thousand slimy things, of course, are the Liberal Party's efforts to come to grips with policy over the next couple of years.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition comes into this place and says that there is an atmosphere of crisis arising from one month's figures—when, in fact, the unemployment rate went down. He challenged the Government to produce a set of propositions to deal with the falling unemployment levels and then had the hide, after challenging the Government, to cheerfully get up and say, `I do not think that we really need to arrive at policies for the next couple of years'. When challenged to state what particular policies he agreed with, he said, `Some, but perhaps not the GST. I do not really want to abandon the GST'. That is interesting. We should listen to that statement as frequently as we can, and take note of it whenever it occurs, because the Leader of the Opposition, who has been obliged by his party at this point to abandon the GST, is only too anxious to interpret any conceivable taxation suggestion thrown at the Government as obviously being a GST.

If somebody in the community makes a suggestion—for example, that the Government might consider broadening the base of indirect tax—then the Leader of the Opposition regards that as a GST. If somebody suggests that there should be consideration given to the introduction of a wealth tax, he considers that to be a GST. Anybody who actually knows anything about the GST—the Opposition is only half educated on the subject, with the Government assisting its education process no end over the last 12 months just to reach that half level of understanding—knows that whatever proposition those suggestions might constitute, they do not constitute a GST.

As far as the Leader of the Opposition is concerned, if he is seeking to interpret those particular community suggestions on taxation as GSTs, there can be only one reason for him to do so. He is not a man who operates in ignorance on these matters; he at least has something of an idea about the general principles of the GST, if not the actual detail of it. He can be doing it for only one reason: he is trying desperately to clear the ground in public consciousness to continue the advocacy of the GST in Liberal Party policy. There is no other purpose served by making such ridiculous arguments.

If he wants to argue against tax increases, he should argue against tax increases within the framework of the particular taxes that are proposed and say whether they are justified in his view. That is fine; that is all part of the political debating process. I am not trying to pretend a particular type of tax is another type of tax. There can be only one reason why he would wish to do that, and that is that he wishes to clear the ground.

We have an Opposition frontbench that will not shut up, the members of which undermine the Leader of the Opposition's position every time they open their mouths. It has a close contestant for leadership who, at every opportunity that arises in public, distances himself from his leader and seeks to manipulate old Liberal Party symbols as effectively as he can to lay the ground for a future leadership challenge against his leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. Costello is trying to promote everything.

—I was not actually thinking of the honourable member for Higgins in this case; it was he on one issue. I had in mind the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). He is consistently undermining his leader.

PARA.TAB: We have the National Party, particularly the National Party in Queensland, saying, `Your continuing policies on tariffs are mistaken; they ought to actually be reversed, not to the level at which the Government has held protection, but taken way beyond it'. That is the formal position of the Queensland National Party. God knows what the position of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) is. But one thing that is absolutely certain is that there is no coalition on industrial policy anymore.

The issues that I have mentioned are fundamental to the nature of this Government, not whether we will get pay TV or when we will get it. They are fundamental to the capacity of this society to employ people and to develop and grow. Leaving aside the question of whether or not the frontbench on this side of the House happens to be performing to the exact delight, detail or whatever of the Opposition, the active subversion of the Leader of the Opposition's position by his own front and back benches is patently clear for all to see. The leadership of the Liberal Party is totally destabilised.

Given the terms of the discussion I thought that I would be debating employment. I would prefer, frankly, to be debating employment, but the Leader of the Opposition decided that he would give the unemployed a brief mention on his way through to make his points about where he thought there were some minor inadequacies in the Government frontbench. In the couple of minutes available to me, I will try to deal with unemployment.

Today's figures are not what the Government would be satisfied with, but that is not a new factor as far as the Government's presentation of its position on economic issues is concerned. The Prime Minister made it quite clear during the course of the election campaign that he considered unemployment levels to be unacceptably high. We have had occasion to remark about the effect of the volatility of monthly figures and how difficult it is to follow them. The fact of the matter is that in the statistics that we have we get a situation month on month in which, when the number of jobs assessed as being in the community rises, the participation rate rises with it. When the number of jobs is lowered, in the way in which the survey is done, the participation rate tends to fall, producing results such as: so many people gave up work, or so many people increased work. If we actually take the minutiae of these monthly figures, we are asked to believe that one month, 150,000 people decide they want to enter the work force and the next month 150,000 people decide they do not want to be in the work force. We are expected to be impressed that somehow or other this has added to our capacity to analyse what is going on in the economy. Of course, we cannot. What we take of these figures is the underlying rate.

For the past five months the underlying rate of unemployment has been falling. As far as job creation is concerned, for the past couple of months the underlying unemployment rate has been static. As far as young people are concerned, the unemployment rate amongst teenagers is 8.9 per cent. As far as the general community is concerned, the rate for this month is 10.7 per cent, down from 10.8 per cent last month. Those figures will bounce around, but the underlying rate will be more consistent. The underlying rate is going in the right direction, but it is not good enough. We said that before the election—it is not some new discovery on our part—and we have said it since the election. Our policies are devoted to dealing with the level of unemployment with a view to getting people back to work and dealing with the unemployed in a decent fashion to ensure that they have dignity and the means to sustain life. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I enjoyed the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) advising us to read The Ancient Mariner. I might suggest to him and to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) that they read The Boy Stood on the Burning Deck. Unemployment might have only got a brief mention in the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), but I intend to dwell on it for the majority of my speech as it is the second part of the matter of public importance.

PARA.TAB: Unemployment figures for the month of April were released today and, whilst the Minister for Employment, Education and Training said there has been a slight drop in the overall number, the participation rate of 61.9 per cent is the lowest for five years and, on those figures, something like 100,000 people have given up looking for work in the last month. This has been raised many times in this House, and whenever the participation rate comes up we get some sort of diatribe about what participation was like 10 or 15 years ago and what it means. That misses the point. Australian society has changed dramatically in the last 10 or 15 years; it has not changed dramatically in the last month. Women constitute a much greater part of the work force. To compare participation rates today with participation 15 years ago is meaningless. Employment has dropped by 75,000 in the last month—that is 75,000 fewer jobs. In the 15- to 19-year old age group it is up above 32 per cent again—

TALK.START.PARA: —And trending up.

—And trending up, as my colleague says. I heard the Minister say a couple of minutes ago that youth unemployment was 8.9 per cent. That is fascinating, because no country in the world looks at unemployment as a percentage of the total population but rather as a percentage of the available labour market. If it was not so comical it would be serious, because to address a problem we have to first be prepared to face up to it and understand it, and the fact that the figures are so easily fiddled shows that there is no real willingness to face up to this problem.

PARA.TAB: Looking at it historically, we had a census in 1933 at the height of the Great Depression, and youth unemployment then was the same as adult unemployment—about 21 per cent. The level of unemployment facing 15- to 19-year olds today is the highest that young people have ever faced in this country's history—higher than the Great Depression.

I want to make three points. The first point is that I believe the Government is completely defeatist on this and it does not have a clue how it is going to get out of it; secondly, high unemployment is becoming a fact of Australian life; and, thirdly, I refer to the human consequences of what we are experiencing now.

A number of things show that the Government is defeatist. A couple of weeks ago we had the Minister for Employment, Education and Training admitting that 500,000 people could be long-term unemployed by the end of next year. That is a wonderful bit of candour and political honesty. It is a pity he could not find the same honesty two months ago. We have been saying this for 12 months, and I have sat here and listened to us getting bagged by the other side because we dared to suggest what the Minister is now admitting. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been reported in the papers as saying just this week to the Caucus meeting, `We have to find novel ways of dealing with long-term unemployment'. That is wonderful—novel ways: `We don't have a clue as to how we are going to deal with it. We have to look for novel ways'.

We also had reports before the election of the Prime Minister saying in a private speech that unemployment had been neutralised as an issue. That is wonderful! I would really like to know whether it is the 100,000 people who gave up work last month who have been neutralised or the 75,000 people who lost their jobs last month who have been neutralised, or both. The fact is this is all a game for the Government and it does not have a clue what to do. This is just like its response to youth unemployment. Do the honourable members remember all the fuss about that a couple of years ago? In a moment of candour the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) commented on that to the Age newspaper. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal Government policies to combat youth homelessness were a fuzzy response to political pressures in the hope that things might get better.
He went on to say that there was no way of knowing whether the money had done anything to help because . . . we weren't all too clear what the problems were at the beginning.
This Government's response to unemployment is the same: do something in the hope that it will go away.

PARA.TAB: The second factor is that high unemployment is becoming a fact of Australian life. In the course of the last Parliament unemployment in this country jumped from 6.1 per cent to 11 per cent. The last Government brought down three Budgets, three economic statements, and they all failed to arrest the increase in unemployment. The number of long-term unemployed has trebled over the last three years. It now stands at nearly 370,000 people. The long-term unemployed are becoming more and more entrenched in an increasingly unequal society. The fact is that after every recession the number of long-term unemployed are ratcheted up and they do not ever come down to the level they were beforehand.

I listened again today to the Minister trying to compare what happened after the last recession. The fact is that during the last recession the number of long-term unemployed in this country peaked in February 1984 at 230,600. The social costs of long-term unemployed are very well known. Last year Bruce Chapman, the person whom the Government is now looking to for solutions to the mess that it is in, made the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: The current state of the Australian labour market augurs poorly for those already disadvantaged in the labour force, of which there are, and continue to be, very many. Our estimates and projections imply strongly the number of long-term unemployed will be, by a very large margin, at unprecedented and still growing levels over the next two years. There is not, now, any chance of avoiding this.
What a pity the Government did not ask him a couple of years ago what he might do, rather than waiting until it thought the problem needed to be massaged.

PARA.TAB: Last year the then Victorian Chief Commissioner for Police, Kel Glare, a man noted for his impartiality, said publicly that he feared that young, long-term unemployed would become unemployable and a disenfranchised underclass. In my own State of Victoria, the number of break-ins has gone up 50 per cent in the last 10 years, 930 a day; serious assaults have gone up by 140 per cent; stealing by 69 per cent; and fraud by 110 per cent. Using statistical data it can be seen that youth crime, youth gang activities, and female crime have all increased. This is simply not an area where the Government has no role. The Government can set standards; it can set examples; it can try model approaches; it can evaluate; it can disseminate; it can initiate. Above all, it can lead. None of that is being done today.
The Prime Minister recognised this in 1980 when he was in opposition in the old Parliament House. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members opposite think that the Baader-Meinhof groups and the urban guerillas in Western Europe will not be a feature of Australia as we move through the 1980s with high levels of unemployment in the cities, I think they may be disappointed.

He imagined the future social consequences; he has done nothing at all about it. All these are just numbers. Imagine the human consequences of each one of them. Imagine you are Brian, unemployed for the first time in your life after 40 years of continuous employment; 56 years old, employed continuously for 10 years as a metal polisher. For Brian, loss of employment has meant a dramatic change in his lifestyle. His family can no longer afford to live in a house—they rent a caravan—to have a phone, to have private health insurance, a car, excursions for their kids, holidays, and going out for meals with friends. Brian is not fictitious. He is in the Brotherhood of St Laurence document Unemployment in the recession—policies for reform. He is a real person.

PARA.TAB: Earlier, I heard the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) say that we had been done slowly because our policies were picked over bit by bit. Let me make two comments on that. The first is that that is exactly what this Government is doing to the Australian people—doing them slowly. It is also what this Government is doing to the Australian economy—doing it slowly. The second point I make is that I happen to believe there is still a place in politics for honesty—not honesty two months after an election but honesty before an election—and courage to be prepared to actually go out and argue for a set of policies which might do something to confront the long-term problems this country faces. The alternative is what we have now—drugs, crime, suicide, despair. I say to honourable members opposite: well done; that is a great effort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a few things in this place that I believe all honourable members agree on. One thing I think we all agree on and have a commitment to is that all Australians who wish to work in gainful employment should be able to do so. It is a little bit of a pity when we enter into these debates that some recognition of that fact is too seldom provided by those opposite.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), who proposed this matter of public importance, barely mentioned the whole question of unemployment, let alone gave any consideration to the sorts of details which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge) has just referred to. I wish to refer to some of the things the Leader of the Opposition said, and hopefully time will allow me to make some comments about the unemployment situation.

Those people in the gallery who were here when the Leader of the Opposition spoke would have seen that he was not speaking to the House; he was not speaking to the Government; he was not speaking to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), who was at the table. He was speaking to his backbench. He was physically facing the backbench in a presentation to them designed to protect his hide and his position. In a rambling speech that barely mentioned the word `unemployment', he spoke to us about pay TV, the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall), possible irregularities in tertiary funding, judicial appointments, the republican debate and the ALP logo—all in a vaudevillian act designed to get him back some favour with his backbench. He showed signs of a person under some stress, of a person under some threat from his own backbench and, as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training quite clearly put it, of a person being done slowly, not by the Government as he was done at the election, but by his own backbench.

Listening to him speak prompted me to dig up one of those old newspaper articles which I am sure those opposite who were in the last parliament will well recall. The Daily Telegraph Mirror of 20 November last year had a large front-page picture of the Leader of the Opposition and a headline that he would resign. The article said this:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal Opposition Leader John Hewson yesterday threatened backbench rebels he would resign rather than scrap the 15 per cent Goods and Services Tax.

He is not making that offer these days. He is not standing up and saying, `I will resign if I do not get my way'. This time around he might find that if he laid his resignation on the table so many people would jump to take it—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, on the question of relevance. The MPI is on a specific issue, and the debate should concentrate on that. The honourable member, even with great indulgence, is obviously not on the issue at all. He is attempting to denigrate the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The discussion has been a far-reaching one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume the honourable member for Indi was in the House at the time to hear his leader speak about the Minister for Communications, judicial appointments, the republican debate, the ALP logo and a lot of other things and barely mention the word `unemployment' or any concern for the unemployed. The fact of life is that we have a Leader of the Opposition who has been under some duress, to the point where earlier this week there were rumours around that he had sent one of his own staff up to the press gallery on the day of his party room meeting to find out whether any rumours had been heard about a leadership challenge this week at his party room meeting. That is the sort of pressure that prompted this matter of public importance and the display we have just seen.

PARA.TAB: Today the Opposition's proposed economic platform is incomplete and in total disarray. Last year those opposite started out with a Fightback package which had a $6 billion hole in it. After the election, they dropped the GST which meant they no longer had $20 billion in revenue. Opposition members are in this House today talking about economic policy and about providing some program to assist the unemployed, but they stand before the Australian people with their policy in shreds. This opposition policy says, `We are $20 billion short of what we wanted to raise last year; we still have a $6 billion hole that we could not fix up before the election; and all of that includes a proposed $7 billion cut in funding to the federal Budget in this financial year'. They are about $33 billion short—but what is $33,000 million amongst friends, I suppose?

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about the unemployed, why don't you?

—The honourable member might have called that out when his leader was speaking. The honourable member was one of those in the chamber who thought it was very entertaining to watch the vaudeville act his leader put on without mentioning the unemployed.The Liberal solution to unemployment offered at the last election was, stripped of everything else, to reduce wages. It proposed to cut young people's wages to $3 per hour and reduce social benefits; for example, reducing the Medicare rebate and so increasing the cost of going to the doctor. But, underneath it all, the Opposition's solution to the unemployment problem was to reduce the cost of labour, to reduce wages even further.

PARA.TAB: Some opposition members may even understand the fact that unit labour costs are now lower than they were in 1983. In fact, labour is cheaper in this country now than it has been for a decade. The international comparison also shows that unit labour costs in Australia are lower than those of our major OECD partners with whom we would want to compare ourselves. One of the great myths which has been perpetrated in Australia is the alleged high cost of Australian labour. The Opposition's solution to the unemployment problem was to strip workers of their rights of representation to ensure that they had reduced bargaining power and thus their wages would be less in the future than they are now. In fact, the Opposition's Fightback document—all 700 pages of it—was modelled on the predication that there would be a zero increase in wages through to the year 2000. That is the basis upon which those opposite modelled their graphs in that 700-page document.

The other proposal those opposite put to the Australian people—which was rejected out of hand—was the $7 billion cut in government spending. We do not need a PhD in economics to understand the direct impact on employment of a $7 billion reduction in government outlays. At various times during the past year different opposition spokespeople were at least honest enough to acknowledge that, in the short term, their policies would have increased unemployment. There was an admission by those opposite that their policies would, in the short term, have increased the number of people out of work. Yet they have the cant and hypocrisy to pontificate about unemployment when they admitted that their policy was designed to increase, in the short term, the number of people out of work.

But worse than that, as part of this fetish for cutting through the public sector and taking $7 billion out of government expenditure, the Opposition was going to abolish programs which are designed and targeted to create jobs, improve workplace reform and provide assistance to the unemployed. It was going to abolish the best practice demonstration program, which has been a great success and is doing many good things in Australian industry. Admittedly those opposite proposed to increase TAFE funding, but to nowhere near the sort of level this government has provided. Had the Opposition been elected, the TAFE sector would have received less money than it will receive under this Government. The Opposition was also going to abolish the local government capital works program—a program which has provided much needed employment, training and skills for local government areas throughout the country.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition should talk to some of his backbenchers who represent those areas that have high unemployment and receive substantial funds. They were the first at the office of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, knocking on the door and saying, `I want as much of this money as I can get because I want to do something to help the people in my electorate'. They at least had the decency and integrity to understand the benefits of the program for their people.

The Opposition was also going to abolish the gender equity programs. Unemployed benefits were going to be removed after nine months—the unemployed would be thrown on the scrap heap. Then, to cap it all off, the Opposition had a policy of zero tariffs—to help Australians get jobs by abolishing all industry protection through the tariff system. That was the sort of policy that the Opposition came up with and yet, in the absence of any meaningful policy, having since then put another $20 billion hole in its own program by abolishing the GST, it has the hide today to talk about doing something for the unemployed.

The matter of public importance was designed and performed to assist the Leader of the Opposition in his woes. It has done very little to that end. It has done even less to further the debate on economics or to assist those in Australia who are unemployed. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. I refer to subparagraphs (1)(p) and (q) and paragraph (2). I would like the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) to clarify exactly what the provisions in subparagraphs (1)(p) and (q) actually mean in relation to the question of the publication of in camera evidence that was the subject of some controversy in the previous parliament as a result of a dissenting report that was compiled by me, Senator Vanstone, Senator Crichton-Browne and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). I note that the former chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), is present in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: This matter relates to the publication of the Operation Ark report published by the committee to which I, the two senators and the honourable member for Gippsland attached a dissenting report in which we published some evidence that had been obtained in our inquiries that was pertinent to that report, which attempted to clarify some of the issues that we believed very strongly were not covered in the majority report of the committee.

In particular, it is important that we clarify the terms contained in subparagraph (1)(p). I am interested in learning exactly what is meant by `operational methods and results of investigations of law enforcement agencies' so that we are in a position as House of Representatives members of the joint standing committee to understand what the motion, which presumably will be carried, will mean as to the publication of material collected as a result of the inquiries of the committee.

One of the central issues that has arisen as a result of the controversial Operation Ark report was that in the Senate Standing Orders there is provision for individual dissenting members to publish in camera evidence that they see as being pertinent to the matter raised in the dissenting report. As we know, the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives do not permit that to take place.

The Operation Ark report was tabled in the Senate, along with the dissenting report. There was some controversy as a result. As a consequence, a matter was referred to the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges as a result of the matters arising from that report.

An important principle arising from this is the principle that in a joint standing committee there is a conflict between the Standing Orders of the Senate and the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives. The Standing Orders of the Senate contain the underlying principle that an individual member may use in camera evidence to substantiate, obviously in good faith, matters arising from the publication of the committee's dissenting report.

As the authors of the dissenting report, we felt it necessary that substantial matters concerned with the Operation Ark report should be exposed to public view. Following the tabling of that report, a letter was received by Mr Justice Stewart, the former chairman of the National Crime Authority, and tabled in the Senate. That letter substantiated the intent of the position undertaken by me and my fellow co-authors, Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Vanstone and the honourable member for Gippsland. In particular, I suppose the actions we took were vindicated to that extent by the Senate Committee of Privileges in its 36th report published last year.

In conclusion, it is important that when moving this motion the Leader of the House should clarify exactly the intent of subparagraphs 1(p) and 1(q) and exactly what it is that we are in fact conveying to the Senate by way of the intent of clause 2. It is clear that there is a conflict between the two chambers and that the Senate Standing Orders allow for the publication of in-camera evidence under the circumstances which I have mentioned. I might add also that there is no question that, in the publication of the evidence in the report I have referred to, there was any exposure of operational matters—and I mean operational matters in the pure sense of the word—that would endanger the operations of the National Crime Authority or anyone associated with any inquiries being undertaken by the National Crime Authority or, for that matter, would make an investigation more difficult to conclude.

In fact, much of the controversy was redundant because the reality of the evidence exposed in the dissenting report was that it related more specifically to deliberations between the members of the authority and members of the previous authority over the dates and other matters relating to the actual compilation and publication of the Operation Ark report some 2 1/2 years ago. Under those circumstances, perhaps the Leader of the House might help us by clarifying exactly what is intended by the inclusion of those three paragraphs in the motion he has just moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 1 to 5 (1993); and Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1993).

SPEECH.PARA: The tariff proposals which I have just tabled contain alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 and the Excise Tariff Act 1921. Customs tariff proposal No. 1 (1993) was introduced into the House on 17 December 1992 by the former Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, Mr Beddall, in the previous Parliament. As the change had not been enacted when Parliament was dissolved, the initiative lapsed and is now reintroduced in this proposal.

PARA.TAB: Tapestry kits are free of customs duty while other needlecraft kits are dutiable at 15 per cent. Both types of kit are designed for needlework hobbyists. As such they compete with and are direct substitutes for each other. There has been an ongoing problem with the identification of each type of kit. In addition, this situation has been further aggravated by a recent Federal Court decision. As a result of this decision many kits not considered by the industry to be tapestry kits are now legally defined as such. As there is no local manufacture of these kits, the Government has decided to dispense with the tariff advantage enjoyed by tapestry kits by providing a free rate of duty for all kits of heading 6308. The change has been backdated to operate from 1 January 1988 when the current harmonised tariff was introduced.

Customs tariff proposals Nos 2 to 4 (1993) formally place before the Parliament, as required by law, tariff alterations made by notice published in the Gazette during the recent recess of Parliament. Customs tariff proposal No. 2, which operated between 13 October 1992 and 28 February 1993 provides for the continuing duty free importation of certain handkerchiefs which are imported in bulk. Procedures to allow the ongoing duty free importation of the subject goods after 1 March 1993 have been provided under the customs by-law system.

Customs tariff proposal No. 3 contains four separate changes which came into effect on 1 March 1993. After discussions with the Canadian Government, this Government will phase out the Canadian margin of preference on certain carpets of tariff chapter 57. This will be achieved by freezing the Canadian rate of duty at its pre-1 March 1993 level until such time as the general rate of duty for the subject goods phases down to the existing Canadian rate. Last July the previous government announced a review of the customs by-law system as it relates to textiles and textile goods. The review is now complete and alterations made to part III of schedule 4 result from recommendations made by the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. The changes combine previous concessions available to importers into one enlarged item.

With the abolition of quota restrictions on textiles, clothing and footwear from 1 March 1993, administration of quota restrictions on cheese and curd have been removed from schedule 5 and placed in a new concessional item 61 in schedule 4. There is no change in duty levels involved in this amendment. Customs tariff proposal No. 4 (1993), operative on and from 10 March 1993, accords concessional rates of duty to the new countries of the Czech Republic and the Slovak Republic under the Australian system of tariff preferences. The new countries have evolved from the agreed division of the former Federal Republic of Czechoslovakia towards the end of 1992.

Customs tariff proposal No. 5 (1993) will operate from 1 July 1993. In the 1991 March industry statement, initiatives were announced to assist local manufacturers of passenger motor vehicle components. That announcement revealed that certain components which had a rate of duty of 15 per cent on 1 July 1992 would not participate in the general phasing down of tariff rates. This proposal implements that decision in relation to those tariff subheadings which contain passenger motor vehicle components and have a margin of preference for goods of Canadian origin.

Excise tariff proposal No. 1 (1993) details rates of excise duty which took effect in 1992 pursuant to excise tariff proposals Nos 1 and 2 (1992). These proposals lapsed upon the dissolution of Parliament on 8 February 1993 and their effect is reinstated by excise tariff proposal No. 1 (1993). These measures are included in the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1993 introduced into the House last week. Summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Andrews) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred again to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Housing development at Flinders View near Ipswich, Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: In January 1988 the Government established the Defence Housing Authority as the first step towards providing a better standard and an increased choice of housing for defence personnel and their families. At this time, the Defence Housing Authority took over responsibility for some 23,000 houses. It now has a current investment program in excess of $270 million per annum.

PARA.TAB: The Defence Housing Authority has entered into a joint venture agreement with Mirvac Projects Pty Ltd to develop a residential subdivision area of 53.8 hectares at Flinders View. The development will provide for 560 residential blocks, incorporating both detached and medium density housing. The Defence Housing Authority proposes construction of around 180 houses for service personnel and their families. The remaining 360 lots will be integrated with the service housing and will be offered for sale to private purchasers.

The development will replace existing substandard housing located in the Amberley area. It is in line with the DHA's commitment to improve the standard of accommodation for defence personnel and their families and its commitment to return houses to the States. The project is estimated to cost $31 million, of which $18 million will be recovered from the sale of building lots. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is planned to commence in May 1993, with completion anticipated in late 1997. I table the drawings and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Mr Willis:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: HMAS Waterhen modernisation, Waverton, NSW.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May this motion was referred to the House by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) but, because of the concern expressed by the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) and the fact that a public works committee at that stage had not yet been re-elected, the matter was deferred. I would now, on the adjournment of that debate, again make reference to the fact that this motion has to be referred in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act and state that it deals with HMAS Waterhen, which is the national mine warfare base for the Royal Australian Navy, located at Balls Head Bay, Waverton, New South Wales, some four kilometres north of Sydney.

PARA.TAB: Existing facilities and services date back to late 1940. A number of demountable buildings and transportable containers have been provided over the years to supplement facilities' requirements pending modernisation. The age and poor condition of existing facilities now necessitates replacement or major specific repair to continue operational activities and provide for the future mine warfare capability. Various proposals have been considered and developed for the Waterhen site over a period of about 10 years. In May 1991 the Defence Force Structure Programs and Policy Committee endorsed the high priority for the modernisation of the existing Waterhen mine warfare base.

This proposal is to provide purpose built facilities for the developing Royal Australian Navy mine countermeasure capability. The scope of the work provides for continuous Navy operations throughout the construction and implementation period and includes an operations and administration building, supply and diving centres, workshop building, a transport compound, flammable materials and explosives storage, and all associated site works and services.

The estimated total cost of the works is $73 million at December 1992 prices. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction work on site is expected to commence by January 1994 and, due to the need to keep the base operational, construction will be staged with completion due by August 1997. I table selected drawings of the proposed HMAS Waterhen facilities modernisation at Waverton, New South Wales, and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mrs Easson:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: May it please Your Excellency:

PARA.TAB: We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, expressed our loyalty to the Sovereign, and thank Your Excellency for the speech you have been pleased to address to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's speech at the opening of the 37th Parliament. Of all the opening speeches to Australian Parliaments there has hardly been one with less vision than this year's speech. It was simply a lengthy regurgitation of election promises, presented without flair or imagination.

PARA.TAB: Lest any of those listening should think that I am reflecting on the personage of the Governor-General, who had the unfortunate task of delivering the speech, I remind them that the text was actually written in the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Address-in-Reply has provided the opportunity over the past two weeks for new members to make their first speeches in this House. In listening to new members on the Government side, one thing is apparent; namely, the number of members who owe their place here not so much to a constituency but to the patronage of the union movement. With few exceptions, the parliamentary Labor Party today consists of Labor Party apparatchiks whose contribution to the nation has been in the unions and the Labor Party as functionaries.

More and more this Labor Party Government has come to represent narrow sectional interests, its representatives here being the professional bureaucrats whose management of unions and the party, replete with salary packages to match, is increasingly remote from ordinary Australians. Yet we are now met with the arrogant assertions from this Government, from the Prime Minister himself down, that somehow Labor is the natural party of the nation—despite, I might add, not having attracted the support of almost half of all Australians.

Indeed, the new honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), a former prime ministerial functionary, repeated this blandishment in his first speech when he said that the aspirations of Australians were held only by those on his side of the House—aspirations which included full employment, aspirations which included this nation having a role in Asia and aspirations which included having an effective education system in Australia. No wonder the Prime Minister could claim privately, as he thought, that `we have been able to spin a giant tale'—a tale, of course, being nothing other than a fictitious story.

But hardly a week passes in this place without the honourable member for Blaxland uttering gratuitous aspersions about, for example, Robert Menzies. Within weeks of his election he was describing Menzies as a political cheat. His other great contribution to the truth on that occasion was to guarantee no increase in taxes, a promise which has already been jettisoned.

Let us look at the Menzies era which the Prime Minister decries. Better still, let us compare those awful Menzies years, as he likes to characterise them, with the glorious 1980s over which the Prime Minister presided as Treasurer. We had an average five per cent economic growth in the 1950s. In the 1980s it was 4.3 per cent. For inflation, the figure was 2.4 per cent in the 1950s and 7.4 per cent in the 1980s. Unemployment in the 1950s was 2.1 per cent; in the 1980s, when the Prime Minister presided over the country as Treasurer, the unemployment rate averaged 7.9 per cent. What is it now? We would like to have a figure of 7.9 per cent today.

Real wages increased for ordinary Australians during the 1950s by an average of 2.5 per cent. During the 1980s they decreased by 0.4 per cent. Most Australians would have preferred similar results from the Prime Minister during the 1980s. These attacks barely mask a personal insecurity—the art of the little man trying to build himself up by putting others down. Here is the psychology of projecting onto others his own faults, calling us on this side of the House divisive to mask his own divisiveness.

Yet the Prime Minister claims that we attack institutions to camouflage his own attacks on institutions. Let us take the republican issue. There are many Australians I suspect who would possibly embrace the notion of a republic if it were not for a churlish refusal by the Prime Minister to concede that anything British has advanced our nation. Even the popular writer John Mortimer, who is an avowed socialist, wittily remarked in his autobiography A Voyage Around My Father that perhaps Britain's greatest gifts to the civilised world were the rule of law and the herbaceous border. But for the Prime Minister there is nothing: not the rule of law—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even the herbaceous border?

—Not even the herbaceous border; not an independent judiciary, not a parliamentary system and all the checks and balances of Westminster—although the events of the last fortnight suggest that we could do with some more of the checks and balances of Westminster, including some ministerial responsibility. No, for the honourable member for Blaxland it is the French and the Italians who contributed, it seems, to our civilisation—presumably in one case with period clocks, and in the other with suits and ties. All of this is wrapped in a new jingoism. Consider this extract from his launch of the book The Burma-Thailand Railway:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia will succeed best if it incorporates into its daily life and the conduct of its affairs the principles of fellowship and co-operation and care for each other. Mateship is as good a word as any other to describe it.

Presumably the mateship that Henry Lawson and others spoke about a century ago was not genuine; presumably it has not existed throughout the decades of this century, or under coalition governments. And all of this when talking of Australians as being the `new frontiersmen' into Asia. What jingoistic nonsense, and what an insult to the soldiers and prisoners-of-war, let alone to the Asian people themselves whose cultures and civilisations have predated European settlement of Australia by thousands of years.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister made similar remarks recently to the H.V. Evatt Foundation. Hardly a day goes by without some insulting remark during Question Time. But those waiting to hear a prime ministerial statement about anything should not hold their breath. He said to the Evatt Foundation—no better place, I suppose, to make these remarks given that Bert Evatt, along with the Prime Minister's other great hero, Jack Lang, were probably the greatest wreckers in Australia's history:

SPEECH.PARA: We can be better if we are united as a people, confident of our identity and what we stand for.

I have not met too many Australians who do not believe that we are united as a people or who are lacking in confidence about our own identity of Australians. I have not met too many Australians who say, `We don't know what we stand for'. Yet this is the sort of jingoistic nonsense we are hearing from the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: All of this is in an attempt to rewrite history—in the words of Manning Clark, to view the historian as a prophet. Why should we not consider the reality and not the Prime Minister's tale? Menzies said in 1958 that the Liberal Party did not seek to win elections by making lush promises about social services. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have, let me remind you, always performed much more than we have promised.

He might have added that Labor always promises much more than it performs—the most recent example being the abandonment of promises to remove pensioners from the tax system by 1995, a promise which was included with the Prime Minister's election statements made at Bankstown during the campaign launch itself.

PARA.TAB: Historically we on this side of the chamber have always seen ourselves as having a mandate for social compassion and social reform. Alfred Deakin, for example, explained liberalism as a belief in equality of political rights without reference to creed, and equality of legal rights without consideration of wealth or quality. Votes for women and the principle of one-man, one-vote were the very plinth upon which this platform was based. Liberalism taught that all, including the poorest in the community, should have their due, and that there should be a minimum rate of wages and wise factory legislation to prevent wealth from taking advantage of the needy.

In the early stages of the Second World War, the Menzies Government announced that social security was to be the one major objective of the post-war period. In 1941 he began a series of new social security programs with the scheme of child endowment. The previous Labor Government had boasted that it would create a national health scheme but had done little more than quarrel with the very people, the doctors, whose cooperation was then vital. It took Australia's first Liberal Government to create a national scheme in 1949. It was not at that stage a comprehensive scheme being, as we recall, only for invalid, old-aged, widows and service pensioners. But it was a Liberal government which started it. At the time it was said to have no superior in any part of the world.

The same government doubled the unemployment benefit and raised pensions which had not gone up under the previous Chifley administration despite rapidly rising prices. Liberal governments oversaw enormous increases in immigration—the great post-war immigrant influx. During the years of Liberal governments when the Labor Party was under the leadership of Arthur Calwell, there was virtually no difference between the Labor and Liberal social policy.

I want to point out a couple of recent social welfare policy signposts on the Liberal side. It should not be forgotten that the Fraser Government introduced the system of family allowances. It is also important to remember that it replaced the pension means test with an income test, including provision for automatic changes in the rates of pensions and benefits in line with changes in the consumer price index. The same government—the Fraser Government—also set up a consultative committee on women's welfare, which Labor has continued but in a more straitened form. In fact, Liberal governments have introduced a wide range of social initiatives over the past 50 years. Since we are approaching 1994, the International Year of the Family, it is probably timely to mention that it was a Liberal Government in 1961 which established funding for marriage counselling programs, and in 1976 established funding for marriage education programs. In fact, much of what passes for achievement in the current Government's rhetoric is in fact little more than a mirage in the desert.

That is enough of the Prime Minister's revisionist history. Let me now turn to his record. If there were one statistic which should be seared into the hearts and minds of all Australians it is that, while in 1982-83 the income of the top one per cent of income earners in Australia equalled the total earnings of the bottom 11 per cent, by 1988-89 the top one per cent was earning an amount equal to the total incomes of the bottom 21 per cent. In other words, from a situation where one per cent equalled 11 per cent, we moved to a situation, during an administration in which the current Prime Minister was the Treasurer of this country, where the top one per cent of Australians earned as much as the bottom 21 per cent of Australians.

Throughout the 1980s we have seen a massive redistribution of income in Australia—a redistribution of income away from many Australians. There are plenty of collaborative studies that support those statistics. A study by Phil Raskall, prepared as part of the inequality project conducted by the Social Policy Research Centre at the University of New South Wales, found that families earning between $20,000 and $40,000 a year have been the big losers. They have suffered a 20 per cent drop in their share of national income since 1975, while well-off families have increased their share by 10 per cent. A study by Dr Ann Harding of the Department of Social Security showed that under the Labor Government the incomes of most social security recipients increased by a much higher percentage than the incomes of most wage and salary earners. But—and it is a big but—most of those people still remain in the poor category, even after receiving the increase.

The Professor of Economics at the Australian National University's Research School of Social Sciences, Robert Gregory, found that the number of low and high income earners in this country has grown significantly, while the number of middle income earners has fallen, constituting an assault, in economic terms, on the great middle ground of ordinary Australians. Labor, despite all its rhetoric, has created a less equal society. In fact, it is one of the great obscenities of our time that this Government can parade itself in the garb of compassion when every objective indicator says otherwise, and every objective assessment of its policies leads inevitably to the opposite conclusion.

According to statistics released in last year's federal Budget papers, more than 300 people with taxable incomes over $1 million paid an average tax rate of 26.1c in the dollar. Those figures reflect the tax changes for higher income earners introduced by the Labor Government. Top earners did not do nearly so well under the previous Fraser administration. Since 1971, the proportion of the population dependent on social security payments—consisting mainly of pensions and benefits—has more than doubled, with over five million Australians presently receiving some form of social security payment.

The upshot of that evidence, which all points in the one direction, is that, in the last 10 years, Australia has become a less equal society than the United Kingdom. In fact, in a comparison of eight developed countries, we are now only more equal than Germany and the United States. The Director of the Social Policy Research Centre at the University of New South Wales, Peter Saunders, concluded that the share of income going to the 60 per cent of Australian families in the middle to low income brackets was smaller than in any of the other countries he had studied. If we look, for example, at the situation of women in this country—many women having become the family's second income earner—we see a feminisation of poverty. At least 50 per cent of the sole parent families that are headed by women live in poverty. While the percentage of women in the work force has increased, in many cases women have gone into the work force to do the lowly paid jobs.

This is all part of the Government's compassion and, as its rhetoric tells us, part of the creation of a more equal and a more inclusive society. Every independent objective indicator of the changes that have occurred to Australians and Australian families over the last decade points to the contrary. Yet the Prime Minister seeks to tell us that his Government and his administration—of the Treasury, for example—has created a better, fairer, more equal society than in the past. That is simply total nonsense.

The Prime Minister, for all his talk of inclusion, has done more than any other person in my lifetime to divide Australia and to bring people closer to Henry Lawson's prophesy that blood would stain the wattle. Since it appears that today is a day for poetry, perhaps the Prime Minister should return to the words of Henry Lawson. He could start with the Vote of Thanks Debate, the poem that contains the memorable lines:

SPEECH.PARA: The other night in Parliament you quoted something true,
Where truth is seldom heard except from one or two.
With apologies to Henry Lawson, I conclude my remarks with another stanza:
Oh, Keating! Have you ever tramped the city streets within?
And felt the pavement wearing thro' the leather, sock, and skin;
