And looked for work, and asked for work, and begged for work in vain,
Until you cared not though you ne'er might touch your tools again.
Oh, Keating! Have you ever felt the summer sun and dirt?
And wore the stiffened socks for weeks, for weeks the single shirt?
And shunned your friends like smallpox—passing on the other side—
And crept away in shadows with your misery and pride.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Before I call the honourable member for Leichhardt, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech. I am sure that the House will extend to him the usual courtesies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is a great honour to represent the people of Leichhardt in this House. I am especially proud to represent the people of Leichhardt on behalf of the great Australian Labor Party as a result of our sweetest victory of all. The election of the Keating Government on 13 March was an inspiring example of our democratic process at work.

PARA.TAB: It is very easy to become cynical about politics and the election process. People talk about media manipulation of the electorate, about television and advertising executives setting the agenda, and about the disempowerment and alienation of the average person in the street. Yet this election proved that the Australian electorate will not be swayed, either by the media or the advertising industry. Despite just about every national and regional newspaper editorialising against the Government, and despite the Opposition's 18-month Fightback sales campaign, the Australian electorate rejected the Opposition's policies. With hindsight, we on this side of the House can say that the choice was obvious and inevitable; that the Australian people had no choice other than to reject the Opposition's rabid free-market policies and its plans to virtually eliminate the trade union movement, Medicare and our world-renowned social welfare programs.

The 1993 election result is testimony to the success of the democratic process in Australia. The process is perhaps far from perfect. For example, this Parliament does not yet reflect the gender balance and ethnic diversity of Australia. However, when we consider that millions of people across the globe still resolve their political differences by non-democratic and often violent means, our democracy is indeed something to celebrate.

It was a joyful experience for me personally to be elected as the honourable member for Leichhardt on 13 March. This is my 20th year as a member of the Australian Labor Party and, like several of my colleagues who have already given their first speeches, I was very much inspired to join the Labor Party by Edward Gough Whitlam in 1973 and by his truly reforming government. A highlight of my election campaign was Gough's visit to Cairns in late 1992.

It is an honour and a challenge to represent the people of Leichhardt in this House. Leichhardt stretches from a few kilometres south of the PNG border, through the Torres Strait Islands to the Cape York Peninsula, including the five communities of the northern peninsula area as well as Aurukun, Lockhart River, Pormpuraaw, Kowanyama, Hope Vale, Coen and Cooktown. The main population centre in the electorate is, of course, the thriving city of Cairns and the surrounding Mulgrave shire. The electorate also includes the Yarrabah community, the sugar growing towns of Babinda, Gordonvale and Mossman and the more tourist orientated centres of Kuranda and Port Douglas.

The city of Cairns brings with it all the urban issues facing other members in cities and larger regional centres: public transport, urban planning, consumer issues and housing, for example. I will ensure that the Cairns community gets the benefit of whatever federally funded programs are available through the better cities program of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) to help improve the city's infrastructure. While Cairns is a well serviced city, there is no getting away from the fact that it is three days drive from Brisbane. The Federal Government has undertaken major works on the Bruce Highway between Cairns and Townsville and naturally I will work to ensure that the road network in Leichhardt is prioritised in the Federal Government road funding program.

Advances in telecommunications have had a profound effect on the Far North community over the last decade. The introduction of the fax machine and the expansion of Telecom's rural and remote areas program over the last 10 years have enabled thousands of people in my electorate to communicate instantly for business and private purposes for the first time. A social justice program now includes access to new information technologies for the disadvantaged, and in this context I welcome the Government's pilot `telecottages' program.

Despite its remoteness, the Cairns region has thrived because of its diverse primary industry base. Tin and gold mining drew European settlers to the region in the 1870s, and then in the 1880s large scale sugar growing began in the Russell and Mulgrave River valleys. Both the mining and sugar industries are still vitally important to the economy of the Far North today. The largest mine in my electorate is at Weipa on the eastern coast of the Gulf of Carpentaria, where the value of bauxite production increased by an estimated 13.4 per cent to $269 million in 1991-92 while estimated production volume increased by 13.4 per cent to 11.4 megatons.

The Queensland sugar industry is continuing to expand up and down the coast, although there has been some contraction in the Cairns area due to urban encroachment. There is no doubt that the sugar industry was a big winner in the 1993 election campaign. The Government's sugar industry package is proof yet again of the consummate negotiating skills of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). The future of the sugar industry is assured as a result of the Government's tariff freeze commitment and the joint State and Federal $40 million infrastructure spending package. I will make it my job to ensure that canefarmers and millers in the Leichhardt electorate get their fair share of that assistance.

The Far North region is booming in terms of international trade. In fact, the top half of Queensland, from Mackay north, exports some $5 billion annually—roughly half of Queensland's annual exports. Putting that into a national perspective, the northern part of Queensland earns as much from exports as South Australia, the Northern Territory and Tasmania combined.

As I said earlier, remoteness and isolation from the southern capital cities has in the past been a trial residents in the Far North have had to overcome. How times have changed. Cairns is still remote from Sydney and Melbourne but is on the doorstep of Asia and the Pacific. Cairns is closer to Indonesia than it is to Canberra. Primary, manufacturing and service industries in my electorate are ideally located to develop trade and investment links with our Asian and Pacific neighbours, which is consistent with Australia's national export strategy.

While the proximity of the Far North to the Pacific and South East Asian export markets gives us a head start on the rest of Australia, the regional economy of Leichhardt must continue to diversify. Industry policies encouraging value adding and manufacturing will enable us to build on the economic bank of tourism and commodities. With this diversity comes maturity of the regional economy and, importantly, long-term sustainable employment. I believe that with a targeted manufacturing policy, not the neoclassical solutions of those opposite, we will achieve this goal. Here I endorse the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) on the need to reform the Industry Commission and the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) on the future direction of industry policy.

I have saved my discussion of the biggest export dollar earning industry in my electorate to last; that is, as my friend the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) says, tourism. In 1992 international tourism to Australia generated $8 billion, up 8.9 per cent on 1991. This accounted for 11 per cent of Australia's total export earnings. The spectacular natural environment of Far North Queensland is responsible for attracting more than its share of those foreign exchange dollars. For example, of the 2.4 million international visitors to Australia last year, 18 per cent spent at least one night in the Far North, and an incredible 6 per cent cleared customs for the first time at the Cairns airport, currently the fifth busiest airport in the country and predicted to be the second gateway into Australia by the year 2000.

In my brief time in this House I have heard many members describe their electorates as the most beautiful in Australia. Of course, I am going to assert the same. But, unlike my colleagues, I am not exaggerating. I am backed up by the people of Australia and international visitors who have voted with their feet on this question. A quarter of a million people visited the Far North last year.

While tourism has brought about an economic boom in the Far North—that has, to a large extent, cushioned the region from the worst affects of the last recession—it has also brought some downside affects. Tourism growth has put pressure on housing supply which has particularly affected the rental market in Cairns, and placed enormous demands on welfare agencies and community infrastructure. The challenge for any parliamentary member in the Far North—and here I include my good friends, my State parliamentary colleagues—is to resolve the conflicts between tourism development and the preservation of our natural environment. And of course there has been conflict in recent years over the extent and nature of tourism development. However, today as I travel within my electorate I certainly do detect a change in the attitude of previous antagonists.

There are very few people in Cairns today who want the Far North to become like Honolulu or Miami or—dare I say—the Gold Coast. The word on everybody's lips is `sustainability'. The tourist industry recognises that the environment is our region's greatest asset and attraction and to destroy that is to destroy the region's future. The environment movement—and here I give praise to the Cairns and Far North Environment Centre, of which I am proud to be a member—is open to dialogue about sustainable growth strategies.

As I said, major campaigns to preserve the beautiful natural environment in my electorate have already been won. The rainforest of the wet tropics area and the Great Barrier Reef have both been World Heritage listed. The Wet Tropics Management Agency, which is located in Cairns, and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in Townsville, have been set up by this Government to manage these unique natural environments so that all Australians and international visitors can enjoy them for generations to come. We cannot afford to be complacent, given the fragility of our natural environment, and I will strive to ensure that the magnificent natural beauty of the Far North is preserved.

The threat of an oil spill on the Great Barrier Reef is of particular concern to many of my constituents in Cairns because of the potentially devastating environmental and economic consequences for the region. While we have a reef plan as well as national and State oil spill plans, there is no doubt that the best plan to take is whatever measures are necessary to prevent an oil spill from happening in the first place. Therefore, I take this opportunity to call on this Government to implement the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, Ships of shame: inquiry into ship safety.

According to the 1991 census, 84 per cent of jobs in Cairns are in the service industry and many of these are directly or indirectly generated by the tourism industry. I believe that this Government's national tourism strategy will provide the direction and the policies that will help create new jobs in the tourism industry. In addition, federally funded programs administered by skillshare, DEET and the Cairns TAFE will help equip people with the skills they need to find jobs in the hospitality industry. Just as importantly for the long-term viability and vitality of the region, the Federal Government has committed $9 million over three years to build a new Smithfield campus of James Cook University at Cairns.

One aspect of the tourism industry that has the potential to create hundreds of jobs in the far north is cultural tourism. A survey done by the Australia Council in 1990 found that half the visitors to Australia were interested in learning about Aboriginal arts and culture, but only seven per cent of visitors were actually able to see a performance of Aboriginal theatre, dance or music. In Cairns, and up the Cape York Peninsula to the Torres Strait, it is impossible to deny the living culture of indigenous Australians; so once again the Cairns community is ideally placed to take advantage of the growing international, and I hope domestic, interest in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture. Clearly, there is an urgent need to implement the recommendations of the June 1992 report of the Department of Arts, Sport the Environment and Territories, Study of cultural tourism in Australia, ensuring that indigenous culture is not trivialised in the process.

In this International Year of Indigenous People there are a few more observations I would like to make about relations between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. I believe in self-determination for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia. The former Minister, Gerry Hand, and the present Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) have earned the respect of many indigenous Australians as a result of the formation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

I am proud to be elected as part of a government led by a Prime Minister who is the first, through his now famous Redfern speech, to recognise the dispossession of Australia's indigenous population. I am proud that Murray island, the subject of the Mabo claim, is in my electorate. There has been a lot of uncertainty about the consequences of the High Court's Mabo decision and, along with many people in the far north, I look forward to the report of the Prime Minister's special ministerial Mabo committee later this year. I believe that there is an urgent need for the Government to legislate to clarify existing and future rights to land in the interests of indigenous Australians, as well as the mining and pastoral industries; otherwise only lawyers will benefit from costly litigation.

Many people—and that includes people on the other side of the House—say that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have too much money spent on them. Fightback wanted to cut $90 million from the ATSIC budget. Obviously, such people have never travelled to remote communities in my electorate. I travel regularly amongst remote Aboriginal communities on the peninsula and in the Torres Strait, and every time I go to these communities people say to me, `All we want is the basics that the average Australian takes for granted—water, and that means clean water; housing, and that means appropriate housing designed by the people themselves; sewerage and electricity'. They are things that people in the electorates of most of the members here take for granted.

The need to improve environmental health factors has been addressed in great detail in the Federal Government's national Aboriginal health strategy, and substantial funds have been set aside to build dams and upgrade sewerage systems in remote communities. In addition, the Goss Labor Government is currently expanding services and capital equipment that were run down, if they existed at all, as a result of 32 years of neglect of these remote communities by the National Party governments in Queensland. We clearly need to do more.

It has been a long and grinding battle to get existing services into remote areas of my electorate, and if it were not for the efforts of previous State and Federal Labor members in the region the situation would be far worse. John Gayler, the former member for my seat of Leichhardt, was a strong advocate of federal intervention to counter the neglect of remote areas by the Queensland National Party government. John will be especially missed in the Torres Strait.

The former State member for Cook, Bob Scott, and his wife Jenny travelled the length and breadth of the Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait Islands for 12 years fighting the appalling neglect of the region by the National Party government. In that time Bob and Jenny earned the respect of everyone on the peninsula, regardless of their political leanings.

Steve Bredhauer, who stepped into Bob's enormous shoes as the new member for Cook, has picked up where Bob left off, with the distinct advantage of being a member of a Labor government. I am indebted to Steve, who was my campaign director, and his wife, Jan McLucas, for their guidance and support during the campaign. Thanks also go to the other Queensland State members in the Cairns area—Dr Lesley Clark; Warren Pitt; the Queensland Treasurer, Keith de Lacy; and their staffs—for their after-hours assistance during my campaign.

I also want to take this opportunity to thank my campaign secretary and my dear friend Michelle Hollywood for her tireless efforts during the campaign and Mike Bailey, the secretary of the Leichhardt FDE. Special mention also goes to my very good friend and president of the Leichhardt FDE of the ALP, John Phillips—a true believer, if ever there was one, and someone who will not allow me to deviate from Labor traditions and policies.

I also want to thank Terry O'Shane, who is known to many members of this House for his work in the trade union movement and as a leader of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. I must also thank the trade union movement for its efforts on my behalf. Industrial relations was a key issue in the campaign, and I am indebted to the trade union movement for taking the message loud and clear to its members. Special thanks go to the Public Sector Union, and I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the many dedicated public servants, both State and Federal, in my electorate who provide excellent services, often under adversity, in remote communities.

Finally, thanks to my parents: to my mother who has encouraged me throughout my legal and political career, and who is always a source of great emotional support, and to my late father, a quiet unassuming working-class man, proud of both his trade and his trade union.

Before I conclude, I must thank all the members of the ALP in Leichhardt. It was because of their support during my preselection, and their work on the ground during the campaign, that I am here today. I am extremely proud to be a member of the great Australian Labor Party in 1993. Some people in the party—and I include myself in this category—were critical of some of the policy directions of the 1980s. In retrospect, I suspect that the events in the 1980s were somewhat driven by structural changes in the world economy to which all governments and labour movements throughout the world had to respond. Overall, the accord has been a great success and Australia is much better placed to meet the external challenges than most, if not all, comparable countries.

Labor in the 1990s under Prime Minister Keating has undergone a renewal—a movement away from neo-classical remedies—which was started by the One Nation statement. I am proud to be a member of a party that is dedicated to the principles of social justice, a party with a vision for the future and the will to implement that vision—a vision that will see this Australia finally come to maturity as a completely independent nation by the year 2000 and a vision that I believe is shared by the overwhelming majority of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in this Address-in-Reply debate and join my ALP colleagues in extending my congratulations to the new honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) on his maiden speech in the House today. I look forward to joining with him and other members of the Government in what I hope will continue to be a cooperative arrangement to try to address some of Australia's major problems.

PARA.TAB: The Address-in-Reply debate has been dominated by a focus on two packages: the Governor-General's speech and the Opposition's Fightback package. Fightback was never intended to be a part of this debate, but it has been dragged in by government members misrepresenting the Opposition' policy at the election on 13 March. Without reflecting on the Governor-General, his speech was delivered to a less than interested audience in the Senate chamber. It was a lengthy speech that alphabetically unfolded what the Government saw as the steps that Australia and Australians would have to take during the term of the Keating Government.

The tragedy is that much of that package offered nothing new, nothing exciting, nothing to turn Australians on and have them believe that the Government had a sense of direction and a sense of purpose. In fact, the initiatives outlined in the Governor-General's speech were initiatives that had already been carefully plucked from the Opposition's Fightback package and in one way or another threaded in to the Governor-General's speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all of them.

—I take up the honourable member's interjection. I did not suggest that the Governor-General's speech was Fightback revisited but much of it contained the things that we had proposed, particularly in the area of industrial relations and enterprise bargaining, and ought to be adopted by the Government. By comparison, I would point out that the Fightback package has, in the debate before the House, been largely misrepresented by honourable members opposite. What the Opposition took to the people on 13 March was a package that, far from being uncertain in its course, far from making direction, was detailed, objective and honest.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that some of the frank things that we said to the people of Australia, some of that honest approach, cost us the opportunity to be in government. Nonetheless the truth remains that the people of Australia had in the Fightback package a far more detailed, purposeful, courageous vista of what would happen to the nation under us than they enjoyed from the ALP going into the 13 March poll or glimpsed in any sense in the Governor-General's Speech which we are debating this evening.

Let us look at what Fightback did in the face of the misrepresentation from those opposite. Much has been made of the goods and services tax; I suppose that is inevitable. But no-one opposite has been prepared to acknowledge the simple, unchallengeable truth that under a GST the proposal was to ensure that people who currently evaded tax were obliged to pay tax. I would have thought that was a very equitable step to take. Nor has anyone acknowledged the fact that under this package the more we consume, the more we pay. I would have thought that was an act of equity almost appealing enough to be endorsed by a socialist.

No-one has acknowledged that in an effort to redress the problems of those facing the most difficult time in Australia, the Opposition proposed, among many things, to double the family allowance and to increase pensions. At no time has there been any acknowledgment from any honourable member opposite of those areas of the Fightback package that were deliberately designed simply to advantage those Australians who are currently disadvantaged; nor has there been any recognition of those areas of the Fightback package that were deliberately designed to ensure that those who could pay did pay.

I invite honourable members to take as an example the Opposition's health package. It has been frequently misrepresented by the Government in this debate but, in reality, the Opposition's proposal for private health insurance ensured not only that those on low incomes could remain part of the existing health scheme but, even more dramatically and ignored by the Government, that those on high incomes would be obliged to pay a levy if they were not prepared to be privately insured. That is a statement of social justice and social equity put together by the Opposition and not acknowledged by the Government.

I thought that the previous speaker from the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), very clearly outlined what the Opposition has been about. Because I was in my office I only heard snippets of what he had to say, but I heard him clearly spell out what had been the policy of the coalition parties in the past in the areas of social security, immigration, health, and the introduction—as the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) knows—of the family allowance, and other social and family initiatives of which we ought to be justly proud.

Throughout this debate there has been no recognition opposite of the role of the Opposition when in government in trying to ensure that there was a social balance in Australia. In fact, if one were to listen to this debate without having any of the facts and had not had the opportunity to hear the member for Menzies, one would have presumed that all sense of social justice and all sense of compassion were vested in the ALP.That makes me angry because that is a gross misrepresentation of what this Parliament has been about and a gross misrepresentation of what my party and the coalition have been about.

We are expected to sit here and swallow this day in and day out in the face of the grim, inescapable truth that one million Australians are out of work under an ALP Government. Is that social justice? Is there any sense of apology opposite for the very policies that created and accelerated that unemployment level? Of course not. Is there any recognition in the Governor-General's speech of the fact that the attitude of this Government, particularly in the interest rate area, had caused small businesses to be crippled and unemployment rates to grow? Of course not.

Is there any recognition of the fact outlined in a report of the Bureau of Census and Statistics of 15 April 1992, which showed that a total of 41.1 per cent of Australians had a yearly income of $12,000 or less? We all ought to be ashamed of that, but particularly the Government. It has been in power for a decade; this is what it has inherited. And it parades social justice and compassion!

Is there any recognition in the Governor-General's speech of the real injustice in economic terms currently facing every rural Australian and every farmer? Let me not fall into the same trap as the majority of speakers opposite and paint the picture that the Government has done nothing. That would be quite unfair. Only in the last fortnight the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) announced a $48 million package specifically designed to help the wool industry. The Opposition, the National Farmers Federation and woolgrowers around Australia applaud that and are grateful for it. But in terms of social justice, what has it really done? It still left the burden for paying that debt squarely with woolgrowers. It has pushed off the debt from a seven-year to an eight-year repayment program, but it does not really address the real social injustice of saying to my farmers, `Because of your assets you will be denied the sort of benefits that go to people who haven't got those assets.' I find that scandalous.

I represent farmers who have large assets—rapidly falling in value, I might add—that are producing nothing. In fact, the average woolgrower will this year have a negative income of $30,000. Surely in the name of social equity he or she ought to be entitled to the same sorts of benefits as those who have an income of zero because they are unemployed.

If the Government is to claim this monopoly on social justice and compassion—which a little later I intend to further destroy—let it, if you will pardon the pun, put its money where its mouth is. Any one of my farmers could sell up and dispose of what is currently productive and, because of the world-wide uneconomic property scene, buy a house in the electorate of the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and qualify for those benefits. Is that justice? I put it to the House that obviously it is not. In the light of a 30 per cent fall in profitability across all of rural Australia—40 per cent in the case of rice growers, particularly those in northern New South Wales currently plagued by drought—I think the Government should look again at what it does for rural Australians. Certainly it did not look again in the Governor-General's speech, as has been clearly pointed out by members of the Opposition and both the Liberal and National parties in previous speeches.

I am affronted by the claim that comes from the Government benches that only people on that side of the House know what compassion is all about, leaving the impression that people on this side of the House have no real feeling for suffering people in Australia at all. If we look at the word `compassion'—which, after all, has been used so frequently by those opposite, and used in such a critical tone when directed at the Opposition—we find that the word `compassion' is derived from two Latin words, `com' and `pati' which, translated, mean `to suffer with'. There is not one parliamentarian in the Federal Parliament of Australia—Liberal, Labor, National Party or Independent—who could claim on that score in party terms to be compassionate. No one of us could claim that we are suffering with those Australians who are currently out of work or with those rural Australians who are currently facing negative incomes.

I am not suggesting that the Government has not endeavoured to be compassionate, but let no-one in this House claim to have a monopoly on compassion because, until someone in this House comes in here resembling Mother Teresa, he or she will be misleading the Parliament. How can we be compassionate with someone else's money? If any one of us chooses to dispose of our lifestyle and live the sort of lifestyle that means we totally identify with those who are suffering, then we can claim to be compassionate, but I have not been prepared to do it, and I have not had particular evidence of anyone else doing it either.

So my claim to the ALP is this: given the evidence offered by the honourable member for Menzies, which indicated that red-blooded human beings concerned for fellow Australians happen to reside on both sides of the Parliament and happen to be deeply rooted in both political philosophies espoused in this place, no one of us should claim to be compassionate unless we are prepared to dispose of all that we have. It is not possible for a party, Liberal or Labor, to claim to be compassionate with what are effectively other people's resources. All that we do in this place is try equitably to spread resources around, equitably to offer assistance.

The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) in a speech which, as I indicated, is a maiden speech he can be proud of, wanted to suggest that we know nothing about the suffering that occurs in Aboriginal communities. I think that the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs and every member of the Opposition currently on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs ought to be affronted by that as well. We know something about suffering, and it is true that in Fightback we proposed to prune that budget, but we proposed to prune all budgets because we were concerned for the direction the nation is taking and for the level of taxpayer burden currently being borne, particularly by business. So, in the interests of the total nation's future profitability, we proposed to prune budgets, were they in Aboriginal affairs or the ABC.

To the credit of the Opposition, whether we were right or wrong, we said so before the poll. We made it perfectly clear to the people of Australia what we would do and, in a decade in this place, the last two years have been the proudest two years of my life because I had a package that I could take to the people of Australia which I knew was not deceitful, which I knew had unpopular aspects to it, and which I was determined to sell.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did it in Wakefield.

—I thank the honourable member for Mayo for his interjection because the vote was a very encouraging one in Wakefield. I accept that the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) will rightly claim that I failed to sell it—and I did—but I did not deceive the people of Australia because I went to them telling them precisely what I would do. I think the Governor-General's speech fails on this count because it has not indicated what the Government will do, and precision is one thing we have certainly seen nothing of.

PARA.TAB: In responding to the Governor-General's Address-in-Reply, let me say this: there is an enormous number of mutual problems this nation faces, not all of them the fault of the Government; there is an enormous number of mutual solutions we can work out. This will always be a chamber of conflict—and so it should be—because here two political philosophies come face to face. I make no apology for the conflict that exists between the honourable member for Moreton and me on philosophic grounds. What I will not tolerate, what the people of Australia will not tolerate and what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has to appreciate is that this is a chamber of conflict, as he acknowledges, but it must never be a chamber of contempt.

My great concern in responding to the Governor-General's Address-in-Reply is that so many of the speeches delivered by honourable members opposite have poured nothing but contempt on a package that the Opposition deliberately shaped to be a package of integrity—not without fault, but at least honourably going to the people of Australia and telling them what we would do. I share with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, a compassion for all Australians. So does my party. I hope that simple sentiment is recognised by those opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The election on 13 March was a watershed moment in Australian politics which historians and political analysts in the years ahead will recognise as an event of profound importance in Australia's history. Labor's victory was an outstanding achievement if one takes an objective view of the circumstances leading up to the election campaign and analyses the way the actual campaign unfolded. Responsibility for this victory is shared by many people and many groups, but overwhelmingly credit is due to the predominant leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Despite the best efforts of the media and our conservative opponents to paint him as arrogant or out of touch, the Prime Minister demonstrated a much greater understanding and feel for the mood and desires of the electorate. Voters knew they could trust the Prime Minister and Labor, unlike their reaction to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

PARA.TAB: Since the election we have had many protestations and whinges from the Liberals, and we heard a little bit of this in the previous speech of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). They protest that they were too honest in the campaign, and that the electorate was just not prepared to accept honesty. Unfortunately, I have to disagree with this assessment. It simply was not the case that they were too honest. The fact was that they could not fully explain the impact of their package; they were not able to come out and explain in detail how their package would affect Australians. They tried to hide behind the fact that this was a great big package, and that the package had to be accepted as a whole. Australian voters understandably said, `I'm sorry, but we don't like a lot of the impacts of this package, we aren't sure about what some of it means and we are just not prepared to trust you with it'. It was because they were not prepared to accept a radical and hard right wing agenda that the Liberals had to offer that the Australian people rejected the coalition on 13 March.

There are plenty of reasons why voters should have been, and probably would have been, prepared to decide that Labor had had its chance and that the other side needed a go. The circumstances were certainly there for the Opposition to win the election, but the Liberals blew it, and they blew it very badly. They thought that if they came up with this detailed and complex agenda with dramatic changes it would capture the imagination of the people and they would say, `Yes, we will take that, it looks fantastic. It is so detailed it must be good'. The Australian people did, initially, respond quite positively to it, because at the time we were in considerable economic difficulties and they thought that any change is better than what is happening at the moment. Unfortunately, the Liberal Party was sucked in by this initial response and it thought that everything would be rosy in the garden. The electorate did not like what the Liberal Party had to offer, so it thought it would have to go out and work harder at selling it.

But once the Australian people started reading the fine print and going through what each and every element of that complex package meant, they woke up to the fact that everything was not going to be as rosy in the garden as the Leader of the Opposition was prepared to present it, and that compounded the Liberal's failure once more to truly understand the mood, desires and wants of the Australian people. Basically, Australians are a fair, easygoing and reasonable group of people. They like our egalitarian way of life, they believe in a fair go for everyone, and they want to help those who they believe need it. They do not like bludgers and whingers, and they certainly do not like people who get beyond themselves and think that they are better than others.

The Prime Minister very successfully tapped into this fundamental Australian philosophy and highlighted throughout the campaign how the Opposition's policy agenda would attack this Australian way of life. The Liberals' plan to restructure the tax base through their inequitable goods and services tax, their plan to destroy awards and minimum working conditions, their desire to wreck Medicare and their proposal to slash some $10 billion from social welfare programs all constituted a massive assault on the lifestyle, living standards and quality of life that most Australians enjoy and want to maintain.

The defeat of the coalition on 13 March means that this hard, rationalist, right wing agenda—which had been developing gradually over the past decade and came together in this one package called Fightback—has been firmly and convincingly disposed of into the dustbin of history by the Australian electorate. Australian politics has now turned the corner. Our Government, working with the whole Australian community, now has a new vista of opportunities and challenges ahead in shaping and directing our structures and institutions in a uniquely Australian way. The electors on 13 March rejected the borrowed and failed economic and social agendas from Britain or America. They upheld their belief in fairness, equity, social justice and an Australian egalitarian society.

The decade ahead will be one of considerable new economic growth for Australia, expanding trade opportunities and progressive reform and growth in employment and training. It will also give us the opportunity to improve dramatically living standards, quality of life, and educational and employment opportunities, and give legal recognition to the original owners and inhabitants of this continent—the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

The High Court decision on the Mabo claim has laid the foundation for Australia's institutions and authorities, as well as our population, to finally give the recognition and entitlements that our indigenous people demand and deserve. In his opening address in this Parliament, the Governor-General outlined the principles and policy objectives that will be followed by the Government in the next three years. As the Governor-General stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is committed to the view that the Mabo decision presents us with a genuine basis for reconciliation.
The Mabo decision goes to the core of the issue: dispossession.
The Mabo judgement is, in the Government's view, recognition of an historic truth and creates the best chance we have ever had for a nationally agreed and durable settlement.

Labor's re-election and our commitment to a fair, just and equitable society makes it absolutely critical that we respond to the Mabo decision with care and without undue haste. The High Court last year finally ended a 200-year-old legal fiction. Our duty is to accede to this new wisdom and give Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people justice at last. We should now give effect to the reasonable proposals of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to gain the equivalent of royalties for any mineral development on their lands; to have the right of veto on any further mining exploration or development on their original lands; and to see the establishment of a land acquisition fund to assist those who have been, and will continue to be, dispossessed. This is what Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people believe is a fair and reasonable response to Mabo and it is also what my party's policy, as contained in our federal platform, recommends.

PARA.TAB: The election campaign in my seat of Moreton was a tough, hard-fought contest. When one is defending a relatively slender margin of 1.8 per cent there is no room for complacency or overconfidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise the comments of the honourable member for Dawson. I am glad I have 1.8 per cent as compared with 0.2 per cent. I hope I never get down to that level. Coming into this campaign, mine was the most marginal government seat in Queensland—and I recognise that the honourable member for Dawson had the most marginal opposition seat in that State. I had experienced a very dramatic redistribution of the electorate's boundaries which resulted in a 50 per cent change in my constituency. I owe an enormous debt of gratitude to many people for the victory we gained on 13 March. I sincerely thank all of the members and supporters of the ALP, the trade union movement, the State and national offices of the Labor Party and the many hundreds of people in the community who came forward proffering assistance and support.

PARA.TAB: It is particularly heartening for me to have gained the renewed confidence of the electorate. I offer electors my ongoing commitment to be a strong, effective and hard-working representative in this Parliament and within the Government. I will pursue their views and interests vigorously and will be a vocal advocate for improved services, facilities and programs to benefit the residents of Moreton.

When one's seat is as marginal as mine, the campaign attracts the attention of many groups and individuals who seek to use the process of the election to pursue their particular causes or policies. This is part and parcel of the democratic process, and I accept and encourage it. In this election, Moreton was targeted by many organisations such as the Wilderness Society, the gun lobby, Right to Life, the nursing home industry, self-funded retirees, the AMA and many other groups across the whole political spectrum. One group, however, stands out above all others in the manner, content and ferocity of its campaign. I speak of the Housing Industry Association.

I want to make my position quite clear. I do not seek to deny any individual or group the right to pursue its legitimate political views within our democratic process. I am a strong advocate of this principle. Nor am I one to seek retribution against anyone because of the exercise of that right. However, it is clear that there are, and should be, certain conditions applicable to that process. Vigorous debate and expression of views does not include slander, massive distortions, abuse of power and position, or vicious personal innuendo and attack. The HIA was guilty of all of this in its campaign of lies, smear and personal abuse in the campaign for Moreton.

I was present in the chamber last week when my new colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) made his impressive debut in this House. I listened with interest and agreement as he outlined his views about the HIA and the way it conducted its campaign in his electorate. I can only agree with the assessment of the HIA Executive Director, Dr Ron Silberberg, as a person without integrity, honesty or intellect. Dr Silberberg was the mastermind behind his organisation's campaign and is guilty of a massive waste of his members' funds, abuse of power and position, and destruction of the effectiveness and influence of his organisation.

Within this context, I wish to take issue with the comments of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) contained in an article he authored which appeared in the Sydney Sunday Telegraph of 9 May 1993. I should also add that I advised the honourable member that I would be making these comments this evening. The honourable member for Bennelong claimed in his article that the HIA had now become the victim of a process of pay-back by the Government because it dared to campaign against Labor at the 13 March election. His article states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government is engaged in squalidly validating that old maxim of `Spoils to the victors and woe to the vanquished'.
Sections of the community which campaigned against the Labor Party are being victimised because of their pre-election stance.

The honourable member for Bennelong is once more guilty of the same distortions and misrepresentations for which the HIA has become infamous. There is no campaign of retribution or victimisation. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry campaigned actively on behalf of the coalition. The Australian Medical Association did likewise. The mining industry, the small business sector, the chairman of Woolworths, other large retailers and sectors of the banking and finance industry all advocated coalition policies and urged their support. Despite these election activities, these groups still enjoy access to the Government and participation in the policy process because they engaged in vigorous debate, but they did it honestly, openly and in an up-front manner.

PARA.TAB: The Housing Industry Association stands alone. Mr Silverberg and his Queensland director, Warwick Temby, spent millions of dollars spreading the most vicious package of propaganda I have ever seen in 21 years of active campaigning at all levels of government in Australia. Their campaign was based on a falsehood concerning the alleged impact of the subcontractor amendments to the industrial relations legislation.

It is patently clear from the HIA campaign that its organisation and its henchmen, Silverberg and Temby, are more interested in protecting the fraudulent and shonky activities of some of its members than properly advocating the best interests of the housing industry. The HIA wants to continue the practice of exploiting subcontractors and workers in the housing sector and it will use any device to advance that aim. The HIA is the rip-off merchant, and all buyers should be warned.

The legitimate and scrupulous housing industry companies who still belong to the HIA have started to understand that membership of that organisation smears them with the tawdry reputation of being sharks and shysters. Any company that still belongs to the HIA has had its reputation fatally damaged by the activities of the senior executives of the HIA. Other organisations with membership in the housing industry, such as the Master Builders Association and the Australian Confederation of Commerce and Industry, have very clearly and deliberately distanced themselves from the political activities of the HIA. They wanted no part of its campaign of lies and misrepresentations.

It is for this reason that the Government has reassessed its relationship with the HIA. This group no longer represents a credible, representative organisation within the housing industry which speaks with integrity and credibility on behalf of this vital sector of our economy. The honourable member for Bennelong is totally off the mark in his written comments and needs to be very careful in associating himself with this discredited organisation.

Housing is an important policy area for the Government and is fundamental to the achievement of our social justice objectives. I am not prepared to stand by and watch shonky rip-off merchants and their illegitimate stand-over thugs continue to exploit consumers and workers in the housing industry. This evening I announce the establishment of a housing industry watchdog to protect consumers and workers.

Any person who has been victimised or exploited by an HIA member can now have their claims pursued within the parliamentary arena. I urge any worker or subcontractor who has suffered because of shonky practices which the HIA seeks to encourage to contact me and, upon investigation of their claims, I will expose the HIA in the public arena. Any consumer who has suffered at the hands of an HIA company should contact my office and I will try to expose the company involved, if the claims are true, to prevent further victims.

TALK.START.PARA: —A rotten campaign, run by rotten people.

—Hear, hear! I agree with the honourable member for Kingston. We have always had a duty in this place to ensure that we work to protect the rights of ordinary citizens, whether they be workers, families, pensioners or others, from exploitation and victimisation. I will fulfil that responsibility to the best of my ability and seek particularly to highlight any unfair practices within the housing industry. The HIA, by its actions, has become a very determined adversary.

PARA.TAB: I conclude on the theme with which I began this address. The 1990s promise to be a decade of great progress, achievement and change for our nation and its people. I am pleased to actively participate in the policy formulation and decision making process as part of a progressive, reformist and democratic Government, advancing the interests of my constituents and my fellow citizens as we shape the future together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I enter this Address-in-Reply firstly to congratulate you on your continuing role as Deputy Speaker and Deputy Chairman of Committees. But I would also like to pass on my sincere thanks—because this Westminster system of ours is a continuing institution—to the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) on his selection as the Speaker of this House and to the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) as the Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees. It is very important that we recognise those positions because this is the house of parliamentary debate for the nation and the manner in which the appointees to those positions react is very important.

PARA.TAB: I would also take this opportunity—it may not always be the case, but we do it on this occasion—to congratulate and pay my respects to those continuing members of the Parliament who go from one parliament to another without election, namely, the Clerks, the attendants and the Hansard people. Too often we forget that we have an orchestra playing to us. Sometimes we are not always led by the beat but it is not their fault, and I think we should place that on the record.

We are here today to reply to the Governor-General's speech to the 37th Parliament, and in doing that I think we have to look at our system of constitutional monarchy. I do not in any way credit the Governor-General with the preparation of his speech because I believe—as everybody else would believe—that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is the architect of that speech. The system demonstrates, as I indicated, with the continuity of those people in office that under our system an ordinary man, a man who in his younger days was a policeman, brought up in Queensland, can aspire to and gain the office of Governor-General. That speaks a lot for a system that we sometimes attack too much; sometimes we do not take on board the positives. Australia is a constitutional monarchy and I wanted to pay my respects to those continuing elements of it.

This is the 37th Parliament and the result of a national poll on 13 March. Every three years our democratic system allows us to go to the people to let them have a say in who are to be their representatives. I am very pleased to be commencing my eighth period as a representative in this place. It was an opportunity for people to cast their votes, and they have done so. I am not going to suggest that the people of Australia got it wrong, but I wonder at times about the manner in which people were driven to the decision they made on 13 March.

It is very timely that I should speak after the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). He is known to be a trade unionist; he is a former member of the teachers union. I want to spend some time indicating the union involvement in the last election. Others would be able to add to this list but within my own division there were people from the nurses union, the teachers union, the seamen's unions, all the craft and public sector unions, who obviously and very determinedly organised against the conservatives and espoused the views of the Labor Party.

We realise, of course, that for the period in which the election is held the official duties of unionists are put on hold while they campaign for the Labor Party. Maybe this is the type of system that we have to expect. But there seems to me to be a lack of democracy in this system where the union itself is involved with many unionists who pay their fees and levies, only to see them directed to the cause and interests of a party which is against their own affiliations. So I believe that there is some need to question the democracy that prevails in that respect.

I understand that the ACTU alone spent $10 million. It has been estimated that the other unions spent another $20 million, a total expenditure of $30 million in the interests of the Labor Party. One has to ask: where is the democracy for the ordinary, normal worker and unionist? Where is their money going? Is it a payback or a pay forward for privileges yet to be received from the government of the day? In that respect it is easy enough to indicate that millions of dollars were given to union movements by this Government, by the taxpayers of Australia, leading up to that election.

When talking about the taxation burden in this country there is obviously one privileged class in Australia who are not taxpayers, and that is the union movement. It is allowed to accumulate huge amounts of tax free money to be used for or against the interests of a political situation. I believe that we should be looking at that.

Another aspect is the non-accountability of unions. A few years ago—I do not believe the situation has changed—a union, compared with a company operating in the commercial field, would be subject to the regulations of an Act which were about an inch thick: pages and pages of declarations and documents relating to accountability. The last union statement I saw filled one page; it might have gone over to the second page for the auditor's comment, but I do not know if the auditor's comment was there. I do believe that there is something wrong with a system that allows unions to participate so much in the democratic process when they are a privileged group living outside the democratic system.

The honourable member for Moreton made allegations in connection with the Housing Industry Association. I will come back to that later, but at this stage I would like to pick up his theme of lies and distortions. If the honourable member for Moreton is offended by the lies and distortions, he ought to have been on our side of the fence and seen the deliberate lies and distortions that were flashed over the media, in the press and in statements. If those statements had been made by a competitive commercial enterprise trying to get a market from the public of Australia—as the Labor Party was trying to do by getting the people's vote—it could have been charged, gaoled or fined tremendous amounts of money under the Trade Practices Act on the basis of its lies, distortions and misleading of the public. In many cases, it could have led to libel and slander charges.

I believe that this 37th Parliament should take stock of itself and realise that our political system that permits those things to happen is the laughing stock of the whole of Australia and the rest of the world. It is rather interesting that before an advertisement can be screened it is subject to vetting by an organisation called FACTS. But FACTS does not look at the facts, does not try to assess lies, distortions and facts, in advertisements. We would take a better hold of democracy and the whole electoral process—the honourable member for Moreton has suggested there were lies and distortions in respect of one set of conditions and I can certainly verify that within my electorate there were lies and distortions—if we had a look at the Electoral Act so that we were put into the mainframe and compared with Australian businesses around the country and so that what we promote as advertisements are put forward as true and factual, and not misleading as is now the case. I am not saying that people got it wrong. What I am saying is that people deserve the Government they get. They have a Labor government again for the next three years. But that Government is filled with a lot of union and minority interests and is not serving the majority interests of Australians.

The Governor-General's address referred to a heightened sense of nationhood. With all due respect, I would have thought that nationhood was predominant in the minds of the early pioneers. Nationhood was very predominant in the minds of those people who put together the Constitution of 1901. It is very interesting to consider the comments of the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, who argues that the constitutional monarchy has a very large part of republicanism built into it. So we are being served as a monarchy and a republic under the one Constitution. The Governor-General's speech suggests that only in 1993 are we getting a heightened sense of nationhood when we are the product of the Constitution of 1901. People have gone to wars to defend that nationhood. We have a younger generation of sporting, community and industry achievers. It is misleading to suggest that they do not have a heightened sense of nationhood and are not trying to build on it. It is misleading to suggest that we never had it and that we should be striving towards it.

We should not make the mistake of suggesting we have no sense of nationhood. I refer here particularly to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) when he said that we should not have an anti-British hatred born out of the Irish abuses of a century and a half ago. I have also read history, and I am not proud of what happened in Ireland in the mid-1800s during the potato famine and things like that. But to now build our nationhood on prejudices which are a century and a half old is not really looking at the facts.

There is also the argument that we should remove British ties. I put it to the House that all ties with our mother country—if you want to call it that—were lost in 1986. That was the last separation of the powers and control that the British Government and people had over us. There has been a tendency since the 1960s to diminish our trade and dependence on Britain in many ways. Britain is further divorced from us at the moment than it ever was: it is more closely allied to the European Community than it is to the Commonwealth.

The suggestion that we have to break British ties again defies history. Our whole Constitution is built on common law. Our political practice is built on Westminster practices. If the argument is that the monarchy has failed us, I would ask people within Australia to accept the suggestion that it is not the monarchy that has failed us but that we have failed the monarchy.

I give the example to this Parliament of Question Time. It has been abused. It is a Question Time without answers. It is a Question Time with prepared statements. It is a Question Time of delivering a political harangue against us or someone else. It is not a Question Time where people can try to expose and get answers to the fundamental problems facing Australia at the moment. It is being reduced to a political exercise.

Another matter that worries me is that we are having legislation introduced into this House at the moment not by the Minister responsible but by the Minister at the table, who would not know what he is reading and who has no empathy for the legislation and puts it out of context. There is no ministerial responsibility in that respect. Legislation flows from the pen of the draftsman, probably through the Minister's office, and it lands in this House for debate as though it is a foregone conclusion with the Minister taking very little interest. Very seldom do we find a Minister who takes the responsibility of listening to the debate. I pay tribute to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean): at least he is here during a relevant debate, listening to it and suffering the consequences of the Government's guillotine because he cannot reply to it.

That brings me to another point. The application of the guillotine is an abrogation of the democracy that we should be exercising in this House. Again, I say that this Parliament is failing the constitutional monarchy, it is failing the Westminster system, while we let the dictates go in one direction. If we have a look at the Ministers, the Parliamentary Secretaries, the Whips, the Speaker and the Deputy Speakers, we will see that this House is controlled by 40 per cent of people appointed by the Prime Minister. I know how the Caucus works—and I am not suggesting that they are all mates of the Prime Minister—but we have a clear-cut indication by that 40 per cent support that anything coming into this House is already predestined. Are we here as an open, democratic society for the people of Australia or to serve the purposes of a Prime Minister who is in his position because of the dictates of the union?

Other honourable members might have come across a determined effort—there was in my last election by an organisation called the Confederate Action Party—for a citizens' initiated referendum. I can understand their frustration. We are getting so many laws, the external powers provisions are being used—not by this Parliament but by the leaders of this country—and we are abrogating our responsibilities overseas. These people want a referendum cast every time a certain matter comes before the House in which there is only a 10 per cent petition for that referendum. It is hopeless to try to govern under those circumstances.

We should not be spending money looking at a republic—a dictatorship, a republic, a monarchy, a union, whatever it is called. If the country is going downhill it will be selling bananas as a third-rate country whether it is a republic, a monarchy or a dictatorship. What is required to bring us into the year 2000 is some discipline on this Parliament. I have already exposed the means by which we have moved away from the democratic principles of the Westminster system. If we were to subject our Constitution to just one change—that the government of this country in any one year should not be allowed to have other than a balanced or surplus Budget—that would be the greatest discipline on this House. It would be a discipline on expenditure. It would make sure that government expenditure was not being allocated to fringe groups and minority groups from whom support is called back at election time. It would make the government deal with a proposition in 12 months in just the same way as does any outside commercial enterprise. If we could just make that one alteration, it would be a great improvement.

We have failed the monarchy; the people of Australia have failed the monarchy. The monarchy has not failed us. We should not be spending millions of dollars on a grand new plan and scheme. Ordinary Australians are living in poverty. Those in the rural industry—the country people, the people in business out there—are living as unequal citizens of this country. They are a lower class. They are the new poor. While they continue to live like that, the Government is spending money on looking at ways and means of changing our system. A Government Minister the other morning mentioned the Titanic. This is just like shifting chairs on the Titanic. The country is going downhill. We are not addressing the matters we should be addressing. We should be addressing the problems of those people who are living in poverty, people who are pioneers and proud to be contributing to Australia, those people whose businesses are going downhill. We, as conservatives, failed those people by not getting into government, because some of them have lost that last amount of hope they held in that respect.

We have got to give some government and some hope to the families of this country. They are the de jure families that have for so many years been part of the British tradition, the European tradition and the Asian tradition that is breaking down day by day. We have as a parliament to look at the concerns of those genuinely unemployed and try to give them jobs—not make-believe jobs; not give them handouts which we cannot afford under our system. We have got to be giving those people hope.

In conclusion, I must say that since 1975 I have not experienced an election in which good people—people who were struggling, who were determined to maintain those values of the family and of business, of what is called the old WASP work ethic—have wanted to contribute of themselves to try to salvage a situation. Because they had no funds to contribute, they contributed of themselves. I am disappointed that the conservatives, while they might have won the battle, have lost the war. But I believe that we have got to put those things in the past, as we should put the Irish famine and other anti-British sentiments in the past, and say that this 37th Parliament is for all the people of Australia, not just one or two, and it behoves us together to operate for the benefit of all Australians. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this Address-in-Reply debate. It has been an interesting debate. I was listening to the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) talking about this Parliament, the performance of this Parliament and how it is judged by the Australian people. Like the member for Dawson, I have seen in operation other parliaments in other parts of the world, and I would put it to the honourable member for Dawson that we are no better or worse than many parliaments in the world. In fact, I think we are somewhat better. It is a vigorous parliament; we do debate vigorously because we passionately believe in many of the issues we argue about. It has been many years since punches were actually exchanged. It has never happened in this chamber; there has been no assault.

PARA.TAB: I recently saw a television special on the Japanese Parliament, where it took two days to vote. I saw a television report of a ruckus in the Korean Parliament. I think many of us saw what happened recently in the Italian Parliament. I make no criticism of those countries. Nevertheless I think that, on a world pendulum, the members of this Parliament might turn out to be fairly tame. Things have changed somewhat since Parliament has been televised. But a lot of my colleagues on the other side are always telling me about letters they receive from their constituents about the performance in parliament. In 10 years in this place, I have only ever received one letter from a constituent complaining about a performance in Parliament. Mr Deputy Speaker, it was during a period when I occupied the position you are now occupying. The constituent was critical of a ruling I gave—or did not give; the constituent wanted me to throw someone out. That is the only such letter.

I do not know whether the people I represent are different from other people but I am not getting an avalanche of letters. When I go out to social functions and sporting functions and go around the shopping centres in my electorate the main issue that people raise with me is not the performance of parliament. The performance of parliament is very interesting. We often hear that people come in here and they leave, saying, `They are like a bunch of schoolkids. We would not perform like that'. When I am sitting in the chair, I often look in the gallery. The average time people stay in the gallery is only 10 to 20 minutes. Many people expect us to sit here for 14 to 16 hours, diligently listening to every debate. I was in the chair during much of the debate on the Gulf War. Even at that period the average time people stayed in the gallery was only 20 minutes. That may have been because of the quality of the debate; it might have been too boring for them.

I reject the idea that this Parliament needs more discipline. I think overall we are a fairly disciplined parliament. We are not as bad as many people may think. Perhaps people in the community have too high expectations of us. We are rather an ordinary group of people but we represent in the Parliament the cross-section of the Australian community.

I am pleased to be in the Parliament again, having survived my fifth election. This, in many respects, was quite difficult in that for the first time I had about nine people standing against me. Most of them lost their deposit, which I was quite pleased about; it is everyone's democratic right to lose a deposit in a campaign. The fact that I now have the second safest seat in Australia does not mean that I will rest on my laurels. As I said to the people of Throsby, I will work as diligently as if I had the most marginal seat in Australia. It is interesting in a democratic society to see the number of people that elections bring out of the woodwork. I had one gentleman standing against me whose name was Zero Population Growth. He represented the party Australians Against Further Immigration. It was quite interesting that this person stood against me in one of the most ethnically diverse areas in Australia and thought that he could be elected.

I congratulate the new members on their first speeches and look forward to the contribution that I know they will make in this Parliament. I especially thank the people of Throsby for returning me to the House once more. Indeed, the people of the Illawarra gave the Australian Labor Party a tremendous vote of confidence.

It was interesting to hear what the honourable member for Dawson said about the involvement of the trade union movement. I am a life-long trade unionist, and every year I continue to take out my trade union ticket. I make no apology for the involvement of the trade unions: they helped me. The Australian Workers Union, the Miscellaneous Workers Union, the Seamen's Union and the various other unions contributed to my campaign. But let us not be one-eyed about this. The small business community did not contribute to my campaign, and the many people who contributed to the conservative side of Australian politics did not contribute to my campaign. McDonald's donated all their advertising space for the period of the election in the electorates of Hughes, Cunningham, Throsby and Gilmore to the Liberal candidates. I will be carefully watching the returns that all honourable members are obliged to put in and checking that McDonalds identifies those donations.

So let us not get too carried away with who the trade unions supported because big business, including the housing industry and many others, certainly did not support the Australian Labor Party. The honourable member spoke about paybacks or pay forwards; that may or may not be the case, but it is the same for those opposite. Big business would not be supporting the conservatives unless it thought it would be getting something. G.J. Coles, for example, contributed very mightily to the conservative party, and it expected to get a payback from that contribution.

The honourable member mentioned that the union movement does not have to pay taxes. Another group in this country, the churches, does not pay taxes on the property it owns. The churches do not even have to pay local rates. So if honourable members are going to come into this place and point the finger at the trade union movement, let us use all our fingers and point them fairly widely at who pays taxes and who does not. Personally, I believe that any business, whether a trade union, a church or whatever, should pay its dues, its taxes and its local rates.

I was pleased that in the Governor-General's speech—a very long speech; I make no other comment about it—that the question of Australia as a republic was raised. I make no secret of the fact that I support the movement for Australia to become a republic. I hope that the debate—there will be a debate, as there should be on this matter—will not be a divisive one, although I fear it will be. Many of my friends are British, so it is not a question, as the honourable member for Dawson says, of whether the monarchy has failed us or whether we have failed the monarchy; in many respects, it is not even a question about the monarchy. We have respect for Her Majesty the Queen as the Queen of England; there is no argument about that. I have respect for her, but it is a question of Australian identity.

People talk about the heightened feeling of Australian nationhood. We have always had a heightened feeling of Australian nationhood. Last night I attended a movie in the auditorium upstairs, and a 1930s newsreel was shown. It was filmed on an Australia Day in either 1936 or 1937, and it said Australia was British and always would be British. Everyone present laughed. We are not British: we are Australian. We are a multicultural society, but we are Australian.

I lived in Britain for 11 years. I have two university degrees from British universities. Many of my friends are British. I go to Britain every second year—some say every year—because many of my friends are still there. Many of my formative years were spent at university in Britain. I am very proud of the two degrees that I hold from British universities, including one from the London School of Economics and Political Science.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going home?
—No. I am not anti-British—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—You like the trains too, don't you?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I like the trains; I like many things about Britain. But we are talking about Australia and its sense of identity. People talk about the framers of the Constitution and those who went to war. No-one is denying the contribution that they made or is denying their loyalty. We are saying that we are a constantly evolving society. The Australia of 1900 was very different from the Australia of 1800, and it will be a very different Australia in the year 2000. In this talk about a republic we are trying to reflect Australia as it currently is. I think that is the important issue. Australia is not a static society. I resent immensely people who suddenly say that Australia will become a dictatorship. Look at the republics in the world. Some of the most democratic societies in the world are republics. Why should it be any different in Australia? It will not be a dictatorship; it will be a republic. Whether the head of state is a president or whatever other name we like to call that person, it does not concern me greatly. But it does concern me that that person be Australian and reflect Australian values. That is the important issue.

PARA.TAB: No one in this chamber or in our society has a monopoly on loyalty. I do not question the loyalty of those who oppose Australia becoming a republic. It does seem strange to me when they are touting how Australian they are that they want to pay allegiance to the head of another country, but I never question their loyalty. However, I resent it immensely when people question my loyalty for putting the view, as an Australian, that what I stand for is an Australia with an Australian head of state. I make the point that no one in this chamber or in the wider community has a monopoly on loyalty. We are and will continue to be an evolving society, and that is good. It is something that as a republic we would reflect.

Much has been said in this debate about industrial relations. Representing, as I do, one of the great industrial centres of Australia, the Port Kembla area, including the port of Kembla, I have a vital interest in trade union matters. One of the major reasons why I believe the Opposition was rejected in the recent elections was the chaos it promised with its industrial relations proposals. To appease its rural supporters it targeted the waterfront. I have absolutely no doubt that if the conservatives had won at the last election they would have engaged in an almighty confrontation on the waterfront. I have absolutely no doubt they would have had the troops out on the waterfront—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—You say, `Rubbish!', but I will tell you why I believe it. I said to my people at Port Kembla that if the conservatives win they have to prove their credentials. One of the credentials they want to prove concerns this fallacy that they go on with about the waterfront. They would have engineered an almighty blue on the waterfront and had the troops in. I have no doubt that they would have got in some of their thugs with a few greased pick handles, and there would have been mayhem on the waterfront. It always amazes me that people talk about the waterfront as though there have been no changes there over the last few years. No other area has been subjected to greater change than the waterfront. If anyone doubts that, I suggest that they read the report from the House of Representatives Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee—an all-party report—entitled Warehouse to wharf. It deals with the various interlocking changes on the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: While the Victorian Kennett Government's so-called industrial relations reforms have understandably aroused controversy, a less well-known but equally significant struggle over workers' rights has been taking place in New South Wales. In September 1992, a small, non-violent picket at an obscure sewage treatment plant at Bombo, near Kiama on the south coast of New South Wales, resulted in criminal and quasi-criminal charges being laid against two union leaders. That raised questions about the right of unionists to peacefully picket during industrial disputes in New South Wales.
