In New South Wales, industrial relations has gone back to an obscure Act introduced in 1900—known as the Watching and Besetting Act. That has very serious ramifications, and not only for the trade union movement. In the past, trade union disputes have been dealt with in industrial relations courts. Now we have industrial disputes in New South Wales being taken to the criminal courts.

It is a basic right of any trade unionist or worker to picket. There is no law on any statute book in Australia that says that it is illegal for a worker to picket. As someone who has been on many pickets and involved in many demonstrations, I find the lack of a clearly defined right to peacefully protest in New South Wales of concern to all community groups and individuals. The capacity for the misuse and abuse of the considerable penal powers accumulated by the State, which can be used against any display of peaceful dissent, is disturbing.

It is disturbing because the Fahey Government, in using this obscure Watching and Besetting industrial relations Act, can virtually accuse someone found looking at someone else of a criminal offence. The legislation could be applied to a mother's union or a conservation group or anyone walking down the street—or it could be applied to those environmentalists who are always protesting about trees being cut down. If they were looking at a tree that was about to be cut down, then under the law of New South Wales they could be charged with a criminal offence.

So great is the Fahey Government's hatred of the trade union movement that it will go to any lengths to make criminals out of trade unionists who going about their lawful and rightful duties. That is what it amounts to: the manic hatred that the conservatives—the people represented on the other side of this House, not that there are many of them here—have for the trade union movement. That is one of the reasons why the conservatives lost the last election. Trade unionists were not going to subject themselves to what they have seen happening in Victoria and New South Wales. They have seen it in Victoria and New South Wales and they are not going to see it happening throughout Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the 11th Address-in-Reply that I have either participated in or been witness to in this place. I have to say that, particularly over the past few years, nothing has changed from the point of view of the Government. We still have tragically high unemployment, falling job vacancies, a balance of payments blow-out, a record Budget deficit, foreign debt increasing at the rate of knots, depressed retail figures, and an unending number of small business and farm bankruptcies.

PARA.TAB: Nothing changed on 13 March, except in a personal sense for members of the Government. Nothing changed for the nation, and nothing will change. There is an air of complacency, even smugness, but certainly indecision about this newly returned Labor Government. There is no will for urgent change. There is no reform agenda. We see the Government more or less on automatic pilot. The Government is seemingly immune to the devastation that 10 years of its administration has brought the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why the people voted for us.

—The honourable member for Throsby towards the end of his own contribution, and now by way of interjection, tries to explain to the Opposition why the election result was what it was. The fact is that the only reason the Government was returned to office was because of its unrelenting campaign of lies and deceptions. Everything—whether it be industrial relations, health policy or tax reform—was utterly distorted by the Government, without shame or honour. Make no mistake; we have got a—
—You've got another 20 years in opposition. You have no respect for democracy.

—The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services is proud of the role he played in the spreading of disinformation and distortion of truth. We have piles of information showing the outright fraudulent, deliberate lies and deceptions spread by individual members of the Government.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member has asserted that I was involved in some sort of campaign of lies and distortions. That is nonsense. The election was won because the people of Australia supported the party on the basis of its policies.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! There was no specific charge against the honourable member as an individual. There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Parliamentary Secretary or any of his colleagues believe that they have a mandate from the Australian electorate, let them get out there and visit those electorates. Do any of them, particularly the Ministers, ever leave their protected environment? From whom does the Government receive advice? Where does it get its reassurance that it is properly managing this country? Is it from today's unemployment figures? Do they reassure the Government? Does it think it has done nothing wrong?

PARA.TAB: The Government has been in power for 10 years. From 1983 until the late 1980s, every government Minister—and there was no greater offender than the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) himself, during his term as Treasurer—blamed the Fraser-Anthony Government for anything and everything that was wrong with the nation. For years and years the Government has played that game. It cannot hide behind that coward's shield any longer because it has held the reins of power for an uninterrupted 10 years. Everything about the nation's economy today, apart from the areas shaped by external influences, is entirely the responsibility of the Government.

I do not want to hear any of the mealy-mouthed cliches that are trotted out, particularly by a number of the ideologically narrow new members, about how the Labor Party has benefited the nation. I advise the Government to go and mix with the people. Who is giving the Government its advice? It is certainly not coming from practical small business people, working to keep their doors open. It is certainly not coming from the farmers, struggling to stay on the land. The Government certainly does not take advice from one income families, who are hit by a taxation system that discriminates against them. It certainly does not take advice from our exporters, weighed down with an array of costs, charges and waterfront inefficiencies that few other of their competitors have to suffer. The Government simply cannot escape its responsibilities.

I find it ironic, even tragic, that at a time when the Prime Minister is asking us to redefine our national identity—as if we do not know what it is already—and is talking about a new nationalism and the creation of a separate identity in our immediate part of the world, that he also speaks of newborn sovereignty. This nation does not have any sovereignty. We surrendered that by way of our foreign debt. What sovereignty does this nation have? We are totally in hock to international bankers. They can call in government and private sector borrowings practically at will.

This Government is talking about an independent nation. We have never been so dependent on foreign powers, not on foreign nations but instead on international banking organisations. The Government has sold out this nation's independence and sovereignty and tried to cover it up with a totally manipulated, cynical discussion about the republic. When we try to explain to people what a net foreign debt of $170 billion but escalating really means, they say—

TALK.START.PARA: —Gross it is, over $200 million.

—The honourable member for Bradfield reminds me that gross it is, over $200 million. When we try to explain it, people say, `It is not my debt. It is of no concern to me'. The debt is roughly divided evenly between private and public sectors, but everybody in Australia pays it. If the debt has been incurred by a public utility, a statutory authority or a government, then people pay for it in higher costs and charges and higher taxes. The Government has to service its debt. In fact, 20 per cent of the Victorian Budget is in interest repayments alone for its debt. So it is paid for by water rates, land taxes and stamp duties.

PARA.TAB: If the private sector has incurred the debt, it is paid for by higher prices. If Elders has a mammoth foreign debt—which we know it does—it is paid for by higher beer prices. People in Australia cannot delude themselves that they are not paying through the nose for the foreign debt—a foreign debt incurred, firstly, by big spending governments and, secondly, by private companies. During the high interest rate period—between 1988 and 1991—some companies had no choice but to seek offshore borrowings.

There is another reason that I want to talk about sovereignty. This nation's sovereignty has been greatly compromised by the influence minority and unrepresentative groups often have over the Government. Let us take the timber industry, which I know well, given that my electorate of East Gippsland is heavily dependent on this industry. The Industry Commission has just put out a draft report on what is needed to make the timber industry in Australia an efficient and important industry, economically as well as socially. It has recommended three things, the first being resource security. This Government will not give resource security. We have introduced a private member's Bill which gives the framework, the precedent, upon which resource security can be given so as to provide the certainty of investment necessary to attract funding and expansion into the timber industry.

Secondly, the report recommends that export controls be abolished. Export controls are a nonsense. Maintaining the balance, the sustainable harvest, should be at the point of entry into the forest. Export controls should not be used over, say, woodchips as a substitute for environmental policy. It is an absolute nonsense to have export controls retained by the Commonwealth. All it does is allow the Commonwealth to override a State which it believes, for political purposes, has not satisfied the extremist Green lobby.

Thirdly, the report talks about corporatisation or privatisation of the States various forestry commissions and forest holdings, which also appeals to me enormously. We have enormous wastage in East Gippsland because the timber is just lying on the forest floor, which is extremely wasteful. It is either being burnt or is rotting. It presents a major fire hazard for Gippsland and the south-east corner of New South Wales. This timber could easily be earning income for a number of small towns in East Gippsland that are slowly but surely dying. That is one example of how the sovereignty of this nation has been compromised. I also worry about the fact that 26 per cent of Australia's total area is locked up against exploration and mining or subject to limited access restrictions, which is up 63 per cent since 1983 when Labor came to power.

Why do we not establish some sovereignty, some independence and some true nationalism in real terms before the Government pursues, for its own political purposes, a minimalist position whereby the name Governor-General is substituted by the name President. There are far more pressing issues that have to do with our future as a nation than the mere tampering with titles, which the Prime Minister wants us to believe is all he seeks. But there is a very long way to go on that debate. I am sure the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) agrees with me that over a period the true agenda of the Prime Minister and his party will be revealed.

If those opposite believe that the Prime Minister only wants to change the name Governor-General to President, then they have learnt nothing over the last 10 years. If they do not think he is operating to a grand plan, the big picture as he states, or the self-style Placido Domingo of Australian politics, they have rocks in their head. If the Prime Minister thinks that the coalition parties will sit idly by and surrender to him the future of this nation and all of its values and traditions, then he has another think coming.

It is no wonder that he appeals for bipartisanship on this issue, but only now. Where has this appeal for bipartisanship on the issue of the republic been over the last six months or so? It is only now, as he is beginning to realise the dimensions of the problem that lies ahead of him, that he seeks bipartisanship. The Prime Minister will never seek bipartisanship unless he wants us to get him out of a hole that he has dug for himself.

In the time remaining to me, I wish to turn more specifically to the rural communities in Australia, which on so many fronts are becoming increasingly disenfranchised. Rural Australia is through with cheap talk from governments. It now faces an attack on its very existence, and it wants action; it will not settle for anything less. It has good reason to be tired of governments.

The enduring agony of the bush has not arrived overnight. The compounding crises have been piled on top of one another in recent years. Long before anyone had heard of phrases such as structural adjustment, asset price collapses, productivity growth and international competitiveness, rural businesses, farms and country towns had been fighting problems year in year out for decades in the middle of the international ring. They were on the toughest arena imaginable. Our exporters, particularly farmers, have had little or no protection to assist them to deal on a corrupted trade market. So they, more than anyone, have had to engage, as the Government so cutely terms it, in structural adjustment and all of that. Faced with collapsing terms of trade, farmers did not shelter behind protection and assistance. They absorbed higher costs and went for improved productivity when no-one else had even considered the option, and well before economic commentators even started using the term.

When interest rates hit the roof, the rural landscape suffered terribly—and it still does. For those who lived in rural towns there was no easy alternative. They could not shop at another mall around the corner or to go to some other service just down the street. Shops, machinery businesses and daily services all just disappeared. Today we are trying to fight for policies to feed into the public arena, to galvanise the Australian public and the Labor Government so that they will take action to help the rural community.

Frankly, it is an unbelievable situation that we have to fight for these initiatives. Rural Australia is not a charity; it is an asset. It has powered economic growth for a century, and will continue to do so. A burgeoning regional economy drawing on a commodities market which fuels demand in the cities will always run like a backbone through the national economy. Some might talk about small, smart technology and intensive metropolitan businesses and point to the nation's economic salvation, but the reality of the Australian future will be forged in the traditional arena of the Australian countryside. That is where the main action will be. That is where it has always been and always will be into the future of Australia.

We need policies for the times. We have to work harder than ever before to keep rural communities alive as viable, going concerns so that they can be revitalised and pull the nation out of recession. This Parliament has the abiding responsibility to resist efforts by those who would pull the pin on the rural economy at the first sign of trouble.

This House can be assured that the National Party, together with its Liberal Party colleagues, will fight those who think that the community does not want the countryside to survive. We have to stand by rural and regional Australia in its darkest hours. If Canberra has no passion for the countryside, the wider community does, and if the Labor Government has no will to build a future for the agricultural sector, then the National Party has enough to go around for everyone else.

There is no greater example of the Government's failing of the rural sector than its policies in regard to wool. Last night the industry was canvassed at great length on the Wool Realisation Commission legislation. A number of my colleagues set out in great detail the irresponsibility and misjudgments on the part of the Government over the past few years that led to the collapse of the floor price, and its inaction following the collapse.

The Government failed the woolgrowers of Australia in a number of ways. Firstly, it left the wool tax at 8.5 per cent. It should have suspended the 4.5 per cent debt repayment part of the wool tax. I understand that will only raise $100 million, and there is enough of the stockpile sales to cover the extra finance, on top of the $120 million already in hand, to cover the interest on the debt and storage charges. Secondly, the Government should have extended the Australian Wool Realisation Commission debt repayment for more than 12 months. The Government should not have put a time limit on the repayment schedule so that it would not matter whether it took five, 10 or 15 years to repay the debt. We have to signal to wool buyers that there will not be a fire sale so that the Wool Realisation Commission can meet its debt repayment schedule.

We published the debt repayment schedule. Is not that a brilliant strategy—publish the debt repayment schedule so that all the buyers out there know each year how much money the Wool Realisation Commission has to pay to the Government and how desperate the commission will be to sell off part of the stockpile. That is part of the economic genius of this Government. We say that instead of just delaying the debt repayment for 12 months as the Government has done—and all that does is assure buyers that there will not be a fire sale for the next 12 months—we should have made it abundantly clear that the Wool Realisation Commission would not be pressured into a fire sale in the foreseeable future. So that was a serious failure.

The third serious failure in regard to policy for woolgrowers was that the Government did not offer household support as a welfare payment to those farmers who were struggling but who wanted to remain on the land. All the Government offers is wholesale support which, as a loan, must be repaid. Rural Australia is on its knees. It needs a Government that understands the state of the rural economy and is determined to do something about it. I am afraid that in both cases the Government fails the test.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Mr Speaker will ascertain when it will meet his Excellency the Governor-General's convenience to receive the Address-in-Reply, and he will notify honourable members accordingly.
Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mr Bilney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill is to authorise a contribution by Australia of $350 million to the 10th replenishment of the International Development Association. Australia has contributed to the previous nine IDA replenishments, the last being for $382.5 million in 1990.

PARA.TAB: The International Development Association is a specialist United Nations agency affiliated with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, that is the World Bank, and the IDA is the World Bank's concessional lending arm. It aims to provide soft loans for major public development and infrastructure projects focussing on the poorest members of the association in the international community. Loan recipients have annual per capita GNPs of less than $US740.The IDA is funded by 22 economically advanced countries, including the United States, Japan, and most of the European Community. In the 10th replenishment the IDA will raise some $US18 billion from these donors together with another $US4 billion in loan repayments. Australia has been a member since the IDA's foundation in 1960. The International Development Association Act 1960 authorised the first Australian contribution and further contributions have been authorised by subsequent Acts passed every three years.

In the explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill the draw downs for the next three financial years are estimated at $9.4 million, $28.3 million, and $47 million respectively. This leaves some $265.3 million to be spent in the five to seven years thereafter, as I understand it. It must be noted that these figures could change because of fluctuations in exchange rates.

Australia's contribution under this Bill will amount to about 1.46 per cent of IDA donor contributions, as opposed to 1.99 per cent in 1990. I understand the reasons for the reduction in that percentage and the Opposition has no criticism of that, for the Opposition supports the Bill. The IDA in our view is a key contributor to development in the poorest countries. It provides support for major public infrastructure projects. IDA loans are provided to governments only. As such, IDA loans are normally accompanied by policy dialogue with recipient countries and this dialogue can be of considerable influence in engendering reform in the economic policies of recipient countries, particularly in Africa. Australian participation, therefore, gives Australia some voice in this process.

The contributions are, together with food aid, the major contributions that Australia makes to the poorer developing countries. This is frequently cited, of course, as an excuse for not giving more to low income countries. This line, in my view, is not seen as credible in the eyes of potential recipient countries and coalition policy has in fact been to favour increased priority for bilateral aid which achieves developmental benefits that are better targeted at specifically Australian objectives.

The Opposition's major concern with this Bill revolves around its implications for bilateral aid programs, namely the inflexibility that is brought to bear within a constrained budget and the extent to which it commits future governments over the next eight to 10 years. The proposed contributions have no direct implications for the overall budget as the amounts are normally found within the overall aid program. But in recent years the impact of the cuts in the global aid budget has fallen principally on the bilateral programs. This has happened because priority under this Government has been given to multilateral institutions such as the IDA.

The commitments set out in the Bill do have the potential to lock Australia into such a pattern for the next eight to 10 years. Without reference to the forward estimates it is difficult to be sure of the precise quantitative effects of the commitments proposed in the Bill. It is clear, however, that it could reduce the ability of future governments within current budgetary restraints to redress the imbalance in the current global budget in favour of multilateral programs by giving increased priority to bilateral aid, food aid, and support for non-government organisations.

It is interesting to note that for IDA-10 the donors have set priorities which include increasing support for programs that are directly poverty related, support for programs for women, and emphasis on environmental sustainability. These were all points upon which the Opposition touched in debate on Australia's contribution in the last contributions to the IDA, that is, IDA-9. The key priority to reflect on for IDA-10 is the greater monitoring of recipient governments' non-development expenditures as a proportion of public spending to ensure that IDA loans are not de facto supporting, in particular, military programs.

The Opposition notes that the Government has taken up with the World Bank criticisms of IDA programs, in particular the focus of some programs and the high administrative costs of the World Bank. We agree that the Government should have done this and we would wish to see such vigilance continue. In the meantime overall, notwithstanding that criticism and particularly noting the changed priorities that have been set here, we are in favour of the Bill, as I indicated.

There are some who put forward a philosophic view to the contrary about the IDA. My concerns have generally revolved around unnecessary expenditure and some of the priorities not being correct. In this instance I congratulate the Government on its constraints on the aid budget which I assume, rather than a change of priorities, has necessitated a lesser percentage in terms of donor contributions, thus ensuring a change in priorities. The Government has taken up the latter point that I mentioned, namely, the high administrative costs that seem to be evident within the World Bank. As I say, the Opposition will not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill the Australian Parliament seems set to contribute another $350 million to an agency of the World Bank. This is just one of the many regular contributions that Australia makes to a variety of international financial institutions—the IFIs, as they are known—every year. We continue to make these contributions in a thoughtless way without giving serious consideration to the effectiveness of the assistance dispensed by these bodies or whether Australia's interests are best served by making these contributions. In these matters, we tend to blindly follow the international herd. It should be noted, however, that the contrast with the situation in the United States at present should be something of which we take some cognisance.

PARA.TAB: The United States Congress currently has before it a Bill very similar to this one, which provides for a contribution to the International Development Association by the United States of some $US1.25 billion. That Bill is the subject of furious debate in the United States and, according to some reports, the Bill is unlikely to pass the United States Congress in its present form.

The reason for this furious debate, of the sort that we never see here in Australia, is that there is a growing realisation in the US that the International Development Association and its fellow members in the World Bank group are ineffective in realising their goals and are extremely inefficient in their own internal operations. Indeed, it was pleasing to see some long overdue recognition of this fact in the second reading speech of the Minister for Development Co-operation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney). The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of criticisms have been levelled at the World Bank over the last few years, some with justification.

That is a bit of an understatement. He went on to detail some of those problems and to claim that the Australian Government was putting pressure on the World Bank to lift its game on a number of different issues. However, what the Minister had to say in his second reading speech seriously understates the case against the World Bank and some of the other international financial institutions to which Australia regularly contributes. Indeed, if one is looking for some indicators for the World Bank's poor performance we need look no further than the annual report to the Parliament of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) entitled Australia and the World Bank.

PARA.TAB: Although this is a regular report which tends to be a bit of a whitewash, the most recent one notes a sharp decline in the internal administrative efficiency of the World Bank, particularly in the case of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Development Assoication. The report notes that the loan and investment commitments per unit of administrative expenditure for the IBRD and the IDA have fallen from 100 in the base year of 1987 to only 85 in 1992. The report also notes a significant decline in World Bank project performance. The number of projects judged satisfactory has declined from an average of 72 per cent between 1987 and 1989 to only around 63 per cent in 1990 and 1991.

The Government is forever telling us in its reports that it is lobbying for improvements in the performance of the World Bank both in its project lending and in its own internal operations, but in all the years that the Government has been saying this there has been no visible improvement in the performance of the World Bank group—in fact, quite the opposite has occurred. This should hardly be surprising given the fact that the United States has had similar difficulties in bringing pressure to bear on the World Bank group, despite the fact that it is one of the biggest single shareholders with influence that far exceeds that of Australia in this context.

The simple fact is that it is almost impossible for member countries to exert influence over the World Bank group and similar bodies because these institutions have their own capital with which they largely determine their own budgets. Organisations like the United Nations, the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs and the OECD by contrast have no funds of their own and are dependent on their member countries to supply them with a budget each year which is carefully scrutinised and voted on by member countries. But with the World Bank and similar bodies the shareholders make commitments of enormous amounts of capital every five years or so and thereby forsake any effective influence over these bodies. Let me remind the House that Australia is one of those shareholders. To illustrate the point I have been making, I would like to have incorporated in Hansard a table from the Economist called `The Pay and Perks Guide'.

TALK.START.PARA: —This table compares the pay, perks and some administrative quirks of the various international financial institutions—namely, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development—
—Good point.

—And I will make the point a little bit in depth, too, with your permission, Mr Speaker. This table compares the pay, perks and some administrative quirks of those institutions with those found in other international organisations—namely, the United Nations, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the GATT. The table clearly shows the lack of discipline on the part of the international financial institutions compared with other international organisations within which Australia also plays a role and to which Australia obviously provides funds. It shows that the international financial institutions are better remunerated, less efficient, travel first or business class instead of economy and have the most lavish offices of all these international organisations.

PARA.TAB: More importantly, the table shows that the only way in which the World Bank group might be disciplined is if shareholder countries were to tie their regular contributions to the group's capital to the performance of its various agencies. Of course, Australia rather stupidly does exactly the opposite of this. The Australian Government maintains that we must remain a substantial contributor to the bank if we are to have any influence—which of course ensures that we have absolutely no influence, because the World Bank knows that, no matter how abysmal its performance is, it will still get our regular contribution of capital. The Government puts forward this entirely circular and ridiculous argument that we should contribute to the World Bank because that will give us some influence over our contribution. The logic of that argument is that the more abysmally the World Bank group performs the more money we should give it so that we can better influence the bank's operations.

The fact of the matter is that the World Bank's performance will continue to be unsatisfactory until we tie our contributions of capital directly to the performance of the World Bank group. That means scaling down or withholding our contribution at times until the World Bank group gets its house in order. It is worth recalling that it was only when Western governments began pulling out of UNESCO that that organisation began to behave in a half-decent way. Prior to that, UNESCO was an international disgrace that thumbed its nose at the Western governments which paid for it.

The lack of discipline on the various international financial institutions was stunningly illustrated by the recent controversy over the extravagance of the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to which Australia also contributes. When the EBRD Bill was debated in this place in 1990, I warned that under the presidency of Mr Jacques Attali the EBRD would become a pleasure palace for international bureaucrats at the expense of Australian taxpayers, amongst others. Sure enough, that is exactly what has happened, but to the extent that no Australian taxpayer could have ever dreamed of in their worst nightmares.

In its first few years of operation the EBRD managed to spend twice as much on its own offices and staff than it spent on aid to eastern Europe, the reason for its creation. Over $120 million alone has been spent on furnishing and equipping its palatial offices in London. This included the purchasing of some 600 desks at around $1,000 each, designed by the architect Norman Foster. The offices are noted for their extensive use of marble which involved, at one stage, spending #750,000 replacing textured marble panels in the bank's foyer with smooth marble, apparently because the original marble panels were judged to be unsatisfactory. Other examples of extravagance include the #52,000 that was spent on the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Christmas party last December—some knees-up that must have been—and the #600,000 spent on hiring private jets for Mr Attali in 1992 alone.

There has been an enormous controversy about this extravagance in Europe and the United States. Republican and Democrat members of the US Congress have rightly been in uproar about this expenditure. But we do not hear a peep out of honourable members and senators who come into this place year after year to approve Australia's contributions to these organisations. Unless people read the nether regions of the Australian Financial Review with its reports taken from the wire services, no-one would ever hear about this controversy in Australia.

It should be noted that the Assistant Treasurer, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), recently addressed the annual general meeting of the EBRD at the height of this controversy overseas. The Assistant Treasurer devoted four paragraphs of his five-page speech to the question of the EBRD's excesses. The strongest words that I could find in that speech were in the comment that:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia strongly supports the need for restraint in the bank's administrative and capital expenditure.

While it is necessary to observe all the usual diplomatic niceties, the Assistant Treasurer must realise that we need to be much more forthright than this in our criticisms of these bodies if we are not to be taken wholly for granted by these international bureaucrats. The Assistant Treasurer had an obligation to Australian taxpayers to deliver a stinging rebuke to the bank for its waste and extravagance. Instead, the Assistant Treasurer called on the bank `to identify more accurately the bank's core role'. He went on to say, `then and only then will . . . our critics be silenced'. Think about that. In saying this, he was effectively putting himself on the side of the bank—the EBRD—rather than representing the interests of Australian taxpayers to that body.

PARA.TAB: The Assistant Treasurer should have fronted up at that meeting and announced that Australia would no longer contribute to this extravagant body. That would have been a speech with real impact. In fact, if the Assistant Treasurer had wanted to be less diplomatic, he could have quoted what Stephen Bayley, the creator of London's Design Museum, had to say about the bank in the arts and architecture section of the European. Mr Bayley said:

SPEECH.PARA: The entire bank is an error of taste . . . a marvellously absurd Potemkin village, disguising a deeper absurdity: the hilarious misfit of glamorous and self-important French bureaucracy in London . . .
He went on to observe, in reference to Mr Attali:

French socialists have never assumed that it was necessary to be badly dressed, ill-fed—or even to be much of a socialist. In all its incongruous splendour, the EBRD is a perfect symbol of that conceit.

The extravagance of the EBRD has direct implications for the World Bank agencies, such as the International Development Association, in that there is a knock-on effect from all this lavishness. The other IFIs get jealous when they see the EBRD getting better pay and perks than they are and so they demand the same for themselves. It is the fat cat relativity argument that we all know so well.

PARA.TAB: This was most vividly illustrated by the effect of Mr Attali's unprecedented salary on the IMF and the World Bank. Mr Attali negotiated a salary of $US290,000 when he was appointed president of the EBRD in 1991. The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Mr Michael Camdessus, was at the time receiving only $US225,000, so he had to demand a pay rise which took him to $US285,000. Of course, this meant that the World Bank president, Mr Lewis Preston, automatically received a similar increase.

While these salaries may not seem excessive at first glance, the Economist points out that when account is taken of their tax-free status and the fact that Mr Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the US Federal Reserve Board receives only $US134,000 for his trouble, then we can see that we have some very well paid people indeed working for these organisations.

It should also be remembered that the generosity of these executive salaries inevitably flows on to the senior staff in these bodies who enjoy equally attractive conditions of employment. The propensity of World Bank and IMF staff to use Concorde and other forms of first-class air travel is well known, indeed notorious. An infamous World Bank internal staff memo of a few years ago claimed that a proposal by the director of the World Bank's health service that staff should travel business class would lead to an increase in what was called `post-mission travel-induced strokes'. I should not laugh and I apologise for doing so, but such is the delicate nature of World Bank staff.

In fact, one could very easily come to the conclusion that the Government's enthusiasm for its contributions to these bodies is really only a reflection of the federal bureaucracy's enthusiasm for working for them. Postings with the IFIs are highly coveted among senior bureaucrats in Treasury and elsewhere. So it is not surprising that they might seek to con the Government into taking on a much bigger role in these bodies than our national interest justifies. This is also why it is futile to have federal bureaucrats review the performance of these organisations and participation within them, since they are effectively being asked to review their own future career prospects in some cases.

It is about time that Australia began to take its role in these bodies seriously, instead of turning our contributions to international financial institutions into an annual ritual with little or no debate. It is difficult to think of an area of government expenditure which receives as little scrutiny as our contributions to these organisations. If we were seriously concerned with assisting eastern Europe, for example, we would carefully evaluate the options available and act on them, instead of handing over money willy-nilly to an egotistical French bureaucrat to lavish on himself and his staff. Any such examination would probably come to the conclusion that the cause of development around the world is best met by private sector capital and not by the funds dispensed by the multilateral development banks.

Australian taxpayers should be up in arms about what is being done with their money and in their name by these organisations with the connivance of not just this Government, but successive Australian governments. The fact that they are not is a reflection of the dereliction of duty that occurs in this place every time one of these Bills comes up for debate.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Having listened to the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), I must say that—
—You're persuaded.

—No, I am not. But it is difficult to see from his speech that the Opposition is in fact supporting the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill. I am glad to see that it is, because I believe we have a duty, as a responsible international citizen, to contribute to the multilateral development organisations—not least the IDA, which is arguably amongst the most worthy of those institutions.

PARA.TAB: I will not restate the arguments which were so ably put by the shadow Minister for foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), but in the two minutes left to me I want to answer some of the criticisms that were made by the honourable member for Curtin. Most of those criticisms related to the EBRD. We have been rather more critical, and have taken rather more stern action, in respect of its excesses—and excesses there have been—than one would gather from the honourable member's speech.

For example, in the case of the notorious Christmas party to which the honourable member referred, our own director serving on the bank returned his invitation to the Christmas party, wrote to the president of the bank, refused to attend and was most critical of the waste and squandering of money that he saw involved in it. I received a private letter from him to that effect which also related some other action which was taken in respect of that.

I do not want to quarrel with the purposes for which the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development was set up. I believe they are widely supported in this House and in this country. The democratisation of eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union seems to me to be one of the most fundamental objectives we can pursue in the West and I thoroughly support it, as does the Government.

So far as the criticisms of the World Bank are concerned, it is also the case that we have taken very direct action to see those administrative procedures improve. The so-called Wappenhans report, Effective implementation: key to development impact, which the bank commissioned in September 1992, pointed to a number of ways in which evaluation of projects could be improved to lead to a greater success rate in implementing bank projects. We will be following up those recommendations and we are pressing, through the executive board, for rapid implementation of the key recommendations of that report. In particular, we are encouraging a greater emphasis on measures to promote quality project preparation and implementation.

We have asked that that report and the bank's response to the recommendations be made public and that benchmarks be identified against which donors can monitor the report's implementation. So far as the pay and perks to which the honourable member referred are concerned, again, that is something towards which we have taken a stern attitude. We voted against the recommended increase in salaries, along with the United States of America and Canada—
