DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mr Tickner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, it was somewhat remiss of me when I was speaking this morning presenting a report of an overseas delegation when you were in the chair to have failed to offer you my congratulations on attaining your high office. I would like to correct that oversight, and do so now.

PARA.TAB: I rise to take part in the second reading debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1993. This Bill seeks to make changes to one of the most significant pieces of legislation which specifically affects the lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The House is also, of course, considering the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1993.

This is the first time that I have spoken in these areas in the House in my new capacity as shadow Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. I come to the portfolio with some background and a keen interest in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, having served as the Deputy Chairman in the last parliament on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and as a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. As a result of these positions and interests I have had the opportunity to travel widely within Australia and recognise the enormity of some of the tasks and problems that lie ahead.

As a demonstration of the coalition's support for the reconciliation process, it is my intention, in addition to my new responsibilities as the shadow Minister, to continue as the coalition's representative on the reconciliation council. We are pleased to see also, in true cross-party spirit, that Senator Kernot has also chosen to remain on the council, in spite of her own added responsibilities as Leader of the Australian Democrats, and we are obviously pleased to welcome that move on her part. Therefore both the major non-government parties on the council have upgraded their representation on the reconciliation council.

Obviously this House will be occupied in the coming months with issues arising from matters such as the Mabo judgment and the implications of potential constitutional change that this might have for our indigenous people. On behalf of the coalition, I trust that we will be able to continue the broad cross-party approach which has been established so successfully by my predecessor as shadow Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge).

In general terms, this amendment Bill proposes changes to three areas of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989. Firstly, it reduces the number of commissioners and the number of regional councils; secondly, it provides for the full-time appointment of all commissioners and the regional council chairpersons; and, thirdly, it removes the existing power of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to appoint the chairperson of ATSIC and the two non-elected commissioners.

It is said quite frequently that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery. So we in the coalition are indeed very flattered by the Government's obvious adoption of two important aspects of our own Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs policy that we took to the last election—an excellent policy and just one part of a broader, caring coalition social agenda which we were regularly accused of not even having.

It is well known that the Government was not expecting to win, and I can see the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, who is at the table, blushing in agreement. The Government entered the election really rather bereft of policies, including, I suspect, some in this area. So the adoption of our policy thrust as contained in the ATSIC Amendment Bill before the House today is a product of an active and an innovative Opposition—an Opposition which set the agenda as far back as June 1992 with the release of our green paper signalling proposed reductions in the number of regional councils from 60 to 30 and a reduction in the number of national commissioners.

The amendments before us today are the first major changes, I believe, to be proposed since the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act was proclaimed in 1989. Though, as I have already pointed out here today, the main thrust of these amendments obviously stems from our coalition policy, I will give the Minister the benefit of the doubt from his second reading speech and focus on his assertion at that time that the amendments are the result of attention to the commission's review into the ATSIC Act.

This review into the operation of the Act was required by section 26 of the Act and had to be conducted prior to the end of the first term of its elected commissioners and to be reported to the Minister. There is no dispute that these recommendations are contained in the review of the operation of the Act and their heralding in coalition policy just under a year ago is not surprising given the wide-ranging consultations with all sectors of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities pursued by my predecessor, the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Chisholm.
In 1992 the coalition's white paper, ATSIC the way forward, was completed. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Currently there are 60 regional councils in Australia. This is an impossible number of councils to be adequately serviced by ATSIC. As the regional councils are to become the prime decision making body at program and project level it is essential that they have the best people on them and are adequately resourced and adequately serviced.

The reduction in the number of regional councils is absolutely central to ATSIC's future success and the implementation of these proposals. The smaller number of regional councils will allow those regional councils to be better serviced by existing ATSIC regional offices.

The coalition's policy at the last election also proposed that the number of national commissioners be reduced from 20 to 14 and that, with an increased workload, commissioners be adequately resourced. The Bill before the House today will reduce the number of commissioners from 20 to 17—one commissioner for each 17 ATSIC zones around Australia.

PARA.TAB: The change to full-time appointments for commissioners and regional council chairpersons is also something the coalition supports. It is widely acknowledged that the burden of part-time work taken on, no matter how enthusiastic the commitment, has proven a far greater than anticipated load than it was at the time that ATSIC was formed.

Given that the commission spends over a half a billion dollars per year, and increasingly will aim to devolve responsibility for management of the regions, both the commissioners and the regional chairpersons must cover large distances, they are responsible for significant sums of money, and they are legally accountable for how this money is spent. The areas of responsibility are quite diverse, ranging from economic matters, health, housing, buildings, attendance at public meetings both within the ATSIC structure and in the broader community. Effectively, this is an enormous burden and it is, in reality, full-time work.

Not to pay commissioners ultimately produces unsatisfactory outcomes. Either part-time commissioners are left to live on a pittance or they are employed by someone else but are not giving their full attention to that other paid employment, thereby jeopardising their job; or they are not giving the ATSIC post its due.

We do not have any problem with the first two areas of this amendment Bill. We do, however, have some degree of concern about the Bill's removal of the Minister's prerogative to choose two commissioners and especially his prerogative to select the chairperson. While we certainly acknowledge the importance of democratic principles in assisting the achievement of greater self-management and independent decision making, the coalition parties are also concerned about aspects of control and accountability, particularly where government funds are concerned.

In its review of the operation of the ATSIC Act, the commission itself acknowledged the difficulties inherent in a community elected chairperson. In expressing the belief that it is time to elect it own chairperson, the commission stressed that the chairperson must be, `a person in whom the Government may have total confidence, at the same time having the confidence, trust and the ability to represent all members of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community'.

Where are we if none of the commissioners fits that bill? Where are we if none of the commissioners, even though they might be a perfect representative for their zone, possess the very special range of skills and background experience as expressed in the ATSIC review report? What controls are there, for instance, for the removal of an elected chairperson who is just simply unable to meet these vital criteria?

These points can be emphasised no better than by turning our focus on the Minister's very admirable choice for ATSIC's first three-year term, Lois O'Donoghue. I believe that without doubt Lois O'Donoghue does possess all of these required prerequisites, and more. She is an outstanding administrator. She is firm and fair in dealing with people and chairing meetings. She gets things done and she is a public speaker and international representative par excellence.

In view of the coalition's concerns in relation to the removal of the powers of the Minister to choose two commissioners and select the chairperson, it is my intention to move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission should consist of 14 persons, of which:
(a)12 must be elected and two must be chosen by the Minister;
(b)the Chairperson must be chosen by the Minister from any of the 14 Commissioners".

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to moving that amendment, I also want to comment on the regional council elections which are held every three years. Of course, voting is not compulsory and is by secret ballot. The last regional council elections attracted a total of some 1,611 nominations for 790 vacancies. Voting took place at 850 stationary booths and 400 mobile polling places. Approximately 37,000 people voted out of a total of 114,000 eligible Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. With the reduced number of councillors, I understand that now there will be only 500 to 600 vacancies at this next set of elections. Obviously, we all hope that there will be a far higher voter turnout at the next election which is due in November or December.

PARA.TAB: One important provision in this Bill which I particularly want to note is clause 18 which allows for rule changes for regional council elections to come into effect with a shorter lead time than at present. I point out that the revised arrangements are in line with what already exists in other government legislation.

Of course, this amendment is necessary to provide a mechanism which will at some time in the future enable the introduction perhaps of things like a ward system such as that which exists in Australia now at the local government level. The importance of a ward system for regional councils will protect against minority groups in the region being swamped by majority groups.

As I have travelled around Australia during the last three years, particularly in regional areas, I have visited a number of places where there has been more than one community. Invariably the less powerful community groups have expressed concerns that majority groups have taken control and ignored the needs of minorities. I understand there is to be wide consultation by ATSIC in the coming months with communities about a possible ward system. Personally, I believe it has a lot to commend it and I hope it will be in operation before this year's elections take place.

The Minister has emphasised the high degree of cross-party support for the direction currently being followed in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. As my predecessor said, such support in any circumstances is often fragile. It is something never to be taken for granted. On this occasion I agree with the Minister that support for ATSIC by both sides of the House is largely attributable to the quality, commitment, expertise and performance of the ATSIC commissioners and their staff.

Of course, the functions of ATSIC include the formulation and implementation of programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, the monitoring of programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and the development of policy proposals to meet national, State, Territory and regional needs and priorities of their people.

It is perhaps rather ironic—and maybe also a demonstration of a certain maturity—that we now and then witness criticisms of ATSIC from within its own constituency when ATSIC has not played to the tune of a particular interest group or individuals. Of course, there is often healthy criticism and it is a positive signal of democracy at work.

The Minister, in his speech, noted the urgent nature of this legislation in view of the requirement for regional council elections to be held before the end of this year. This means that, unless the proposed changes to the Act are made prior to the winter recess, the opportunity to implement the changes proposed by this Bill would be lost for another three years.

Of course, I will be taking special interest in the next round of regional elections. I shall be watching with great interest, particularly in view of the disappointing turnout and the quite immense criticism of this poor turnout at the last elections. I cannot state strongly enough how vital these elections are to our indigenous people. It is vital that they demonstrate their willingness and ability to be part of determining their own futures.

The candidates standing for election are presenting themselves as candidates for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to represent the views and aspirations of their region. A vote in the ATSIC regional council elections will mean a vote in support of taking control; a vote in support of Aboriginal self-reliance—and what, I ask, could be more important?
The Minister, in his second reading speech, also noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Additional proposals for changes to the Act will be put before the Parliament at a later stage.

The coalition will be waiting for these changes and we commend further measures in our own policy to the Minister for his attention. We are particularly keen to see the continuation of the present high commitment to accountability by ATSIC provided through the Office of Evaluation and Audit. However, we would point out to the Minister that we do have some concern that the ATSIC Act does not contain a provision requiring the tabling of other audit reports of portfolio related agencies and ATSIC funded organisations. We believe that it would be appropriate for those to be required to be tabled in this Parliament so that Parliament can examine them directly.

PARA.TAB: The Government should not assume that, because the coalition is determined not to obstruct the path towards a proud and self-sufficient life for all of Australia's indigenous people, it will not be immune from our continued scrutiny of its policies. I remind honourable members of this House that, beyond all the promises and the rhetoric, the bottom line is that what all of us must achieve is a vastly improved living standard for this most disadvantaged group of Australians.

As expressed in our policy, we on this side have clearly defined objectives to address this disadvantage. These goals must be achieved and they must be achieved by focusing on tangible benefits at the coalface as a result of the programs, and not as a result of the regular distribution of welfare. With a commitment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves towards self-reliance and with cross-party support in this Parliament we have already seen an increased number of success stories in business enterprise, academia and in sport, but there is of course still a very long way to go.

I will now move to the second Bill in this cognate debate, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1993. The purpose of this Bill is to add three parcels of land to that granted to Aboriginal land councils in the Northern Territory. These additions result from agreements between three parties, the Northern Territory Government, the Jawoyn Association and the Zapopan mining company.

I understand this is an amicable settlement of the Catfish Dreaming and Eva Valley land claims and under the agreement Zapopan will be allowed to proceed with the gold mining venture at Mount Todd, a development which is important to the region and to our national economy. It has effectively resolved a longstanding claim for the Jawoyn people. The Jawoyn have agreed not to pursue any further claim to native title or to support any such claim by any other person in respect of the mineral leases involved.

It has also agreed to allow Zapopan unrestricted access to the land whilst undertaking to support ongoing exploration activity by the company. In turn, Zapopan has agreed to provide employment and training for Aboriginal people at the mining site.

The third parcel of land involved effectively secures for the Northern Territory the current and future water supply for Tennant Creek in return for its support for the scheduling of the land. This is to be achieved by the granting of a licence allowing the Northern Territory Power and Water Authority the right to continue its borefield operations in the Tennant Creek area and by the granting of a lease to secure access to present and future borefields on that and adjacent Aboriginal land.

This whole package is an important agreement. It is important that these three parties have agreed on some critical issues and it is also important for its demonstration of the Northern Territory Government's capacity to deal with Aboriginal issues in a rational and productive manner.

The coalition is of the view that were the Northern Territory a State in its own right it could of course have proceeded in this freely negotiated deal, for effectively that is what it is, without Commonwealth involvement. However, whilst we on this side of the House support the Bill for the reasons I have stated, particularly in view of the productive outcomes it will achieve, we must express some dismay in relation to the aspects of the bargaining against implied native title entitlements which underpins the agreement. We are adamant that such bargaining tools should not be seen as setting a precedent for future agreements.

The coalition supports the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill and commends it to the House. The coalition also supports the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1993, subject to the amendment that I have moved to enable the Minister to nominate the chairperson of ATSIC. The coalition awaits the outcome of these measures with interest and with the fervent hope that they may benefit the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—The amendments proposed by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), which go to the election by the commissioners of their own chairperson, and the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition, in a sense, indicate some of the differences of approach that exist between the Government and the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The Minister is to be commended for bringing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill into this House. In a sense, the legislation represents the confidence of the Government in Aboriginal people being able to choose their own leadership as an essential part of their right to basically deal with their own future, to make decisions which are essential to be made by them on behalf of their people and, if we are to be logical, to apply the principles that apply right throughout our own democratic institutions.

I listened with great interest to the comments made by the shadow Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander affairs, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), on the commendable qualities shown by Lois O'Donohue; and I agree with them. But, if these same rigorous standards were applied to all the members who from time to time are elected to this Parliament, the honourable member might well have some doubts. If we consider the speculation going on within the Opposition and the public comment being made about the requirements of the existing leader or a new leader, it seems to be a bit rich for the shadow Minister in this situation to come in and say, `It is all right for us in political parties to have these kinds of problems. It is all right for us to have these kinds of problems in this Parliament. But it is not all right for those same problems to be confronted by Aboriginal people because we somehow doubt their capacity to wrestle with those problems with the same capacity that we wrestle with them in our own political institutions and to reach the best decision'.

It may well be that the next chairperson does not have all the same qualities as Lois O'Donohue but may well bring to the job new qualities. I do not think members of the coalition feel deeply grieved that the present Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) does not necessarily have all the qualities of Sir Robert Gordon Menzies. Perhaps they wish he did. But at the end of the day the Minister has acted upon the representations that have come to him from the Aboriginal leadership itself.

I do not doubt the sincerity of the shadow Minister but I say, on the basis of some considerable experience in this matter, that at the end of the day, if we are serious about reconciliation, it is essentially a white problem. For some 200 years Aboriginal people throughout the length and breadth of this great nation have been trying to reconcile themselves to living within the framework of a dominant white culture—a culture which in many ways they found brutally oppressive and foreign to the traditions, attitudes and religious beliefs that had governed them before our predecessors came to this land.

If that is the case, the shadow Minister should withdraw his amendment. For once, let the coalition say that it is prepared to take the same sorts of challenges as the Minister has accepted and accept the fact that although ATSIC is in many ways an imperfect instrument it is a major step forward. But it is no more an imperfect instrument than any of our own political parties. It is no more an imperfect political instrument than this Parliament itself. It seems to me to be an exercise of almost continuing patronage to say, `Yes, we think it is not a bad idea, but not now'. It is always for the coalition `not now'.

I was interested to listen to the view taken by the shadow Minister on behalf of the coalition, but I was not surprised at his position on native title. I am one who thoroughly supports the High Court decision and rejects some of the notions that have been put forward by a range of vested interests in this community that there is something somehow indecent about the High Court recognising that which is a historic fact and giving legal recognition to native title and saying that it creates uncertainty.

Speaking as a lawyer—I think any lawyer in this House would agree—there are very few major cases in the history of the High Court which, while solving the immediate legal issue, in judgments created and elucidated by the justices, do not at the same time open up other questions which have to be the subject of ultimate legal resolution. Did the legal profession seriously complain when exactly that process brought forth a stream of litigation interpreting section 92? Half the lawyers I know who were involved in those matters educated their kids on the basis of those uncertainties. When Chief Justice Barwick took the court in the direction of opening up significant areas of the Tax Act, which ultimately led to very serious problems for the Treasurer and for governments in tax evasion, was there an outcry from the accountants, the corporate lawyers and the miners, saying, `Goodness me, there is going to be an area of uncertainty in this area of the law'?

But on the first occasion when our indigenous people have won a significant judgment which recognises their previous occupation of our island continent and when the court takes a step forward to recognise in legal terms the reality of our history, goodness me, some uncertainty is also created. What is new about that? Again, I was interested to hear the shadow Minister indicate how proud he was of certain aspects of coalition policy on Aboriginal affairs.

If we are talking about legal certainty, I would think one of the areas that the shadow Minister ought to look at and repudiate, particularly if he is concerned about legal uncertainty, is the decision of the coalition prior to the last election—and presumably it holds now because I see nothing repudiating it—which said it would hand over Uluru and Kakadu National Park to the Northern Territory Government. I invite the shadow Minister to consider the implications of that decision and to consider the legal implications when he is talking about the creation of uncertainty.

The problem with an alternative government saying, `If we win the election we are going to hand over Uluru and hand over Kakadu National Park to the Northern Territory Government and its administration' is that it involves some very novel concepts indeed. The Commonwealth does not own Uluru or Kakadu; they are owned by their Aboriginal owners. In both cases the Commonwealth has a lease. I find it an extraordinary proposition, when the Commonwealth has leased property all over Australia, for us now to say `We not only reserve the right to repudiate the lease agreements that we have entered into'—and in the case of Uluru the period to run is some 90 years—`but also, as the lessee, we also reserve the right to tell the owner what is going to happen to it'. It is legal nonsense, and the honourable member knows it is legal nonsense.

More than that, if the Commonwealth is going to take property that it does not own and it is going to tell the owners what is to be done with it, first the Commonwealth might have to compulsorily acquire it. Have those opposite thought of the hole that would blow in the Budget when we look at compensation and loss of property for some 90 years, and the damages and fiscal outlays that would involve? I say to the spokesman for the Opposition that it is time that he, because I do not doubt his sincerity in this matter, took his party back to the drawing board on the question of the significance of the Mabo decision, and was prepared to extend to the Aboriginal people and to ATSIC the same rights as are inherent in our political structures.

It may well be that they, in their own right, elect a leader who is less than adequate. But I would have thought that, even though some sections of the shadow Minister's own party believe that that has occurred, he should sympathise with the Aboriginals' right to do that. It is time that those opposite abandoned this concept of saying, `We will give to the Aboriginal people with one hand and take away with the other'. Previous decisions of this House affected the development of Kakadu, and the Aboriginal ownership did not come out of just the policies of the then government. Many aspects of it were implemented by a Liberal government under Fraser on the basis of an independent report. One of the options put—do not think it was not put to Prime Minister Fraser by the Northern Territory Government at the time—was that the Northern Territory Government should have Uluru and Kakadu, and he refused. He was right to refuse.

So, if there was a change in that view prior to the last election, it was a change that turned its face upon the previous policy of the Liberal Party. Worse than that, it involved the creation of legal principles, if those opposite are talking about uncertainty, which make Mabo look one of the most certain legal decisions ever made in the history of the Commonwealth.

It is an appalling legal proposition. Would those opposite go to a group of owners of property in the Melbourne or Sydney central business districts and say, `Although you may have leased this to the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth feels that it does not want to go on with these leases. We are not only not going to go on with it but also we are going to tell you what you as an owner should do with it? Where does the Opposition get the precedent for that ugly concept? But it was good enough for the Opposition to write it into its policy; it was good enough for its candidates throughout Australia to stand on that when they were dealing not with the property owners of Sydney and Melbourne but with the traditional owners of these areas of land.

I was the Minister who had the responsibility of negotiating with the traditional owners of Uluru. It was not easy. When I went to see them to say that the Commonwealth had decided to give it back to them, they thought that was very nice and they thought they were doing the Government a favour by letting us give them a bit of paper, because they said, `That is nice. If it makes you happy, that is good, because we know we have always owned it'. When it was handed over, I stood and watched Aboriginal people who had driven from all over Australia to visit the centre of their dreaming. I watched a young girl of 13 from Queensland stand in tears as she realised that this land, this symbolic edifice, central to their dreaming, was now theirs, and was pledged to be theirs by the Commonwealth Government. In a moment—I hope of political stupidity—the members of this coalition are prepared to say, `If we are elected, we will take it away from them'. It is a novel concept—a brutal concept. But it is a stupid concept.

So I believe the time has come when, if the shadow Minister can undertake a reconciliation process, he will do the Opposition some credit—if he takes the Opposition back to the drawing board on those aspects of its policy which did not get much of a mention in the election campaign. He could also do himself some considerable credit in the eyes of this Parliament if, by the time this legislation gets to the Senate, he can organise a major rethink within the Opposition that says, `We as a parliament are prepared to trust the Aboriginal leaders of ATSIC to accept the same responsibilities, to possibly make the same mistakes and, indeed, to make the correct decisions when it comes to the election of their chairperson and the operation and management of their structures as we accord ourselves such trust in our parliamentary institutions and in our political party'. If that occurs, I will say, and be happy to say, that this coalition has taken a major step in the process of reconciliation.

I will finish as I began: reconciliation is not an Aboriginal problem. It is a real problem for those of us who live in a dominant white culture and who have got to come to terms with the depth of Aboriginal culture, their history, their religion and their relationship to this land. When we do, this community will take on a strength, a durability and a relationship to our land which sees it as something more than a simple object of real estate speculation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make a few brief comments in this debate—and they will be reasonably brief—I would like to join the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) in paying tribute to the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), the previous shadow Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, for his sensitive and caring comprehension of all the issues involved in that portfolio. His handling of the issues was a credit to himself and to this Parliament, particularly in view of the very necessary bipartisan approach taken to the reconciliation process. This House should continue to support that reconciliation process in a very strong, bipartisan way.

PARA.TAB: Like the honourable member for Aston, the Opposition is in general agreement with these Bills. That agreement is subject to a specific amendment to one Bill, and to a caveat in principle on the other. There are two issues I would like to cover briefly. The first is the issue of responsibility and accountability; the second is land rights. Both issues have been covered very sensitively by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding); especially so for somebody of his portfolio exposure and experience as a member of the legal profession. That is not to say that I agree with all that he has said tonight. Nevertheless, we should all take his remarks on board.

I disagree with the honourable member's analogy about leadership, some of his criticisms and his rather party political approach to some of these issues. He talked about responsibility and accountability in a way that rather implied that the Opposition was critical of the Aboriginal people for their shortcomings in those areas. I would say to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), and to the House generally, that the basis of our amendment is this area of responsibility and accountability, both of which, of course, extend to the Minister. We have to look at both of those qualities—responsibility and accountability—as they relate to the Minister, the ATSIC zones, and the local Aboriginal bodies, such as the Aboriginal and Islander housing companies.

With all due respect, that is where the honourable member for Melbourne Ports got his analogy all mixed up, and that is the logic behind the Opposition's amendment. We are saying that the Minister should continue to exercise his ministerial responsibility—his discretion—and that that can best be done by his appointing the chairman and at least two of the commissioners. There is no hidden agenda. There is no implied criticism of the Aboriginal people by reference to their inadequacies. That is where the honourable member for Melbourne Ports was quite incorrect.

On the issue of land rights, anybody who suggests that the Mabo case is clear-cut is fooling themself. It is a Pandora's box. That is why the honourable member for Aston, the shadow Minister, made the point about the Opposition's caveat on the second Bill. In some ways it is a bucket of worms—a bucket of legal worms—which still has to be worked through. I suspect that the legal argument surrounding that judgment will continue for some years.

I am delighted that the Minister is in the chamber because I would like to read into Hansard excerpts from an article in today's Australian Financial Review by the former senator, John Stone. While I do not agree with the article, it highlights certain perceptions in the community which need to be addressed. When the Minister eventually enters this debate, I would be interested to get his reaction to those perceptions. In the article, Mr Stone referred to an IPA booklet, entitled Black suffering, white guilt? and statements made therein by his IPA colleague, Dr Ron Brunton, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . only when the special legal status of Aborigines is abolished will it be possible properly to address the problems of Aboriginal disadvantage. Governments should move towards dismantling the whole structure of `Aboriginal' policies, departments and institutions. Statutes and regulations should not distinguish Aborigines from other Australians. . .
I am sure the Minister will make some comment about Mr Stone's own comments, when he says:
Most Australian's wish to see their Aboriginal fellow-Australians happy, healthy, well-educated, well-remunerated and well-housed: while many of them are, the majority clearly are not.
We are, however, told that so-called `assimilationist' policies are `not acceptable'; and that Aboriginal culture must be respected, preserved and made available again to Aboriginal Australians.
Increasingly, there arises the `unthinkable' question. Can Aboriginal culture really survive (other than in a museum sense) in this 20th Century high technological world?

TALK.START.PARA: —That's awful!
—I hope that is what the Minister will say. Mr Stone continues:

SPEECH.PARA: And do policies which tend to push Aboriginal Australians back into it merely condemn them to further disorientation and alienation from the mainstream Australia in which, like it or not, they will have to live?
Mr Stone then refers to comments made by the deputy editor of the Canberra Times, Mr Jack Waterford, saying:
Waterford, who is personally very sympathetic to the Aboriginal `cause', strongly criticised his fellow journalist for so neatly toeing the politically correct line on these issues.
In particular, he argued that the mindless charges of `racism' levelled against anyone who questions current official policies are highly detrimental to the interests of Aborigines themselves.
But the real problem, he says, is this: `Real change in Aboriginal affairs depends on Aborigines themselves. Only they can liberate themselves . . . '
He concludes:
As Brunton says: `Aboriginal suffering is a valuable `resource', that can be colonised by a wide range of individuals for their own ends'.

Personally, I regard the article as extreme, but I would be interested in what the Minister has to say about it, and how he reacts. I hope that no-one in this place, least of all the honourable member for Melbourne Ports—who is a reasonable man—would disagree that Aboriginals are more disadvantaged than any other group in our community. However, there are perceptions in some quarters that they are receiving more than even-handed treatment. That is not my view but it is a perception. It is a perception that all of us have to get around, educate people about, and make sure that it does not get out of control.

PARA.TAB: From local experience, I know—and the Minister knows from papers I have given him about local problems with accountability, responsibility and all the rest of it—that, when some of these people break the law, issues of racism are raised. In recent weeks I have been referred to as a Black basher and a racist—not by the Minister, I might add—by some of the local Aboriginal militants, if that is the right word. The Minister knows me well enough to say that is not so. I am not a racist and I am not a Black basher. But remarks like that are made as a defence mechanism when some Aboriginals are breaking the law.

The point that I am making in this debate is that people have to understand that there is such a thing as the law of the land. I realise that there are laws within the Aboriginal community as well, but there are laws in this land which they, like everybody else, have to adhere to. Not everybody might agree with that, but in my view, that is the case—that they have to adhere to them until such time as those laws are changed. At the moment, when they do infringe the law, they are very quick to react by turning on people and referring to them, myself included, as racist.

I am very appreciative of the communication I have had from the Minister in terms of these local problems with my groups in the Toowoomba area. I hope that they are being investigated. I am sure they are, as the Minister has indicated.

In concluding, I would say to the honourable member for Melbourne Ports that the reconciliation process is something that we all must comply with. I think it is in the national interest that we complete it. But personally I draw the line at treaties and open-ended land rights. I know from what the honourable member said earlier that he will not agree with me, but it seems to me that land rights should not be open-ended, as I think he is indicating. Nevertheless, I think it is in the interests of this nation—and the Aboriginal people are part of this nation—that the reconciliation process should continue and we should continue to support it strongly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill. I acknowledge the work that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has been doing, particularly in relation to ATSIC. I have a real interest in the area of Aboriginal affairs, as does the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent). I think that our commitment to reconciliation in the years ahead is extremely important. As other speakers have mentioned tonight in relation to the Mabo case, I think it is very important for us to work together at this time to bring some resolution to a reconciliation process that is long overdue.

PARA.TAB: It is clear from the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody that more government action is needed, and that is certainly something that we need to have a look at. There are a number of Aboriginal people in an urban area in my electorate. I do not really think that we always get to their problems. Really, we have to be more caring towards the Aboriginal people and the problems that they face. I believe that the royal commission report highlighted to Australia the problems that are faced out there and why we as a nation need to work closer to resolve the problems. Only today my friend the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) asked a question in Question Time about another death in custody of an Aboriginal person. I think that is a very important area.

The Bill makes further changes to ATSIC. In my view it gives ATSIC a lot more autonomy in the way it deals with helping the Aboriginal people and in the work it needs to do to make life a lot easier and a lot more equitable for Aboriginal people. As we head towards the centenary of our Federation we need to look in a bipartisan way at the links between the Mabo case and what goes on in the reconciliation process.

The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) spoke earlier tonight. From his experience as a Minister for Aboriginal affairs he is well across the subject and, of course, the comments that he made are very highly regarded, certainly by people on this side of the House. I have tripped around on Aboriginal affairs committees—and honourable members opposite have as well—and seen the problems that they have. We must assist them to determine for themselves how they can best be assisted and how they can make their own decisions. Only in this way will they have restored to them the pride and dignity that they really should have. Their whole culture has been through a 200-year process of a lot of damage and that needs to be resolved in the years ahead.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mr Tickner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I understand that this is a cognate debate. Correct me if I am wrong.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I believe we are in a cognate debate. Are we not dealing with the second Bill?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will talk to the second Bill, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill. I think that it was in 1984 that we introduced legislation in Queensland which delivered ownership of the 7 1/2 million acres of land called the reserves to the local shire council that had been set up. It had both legal and beneficial ownership of those areas of land. The council had a mechanism by which it could pass that land down to private ownership, and it was our stated intention that it should pass it down to private ownership. I think the record speaks for itself. In six years we did not have a single riot in Queensland. In the last four months we have had six major riots in which police have had to be flown into the reserves. In those six years the trauma rate in the areas concerned dropped by half. Since the reversal of that legislation the trauma rate is again rising.

PARA.TAB: What in fact happened was that Queensland came into line with the laws of the Federal Parliament, so that the legislation in Queensland is almost identical with that being considered here this evening. It has been a disastrous failure. Even the most cursory glance at what has occurred in Queensland would indicate the failure of those laws. I would add that the worst riots in parliamentary history in Queensland took place when the ALP Government passed the new legislation. The previous Government never had a single demonstrator when it passed its legislation. We had nothing to hide. We flew all the Aboriginal council representatives down to Brisbane and gave them the legislation to go over, which, of course, they had been over many times before.

In sharp contrast, the laws that were subsequently passed in Queensland were rejected by 1,000-odd people who demonstrated in front of Parliament House. They tore down the fence and the flag post in front of Parliament House and, in a very ugly confrontation with the police, tried to tear down the door of Parliament House itself. Those were the worst riots in parliamentary history in Queensland—and let me tell honourable members: we have had many bad riots in parliamentary history in Queensland. But these were by far and away the worst. Blood was shed on the portals of Parliament House.

That was the way in which that legislation was received, in sharp contrast to the acceptance of the legislation passed by the National Party Government in Queensland. I take great delight in quoting from the ACC meeting before last at which one of my critics—and I say this with no degree of false humility—said, `Would to heaven we had the laws that we once criticised back in the State of Queensland'. Tonight we see the continuation of a failure.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK (ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT CHARGE-GENERAL) BILL 1993
GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK (ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT CHARGE-EXCISE) BILL 1993]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mrs Kelly:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Environmental Management Charge-General) Bill 1993 and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Environmental Management Charge-Excise) Bill 1993. The legislation introduces a user-pays principle into the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Together with the regulations that will be tabled subsequently, it enables the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to levy tourist operators on the basis of the number of tourists who use their facilities. For the first time, tourist operators are permitted to transfer the permits which are enabled in other sections of the GBRMPA legislation. That means that they will be able to sell permits to other operators. I will say more about that later. Transit operators will also be exempted by the Bills.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition will not oppose the legislation, but we are concerned about what may come from this legislation in future. It is feared that the Commonwealth will reduce its funds to GBRMPA if funds are raised in this way and that, in return, GBRMPA will have to use its funds to manage the park rather than for the research for which it was originally intended. There is the further fear, voiced by the conservation groups, that GBRMPA will be forced to encourage what might amount to non-sustainable tourism to obtain sufficient funds for the running and management of the park. There is also the fear of the tourist operators in the area that this is indeed the thin edge of the wedge.

In the second reading speech the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) said that the regulations will specify that the charge will be only $1 per day per tourist. However, this can be changed by regulation, and the tourist operators have very real fears that this is going to escalate. In Tasmania, where the user-pays principle has been brought into its park, those charges have escalated to the extent that the new national park fees are biting into park user numbers and one operator has totally lost his or her custom. We are concerned about what might happen in the future.

The coalition also sees problems with the levy as it will be applied at present. The tourist operators will bear the full burden of this charge. The charge was one of seven recommendations in the report of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. The report recommended that recreational users of the park be charged as well, but that has not been done in the Bill. Recreational users often cause more damage to the park than the tourist operators who maintain and care for the park. Special mention should be made of the Quicksilver operation and the marine biologists it employs to make sure that its facility is well looked after.

Although the permits for the tourist operators have been made transferable, they last for only three to five years. It would be much more advantageous to the tourist operators if the permits were for a longer period, because it puts the burden back onto them to care for a resource where they can sell that permit for a longer time. They are looking after it in perpetuity because it guarantees the capital investment that they have in that area.

The Bill is only an enabling Bill. It is the regulations that set the path of what happens in this Bill. These regulations are mooted to come into force on 1 July. However, they have to be tabled for 15 days in parliament, which will not be sitting until August. The charges will be in force long before the Parliament has a chance to disallow them. This is a concern because there has to be retrospectivity if the Parliament disallows them.

It is essential that GBRMPA be properly funded to protect the Great Barrier Reef. The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest reef. Seventy per cent of the coral reefs in the world have been degraded. The Great Barrier Reef is one of the last remaining reefs not quite in a pristine state but certainly in a better condition than the rest of the reefs around the world. The park has 2,900 individual reefs, and it takes up 3,444 square kilometres—larger than the size of Great Britain. After Greenland, it is the planet's biggest protected area. It is the breeding ground for the 40-tonne humpback whale, and it is home to 1,500 species of fish. It has 350 types of hard coral. One million tourists a year come to the reef, and that is increasing at 10 per cent per annum. The economic value of the Great Barrier Reef to Australia is $1.6 billion.

This is the heritage that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is charged with protecting. But the reef is not without its problems for the management of GBRMPA. One problem is tourism. Between 1977 and 1987 the number of tourist operators in the park increased tenfold, and during that time the number of passengers they were carrying increased 35-fold. This has had an inevitable effect on the reef. The big cod are frequently found with gashes in their heads from the motor boats that cross them and other fish are found with fishing lines entangled in their mouths.

Recreational users of the park are not always as careful as those who are taken out by the tourist operators. There is damage to the reef from anchors from small boats. Tourist development has led to the destruction of mangroves. That was referred to in a report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts as the tyranny of small decisions where developments along the coast remove the mangroves and each council says, `Well, it really doesn't matter if it happens here because they are somewhere else'. That is the concern about the proposed development at Trinity Inlet.

Bottom-trawling is an enormous problem, but at present GBRMPA has not the funds to fully research the effect that bottom-trawling is having on the reef. It has a huge by-catch and the scientists feel that this is damaging the reef. At present there are not the funds to research its effect on the reef.

There is always the possibility of oil tanker disasters. I referred to this last night in debate on Bills put before the House by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe). The waterway between the reef and the mainland is a shipping lane and there is a great need for the larger boats to carry electronic mapping and the differential global positionary system, DGPS, which enables them to see where the reefs are and anything in the channel and, at the same time, to be navigated by the satellites to where the ship is. There is also a need to examine whether it is possible or even desirable to use a route outside the reef and the advantages and disadvantages of requiring oil tankers to have double hulls.

The reef is suffering from eutrification. The nitrogen phosphorous from the farms up the rivers is coming down in the rivers, out onto the reef, and is deforming, weakening and killing the coral. This is one of the more serious problems that GBRMPA has to look at.

There is also the possibility of heavy metal pollution coming down from Papua New Guinea from the OK Tedi and Porgera mines, and that again has not been sufficiently researched. If that were not enough of the man-made disasters we are subjecting the reef to there is, of course, the danger of cyclones, the natural disasters. I refer to cyclone IVU where 70 per cent of the living coral in a reef 80 kilometres south of Lizard Island was destroyed. These then are the problems facing GBRMPA in its management of the Great Barrier Reef marine park.

The authority has to maintain the value of this incredible resource whilst allowing multi-use of the site. It needs to manage the reef in such a way as to avoid overuse and user group conflicts, and at the same time it has to plan for the long-term future of the reef. GBRMPA clearly needs large resources to manage the day-to-day activities on the reef, to educate the reef users and to fund research into the problems facing the reef, but its budget is not big enough.

At present there are 92 field officers at the reef—that is one field officer for every 3,500 square kilometres. GBRMPA estimates that it needs a minimum of 120 field officers. This year the Commonwealth Government contributed $14 million to GBRMPA, which is less than one per cent of the return from tourism in the area. The levy which GBRMPA will be able to collect after the enactment of this Bill and the tabling of the regulations will only add $1.5 million to its funds and, of that, 10 per cent will go in administration.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority not only needs a larger budget to run on; it also needs money for capital infrastructure. The situation is so bad that the authority has no money to put up signs which say `No Fishing Here' or to inform people what is acceptable or unacceptable on the reef, which are minor things. It needs large capital injections because it needs bases for the boats that are presently berthed at Cairns, Townsville and Rockhampton, which are not regarded as sufficiently close to look after the problems that arise on the reef.

In conclusion, the coalition has grave concerns that the present resources available to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority are insufficient and that the current level of funding to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is not adequate for the job it has been entrusted with.

We are concerned that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, in its search for funds to manage the reef, will be forced to allow use above what is sustainable and that the Government will exploit charges to tourist operators. Overall, this Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in caring for one of Australia's greatest assets, the Great Barrier Reef marine park.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech we have just heard from the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) is interesting in that it was reasonably well informed on the details of the legislation but she did make some outrageous claims later in the speech with respect to alleged escalation of fees, which have not yet occurred. I would suggest that those fees are not substantiated by any evidence whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: It was rather ironic to hear her complain about alleged lack of funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority when, under Fightback, there was a promise of a $10 billion cut in budgetary expenditure for 1993-1994. Members of the Opposition find themselves in an impossible situation when they come into this chamber, shackled as they are, burdened as they are, by the insufferable weight of Fightback.

I will deal with a number of issues in respect of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Environmental Management Charge-General) Bill 1993 and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Environmental Management Charge-Excise) Bill 1993 which are being debated on a cognate basis. The honourable member mentioned the condition of the reef. There have been allegations by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority that the reef is generally in good condition. They lead me to believe that there is evidence of some degradation around heavily used areas and major centres of population such as Cairns and the Whitsunday Islands. I thought those assertions which have been made by the authority were inconsistent with the remarks reported to have been made by the chief of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority water quality project, a Mr Jon Brodie, in the Australian newspaper on 13 April 1993. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a perception that the water of the reef is more turbid than in the past, and that the reefs are covered by more algae. We have photographic evidence that reef flats that were covered with staghorn corals 40 to 50 years ago are now totally denuded.
Mr Brodie went on to say:
There is enough evidence for us to be worried about the future of the Great Barrier Reef.

In another report published in the Canberra Times on 29 March 1993 the chairman of the World Conservation Union, a Mr Bing Lucas, said it was easy for people living in the region to forget the reef's importance. He went on to say:
The world would be poorer without the Great Barrier Reef. The world appreciates its values and that is why the reef was included on the World Heritage List.

As a resident of North Queensland, I would share the concern of those two authorities that there are grounds to be concerned about the condition of the reef. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority must ensure that the reef is monitored more closely than hitherto with the impact of heavy usage of the reef by tourism operators and also by the other matter referred to by the honourable member for Hindmarsh, the intrusion of nutrients from farm use into the Great Barrier Reef itself.

PARA.TAB: I want to pay tribute tonight in this debate to a former Minister for the environment in the Hawke Government, Mr Barry Cohen. He did a wonderful job for the environment, particularly in relation to the Great Barrier Reef. I have often heard him in the House of Representatives chamber lauding the work of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and, in particular, its chairman, Mr Graham Kelleher.

Mr Cohen, on a number of occasions, and indeed in an article published in the Australian on 18 May 1992, reminded his readers that it was the Whitlam Labor Government in 1975 that introduced legislation to establish the Great Barrier Reef marine park, and it was passed by that Government. That enabled the Fraser Government to establish the marine park in 1976. It should not be forgotten that it was the National Party's State Government in Queensland which vigorously resisted the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef marine park on the ground that it was an alleged infringement of State rights.

That legislation that was passed by the Whitlam Labor Government, although the park was established by the Fraser Liberal Government, was sufficient to give impetus to the campaign in 1981 to have the Great Barrier Reef inscribed for World Heritage listing. In that regard the Fraser Government deserves great credit for its support of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

Having regard to the history of protecting the Great Barrier Reef, the article I referred to in the Australian on 18 May 1992 also canvassed how any sane, reasonable person could object to the establishment of a small fee, $1 per tourist, when the tourist would perhaps pay $75 or $100 to travel to the reef. It mentioned that that money would be used by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority by way of compensation to carry out the necessary monitoring work that is so essential in this area. Indeed, the Liberal and National parties in their Fightback package acknowledged the principle of user pays. The Fightback document says:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe users of our national parks should contribute more towards their upkeep and the provision of facilities.
I have no quarrel whatever with that assertion.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the growth of tourism on the reef, I am informed that in 1992 an estimated five million people visited the Queensland coast adjacent to the reef and spent about $1.4 billion. The best advice from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority itself is that by the year 2000 there will be between seven million and 11 million visitors to that region of Australia. Indeed, with that intrusion of tourists into the marine park area, one can appreciate the concerns of the authority that the cost of management is rising dramatically, that governments are finding it difficult to meet the costs of management, and also that there are costs involved in the research and education necessary to ensure the continued conservation of the reef itself. Furthermore, 75 per cent of that net revenue that will be raised by this new charge will be going towards the recently created cooperative research centre which will deal with the preservation and management of the Great Barrier Reef.

I find the reaction to the charge by certain individuals somewhat difficult to accept seriously. I know in my own area there was one particular operator who was belly-aching about the charge of $1 per passenger to travel to the reef, but the same person had no difficulty accepting a 15 per cent goods and services tax on the fee for a person paying up to $100 to travel to the reef and had no difficulty accepting a $10 billion cut in budgetary expenditure and the effect that would have on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Indeed, the loudest squeals have come from those who will benefit most from these measures.

These measures are not coming as any surprise to the population. In a communique issued by the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council meeting on 10 May 1988, it was proposed that the user pays principle would apply to tourist operators and tourists visiting the Great Barrier Reef. I quote from that communique:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the principle of charging for the commercial use of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and Queensland marine parks was endorsed by Council.

Who constituted the council? In attendance were Senator Graham Richardson, Senator Margaret Reynolds and—listen to this—the Hon. Geoff Muntz, MLA, then Queensland National Party Minister for Conservation, Environment and Tourism.

PARA.TAB: I should also make the point in the debate that, for example, direct transfers between parts of the mainland and Queensland islands such as Magnetic Island, and so forth, are exempt from these charges, as the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) said in her second reading speech. Private recreational activities like boating and general access to beach and reef areas will not be subject to the environmental management charges referred to. In other words, the Government has gone to great lengths to try to assuage the concerns of people who thought that they might be adversely affected by the charges to be introduced.

I want to make the point, as the honourable member for Hindmarsh has said, that these charges will be introduced to take effect from 1 July this year. The commercial operators will be required to have permits from the authority for the payment of these fees, except, as I said earlier, for the operators carrying direct transfer passengers. Commercial fishermen will not be charged as they already pay fees to fisheries management authorities, and private boat owners and persons using the facilities will not be charged these particular fees. The legislation provides for a fee corresponding to about $1 per passenger per day.

I appreciate the support of the Opposition on these particular measures. The honourable member for Hindmarsh outlined why the charges were being introduced—that is, because of the use of the Great Barrier Reef, particularly with tourism increasing dramatically at about eight per cent per year. I notice that in the Cairns area tourism growth is estimated to be at about 18 per cent per year. It is generally accepted in modern society, except sometimes in the National Party, that commercial users should contribute to the increased costs of management.

The other issue I should raise is that the process of consultation with persons affected has been going on, as I said earlier, for a long time. Indeed, for the last four years extensive consultations have been held with relevant industry groups up and down the length of the Queensland coast. This user pays notion of charging commercial users of our national parks is not unique. Indeed, the Queensland Government requires commercial tourist operators in national parks to have a commercial activities permit that costs $100 a year and a per head charge from $1.15 to $4.30. In the Hervey Bay Marine Park whale-watching operators pay the Queensland Government a fee of $500 to $1,500 per year and a per head charge of $2 per adult and $1 per child.

Overall, I believe that in a short period of time this legislation will be welcomed by its current opponents. Eventually they will have to face the fact that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority needs the money to provide this additional management that was referred to earlier by the honourable member for Hindmarsh, and also that it is only right and proper that commercial users should make some contribution to the management of one of Australia's greatest national assets.

I also believe that the efforts of our Minister in ensuring that this legislation has been introduced to the Parliament should be commended by all honourable members. She has been an indefatigable fighter for the preservation of our environment and has done everything possible to ensure that not only are there adequate laws for the protection of our environment, and particularly for the Great Barrier Reef, but also that there are adequate funds for the statutory authorities charged with the responsibility of monitoring, researching and educating Australians about the worth of these great national assets. I support the Bills before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for calling me. I sincerely hope that you do not cut me off, too, as the night goes on.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—I would not do that to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that. I would get my own back at some stage, as you fully understand. However, I want to reassure the previous speaker, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), that the Opposition does not have an impossible task at all when it comes to talking about issues of this description. I found the giggling that went on at the table quite disturbing when we were discussing a subject as serious as the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

PARA.TAB: I have spoken on this subject every time there has been an amendment to the 1975 legislation. I was pleased to note that the previous speaker did acknowledge that it was the Fraser Government which introduced the legislation into this House. Before I commence my remarks, I would like to say that it comes as no surprise to any member of my party—state or federal—that the principle of user pays is a necessary requirement for all national parks. There are honourable members in the House at the moment who have opposed, on a state basis, our introduction of user pays for national parks. I wonder whether we should perhaps read some of those honourable members' comments about this user pays principle. However, I will not do that tonight.

I think it should also be noted and recorded quite clearly that all the amendments that have been made to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act which we brought in in 1975 have been supported by the Opposition, certainly in the last 10 years. I think a lot of the breast beating which has been going on in this regard is totally and completely out of place.

I speak on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill because I have a long and continuing interest in this particular area of Queensland, having lived there for an important part of my life. I remind members of the parliament that some of us have been vitally and practically concerned about the welfare of the Great Barrier Reef for a lot longer than others. I guess my concern—I have a few years under the belt—for the welfare of the reef goes back longer than anyone's in either party.

I am sure the previous speaker would understand, having come to North Queensland and then entered parliament, that one cannot live in North Queensland—as I am sure the next speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) will also tell us in her first speech on the subject—without becoming vitally concerned about the reef, irrespective of party politics. I suppose when one talks about the north of Queensland one has to include Central Queensland, which of course takes in the seat of Capricornia. What people from the south who have not been to the Great Barrier Reef can never understand is the local population's appreciation of the reef's significance.

So I rise tonight in support of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly). But I am amazed that, yet again, the Minister is not present for a debate on an amendment to this Great Barrier Reef legislation. She has not been present when any of the amendments have come through this House. I find that extremely disappointing, and honourable members may find it disappointing as well.

Before I proceed to the nuts and bolts of the legislation, I want to place on record yet again my total rejection of the Government's use of the guillotine, to which this Bill has been subject. We almost saw this situation aggravated earlier, Mr Deputy Speaker, as we have already discussed. I spoke on the matter of the guillotine at length last week. However, in prefacing my comments this evening the Government deserves to be soundly condemned for the way in which it has mismanaged the legislative program which has seen the guillotine brought to bear in only the second week of the 37th Parliament.

We understand that governments—it happens to all of them—have to bring in guillotines at the end of sessions. Legislative problems always develop. But to have us geared for the guillotine in the second week of a new parliament? The Government has us rising on 27 May when we could have stayed here for at least another three weeks. Of course, as I said last week, the Government's executive could have a hidden agenda—perhaps involving some of its overseas trips. I do not oppose those. I see the new Minister for Resources (Mr Lee) smiling; goodness knows what he is smiling about. We could finish that very quickly. But I have great difficulty with this situation. My party has never stopped a parliament at the end of May. It has never brought in guillotines in the second week of a new parliament. This is absolutely awful and it bodes ill for what we will have to handle in the next three weeks.

So in answer to the previous speaker's throwaway comment that he thought we had an impossible task, let me reassure him that we come here with no fears of that at all. I do not want him to go home to Townsville upset about this. I do not want him worrying about our having an impossible task. He can relax; we are not worried.

The Great Barrier Reef is truly one of the treasures of the world, the protection of which Australians can feel justifiably proud. It has been—and I hope it remains—above party politics. I suppose it is significant that we have more people in the advisers' box for the debate on this Bill than we have had for any Bills in the last few days of sitting. That is a good sign. I am glad that they, at least, are here.

As I said, we have always supported legislation of this nature. The coalition has a proud record in regard to the environment, but particularly in regard to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I stand here, with some experience, to let the House know that I have been part of this process over a period of time. This is not something one reads about. The next speaker has not read about it, she has lived it. The previous speaker, living on the reef, would have faced daily concerns such as when that awful hotel was built. Everybody was staggered by that. I just hope it is succeeding in Vietnam.

As I said before, we brought in this legislation in 1975, but the concern should not be about who brought it in or who did not, or who introduced it or who did not. That will get us nowhere. Two weeks into the 37th Parliament, I say to the Government: it does not have to worry about that. It has three years to attack us; but, by the same token, we have three years to attack it. It should watch out and be careful. I will digress from the Bill for a moment, Mr Deputy Speaker—I know I have your permission—but if you had told me that we were going to win the first week of parliament, I would have laughed at you. But I think it is generally agreed that, to date, the Government is not exactly in front as far as the public is concerned.

Let me get back to the Bill. I refuse to be tempted to digress, even by the Minister's mention of a television show. I must express my delight that, for the first time, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has come into the House to debate legislation about the Great Barrier Reef. I thank her very much; we are very appreciative. She might have come in to hear the next honourable member's speech as well.

As the Minister said in her second reading speech, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park supports tourism and fishing industries worth in excess of $1.3 billion annually. As we all know, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority spent approximately $17 million in the last financial year, about $14 million of which, thank goodness, was Commonwealth money. It is clear from these comparisons that use of the park via tourism and fishing is exceeding the park authority's ability to fund maintenance of the park, and that forms the basis of the legislation we are debating tonight.

As I have already said, I am pleased to speak in support of this Bill. I believe that it is only fair that, when we are faced with preserving one of the most treasured natural assets in the world, those people having access to the park and enjoying the recreational and commercial benefits that the park provides should be encouraged in some manner to contribute towards the maintenance of this wonderful area.

It is clear that, despite the efforts of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the continued increase in tourism—and I was equally impressed by the figures that the previous speaker mentioned as the likely outcome in the Cairns area, et cetera—to the park has led to an increase in the workload for the authority and the strain on the resources with which it is equipped to protect the park. The authority is principally financed through State and Commonwealth appropriations, although the authority does collect some revenue through permit assessment fees which allow operators within the park.

The Minister made it clear in her second reading speech that the Keating Government is having difficulty in maintaining recurrent and adequate funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I do not find that surprising given the unprecedented state of welfare dependency in this country from the Keating engineered recession.

I do not wish to get into a long debate on that subject; in fact, I will not even debate it all. But I would draw the attention of the House to the fact that since the election it is readily apparent that this Government has no money, and Bills of this nature to do with cost recovery will be seen more frequently in this place.

However, to give the Government and the Minister credit, I am aware that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics did recommend some form of charge for users of the park, and I am led to believe the authority has had extensive consultations with representatives from the Queensland tourism industry. From my knowledge to date the tourism representatives have not objected to the charge in general; nor indeed to the user-pays principle which this Bill is all about. I am hopeful that such cooperation between the commercial and recreational users of the park and the authority will continue. In fact, it must continue.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is the Federal Government's principal adviser on the care and development of this marine park. And through this debate I should like to remind honourable members of the authority's goal. In its last annual report the goal of the authority was specified as:

SPEECH.PARA: To provide for the protection, wide use, understanding and enjoyment of the Great Barrier Reef in perpetuity, through the care and development of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

That is the central issue in regard to this legislation which we are debating tonight. We must be vigilant in protecting this wonderful area while still allowing scope for the general public to have access both in a commercial and recreational sense to the reef.
