Such care must relate particularly—and I bear in mind the next speaker will no doubt be speaking more on this—to the Shoalwater Bay region which I was privileged to visit last year as a member of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. It was interesting to note how well the Army is looking after the area under its control, and I was very pleased to see how concerned the fishing industry in the Rockhampton area was that its fishing waters were duly protected and cared for.

PARA.TAB: I hope that in any future association with the reef the concern of the very active Shoalwater people is very much taken into account. It is the essence of the buzz phrase at the moment of `ecologically sustainable development' which is bandied about frequently these days. It is a trite unfortunate that sustainable development has become a term which is used far too often in the environment area and tends to lose its meaning because of its overuse. However, through debates such as this discussion tonight, I want to reinforce that message to the House, that it is areas such as the Great Barrier Reef which are the real tests of what sustainable development should be all about.

There is no second chance when it comes to the Great Barrier Reef. It is an area so unique that measures to protect the reef must be encouraged almost at all costs. That is what the marine authority is there to do, and this Bill will enable the authority to improve its effectiveness in its objectives.

I note that the starting date of this legislation is to be 1 July this year. However, my understanding is that those organisations which presently hold a permit from the authority as well as those organisations granted a permit after 1 July will both be affected by the charge. I also note that the Minister has excluded private recreational activities from the charge. And I understand from the second reading speech that such activities to be exempted from the charge will allow private boating and general access to both the beaches and areas within the barrier reef. The previous speaker expanded on this and I agree with all he said.

I do not have any opposition to any of these items and the remainder of the Bill is not contentious. I would just add one note of caution to the Minister in regard to funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in light of the legislation we are debating tonight. The Minister made the point in her second reading speech that the Government had been successful in increasing the level of funding for the authority by 2.9 per cent per year in real terms. As we prepare for the winter recess after an unduly short autumn session, I say to the Minister that, as preparations are made for the Budget, it is my fervent hope that an increase in funding will be made to the authority as it carries out its important work over and above what we are debating today, and that this Bill is not seen as an avenue for the Government to cop out on its funding for protection of the Great Barrier Reef.

The Bill will certainly assist the authority in its endeavours to protect the reef. However, the Government must play its part in providing the necessary funds for that work to continue. I support the objectives of this Bill, though I will continue to keep a keen interest in the regulations for the charges which must be tabled in accordance with the legislation. I take this opportunity to once again congratulate Graeme Kelleher, the Chairman of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, and his staff for their superb work in protecting this wonderful area. I hope that the expected revenue that this Bill will provide—somewhere in the vicinity of $1 million annually—will allow for greater protection and enjoyment of the Great Barrier Reef.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I finish by saying to you, Mr Queenslander, and I am an old Queenslander—what is it Queenslanders now say?—beautiful one day, perfect the next! Let us hope this remains the case with the Great Barrier Reef.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill and cognate Bills presented to the House by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Ms Kelly). Her presence in the House is only one indication of her total commitment to protection of the environment across the continent but more particularly in the Queensland area, for which I commend her. Following my colleagues from Queensland, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and, indeed, the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), it is fair to say we can all speak from the heart on these Bills because we have been fortunate to live in the region and represent electors who live and work in the area. I know that the Minister also responds from the heart, as she has visited this area and been profoundly affected by those visits.

PARA.TAB: On the day following the election on 13 March 1993, when we were supremely successfully, I took my family to the beautiful Capricorn coast, more particularly to Emu Park, and purchased a home with a view of the Keppel Islands, part of the Great Barrier Reef. My new responsibilities as the member for Capricornia have, unfortunately, not allowed me to enjoy the wonderful view from my lounge room window of this beautiful area. I am not sure just when I will be able to spend some time enjoying the view.

I am very privileged to live in this area and I know that the electors of Capricornia, particularly those who live and work in the mining towns and the primary producers in the hinterland, also have a particular affection for the Great Barrier Reef area, the Capricorn Coast, where they come to for recreation from their normal responsibilities out west. With the privilege of enjoying and living in this beautiful area comes a responsibility to protect this resource which justifiably earned its World Heritage listing in 1981.

Many Australians take their natural environment for granted. It is only when we travel that we become aware how much population pressures, industrial development and lack of knowledge have contributed to environmental destruction elsewhere on the planet. Unfortunately, it is often only when destruction is imminent that we Australians mobilise our concerns. In relation to the Great Barrier Reef, this occurred when proposals to drill the reef for oil and mine limestone were made by the Bjelke-Petersen Government in the 1960s. Then indeed we saw Australians, particularly people from Central Queensland, become very vocal in order to protect this asset.

This culminated in 1973 when the Commonwealth Parliament passed the Seas and Submerged Lands Act establishing Commonwealth jurisdiction over and title to the seabed below the low water mark outside State internal waters. Despite challenges by the States, the High Court upheld the Commonwealth's position in 1975. Of course, it was in this year, as has been mentioned by previous speakers, that the Commonwealth Parliament passed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority Act to which these Bills relate.

Today people would be surprised if someone argued that such a priceless asset as the Great Barrier Reef ought to belong to and be controlled by a State government. However, this was the preposterous proposition peddled by the Bjelke-Petersen Government at the time. As with many other key environmental issues in this country it was a Federal Labor Government which saved the day and initiated the preservation of this unique asset which is now contributing approximately $1.6 billion to our national economy; $1 billion of which derives directly from tourism.

As previous speakers have done, I pay credit to Malcolm Fraser who, during his prime ministership, signed an agreement which set out the basis for joint management of the marine park with the Bjelke-Petersen Government. Since that time, 98.5 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef region has come under the Marine Park Authority's jurisdiction. As the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) mentioned in her speech, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park covers an area in excess of 300,000 square kilometres—an area larger than the United Kingdom—and extends 2,300 kilometres along the east coast of Australia from Papua New Guinea to south of the Tropic of Capricorn. The region includes 2,900 individual reefs, ranging in size from less than one hectare to more than 100 square kilometres, and 250 continental islands.

The region is both complex and vulnerable as an ecosystem and management of such a vast area requires cooperation between State, Federal and local governments and all of those whose activities impact directly or indirectly on the reef. Human activity on the reef includes: commercial fishing and tourism and private recreational activities, such as fishing, diving and camping, apart from shipping, scientific research and indigenous, cultural and economic activity.

As I said earlier, tourism is the big industry contributing in excess of $1 billion to the Australian economy. A significant proportion of this comes from overseas visitors, thereby contributing favourably to our balance of payments. Overseas visitors stayed approximately 5.9 million nights in reef resorts in 1991. Those Australians who sensibly holiday at home in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park also help to promote our domestic economy and employment in the tourist industry. For those of us who have been fortunate enough to sit on the beach of one of our beautiful islands and look back to the coastline of the mainland, it is indeed a profound experience and I recommend it to all those honourable members who have not had the opportunity.

In 1991-92, approximately 2.81 million people visited the Great Barrier Reef and, as has been mentioned, forecasts estimate that this will grow to 3 million in the current financial year, representing a growth of between eight and 10 per cent a year. What is the impact on the reef of all these people? Are we in danger of loving the Great Barrier Reef to death? Some of the negative ecological effects of tourism include direct trampling by visitors. While it would seem wonderful to be able to put on a pair of sandshoes and walk around the reef, the impact is quite severe. Anchor damage by private and tourist operators from boating operations, the impact of construction of jetties and mooring structures and marinas on the reef, sewerage discharge from tourist resorts and vessels and the impact of recreational fishing and the collection of marine organisms on the balance of flora and fauna population composition are all negative impacts from tourism.

One of the urgent needs is to research and manage the impact of human activity, not only to protect the ecological integrity of the area but also to preserve those attributes that are the basis for the tourism industry. The purpose of the Bills is to provide those people who benefit from the continued protection and management of the resource to make a contribution to the cost of the said protection and management; the user-pays principle. It is reassuring, as the honourable member for Herbert said, to learn that the Opposition parties supported this principle in Fightback which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Tourists should contribute to the cost of maintaining and protecting environmental values. We believe users of our national parks should contribute more towards the upkeep and provision of facilities.

The only problem was that the coalition planned to cut spending on the environment by $10 million and, I dare say, to try to make up the difference with the user-pays principle and, of course, the GST. The figures were not going to add up. However, from the Government's point of view, the Bills presently before the House will raise $1 million in 1993-94, a significant addition to the $15 million the Federal Government now contributes to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority with a further $4 million coming from the Queensland Government.

PARA.TAB: As has been previously mentioned, 75 per cent of the revenue raised from these Bills will go to the recently created Cooperative Research Centre for Sustainable Development of the Great Barrier Reef located at Townsville. The tourist industry will be represented—the Association of Marine Park Operators—as will the Marine Park Authority, the James Cook University, the Australian Institute of Marine Science and the Queensland Department of Primary Industries. The core parties will be contributing $30 million in cash or kind over a 7-year period including an estimated $6 million from the tourist industry. This is another excellent example of industry, governments, and research institutes cooperating together. However, the cost to users, approximately $1 per passenger day, representing approximately one per cent of the cost—a typical day trip to the reef costing $100—is a small price to pay for the protection of this priceless World Heritage asset.

As has been noted, there has been extensive consultation with all participants in the industry over a four-year period. In speaking with some local representatives in Capricornia, it was pointed out to me that while there may have been some concerns raised, because no-one likes to pay a new imposition, in general terms all tourist operators are aware of their responsibilities and are prepared to support these new charges. Indeed, many of the concerns raised by tourist operators have been addressed in the schedule of charges during this period. They are designed to impact fairly on operators irrespective of their size. The fees also protect visitors from multiple charges and are in fact modest when compared with entry charges to other national parks in this country.

It is very important that users across the board are aware of their responsibilities. In fact, I think it is true to say that when we do have to pay we value what we pay for. To digress, I am reminded that when I visited the Kosciusko National Park the imposition of the user charge brought it more directly to my awareness that this charge was necessary to protect that particular national park.

I believe that Australians increasingly understand and accept the importance of protecting our environment and that this responsibility must be shouldered by the entire community. It is to the great credit of the Minister and this Government that emphasis is being placed on education of environmental issues. Having spoken to the Minister about these matters I look forward to her announcement on a number of educational initiatives which will educate the entire community on the need for environmental protection.

I hope that users of the reef will be made aware of their impact on the area and learn to cherish it, while being profoundly moved by its beauty and diversity. This awareness must also extend to communities and industries along the coast and hinterland adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Considerable research is required into the impact of rural and mining areas, as well as pollution due to urban development in coastal areas, including the clearing of coastal rainforests on waterways that ultimately empty into the reef. This is one of the responsibilities presently being undertaken by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. These Bills continue the Labor Government's responsible record on environmental protection, and I am pleased to support their passage through the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to participate in this Bill because the best part of the Great Barrier Reef goes completely along the coastline of Dawson. At the time when Dawson included Yeppoon and Emu Park all the major off-shore developments actually took place in Dawson. I cannot stress enough the beauty of this area and the need for its protection.

PARA.TAB: From time to time the National Party, with which I am closely represented in Queensland, has been basically called to account for rape and pillage of the environment. Yet it is in the history books and on record that it was the Queensland coalition and the Federal coalition that really sealed this beautiful area into a park. While there are disciplines associated with a park environment—as there have to be—over the period of the last 20 years, developers, and, I believe, all Australians, have made a conscious and deliberate effort to consider the environment in any development that takes place.

An example of that is somebody who is not well thought of in the tourist industry at the moment—Mr Skase. I believe that the Sheraton Mirage Hotel at Port Douglas is the most environmentally compatible development ever associated with the tourist industry. The basic ingredients and natural attributes of the surrounding place have been maintained. Anybody who looks at that development can only say that the developer has left the site in a better state than it was initially.

In much the same way, within the Dawson electorate and very close to Proserpine—adjacent to the Whitsunday Passage—is the latest development of the Laguna Keys by Aqua del Rey. While there was a lot of concern initially as to what was going to happen, somebody described the land on which this $1 billion complex eventually is to rest as `so hungry that even a brumby would die on it'. That was what it was. In that development, even in the first stages, they have created a marina, a golf course and other facilities. Again, one has to say that the basic philosophy, both of government and developers, has been to be compatible with the environment. The Aqua del Rey facility has enhanced the land and we are the beneficiaries of it. That is onshore.

Offshore, while some of the early developments might have created some of the problems that were mentioned by the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell), that development again is going on in sympathy with the surroundings. Probably the densest offshore development on that coastline is in that Whitsunday Passage area. On Brampton Island, Hamilton Island, Hayman Island, Lindeman Island and all the other associated islands, it is great. It is to our credit that Club Med decided to build the first of its facilities in the Southern Hemisphere on Lindeman Island, and did a wonderful job of it. As well, I want to stress that, while disciplines are necessary in some ways, the cooperation of the charter people and the developers has been great.

The honourable member for Capricornia also spelt out a list of the problems that could eventuate from human passage and human degradation on the reef and within the islands. Nature also has a way of doing things which we cannot prevent and a lot of the damage that has been ascribed to the tourist industry or to people abusing the situation is small in comparison to the damage that can be done by a flood from the mainland and natural occurrences such as cyclones and things like that.

It is interesting to note from the GBRMPA report that it associates itself not only with the main reef but also the problems associated with it from the mainland. In particular, the aquarium at Townsville is a great credit to it. It is possible to get a sense of the reef just by going through that aquarium. Again I notice from the 1991-92 report that the outlays on the aquarium are not covered by the income. I suppose it is something that somebody has to look at from the point of view of recovery, while realising that this is a facility that is being offered onshore for the education of Australians who cannot get offshore, or even the visitors who come there. That is very important.

The basis of the legislation is the user-pays principle. I know that the former Queensland Government was looking at this in conjunction with the Commonwealth. I think it is fair to say that the tourist operators are not enthusiastic about the discriminatory manner in which this charge is being made, as well as the possibility of it being increased tenfold just by the stroke of a pen. That is the real fear. It might be easy enough to say that a dollar per passenger per day is not a great amount, but other government charges and costs and taxes that charter operators have to bear are added to that—and I mention the greatest one of all, the fuel excise. They do not have bitumen roads. The roads out there are pretty rough at times, yet their contribution does not assist them in any way in their activities.

Fuel is a large cost. If we take into account sales tax, payroll tax and all the others, this extra charge is just a bit at the end. To describe it as a dollar overlooks the fact that some of these operators—and they have been to see me—are in a situation where they could be paying $10,000 extra, and having $10,000 coming out of their operations is very difficult for them. These areas are not associated with the main international routes. They have to fight for their tourist dollars as much as anyone else. The discriminatory aspect of it is the fact that casual travellers—there are thousands who use that reef in their own motor boats—are less disciplined in their approach to the reef than the charter vessels are, or have become over recent years. The Bill is discriminatory in that while I understand it gives the ability to tax these casual visitors, it is not going to do so.

Obviously the Government has come to the natural conclusion that while it can assess and tax charter operators and let them bear the cost of collection and recovery, it cannot do it to private operators. Indeed, the policing of it would be an impossibility, and it is discriminatory. I have to say to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly)—I think she already knows it—that although agreement might have been reached with all the tourist authorities in Queensland, there is by no means harmony within the charter operator camps. I believe, as others have said, that they are prepared to cop it, but they do have the fear that at the stroke of a pen the amount can be increased and they will be left to bear that charge.

They are also concerned about how the amount of $1 million will contribute towards meaningful research and protection of the reef. That is very important, but I think the Minister would be aware of those concerns and I hope she is able to allay the fears that these people have. If the money is just going to go into a bottomless pit or perhaps pay for the recovery of the aquarium at Townsville, there would be a lot of unhappy operators in the Whitsunday Passage. It is very important, as the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) has just said, that with this gradual tendency towards cash recovery, or user pays, that we do not allow the Commonwealth or the State of Queensland to pull out funds as has been done in other operations, and leave that flow-over to be collected from the people themselves.

One of the other fears I have as far as the reef is concerned is that it is becoming a bigger trade route not only to Europe but also to Asia and the Pacific, and vessels carrying coal are now in the vicinity of 200,000 to 300,000 tonnes—they are huge vessels. When we are looking at vessels of that size carrying coal, and we have oil tankers of the same tonnage using that route, any mishap in that area will be catastrophic. While there may be different opinions of what oil would do to the reef, through drilling in it or otherwise, there is no doubt that oil would cause a massive problem to the fauna and flora of the reef.

We had the Ships of shame report. I think it is imperative that Commonwealth authorities maintain their vigilance, allow only properly surveyed and authorised vessels within that area, and ensure they are piloted, whenever possible, at all times. I have had a complaint in my office from a person who was a captain on one of the oil rigs in Western Australia. That complaint proves conclusively to me that the Commonwealth has been derelict in its responsibility in allowing ships which did not have all the safeguards that were necessary to be anchored at the platforms in that northern area of Western Australia, and particularly with the drilling of oil that could have been catastrophic.

Within the last fortnight I have had complaints about the recently convened committee of Mr Tom Burns, the Queensland Minister, in connection with recreational fishing. It appears to the commercial fishermen that the recreational review is pinpointing controls on commercial fishing with no suggestion of such controls on recreational fishing. There has to be some curb on recreational fishing. The professionals use reefs that are authorised for fishing, whereas the recreational fishermen, the part-timers and weekenders, cause a lot of mischief on reefs that should be out of bounds to them. There has to be a period allowed for a reef to be safeguarded so that fishing species can re-breed, and there has to be some control over recreational fishing.

At the moment, the concern of the commercial fishermen is that all the inquiries they have been able to make, in spite of the fact they have had a two-year management plan in place, show that the whole basis of the recreational fishing inquiry is going to mean another penalty to beach fishermen and net fishermen, and also the re-licensing of boats. They have already gone through a rather grim two-year period on re-regulation and re-licensing and having licences taken off them, and also having reefs closed.

It appears in this Bill that there is a penalty for people who try to operate a small business in the area, but for anybody who wants to operate freelance there is no control whatsoever. Yet I would suggest it is the charter vessels, the professional fishermen, who have a greater concern for our environment and the reef than do the casual weekend users. I suggest to the Minister that there is concern about the imposition of this levy, mainly because it could increase. I entered this debate to set the history straight on who is responsible for the barrier reef—I well recall David Thomson, who at the time had some control over the reef, giving a guarantee to this Parliament day after day after day—

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be no drilling on the Great Barrier Reef.

—That is what he said, and in about that tone of voice. I ask those opposite to look at the Opposition as having a responsible point of view. We are not ravagers and pillagers of the environment. I believe we have a very proud record with regard to the reef and none prouder than that evidenced by the establishment of the Marine Park Authority.

—I will briefly join in this debate on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill. May I endorse some of the statements made by my good friend the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). I think the summary he has given the House tonight on the attitudes towards this particular Bill are very relevant indeed.

PARA.TAB: It is true that some four years down the track, after a great deal of debate and a great deal of discussion, we now have a situation where the levy is finally going to be implemented on 1 July this year. As the honourable member for Dawson has just said, while we are only talking about $1 per head per day, I think that the tourist industry will be ever vigilant in terms of monitoring the progress of any proposals to increase charges. I know that over the years there has been some concern, but I believe that in Australia now, in most areas, we have a most responsible tourism industry. Indeed, the cooperation that has gone on over the years between the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the various levels of governments and departments has developed to a stage now where I think it could almost be said that some of our greatest conservationists are the tourist operators. That is terribly important because the Great Barrier Reef is one of our great natural assets and will continue to be one of the very great tourist attractions for Australia.

I am delighted to see that the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) is in the House at the moment because I am sure he has briefed himself on the development of inbound tourism and the fact that North Queensland is poised to take some quite massive increases in the number of visitors who are coming in. We have seen enormous growth in Cairns. A speaker in this debate tonight mentioned that the industry there is growing by about 18 per cent per year. We are about to see Proserpine international airport come on line. If all the plans go accordingly there we will see international flights entering that particular part of the world over the next few years. There has even been some interest in Townsville as an international destination for charter flights.

In the House the other day I was interested in the dorothy dix question the Minister for Tourism received on the projections on inbound tourism growth for Australia. He chided me somewhat because we had the effrontery to go to the election projecting that we could attract 10 million international visitors into Australia by the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Geoff Carmody said they were courageous.

—They are courageous figures and they are quite achievable. If the Minister is going to set his sights on just $6 1/2 million to $7 million, I hope the country is not going to be caught short. The reality is that the Asia-Pacific basin is going to be the area that will literally explode in the second half of this decade in terms of international visitors going overseas. When we consider that from the Asian countries alone some 140 million people will be travelling offshore for their holidays by the year 2000, the opportunities for Australia as a destination are absolutely enormous. If we got 10 per cent of that business we could not handle it. We would be far in excess of the Opposition's proposed target of 10 million, and we would be in some very real trouble.

PARA.TAB: I think the fascinating thing is that the numbers for Australia are there because all of a sudden there is this awareness that is starting to build in the South-East Asian countries that we are a destination that is worth seeing and is quite different. One difference is the great natural attractions and the fact that they are in a pristine condition.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK (ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT CHARGE—GENERAL) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mrs Kelly:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: p.m.—Mr Deputy Speaker, when we see the results of overdevelopment in some of the major diving and reef destinations of the world, particularly in the West Indies and in some of the Indian Ocean ports, we realise the dangers of overexposure to the flow of tourism traffic. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Environmental Management Charge-General) Bill we are debating tonight will, I hope, help in a small way with the continued planning of access to the Great Barrier Reef by members of the tourism industry.

PARA.TAB: But the issue goes beyond the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park; it goes to a number of our national parks and the need to ensure that alternative destinations are opened up for the inflow of the great number of tourists coming through. While Far North Queensland, with the barrier reef in particular, has been a popular destination for Japanese and American tourists, it is now coming to the forefront of European tourist programs. It is quite interesting to move around the reef resorts and see the number of people, euphemistically called backpackers, who are visiting that destination.

The old saying that a backpacker was somebody who came to Australia with a clean shirt and a $10-note in his pocket, and while here changed neither, is no longer true. The backpacker—the independent European traveller—is now our biggest spender in tourism terms. The natural progression of backpackers appears to be to the north of Australia. When one looks at the projections, the reality is that there will be some tremendous pressures on Far North Queensland, the Northern Territory and, of course, Sydney.

It is for the Northern Territory and the Great Barrier Reef that we must have particular concern. While planning for access to the reef has gone quite well so far, one hopes that work will be extended and new tracts of the reef will open up for international visitors. That is terribly important.

We have seen instances of overusage in the past. A number of those honourable members who are familiar with the area would have expressed concern over the years about the overusage of places such as Green Island. A number of restoration measures had to be taken there, and Green Island is now coming back as one of the major destinations. However, just as the Northern Territory Government is looking at opening up new access to some of the magnificent northern parks in that part of Australia, so too we must be looking at ensuring that we do not cut off the hand that feeds us. We must ensure that access to new areas of the Great Barrier Reef is fully controlled so that, while we do not lose the tourism inflow, more importantly, we do not ruin the very great asset that we have.

I thoroughly agree with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) about the contribution that industry operators are already making. I have never been able to work out why, when the fishing industry receives its fuel tax free, the same condition does not apply to boat operators operating in and out of the reef. When we look at an operation like the Quicksilver, operating out of Port Douglas, or some of the other Big Cat operators out of Cairns, we see that their contribution to Commonwealth revenue through the fuel excise is absolutely enormous. We hope that those operators will get a sympathetic hearing from this Government about any future charges. While the principle of user pays is a good one, we must ensure that we do not overcrowd the industry with charges to the extent that we become non-competitive.
I support this Bill. I will certainly be joining other members of the Opposition in monitoring the situation so that it does not get out of control. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK (ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT CHARGE—EXCISE) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mrs Kelly:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to make a few brief comments in the debate on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Environmental Management Charge-Excise) Bill because time does not permit anything else. Firstly, I want to make some observations about the charges imposed on private operators in marine parks and other world heritage areas in Australia. There is a tendency for governments to set up world heritage areas in Australia without providing adequate funding to ensure that those areas are kept in the appropriate manner. There appears to be a great propensity for setting up world heritage areas in Australia, and I fully support their establishment. They are very worthwhile and contribute to Australia in tremendous ways. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), indicated, they are very attractive areas for tourism, and the Great Barrier Reef is one of those areas.

PARA.TAB: However, when we as a parliament decide that an area is a world heritage area, we should at the same time give real thought to the funding of those areas, and not lob that problem onto the operators, five, 10 or 15 years down the track. If these are world heritage areas, then there is logic in our funding those areas as a total community, rather than having the operators fund them. The fact is that many operators are already contributing very substantially to government funding through fuel excise and so on. My plea to the Parliament is: let us have our world heritage areas by all means, but let us also give consideration to the best way to fund and maintain them.

If we are going to raise moneys to support our world heritage areas in a piecemeal fashion, the administrative costs involved will probably outweigh the benefits. I suggest to both sides of the House that it might be better to raise those moneys through general revenue rather than continuing with the present piecemeal approach, such as we are seeing here, of adding a dollar to fares and so on. I am sure that the administrative costs involved for the operators and the overall administration—the government and departmental structures—far outweigh the benefit of a $1 increase. Furthermore, I do not see it staying at $1. No doubt it will rise, and rise rapidly. That will be just the start of it—the thin edge of the wedge. We need to think more carefully about how we fund our world heritage areas.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Lee) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL TRAINING AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1993]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill, in some ways, is a mechanical Bill. It meets the requirements of the present Act that the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and related bodies be reviewed within five years of the commencement of the Act. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) pointed out in his second reading speech, the five-year period ends on 30 June 1993 and the Government, not having already acted, therefore has no chance of meeting this deadline.

PARA.TAB: This amendment provides for another 12 months for the review, and the report of the review, of NBEET to take place, for the Government to decide what it will do about the recommendations and for the Parliament to act. The Opposition, of course, will not oppose this Bill because it is necessary under law that the review take place, and we would want to expedite the review itself.

For a very long time—indeed, from the inception of NBEET—we have been critical of this structure of post-secondary education in Australia. NBEET replaced independent councils which were funded to have an independence of government, to put in independent reports on matters of educational moment, to make those reports available for public comment and criticism and for government to make determinations on whether or not to act on its recommendations. NBEET is a very different kettle of fish altogether. It has become essentially an arm of government. It is not sufficiently well funded in its secretariat and in its general funding to be able to act independently of government, and it is very much under the influence and the purview of government.
The Opposition also would voice a very obvious criticism of the Government in not having acted to meet the Act last year. The Minister said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . at that time—
that is, the time when the review should have been announced—

it was clear that an election was pending and that the policy statements of the coalition and the Government saw very different futures for NBEET. The coalition undertaking to abolish NBEET was of particular significance.

I find it passing strange that the elected Government can decide within the 12-month period before a mandatory review that the fact that the coalition, its opposition, had a different policy on this body meant that the Government could not act. The Government was, of course, obliged to act. The Government is saying that it is the coalition's fault that this extension of 12 months has to happen, which is utter nonsense.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to consider what would have happened if the Government had met the imperatives of its own Act of Parliament. It would have been necessary to adjudge some time in advance last year the appropriate time for the review to be carried out. To do that, it had to appoint someone to undertake the review and it had to give some attention to the terms of reference of the review. This should have happened the best part of 12 months before 30 June 1993. So early in the second half of last year the Government should have been giving consideration to these things.

It probably would have been possible, if the Government had acted when it should have, to have had the report in by the end of last year. That would have given adequate time for the Government to have made its determination, acted and put legislation in place before 30 June this year. But the Government apparently had the election on its mind. That much emerges from the message in the Minister's second reading speech.

The Government saw one of a number of scenarios. You will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there were many who rather confidently expected the federal election to happen last year. There were others who thought that was probably not so likely and it could happen at about the time it did—late February-early March this year. But then there was another school of thought that it might have been as late as mid-May. All of those were possible.

What would have happened, if any one of those dates were chosen, if the Government had acted to review NBEET when it should have? Had the election occurred at the end of the year, even if a report had not been completed, the review would by that time have had many submissions. There would have been a great deal of highly critical comment of the Government, its actions, its structures and its policies in relation to post-secondary education. That is not the build-up to the federal election that the Labor Government wanted.

Even worse, if it had waited until March or May of this year for that election that it had not then determined, it is almost certain that the report would have been out. Indeed, if the election had not been held before May, it would have been necessary for the Government to have had on the table of this Parliament the amending legislation—and the cat would have been out of the bag. The public—or that part of it which cares about what happens in education in Australia today—would have seen a process of public criticism of the Government's educational structures and policies and it would have seen the Government's response. It would then have been able to choose fairly between the Government's intentions in this area and the Opposition's policy, which was to abolish NBEET—not abolish it just for the sake of abolishing it but as part of a tertiary education movement which was meant to lead once again to the growth and expansion of our tertiary institutions in Australia.

Part of the policy was to stop forced amalgamations, to stop government forcing educational decisions on institutions which would rightly be independent and, in the place of NBEET, to institute an independent body to give objective, critical and constructive advice to government on what it should be doing in the tertiary area. That was what happened before the election of the Hawke Government.

The old education councils gave good advice to Liberal and Labor governments alike. They were not at all uncritical. They were frequently critical, and I as a member of the Fraser Government remember some of those criticisms and would say that a number of them were justified in certain circumstances. The Fraser Government was responsive to them.

I believe that the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the present Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), has earned himself a very particular place in the history books of education in Australia. I think many people come into this place thinking that their names will end up in the history books. The fact is that very few do. Not even all Prime Ministers get much of a mention in the history books. It is rare indeed for Ministers to get much note taken of them after they have gone. Most of us are just part of a process. Nevertheless, I believe that the legacy of the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training will be a notorious one. It will be his legacy to this country that we have seen unparalleled dislocation, forced amalgamations, rigidity in the tertiary sector, lack of resources and an altogether dismal outcome.

I firmly believe that even worse is ahead. We are long past the stage of bandaid solutions in the education area. The Government had a defensive approach to undertaking this mandatory review. It is because the Government did not undertake the review that we are looking at this Bill tonight. This clearly indicates that the Government feared what was coming. The present Minister for Employment, Education and Training has some background in education and, whilst I do not agree with everything he has said or done, I have an expectation that, because of his background, he will have a better appreciation of, and sympathy for, the tertiary education sector, and particularly elections.

The so-called reforms that his predecessor brought in have left a dismal legacy. Tertiary amalgamations have had an objective of control, not development. They have been anti-education. Many times in the last 10 years I have wondered whether this Government had any sense of what education is supposed to be about and whether it had any sympathy for education. I know there are individuals who have a motivation in education, and I include the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), who is at the table. I have worked with him on House of Representatives committees on education. I know that he is well motivated. I fervently hope that he will have the satisfaction of serving in a government which will allow him to express that motivation and to achieve a desirable outcome. I hope so for the students, the institutions and the future of this country.

I believe passionately in the importance of education to humanity. I believe it is as important in those countries where there are still, unfortunately, high levels of illiteracy as it is here. I believe that, when humankind is educated and when humankind has a trained mind, we are more likely to get reasonable and good outcomes in human history than has been the case in the past. It is so easy to manipulate minds that are either uneducated or that have been narrowly educated. Under those circumstances, it is so easy for the demagogue to lead those who are well-intentioned.

I fear that, instead of having an area that is growing, an area that builds on the high level of literacy, of creativeness and inventiveness, which has been a mark of Australia in the last 50 or 60 years, we are actually losing things. It is a common complaint from those involved in tertiary education that they are stifled and restricted these days. Structures have a lot to do with that.

There was a time when there was vigorous criticism and debate of what was happening in education, especially in the tertiary area, in Australia. The Government made good structures available to people for directing criticism and debate to some good outcome without predetermining what that outcome would be. That went when the old education councils were abolished and NBEET was set up. NBEET has a number of subsidiary councils that have particular responsibilities but, underresourced as they are, there is not coming out of them what previously did. I remind the House that those councils were higher education, technical and further education, skills formation, schools and research.

So far this evening I have talked essentially about tertiary education. Because there is a guillotine on the debate on these Bills tonight and there are others who wish to have the opportunity to speak, I shall be cutting short my speech, but I do not want to finish without saying a few words about the TAFE area. I am aware that the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) is to speak tonight and I am sure he will have much to say about that subject.

It is relevant to make some comment on TAFE when talking about the tertiary area. It is relevant for this reason: some 18 months ago, as I recall, when there was a particular outcry about the shortfall of places in universities for properly qualified students, Minister Baldwin came forward with the solution that the students that missed out on university places should consider entering TAFE colleges. As far as I am concerned, that is no solution at all.

If it is Minister Baldwin's view that we need some sort of, let us say, junior college system in Australia, somewhat on the model of the United States of America, then I would be interested to hear him float that idea and let us have a constructive and vigorous debate on this potential structure in Australian education. But he has not done that. He has tried to push down into the TAFE sector the unsatisfied demand of students in the tertiary sector.

I do not say that there is anything wrong with those students going to a TAFE college—not at all—or an institute, as they may be called these days. Minister Baldwin made the point that they would probably profit in later tertiary education if they got there as a result of having studied certain courses at TAFE. For a number of them that would be true. The facts are that most students there would be there simply studying for the sake of it and hoping somehow to get into a university to do what they really wanted to do. That is a waste of money, energy and resources of the students and the colleges concerned—but worse, if you are going to push down that way, something is going to come out the other end.

What Minister Baldwin essentially was setting up was a situation of quasi tertiary TAFEs—or at least a section of them being quasi tertiary. The resources of those institutions being devoted to students who properly should not have been at a TAFE and who did not want to be there, necessarily must deny students who otherwise would have gone to a TAFE because that is where they wanted and needed to be, the opportunity to be there.

The Government can talk about expansions of funding for TAFE but at least an amount of this has to be addressed to those students. As I said, it is not even a bandaid solution at this stage. It is a twisting, a distortion, of the structure. I believe that if this goes on, before very many more years we will need to seriously review the entire structure of post-secondary education in Australia. Along the way, however, the cost will have been very high. It will have been high in terms of wasted and lost opportunities for students. It will have been high in terms of resources diverted to a purpose that was not wanted and probably was not even needed. It will have been high because it will have been done for the wrong reasons.

As I said a couple of minutes ago, if Minister Baldwin wanted to institute a system of secondary colleges, following high school, pre-further university study, let us say, then that is a subject worthy of discussion. I think it has a lot of merit. I am not committed to it, but I think it would be a useful examination and debate. But that is not the way it has been done and it is not the reason it has been done. It has not been done because there will be a better educational outcome. It has not been done because we will have better educated students. It has been done as a way of trying to disguise the Government's shortcomings in the tertiary area.

I wind up my remarks by reiterating that obviously the Opposition is not going to oppose this Bill. It wants to see that review take place. It wants to see that criticism take place. It rejects utterly that the fact that there was going to be an election, and that a different government could well have been elected, was a reason for deferring this mandatory examination of the Act. It says that the Government ought to take responsibility for the consequences of its actions. We welcome the opportunity to thoroughly examine the structure, the intent and the outcome of tertiary education in Australia today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill which is designed to allow the secondment of an individual, who is currently serving as a Commonwealth or State public servant, to the position of chief executive officer of the Australian National Training Authority. This amendment is needed in order to ensure the appointment of the former head of the Victorian State Training Board, Mr Terry Moran to the position of CEO of the ANTA.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to support this amendment because in my previous guise as secretary of the Federated Clerks Union, Victorian branch, I had a fair bit to do with the Victorian State Training Board and the development of industry training boards in that State while Mr Moran was in charge of that organisation. It is fairly widely acknowledged that Victoria has led the way nationally with respect to training in recent years in this country and the appointment of Mr Moran, and also of Mr Peter Noonan, to key positions within the Australian National Training Authority reflects this acknowledgment.

Since the mid-1980s, training in this country has undergone something of a revolution and I am very proud of the fact that Labor governments, both State and Federal, have been leading the way. In particular, my background as a union official representing non-trades workers, particularly in the area of office workers, who historically have been seen as performing work that is of low skill, of low value, and not really relevant to formal training, has been something of considerable importance to me.

If we look at the training agenda for the non-trades area prior to the mid-eighties, what we see is that training in this country was effectively in the dark ages. There was no serious accreditation structure, no obligation on employers to train their employees, no serious links between remuneration and training, and no recognition of work such as office work as being genuinely skilled, valuable and responsible.

I would have to accept that trade unions, just as much as any other section of the community, be it employers, government or whatever, were just as much to blame for the lack of serious attention to training in the non-trades areas. There were, of course, well established training structures in the trades areas through the apprenticeship system, which had lasted for a very long time, but in the non-trades areas we were very much in an unregulated, unstructured situation.

When it came to my lot along with others within the clerks union to consider the issue of training for office workers we found that we had to actually start by finding out what on earth was actually going on out there in the work force before we could even start to develop policy about how training should be conducted for skilled clerical and office workers.

The outcome of the examination that people such as myself and others were involved in led to some reasonably frightening conclusions. These included things like: the training at induction was fairly limited; large companies that performed in-house training operations tended to produce credentials that were not portable, not transferable to other work environments; many workers were expected to undergo training in their own time and at their own expense; office work in most of its forms was widely seen as unskilled, the sort of thing that anybody could walk in off the street and perform just as well as a trained person; training was often delivered informally by a co-worker, often by somebody who had no training as a trainer to be delivering that sort of training in that particular type of work; fly by night operators in particular courses, particularly in the computer area, tended to proliferate, while the quality and value of the types of training they were delivering were at a fairly expensive price, and in some instances were, at best, dubious; and the final feature, the most common training technique was basically, `Here is the computer. There is the on switch. There is your chair. Go for your life.'

That may sound a bit strange but I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in my experience in dealing with office workers that is an all too common technique or non-technique for training people in often very skilled and responsible functions. Naturally, those people tend to perform as best they can. Often it creates serious pressures, serious strains and difficulties, and the employer in the long run looses out because of an undertrained or an underskilled person struggling to keep up.

Fortunately, this Labor Government and State Labor governments have pursued a range of initiatives in the last five to seven years, along with the trade union movement, which are gradually starting to address this problem. I applaud the Government very strongly for doing so. I particularly refer to the efforts of Laurie Carmichael, who has been a key figure within the trade union movement and in government circles, in getting people interested in these issues and aware of the critical importance of training in up-skilling our work force and meeting the economic demands of the 1990s and beyond.

I refer to a number of aspects of various governments' training programs and policies. The first one is the traineeships program. I had a fairly hefty involvement with that program in my then capacity as assistant secretary of the Victorian branch of the clerks union. The traineeships program has been a very worthwhile attempt to spread something approximating the apprenticeship structure into the non-trade areas. It gives workers the opportunity to have both on-the-job and off-the-job training and in a way where they are paid at the appropriate award rate for the time they spend on the job. I have witnessed at first hand, in my capacity as an employer, as secretary of an organisation that employed over 30 people, the value of that structure because we had a trainee in our office. I have also seen it in other employment circumstances.

I suggest to the House that the training guarantee levy, which the Opposition was committed to abolishing, has been a worthwhile initiative of the Government. I have also had direct experience of that initiative from both ends, as an employer and as a representative of employees. As an employer, when the training guarantee levy was introduced our organisation was obliged to comply with that legislation. This prompted us to translate what had previously been an ad hoc approach, with no overall planning with respect to training of our own staff, into a concerted, planned and thought out approach. We established a training committee with staff representation on it. We were compelled to pay attention to the broad question of how our organisation devoted that part of its resources to training: to which people, to what types of employee and to what ends. The training guarantee levy had a positive effect, certainly in our organisation.

I have seen equivalent effects in a number of other organisations which are perhaps of a more ordinary private sector, wealth producing nature, where I or other officials of my union have been involved in representing the employees. The consequences of setting up a training committee with employee representation have been improved staff morale; better direction of the training effort so that there is a better balance in terms of the needs of the employer and the interests and the aspirations of the employees; and the possibility of more orchestrated career paths for workers in that company. I suggest to the members of the Opposition who were committed to abolishing the training guarantee levy that, if they actually went out and checked in a number of places, they would find that there are many areas in industry where the impetus generated by the Government's initiative has in fact produced positive results for the company itself.

The award restructuring program, which has been particularly difficult for many unions—unions such as my own—has nevertheless had a very positive element of connecting training levels with classification structures and remuneration levels. The landmark clerical and administrative employees award decision of the Victorian Industrial Relations Commission a couple of years ago, which established a six-level structure based on skills for the first time in the area of office work, was a breakthrough in this regard.

The State Training Board and industry training boards in Victoria have also been a very positive development. It is an illustration of the value of the work that has been done by the Terry Morans and Peter Noonans of the world that in the State Training Board we have Ivan Deveson as the chairperson, John Halfpenny as the deputy chairperson and David Edwards. In spite of the obvious differences of view and differences of constituency represented by those people, the State Training Board operates essentially on consensus and on agreement, which is a tribute to the efforts not only of the individuals I have known but also the key figures in the organisation.

At the national level we have had bodies such as NOSFAB, the national office skills formation advisory board, which has played a leading role in pursuing the development of a common framework for office skills recognition across Australia. We have had VEETAC in more recent years with the development of competency based training and a system that is designed to be focused on being standards driven and pursuing outcomes as its predominant focus, and to be based on an assessment of competencies actually achieved.

Finally in the area of training there has been the development of the network of skillshares across the country. I have about half a dozen of them in my electorate. From my observation, skillshares have played a very valuable role in improving the skills match between local workers and local businesses and providing job opportunities for people at the very disadvantaged end of the employment scale who would otherwise be seriously at risk of remaining unemployed for a very long period of time. Most instances I have seen have been quite well connected with the local business community, with a strong involvement in the orientation and management of the skillshares.

Only recently I had the pleasure of being able to visit one of the skillshares in my electorate, the RICO skillshare, which is an abbreviation for Richmond-Collingwood skillshare. I was called upon to present certificates to people who had completed catering and cleaning courses. In the presentation that I made I pointed out how pleased I was to see that people performing what had traditionally been regarded as unskilled or low skilled work that could not possibly be deemed to be worthy of accreditation were actually being recognised. They were performing work that had a significant element of skill in it that was worthy of training and accreditation.

As somebody with a background of representing office workers, who all too often have had to cope with this problem of people feeling, `You are just a clerk, you are just an office worker—any fool can do that sort of work'—and believe me, that is a very common view in the community—I was quite moved to see the pride of these people, many of whom were very disadvantaged in terms of employment prospects, in successfully completing the courses. They were looking forward to quite reasonable prospects of being able to obtain work in the catering industry or as cleaners or whatever. That is a very good illustration of the value of the skillshare program. It is pretty cost effective, and a good illustration of the appropriateness of the approach by Labor governments in this area.

Finally, it is worth mentioning, I suppose, that to the more ideological members of the Opposition this type of interventionist approach to labour market policy is anathema. I was interested to hear the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), with respect to the divide between TAFE and higher education. The fundamental problem that the former Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), had to deal with was the fact that up to 90 per cent of people completing year 12 in States like Victoria were actually applying for university. Therefore, there was simply no alternative than to suggest that, unfortunately, we do not have a university system able to cater for an intake of 90 per cent of year 12 people, and logic dictates that some of that group will have to move on to the TAFE system.

The key issue is: what do we want people ending up doing? Do we want people to get law degrees in order that at some stage down the track they can be technicians, for example? Do people need to get law degrees in order to end up being a secretary? Clearly, with any of these issues there has to be a broad approach which matches in a very general sense the education requirements with the actual employment requirements of the economy. So to suggest that a pure free market is the solution to these things is a fairly peculiar sort of approach.

The approach of the Government, I am very pleased to say, has been oriented towards developing Australia into a high skill, high quality and, dare I say it, high wage economy. The Government's approach has been aimed at improving the match between the skills in the work force and the demands, in a labour market sense, of a rapidly transforming economy. The Government's approach has been aimed at increasing the recognition of historically undervalued skills associated with work that has been predominantly performed by women workers. The clerical area is a classic example of this.

There has been a long battle which is continuing with unions that represent female workers to ensure that the traditional imbalance, which has defined work performed predominantly by men as skilled and work predominantly performed by women as unskilled or low skilled, is being turned around. For example, the very substantial skills that are exercised by a secretary, such as organisational skills and human skills that in many people's eyes are not seen as skills at all but ordinary day-to-day human activities, are finally being recognised as worthy of accreditation and worthy of recognition by remuneration.

The Australian National Training Authority is the last stage in the broad approach of the Government to reform in the training area. It is a very positive initiative. It has inevitably limited powers because it is based on a consensual approach with the States. I have made comments about the federal structure in my maiden speech so I will not repeat them. I suppose we have to live with the current circumstances in dealing with these issues. I applaud the Government for its approach to training whilst labouring under those limitations.

The Bill that is before the House ensures that the new leadership of the Australian National Training Authority, originating as it does from the Victorian State Training Board, can be properly put in place and the very important work that ANTA has been established to do can be pursued. This is based on challenging the traditional and outdated notions of training that I have referred to and placing an emphasis on quality, consistency and portability. By establishing the appropriate structures the Labor Government has focused on accreditation, on standards, on assessment and on the use of industry advisory bodies to connect the role of training and people getting general education, as well as vocational education, to the needs of industry and to the needs of our economy as it transforms itself.

The Australian National Training Authority is the last piece of the plan. It is to provide strategic coordination and generate national momentum, ideas and coordination in training. In my capacity as a trade union official I was very critical of the Government in many areas—not the least of them being industrial relations policy—but I am happy to place on record that this is one area of performance of both State and Federal Labor governments that I am very proud and pleased with. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill which we are debating tonight alters the mechanics for hiring the chief executive officer of the Australian National Training Authority which is, at the present time, in its birth throes. As it stands the amendment appears unexceptional. The Bill provides for the secondment of the chief executive officer of the authority from a State public service or authority. The original Bill provided for the secondment of lower level staff but despite detailed guidelines for the appointment of the chief executive officer, failed to make any such similar provision for the appointment of the CEO. Therefore, the Solicitor-General advised that secondment needed to be spelled out in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The chain of events leading to the proposed amendment, began with the appointment, as has been pointed out by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), of Mr Terry Moran which was announced last month. The question is why Mr Moran, a senior Victorian public servant, could not simply be appointed rather than seconded. This is a rhetorical question because I already know the answer. The reason relates to the superior salary structure for senior public servants in the State public services of the major States as compared to that of the Commonwealth.

I am informed that Mr Moran's move to the Commonwealth Public Service would have involved a loss of income for him of between $20,000 and $40,000 per year. Although a couple of rungs below department secretary in the hierarchy, Mr Moran was in the Victorian Public Service earning in the vicinity, I am informed, of some $170,000 compared to the $120,000 received by departmental heads in the Commonwealth Public Service.

While the $120,000 is before add-ons like superannuation, and the $170,000 includes them, because of the generous bonuses of the State service the difference in the salary Mr Moran would have received had he simply moved to the Commonwealth is still in the vicinity of $20,000 to $40,000, according to my advice. The Government argues that it must have the best man for the job, who in this case is deemed to be Mr Moran, and that it would be unfair to ask him to drop his salary. We understand that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) approached the Remuneration Tribunal to adjust Mr Moran's pay packet upwards but it said `no go' and the Minister had to go back to the drawing board.

We have no quarrel with the appointment of Mr Moran, but the greater general public—large numbers of whom are unemployed, many for a long time—cannot help but marvel at the salaries of men who are supposed to be their servants. When the average salary in Australia is I think in the order of $31,000, $120,000 looks very healthy and $170,000 positively extravagant. One would be forgiven for thinking that it is just a tad insensitive of the Government to introduce a Bill to assist one man to a salary of almost six times the average.

Mr Moran's soon to be fellow Commonwealth departmental heads will also be forgiven for being somewhat peeved at the engineered disparity between their situation and that of their colleague. The principle of equal pay for equal work does not seem to be in operation here. Dare I say it, but to Mr or Mrs average Australia—who is in debt up to his or her ears with a mortgage on a house worth possibly a whole lot less than he or she paid for it when the Government allowed interest rates to hit 18 per cent a couple of years back, who is supporting adult children who cannot get jobs and who is stressed out because any day his or her own job might be lost—this legislation would look like yet another episode of Canberra's answer to Fat Cat and Friends.

I take this opportunity to raise the chief concerns connected with the establishment of this new national megalith, the Australian National Training Authority. In principle, it seems a perfectly good thing: a means of raising the vocational skills of the population and of introducing some harmony into the national chaos of training. Cynically, however, I fear that it just another example of a Labor government's residualist, totalitarian mania for large totems, of which many see this House on the hill as another example.

The declared intention behind the Australian National Training Authority, set in motion under the Act which was passed last year and agreed to by the Commonwealth, States and Territories, was to establish a national vocational education and training system to have close interaction between industry and vocational training providers and to promote an effective training market and improved cross-sectoral links.

ANTA is to commence its operation on 1 January 1994. Its board is to comprise five members appointed for five years by the Governor-General on the nomination of the ministerial council. It has been described variously as either a bank or a post office, with the States pouring in their vocational training funds and getting them allocated back on the basis of principles determined by the ministerial council and the States administering programs within guidelines approved by that council. The council, made up of one Minister from each State and Territory and one from the Commonwealth, is to make up national goals and decide the principles according to which the funds are allocated. Such, at least, are the bare facts. But how will it operate in effect?

Some serious questions were raised during the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training last December when it met to consider ANTA. Peter Eggleston from the Australian Mining Industry Council testified that what industry needs is a decentralised and responsive approach rather than a centralised bureaucratic approach. ANTA appears to be just adding another layer of bureaucracy.

Further, it is premised on the idea of dealing with the supply side of training; that is, developing training profiles and national priorities. Peter Eggleston said that what had made mining competitive internationally was its ability to respond quickly to changes in the market and to implement new technology and develop new skills as required. Training, he said, should be driven by the demand side, by the marketplace. The test, he said—and this was the overall conclusion of the Senate committee's report—was that the raison d'etre of the authority was to improve productivity. Mr Eggleston said that, looking at the plan of the authority, one could not predict that ANTA would achieve any such increase at the local level. National profiles were, he believed, a means to a control system rather than the flexible system required by industry.

There was a view registered by the industry witnesses at the hearing that the national framework made sense in terms of providing consistency across Australia, but that it should be only a loose structure to enable decentralisation of decision making, curriculum development and skills development to allow a swift response to a local clientele. Mr Mark Patterson from the Retail Traders Association declared that industry was being ignored in many of the decisions already being taken. He said that when his national industry training council saw a copy of the draft legislation, it was refused access, although it had already been tabled in Parliament. Mr Patterson said:
Our concern is that it—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, ANTA—
is saying one thing and doing another.

There are also question marks about the overlapping of areas dealt with by ANTA and by the national training board, by the Australian Committee for Training and Curricula, by the Employment and Skills Formation Council and by the Vocational Education, Employment and Training Advisory Committee.

PARA.TAB: One witness, Dr William Hall from the National Centre for Vocational Education and Research Ltd, said there was a danger in that ANTA represents a non-representative level of government, whereas hitherto the training committees have been composed of representatives from the States, Territories, unions, employers and so on. There was little consultation in the setting up of ANTA. The choice of Brisbane as the headquarters was, as Dr Hall has written, `an example of raw politics'. It was fascinating to note that Dr Hall, in his submission, testified that he was `one of the few people who fearlessly write about this and express concerns in the media'. One wonders what others have to fear.

While we support the idea of providing a cohesive national training system, we are fearful it will only be another episode in the Government's drive to impose a rigid, central control via a national curriculum which, though claiming to promote vocational skilling, will actually hold it back. These changes are, of course, predicated on the destruction of an efficient system of vocational education delivered through the colleges and technological institutes until they were incorporated into the new mega-universities. In this connection, it is interesting to note the remarks of the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) on the national unified system given in a 1990 address to the University of Wollongong. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We might by the year 2000 have returned to a binary system of tertiary education either de facto or de jure, recognising with hindsight that different people have different needs and that institutions can and should provide a variety of approaches, not all necessarily under the title of university.

We can only hope that this Labor Government will learn from its own mistakes. However, we should not trust in miracles. On balance, we do not oppose this amendment, though we support it without great enthusiasm.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the surface, the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill and cognate Bills requiring the Higher Education Council to report annually to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training instead of the present twice-yearly reporting mechanism seems reasonable, but I am concerned about the possible impact of this on country students. The reason given for this proposed amendment is that the council has experienced difficulties in providing a substantial report in August because of lack of data. Perhaps instead of changing the reporting conditions, we should be examining the data and its collection.
