PARA.TAB: As honourable members would know, the Higher Education Council advises the National Board of Employment, Education and Training on a range of higher education issues, including development funding and the identification of priorities for staffing and for facilities.

I hope the council has been examining the desperate need for a massive increase in places for students at higher education institutions in Australia, and particularly in country areas such as Bendigo. This year, thousands of Victorian students were unable to continue their studies because the Government did not fund sufficient places to meet the demand, and that demand continues to increase.

For example, in Bendigo this year 3,933 students listed University College of Northern Victoria courses in their first three preferences, compared with 3,438 in 1992. In March last year, the then Minister for Higher Education wrote to me and admitted that the demand for higher education would rise, yet he did nothing to create enough tertiary places to meet the demand.

The Minister did allocate an additional 35 places for La Trobe University for 1993, but these extra places had to be shared between La Trobe University and the University College in Bendigo. That was woefully inadequate considering the increased number of country students wanting to continue their studies in Bendigo.

In fact this year the Victoria Kennett Government came to the rescue of the Loddon-Campaspe college of TAFE in Bendigo and provided $9.4 million to fund an extra 500 places at the TAFE college and ease the shortfall of places. Where was the Minister of the day while all of this was happening? He was probably sitting on his hands and hoping the problem would go away, or that his Government would not be re-elected and would not have to address the problem.

The Keating Government has been re-elected and must now deal with the problem of insufficient tertiary places to meet demand. I wonder whether the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) has any plans in place yet to cope with the demand for tertiary places in 1994. Regrettably, I suspect he does not. Perhaps the Minister is hoping that the Victorian Government will once again come to the rescue and do his job for him.

The education of young Australians is of critical importance to our nation—these young people are our future, and this Government should be encouraging them by ensuring places are available for those who wish to study and equip themselves to make Australia truly the clever country.

I suggest that the Minister needs to take more notice of what is really happening in tertiary institutions around this nation. Perhaps he should make the effort to see first-hand just how much pressure institutions like the University College of Northern Victoria are under to provide sufficient places for suitably qualified students. I would be happy to have the Minister in my electorate at any time to visit University College to see the problems in that area.

Perhaps the Minister, through the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, should take more notice of the Higher Education Council. To my mind, it makes more sense to have regular reports on the needs of higher education institutions in order to respond more quickly to those needs. A quick response cannot happen when the Government receives only one report each year. After all, this Government has already shown it is incapable of acting quickly to solve a crisis that it has known about for some time.

The Labor Government's lack of action in dealing with problems like insufficient tertiary places is hardly surprising when one considers the origins of the word `labor' in Labor Party. It comes from the Latin laborem, meaning distress, trouble, painful or compulsory exertion, and that is the problem with the party on the other side of the chamber—it acts only when it is painfully compelled to do so.

The educational needs of young Australians should be compelling enough reason for the Minister to act. Let the council continue to report twice a year, and let the Minister act on those reports. I challenge the Minister to clearly define the course of action he will take to ensure no suitably qualified students are left without fully funded places in Australia's tertiary education institutions in 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of observations about the remarks made by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). Actually, the honourable member for Menzies was probably the only Opposition speaker to touch on the substance of the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill. I would like to point out to him that the selection of the chief executive is a matter for the ANTA board in consultation with the ministerial council. I am sure he did not mean to suggest that this was the responsibility of the Commonwealth alone. The Commonwealth is just one member of the ministerial council and I think that needs to be placed on the record.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether the honourable member intended, strictly for the purposes of debate, to attribute some sinister motives to the establishment of ANTA or suggest that there is more to the national training agenda than is strictly apparent in the legislation and in the action that has been taken to establish ANTA so far. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight in anger at a photograph which appeared on the front page of my morning Advertiser in South Australia. It is a picture of a journalist, hand-cuffed and manacled, being led along a public street of Adelaide to his appeal hearing. It is a disgrace and I feel shamed that this has happened in my State. It is, if anything, a re-creation of the events at Port Arthur decades ago. It is simply an uncivilised move by an uncivilised government whose Attorney-General has attacked this journalist in the Legislative Council in South Australia after he has been cleared by a jury of any default at law. He has been given a vindictive sentence of four months for refusing to reveal his sources of information. This is occurring in a State with the greatest cover-up of financial depredation in Australia's history, and in which there is deliberate intimidation of reporters who dig out information about these depredations.

PARA.TAB: Think of it, Mr Speaker. We have a bank that has lost $3.1 billion. It is a bank which has left a trail of bad decisions, a display of selfish management and a string of crooked arrangements in the deals it has financed. Yet the bank now attacks this reporter, David Heilby, who is the second reporter threatened with gaol for refusing to divulge his sources. He has been able to ferret out many of these details which the bank itself was hiding.

It is not good enough that the State of South Australia is really becoming a penitentiary of the mind, as those who reveal wrongdoings are the ones who are attacked. In my State there is a loss of $3.1 billion but there are no prosecutions, no attempted prosecutions. There are attacks by the Attorney-General upon journalists who reveal these facts and the State goes on. It is a disgrace. Who would believe the State Bank? The State Bank is attacking the reporter and not the paper. It is the direction of its attack that explains and fully reveals the bank's policy of intimidation. Well it might. I remember serving on the banking inquiry when we took evidence, as you well know, Mr Speaker, from bank officials which then revealed a loss of some $2 billion.

I said publicly after that, from what I had heard, that the loss would accumulate to $3 billion and I was violently attacked in the media by Mr Johnson, the new manager of the State Bank. What is the loss now—$3.1 billion. Who would believe Mr Johnson? Who would believe these gutless administrators of a State bank who attack reporters and do nothing about the deprivation of the State's finances?

It is simply an utter disgrace. I would like to see a post on every corner throughout South Australia with a photo on it showing a manacled, handcuffed reporter being sentenced to a vindictive four-month sentence for refusing to divulge his sources and being led up a public street in Adelaide. I would like to see that photo on every corner in South Australia with the caption: `This happened in my State under a Labor Government'. I know that the result is inevitable: this rotten administration which attacks those who reveal its faults, its failures and—

TALK.START.PARA: —The truth.

—Yes, and the truth. This administration attacks the reporters rather than attacking those who caused the problem. The criminals are out there in the community, hidden; the reporters are going to gaol and the Government has to go.

—It is always inspiring to hear a fiery speech. Tonight I wish to talk about what I regard as another example of the colonial cringe and that is in the new-found obsession with foreign languages. Of course there is a place for learning foreign languages, but the obsession with teaching them across a broad range of students as a ready means of improving trade is simplistic and misplaced. In fact, it is just another educational fad that will pass with time, but which will lead to valuable resources being misplaced and misused.

PARA.TAB: Certainly those students who do not study foreign languages should not be penalised, particularly not in prime courses. Yet this is precisely what Melbourne University is effectively doing. The university has adopted a bonus system for the 1995 entrance which will unfairly advantage students studying languages other than English. As has been pointed out by Robyn Spencer in a letter to the Australian of 22 February 1993, entrance scores in maths and science for medicine are already 96 per cent. When the language other than english bonus of 10 per cent is added, this will prove decisive in many cases, if not in most cases.

A local Australian student without LOTE who qualifies in maths and science for medicine may still miss out to a student who scores less in these areas but who has LOTE. This is either a piece of fashionable stupidity on the part of Melbourne University or an insidious way of ensuring that it receives more full fee paying foreign students.

Universities already effectively exclude qualified locals in prime courses, setting a local entry rate lower than it need be in order to attract foreign students. This is because foreign students pay full fees which the institutions can use at their discretion while locals are subsidised. It is much more lucrative for institutions to take foreign students. Foreign students already occupy up to 50 per cent of places in sought after courses in some of these institutions.

There are many courses which are supposed to be making us the clever country. Locals are now to be further disadvantaged in accessing them because other institutions will copy Melbourne University. All we have heard about this issue from the institutions and their representatives has been misrepresentations and denials. Yet these are the facts.

The institutions have also placed representatives in overseas countries to drum up foreign student business. The methods of some of them have been subject to sharp criticism in Asian countries. All they seem to care about is the numbers and the money. Quality and the best interests of Australian locals run a distant second. Far from improving our image overseas, these institutions make us look like grasping money grubbers. So much for those who worry so much about how we are perceived overseas.

If this sort of problem is not enough, we now have members of the Australian Tourist Commission wanting to open up tourism trade from China. The fiasco with the Chinese students did not do enough for these geniuses; they want to repeat it with Chinese tourists. I can tell the House what will happen if this goes ahead: many of the so-called tourists will lie to obtain visas, come to Australia and either go missing or claim that they will face persecution if they return to China. In other words, they will claim refugee status, along with the thousands of so-called Chinese students who have already done just this. The big difference is that there will be many more pseudo tourists than pseudo students.

The ATC will point to the number of Chinese tourists coming in and claim that it is great for the economy. In the meantime, it will have to bear none of the costs of tracking down overstayers and processing refugee applications. Humanitarian lawyers, posturing journalists and the associated industry will have a field day defending the pseudo tourists and attacking the immigration authorities, who will have to come in and try to clean up the mess.

The way things are going with the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) making approving noises, this stupid scheme may be accepted. Would the ATC be so enthusiastic if it were made to bear the financial responsibility from its own budget for any Chinese who overstay or pseudo tourists claiming refugee status who came in under the proposed scheme? This is precisely what would happen, because these characters clearly have no conception of the wider national interest. All they want to do is point to the numbers and say, `Just look at how well we are doing. Just look at all the tourists coming in'. It will not occur to these Einsteins to count the tourists going out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address the House in response to the comments made on Tuesday by the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith). I am appalled that the honourable member for Perth, a former adviser to the worst government in Western Australian history, should have the temerity to question the Court Government's decision to close the Midland railway workshops.

PARA.TAB: The decent, hardworking men of the Midland workshops have been sold out by the ALP in Western Australia, the party that so many of them have loyally supported. They are the victims of Labor's mismanagement. They have become the pawns of a Labor government which pretends to represent the interests of the workers but which in reality looks after only the elite of the Labor hierarchy and its mates. Men such as the honourable for Perth who sit in this House in their designer suits, who have never known what it is like not to have a job or prospects for one, should remember that if they are going to live in a glass house they should not throw stones.

It is fascinating to hear how the honourable member for Perth suddenly put such a high priority on the jobs of 850 men employed in the Midland workshops when the Labor Party in Western Australia has downgraded them for the last 10 years. It was going to take 10 years to ensure the job security of these workers through the implementation of a program of upgrading and expanding the operation of the facility. However, the facilities were allowed to fall into disrepair with antiquated equipment.

It is a cruel joke on the hardworking employees. Everyone in Midland knows that during the 10 years of the Labor Government the Midland workshops have become little more than a museum. It is a joke attempting to train apprentices, whose number is now at an all-time low, in these workshops. These apprentices have little hope of employment after training on outdated equipment. So much for Labor's practical belief in training.

Just what sort of a State government commissions reports, accepts submissions for reforms of workshops that could have been saved by an earlier injection of capital and expansion into the private sector market and then sits tight and ignores the options, all the while the Westrail fleet was being cut so that less work was required? The workshops lost $80 million of taxpayers' money last year and $22 million the year before. Eighty million dollars could pay for nine new primary schools or upgrade existing schools in the Swan View area.

It was typical of the practice of the Western Australian Labor Government that it concealed the full commercial realities of the workshop from public scrutiny, and squandered so much public money on WA Inc. deals, that the capital funds that today might conceivably have rescued the workshops do not exist. The Court Government intended to try to revitalise the workshops, and would have pulled out all the stops to do so, but the facility is simply too far gone after a decade of Labor mismanagement.

This is a disgrace and all of Midland knows where the blame ought rightfully belong. If the honourable member for Perth wants to help the workers in his party, whom he has betrayed, he should get behind June van de Klashorst, the State member for Swan Hills, who is now actively supporting Westrail's redeployment task force. Already 250 workers have sought redundancy and 60 new local jobs have been found, no thanks to the ALP in Western Australia. So much for Labor's track record. Labor members are so far out of kilter with the Australian worker that they should be ashamed to raise their heads above their desks in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I must say I have not had the opportunity to congratulate you on your election to high office, nor to commend you for the very tremendous way you have been exercising your duties.
—A pity about the Steelers.

—As the honourable member for Parramatta so rudely interjects, a pity about the Steelers. I want to raise a very important issue about people who are social welfare beneficiaries. Unfortunately, I am sure that every member of the Parliament has heard of the incident of unemployed people who have been found collecting unemployment benefits inappropriately, and who have been rightly prosecuted by the department. I make it quite clear from the outset that I rightly condemn such action, but recently there has been in my electorate a case where it was found that an employer, a company, was encouraging unemployed people to retain their social security benefits and to be paid cash in hand. What surprises me is that the department is quite rigorous in prosecuting the unemployed person and recovering the money, but there appears to be little in the Social Security Act that is brought to bear against the company or the employer. It is my understanding, in law, that the only remedy available to the department is prosecution under conspiracy provisions.

PARA.TAB: I am very interested to know from the Department of Social Security how many cases it has detected, or believes it has found, where there is a prima facie case against an employer for inducing a social welfare recipient to work for that employer and retain the benefit.Of those cases I would ask how many have been prosecuted, and with what result. I think, quite frankly, it is outrageous that the full brunt of the law is brought to bear against only the social welfare recipient. As I have said, I do not defend such people. I think they are wrong but I believe that the greater wrong has been by the employer.

Mr Speaker, I can also advise you that regrettably there has been a raid by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, with similar results. I am very keen to know from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs whether the same situation applies with the Immigration Act as it does with the Social Security Act.

In how many cases has the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs found that it has had a reasonable or prime facie case against employers wrongfully employing illegals? How many have proceeded to court and to what effect? I feel that the Government must be even-handed and that we should condemn both individuals—the illegal alien and the employer.

I give notice to the House that, unless I can get some satisfaction on these issues, I am not going to let go. It will be my intention to introduce a private member's Bill which will rectify the law and provide some justice for all involved.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the negative.
Bill returned from the Senate with an amendment.
Ordered that the amendment be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Senate's amendment—

PROCTEXT.PARA: After clause 3, page 4, add the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "4. Schedule 2, Standard Conditions, Part 6, Subscription Television Broadcasting Licences, clause 10, paragraph (1)(g) of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `and the ABA has approved the broadcast of such programs;' and substituting `and the ABA has recommended, and the Parliament has, by resolution of each House, approved, the broadcast of such programs;'.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is to the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) which, whilst a lengthy piece of work dealing with a number of matters, fundamentally achieves its fame by virtue of the fact that it adds to the provisions associated with bidding for subscription television broadcasting licences a requirement that a deposit be placed by any of those bidding. It is necessary to deal with the Bill at this stage because, in the process which is under way at the moment, there is a possibility that clauses in the original Act may be activated which would require a reconsideration of the people who were initially invited to take up an option on a licence.

PARA.TAB: This amendment has nothing to do with that particular issue. This is an amendment moved by Senator Harradine which goes to certain responsibilities of the broadcasting authority in relation to materials that may be broadcast by the subscriber. The amendment is to schedule 2, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is amended by omitting `and the ABA has approved the broadcast of such programs;' and substituting `and the ABA has recommended, and the Parliament has, by resolution of each House, approved, the broadcast of such programs;'.".

Anyone who knows the record of Senator Harradine in this place over the years would know that he is always most keen, in areas where there is a conceivable degree of interest on his part, dealing with materials broadcast by would-be licence holders of any description, that a high level of parliamentary scrutiny be maintained over those decisions which are reached.

PARA.TAB: Generally speaking, historically, both sides of the chamber have tended to resist that. That apparently has not taken place in this instance. I do not know who in this particular instance went to water, on either side of the chamber—or, indeed, whether anyone did and the thing just slipped through unnoticed. In any case, we are not particularly fussed about the amendment at this stage.

As I have said, of all the matters of controversy which have divided the House, and more recently the Senate, on this matter over the last few weeks, this ain't one of them. Nevertheless, for the Bill to become law, we have to deal with this matter now in order that it can become operational immediately; and there are sound reasons as to why this Bill ought to become operational immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) said, the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill has as its principal purpose the establishment of a condition for all remaining tenderers—if they happen to have a chance to become the principal tenderers for the subscription television by satellite licences—that they must pay five per cent of their tender as a deposit. This change was quite unsatisfactory in the view of the Opposition. It was a piece of legislation that the Opposition disapproved of and opposed. It was a condition which we believe should have been in the original provisions for the tenders. The fact that it was not in the original conditions shows the incompetence with which the tender process has been handled.

PARA.TAB: The Government then recognised that without such a provision the tender process was open to speculative tenders; it was open to the production of inordinate delays in the granting of licences; and it was open to processes which involved multiple reducing bids. From the public's point of view, the Government's point of view and the Opposition's point of view, the process which had been established was unsatisfactory. It was established because Senator Collins decided that it was sufficient exercise of his ministerial responsibility to sign the cover note of the determination and not to read the contents. What we have here is another part of the fiasco of the introduction into Australia of pay television.

The Opposition opposes this because we believe it was quite improper to change the conditions of the tender retrospectively. Not only does it call into question the capacity of those who won the initial bids to obtain the finance to implement, construct and make valid and practicable their tenders; it also strikes at any future tenders that the Government might put forward. What confidence could anyone have in a tender process established by this Government when the Government apparently sees fit to change the processes and guidelines of the tender before the whole procedure has been worked through?

In our view the initial legislation was unsatisfactory—it was retrospective, it was obnoxious, and we opposed it. It has now gone through the Senate. We have been told this evening by the Government that it has been amended in the Senate. The Minister admits that the amendment is one which has slipped through. Apparently the Government is now in a frame of mind in which it will accept anything to move this smelly mess off its plate and as fast as possible to remove it from the consideration of the Parliament.

We have seen in this legislation—and in other legislation debated at length in the Senate tonight—that the Government is prepared to accept amendments which it does not believe in, which it does not see as necessary and which under ordinary circumstances it would not support and would not be recommending to the Parliament, because it will say and do anything to get its legislation through.

In this House we are now observing evidence of the chaos that has ensued from the Government's whole conduct and implementation of its pay TV policy. The people of Australia should know that this vital service is being handled by a government which has completely set aside consideration of the public interest, which no longer conducts any reasonable scrutiny of the legislation, but will accept any amendment, provided it gets through a few of the basic provisions necessary to rescue it from the colossal fiasco caused by the negligence of Senator Collins.

The Opposition does not object to this particular amendment. We are prepared to accept it as an amendment to the legislation, given the fact that the legislation has now been passed by this House and by the Senate. However, on behalf of the Opposition, and on behalf of the people of Australia who are listening to this debate, I want to register in unequivocal terms our disgust at the entire process—the way it has been managed, and the way legislation, whose content is not of the slightest concern to the Government, has been stampeded through this House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I take this opportunity, the first I have had to do so, to congratulate you on your election to your high office. I wish you well in your term as Speaker of this House. I hope that you will be seen in the future as having been a fair adjudicator in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: During Question Time today I asked the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) if he could advise honourable members, in view of the Government's planned introduction of its new vision of enterprise bargaining, how it will treat the 70 per cent of Australian workers in the private work force who are not members of unions and have no wish to have their wages and conditions of employment controlled by the union bureaucracy.

I listened with great interest to the Minister's answer. The Minister gave us a lecture, in poor syntax, about the consultative process he used in developing the legislation which, it is my understanding, he intends to bring into this House in the Budget session. He said, over and over again, `I am consulting with the unions'. At the end of the day he had said nothing about how he intended to integrate those workers—representing 70 per cent of the private work force and 60 per cent of the total work force—who are not members of unions into this grand vision of enterprise bargaining. He basically had no answer.

It is my fair expectation that the Minister has no answer because he really has no intention of honouring the promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to 700 industry leaders in Melbourne some two or three weeks ago. The reason for that is that this Government, tied as it is and constrained by its formal relationship with the trade union movement, with the ACTU, is hamstrung in any attempt to deregulate the labour market in Australia.

A recent EPAC report states very clearly that if we want efficiency out of the labour market in an overall economic sense, then either we have an extremely highly regulated and controlled system which is seen to be fair or we deregulate the labour market. We do not have a halfway house. What this Government has proposed and has in train in a sense is a halfway house.

We have at a base level a set of awards which are supposedly negotiated by unions on behalf of employees but which are in fact awards determined by the ACTU and the State based Labor councils and ramrodded through compliant and complacent employer organisations which are members of the club. These awards then become the benchmark and no-one goes below them, regardless of what they say. So the award becomes a base and enterprise bargaining is used to see how much we can get above the award.

My colleague the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) spoke earlier in the week in this House about the shearers. The Industrial Relations Commission, at the behest of the unions, says that shearers ought to get a wage increase. But what is happening to the people who own the sheep? They are going broke. They do not get a wage increase; their incomes are reduced still further in the negative this year from last year and perhaps next year as well.

The Prime Minister's vision of enterprise bargaining becoming the benchmark for the Australian industrial relations system is nothing but a sham on top of sham, on top of sham. The Labor Party has this great rhetoric—pick up the Opposition's language, use the language, use the rhetoric and run the line but at the end of the day accomplish absolutely nothing in terms of giving Australians a fair go, giving industry a break and doing something about jobs for those who do not have jobs and not worry about those who have jobs and are well taken care of. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to get this opportunity to speak on the adjournment, not having got the call earlier in the day. Today I submitted to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) representations from a group of civilian widows in Rockhampton who feel they are being discriminated against because they are no longer eligible to apply for the widows pension.

PARA.TAB: Within three months of the death of their spouse they must register for the dole and cope with the stress of applying for jobs. Many of these women have never been in the paid work force as adults. They have been full-time homemakers and are the backbone of many voluntary community services.

They grew up at a time when educational opportunities were not available to girls. I am thankful to say, given 10 years of good Labor government, that that situation has now changed dramatically. Although they have many practical and life skills, they do not have the necessary qualifications to be competitive in a labour market which is very difficult for most people, let alone unskilled older women against whom, as we know, there is a great deal of discrimination. I am certain that the new women members of the House will do much to offset that.

It should be remembered that this difficult challenge for this group of women is presented to them when they are adjusting to the reality of the loss of their partner, often after nursing their spouse through a long illness or with the shock of sudden death of their spouse. As a counsellor, I can assure the House that the grief process takes a lot longer than three months to get through and it is at this very time that widows are actually beginning to face the reality.

The most disadvantaged group is women over 50. As I said before, they are particularly disadvantaged when they go to seek work. As the Government is now looking at the position of the older long-term unemployed, it would be timely to also consider this particularly disadvantaged group of women.

This group of women, and others whom they represent across the country, do not want anything particularly special: they want relativity with benefits available to other social security pensioners. At the present time, this group of women feel like third-class citizens, and very often they do not have money laid aside or have not been part of superannuation schemes. They have been battlers who have paid taxes and now find themselves in an invidious and poverty stricken situation.

I applaud the Government's actions on providing opportunities for women of all ages and acknowledge that many widows have in fact used these opportunities. But the group that I am most concerned about, while having shown incredible ability to lobby politicians and gain considerable community support, still feel themselves to be disadvantaged and discriminated against. They are aware that the widows pension is unlikely to be brought back in. They are not looking for that but for some more creative solutions from our Government to deal with their needs. I believe that those creative solutions are there and require some flexibility in policy making, and I will be making further representations to the Minister on their behalf.
This issue concerns the widows of not only Capricornia but elsewhere in Australia. I know their situation has been taken up by other women's organisations such as the Country Women's Association.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on your elevation to your honoured position. I rise tonight to address a matter of importance to the electors of Cowan and possibly to those other electors in marginal seats. Like other seats, on 13 March Cowan experienced a change of member, electing myself in preference to the Labor member, Mrs Carolyn Jakobsen. I have been very disappointed, even annoyed, at the difficulties I have experienced in the changeover of the electorate office from Mrs Jakobsen to me. In my view, Mrs Jakobsen has seriously jeopardised the effectiveness with which the interest and concerns of the electors of Cowan can be properly represented.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Jakobsen, having had some weeks notice to make the necessary changes to remove herself, staff and belongings from the electorate office, had to be forced out of her former office by the Department of Administrative Services. In addition to knowingly and possibly deliberately obstructing me from the beginning to represent the interests of my electorate, Mrs Jakobsen cleared the entire office of every possible belonging and item, with the exception of filing cabinets, workstations and chairs, telephone systems and an answering machine. To paint the picture more clearly, Mrs Jakobsen took everything, including telephone books, manuals to phones and computer systems, information guides for electors, departmental contact lists, toilet paper and many other items that I as a member should have been able to use immediately on taking up my position as the new member for Cowan in the service of the electors.

Of more concern to me and my ability to perform effectively as a representative of the people of Cowan was the fact that the former member chose to remove from her office the many constituent files that had yet to be attended to or even acted upon. These electors have concerns that deserve and require the attention of their member of parliament, irrespective of their political persuasion. Given Mrs Jakobsen's irresponsibility and mischievous actions, how was I supposed to represent the interests of those constituents? Needless to say, the problem has now been overcome.

I draw on my own personal experience with the former member for Cowan to highlight a much more important issue and one on which I would like to have my comments and thoughts recorded early in my parliamentary service. The issue is representation and the value which members place on that important and often burdensome obligation. Surely, each of us owes it to our constituents and electorates to ensure that a smooth transition of office occurs between representatives who replace former members of parliament, thus ensuring that electors are guaranteed representation on a continuing basis.

It is often mentioned in this place that our conduct is worthy of improvement and that our attitudes for respect for this place, its traditions and institutions are looked upon with disdain by members of the wider community. I agree with the sentiment of many that we owe it to ourselves in the community to improve our performance, but I wonder how effective we are in looking after the interests of our electors if I as a new member am forced to confront attitudes like that exhibited by the former member.
I would like to quote an important former member of this place, one who understood the importance of tradition and civic responsibility. In 1948 Robert Menzies, as he was at the time, noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Politics is the most important and responsible civic activity to which a person may devote their character, their talents and their energy. We must in our own interests elevate politics into statesmanship and statecraft. We must aim at a condition of affairs in which we shall no longer reserve the dignified name of statesman for a Churchill or a Roosevelt but extend it to lesser persons who give honourable and patriotic service in public affairs. Our electors have a right to expect as much.

My experience is the ultimate paradox for the constituents of Cowan, especially when the former member prided herself on `caring for Cowan'. Only now, only from 13 March, will they have a fully representative member of parliament interested in their issues and their concerns.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, can I take this opportunity to thank the officers of the Department of Administrative Services in Perth, in particular Chris Palser, and the Australian Electoral Commission office in Cowan for all their very generous assistance to me and my staff since I became the federal member.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have almost completed my first two weeks as a member of this House. It has been a very interesting time. There are a lot of things to learn and a lot of things to take in. But I guess the most disappointing aspect, from a professional point of view as a member of parliament, that I have noticed in the last two weeks has been the absolutely pathetic and appalling quality of the Opposition's debating in this House, its absolute failure to talk about any substantive issues. I think the last two speakers from the Opposition, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) and the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans), are very good cases in point.

PARA.TAB: Today of course we also had the spectacle of the Opposition in Question Time failing to ask one single question of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I do not know whether that is a tactical decision or not, but it shows that those opposite just do not have the guts to let the Prime Minister speak in Question Time. One can only imagine what their fears might be.

Over the last couple of weeks, I have listened very closely to the Address-in-Reply debate and debate on the appropriation Bills, et cetera. All that those opposite have done in those debates has been to try to re-fight the election campaign, to whinge about the Government's victory, and to complain about how the people did not vote for Fightback because we told lies, because we were dishonest and they were the only honest people. They cannot accept the fact that the people of Australia totally rejected their draconian, New Right, economic rationalist package—they threw it out; all they can do is whinge. They complain and whinge about their failure.

Those opposite cannot say anything constructive. They obviously have not learnt anything by their ignominious defeat on 13 March. Apart from trying to re-fight the election campaign two months after the event, the only other contribution they have made is to whinge about the republic debate. We cannot have change in this country. We have a Constitution that is 92 or 93 years old, and these people seem to think that it is absolute sacrilege to talk about any reform or change to the Constitution. How dreadful that people talk about change!

I joined the Australian Labor Party because it was the party of social reform and change—and I am glad that I did. The Labor Party is the party of ideas—ideas that it puts up to the electorate. It has been said in the past sometimes that we can be slightly ahead of public opinion and that we need to educate the public to bring them up to agree with the reforms that we put in place. But we have the Labor Party first, we have public opinion which comes along and eventually is second, and then we have the Liberal and National parties who are about 10 years behind. We have seen plenty of examples of that. There has been the example of child care. Suddenly in Fightback on 18 December the Liberal Party discovered child care as an issue—after 10 years or so. So those opposite had to exempt child care from the GST. They were a bit late.

But in speaking of those opposite, I have to give the honourable member for La Trobe points for courage. This is the man who accepted an invitation to be the guest speaker at a conference of the Public Sector Union in New South Wales where I was a delegate at the time. This is the man who came along and tried to sell Fightback, including his attacks on the public service and trade unions, to the Public Sector Union conference in New South Wales. I do not know whether it is courage or stupidity that we should give him points for. Tonight he once again exemplified his ideological obsession with attacking the trade union movement.

Those opposite have absolutely no substance. They cannot learn from the fact that for over 10 years they have been rejected by the Australian people. Their anti-union, anti-worker and anti-ordinary people policies and attacks just have not been accepted by the Australian people. From their performance in the last two weeks, they have clearly learnt nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) is in the House because I have an excellent suggestion from a group in St Arnaud in country Victoria called the Health and Welfare Coordinating Committee. It has concerns that the local DEET clients must travel from St Arnaud to Ararat—a distance of around about 150 kilometres—so that they can have an interview for their newstart allowance. It is inconvenient for these people, there is no public transport between those two towns, it adds an additional cost to their normal daily living expenses, and they could well do without that facility.

PARA.TAB: The St Arnaud Health and Welfare Coordinating Committee is prepared to allow DEET to use its personal computer in the community health centre; however, it believes that the costs associated with the installation and operation of the modem should be met by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I understand that the committee has put a case to the Minister and to the department, hoping to be able to encourage the Department of Employment, Education and Training to be more flexible in its administration, because rural Victoria is very poorly serviced by that department.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were going to take $10 billion out of the public sector.

—Yes, and I hope the Parliamentary Secretary is taking note. No wonder he is still a Parliamentary Secretary. Perhaps I should address my comments to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear). Services to rural communities is an important issue, and I ask the Parliamentary Secretary and the Assistant Treasurer to take note of this and refer it to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and try to convince him to provide some services to people in remote and rural areas.

—Last night I mentioned to the House substandard shipping and casualties in shipping around the Australian coast, and the tabling on 17 December last year of our report entitled Ships of shame. It has received worldwide acclaim and support from bodies including the world tanker industry, the world bulk carrier industry, the US coastguard, and shipping interests and government interests across Europe. It was a cooperative effort from the transport and communications infrastructure committee of this House. We recommend the report to everybody in the industry. It has been picked up by the BBC and was included in the broadcast of its Panorama special Scandal at sea on 15 February this year.

PARA.TAB: Much has been said about substandard shipping. In 80 per cent of shipping casualties human factor is the major element involved. Problems arise with the use of incompetent crews, crews that are demoralised and exploited, crews that are starved and crews that are denied contact with their families at home. We can have unseaworthy ships and incompetent crews, but not much happens unless somebody uses those ships. I make the point very strongly to this chamber that the users of those vessels—the exporters, the importers and the charterers—must bear a level of responsibility for the dangers they create for the lives of those seafarers, and for the world marine environment.

Next Sunday morning the Channel 9 Sunday program will broadcast a special 50-minute documentary on Ships of shame. It will incorporate the BBC Panorama show and it will incorporate a deal of Australian content. There have been threats of legal action about this program; legal advice has been taken about the content of the program; and references are made by a number of people interviewed in the program, including myself, to the comments about shippers, in particular, CRA.

Four vessels sailed out of Dampier loaded with iron ore and subsequently sank at sea. They suffered catastrophic failure of one type or another. Another two vessels went out of Port Wallcock and another vessel later went out of Cootan Island.

I want to say that I am totally committed to the view and, because it was a unanimous report, I suggest it to colleagues on both sides of this House: the users of these substandard ships must accept a level of responsibility for the dangers they create to the hundreds of Third World seafarers who crew these vessels, and to the marine environment of our nation. It is not enough to say that they charter a ship because it is the lowest rate. If they want to enjoy the lowest rate, the poverty rate that these vessels offer, then they must accept responsibility for the dangers that those vessels create.

So I recommend that program to honourable members. I seek the support of honourable members on both sides of this House because that report and its recommendations were unanimous. It had the unanimous support of all parties represented on the committee. The users of those vessels cannot escape responsibility for the dangers that they create.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question resolved in the negative.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill introduces changes to part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992—the provisions dealing with subscription television broadcasting services, or pay TV.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, as you are aware, on 29 January this year, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) announced changes to defer the allocation of licences under section 96 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 for subscription television broadcasting services delivered on multipoint distribution services. A full explanation of the Government's proposed changes is found in the second reading speech delivered in the Senate.

The Bill introduced in the Senate reflected the policy notification. The Bill has been significantly amended by amendments moved by the Australian Democrats in the Senate and accepted by the Government. The amended Bill has the following effects. It places a deadline of 1 March 1994 on the satellite licensees to reach agreement on a full digital transmission standard to provide an impetus for the early introduction of nationally available satellite pay TV services. It also ensures that a subscription television broadcasting licence cannot be allocated for an MDS pay TV service until a satellite service commences or before 1 January 1995, whichever occurs first.

The Bill will also require the ABA to monitor cross-media ownership of licences allocated under section 96. If the ABA is concerned that the objects of the Act are being undermined, the ABA must report to the Minister and a copy of the report must be laid before each House of the Parliament.

The Bill also ensures that the Minister can direct the ABA to impose conditions on subscription television broadcasting licensees, and not just licensees A, B and C, requiring them to develop Australian industry plans.
I commend the Bill to the House and table the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave not granted for debate to proceed forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move pursuant to contingent notice of motion:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Bill being passed through all its stages without delay.

SPEECH.PARA: I move the motion that stands apparently permanently on the record of the Parliament, and I thought after about five years in the House there would be nothing that would surprise the Leader of the House, but the fact that we have that in position is another thing, I understand, I owe to the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). He invented all these procedures many years ago for which we now, at this late stage of the night, probably do not thank him.

PARA.TAB: I think that in all probability this House and the Senate have considered this legislation enough. It has had an enormous going over in the Senate. Its provisions really are quite simple, as I outlined in the remarks I made in the course of the second reading. The Opposition has chosen not to facilitate discussion on the Bill. It is an Opposition entitlement to do that. There are obviously going to be a number of reasons why it takes that view.

The reason why we are pursuing the matter at this late stage on this night is not that we wish to stick one on the Opposition but that, basically speaking, the industry and all sources of it has presented to us a requirement in its view that we establish as much certainty around these propositions as is possible. Even were we not to use that contingent motion and pursue it, it would be patently obvious that in a week and a half's time, when the House of Representatives met again, the Bill would then pass in its amended form all stages through the House and, as a result of that, the Bill would come into force.

The industry has made absolutely plain to Senator Collins, as it is entitled to in the circumstances, that it wants the matter wrapped up right now. Whilst it is not absolutely essential that that take place, I think in all the circumstances that industry desire ought to be readily comprehended by members of the House and sympathised with. As I said, the Bill has had enormous scrutiny in the Senate. The issue will continue to have enormous scrutiny in the Senate. I think that it would be very useful if we were able now to provide the industry with that certainty, knowing that that scrutiny continues.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Opposition Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has chosen not to grant leave to facilitate what the Government wants because it is necessary, even at this late hour, to emphasise again from our side of the Parliament just what an enormous shambles has attended the Government's handling of matters relating to broadcasting and ancillary matters.

PARA.TAB: We are coming to the end of the first two weeks of the 37th Parliament—and this was meant to be the triumphal march of the true believers—and over the last two weeks we have been treated to an absolute parade of ministerial incompetence, of ministerial bungling, of Ministers barely in control of even the fundamentals of legislation. The Government has had a Minster for Communications in this House who, in the words of Wallace Brown, one of the most experienced political journalists in this country, put on the worst ministerial performance in the House of Representatives in 30 years. The Government has had in the other place a Minister clearly unable to decide whether he did not know what he was signing or whether he decided not to look at what he was signing.

In the case of other aspects of government administration, over the past couple of weeks we have had a demonstration that, so far from the front bench of the Keating Government being the glorious parade of talent that we are led to believe, it is anything but that. So for those reasons we decline to give leave. Undoubtedly the Government will take whatever course of action governments normally take in those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage of the proceedings I just want to address some of the remarks that were made by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in asking the House to accept the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1993. It is not the case that this Bill has received enormous consideration in the Senate. The amendments that are now being put before the House were introduced and agreed to in the Senate only this evening.

PARA.TAB: These amendments have not been placed before the House for any period of time whatsoever. The Minister has not given the Opposition the opportunity to study these amendments. The amendments are a matter of agreement between the Australian Democrats and the Government in the Senate. The Government has, in fact, shown in the Senate debate that it does not have great confidence in these amendments. These amendments have been accepted by the Government because the Government will accept anything to get the smelly mess of this legislation off its plate.

For the Minister to suggest that somehow or other this Bill has received full and adequate consideration, and that therefore there is no reason for this House to look at the Bill in any detail and no reason for this House to be concerned that at 1 a.m. the Bill is now to be rushed through before the House of Representatives rises for a 10-day period, is utter nonsense. To suggest that the industry needs this Bill now is simply not true. It is not the case that the Government and the industry could not wait until the Parliament resumes in the next sitting period; that is, until we have had a chance to view this Bill in its entirety as it has been amended by the Senate.

It is undoubtedly true, as the Leader of the House tells us, that the industry is looking for certainty. Who could blame it? This is the greatest shemozzle that this country has seen in any policy area that I can recall. The industry in Australia is appalled by the mess that the Government has created. The industry internationally is appalled. Even Mr Conrad Black, one of the close friends of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), said to the international press that this was absolutely no way for a government to handle a licence procedure.

The legislation that was considered just prior to this has created huge uncertainty in the industry. Everything the Government has done is creating uncertainty. For the Leader of the House to tell us that we must stampede another piece of legislation through this evening—with amendments that we have not seen, and that Senator Collins has made quite clear in the Senate that the Government does not particularly agree with and does not want but is accepting simply because it wants the legislation through—is an insult to this House and an insult to democracy. That is why we will be opposing this stampede of the legislation through the House of Representatives.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that the Broadcasting Services Bill 1993 has been rushed into the House with indecent haste this evening shows how desperate the Government is to terminate parliamentary discussion on this matter. Honourable members should have seen the smile on Senator Collins' face this evening with the sweat pouring down his forehead realising that the pressure was about to be removed because he had given into the Australian Democrats and had agreed to conditions which he did not approve of—and which he said in the debate he did not think were proper and the right conditions for the Bill. But he was prepared to agree to anything this evening. So we now have the Bill being brought back into the House.

—Before the honourable member for Goldstein continues, I remind honourable members that it may well be early in the morning but there are still standards in the House. Would honourable members resume their seats or carry on their conversations outside.

—The Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) is at least sitting quietly and listening intently. It is good to see the Minister in the House. I noticed the Minister was not involved in the discussions to bring this Bill back into the House. I assume he was involved at some stage and was informed. But he was one of the last into the House and so perhaps it is a surprise to him that this Bill has come back into the House.

PARA.TAB: The Minister was not here for the introduction of the Bill. As we know, the Minister was not informed by Senator Collins of the conditions for the independent inquiry and he was unable to answer questions that were put to him by the media hours after the conditions had been made public.

The Government is desperate to get this legislation through and it is giving every excuse under the sun: the industry wants it; the industry must have it for certainty. It is imperative that this Bill go through at 1.15 a.m. rather than wait 10 days until the Parliament resumes so that this House has an opportunity to actually investigate the provisions which have been placed in the Bill by the deal between Senator Collins and the Democrats.

When one looks, in the short time that has been made available, at the amendments to this legislation, one thing stands out with absolute clarity—that this legislation is the final humiliation of Senator Collins. We can understand why he was so keen to shovel it out of the Senate, back into the House of Representatives and through the Parliament. We remember last year how Senator Collins obediently followed the views of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as expressed on that famous Sunday program with `Laurie of the Overflow'—sorry, Laurie Oakes.

He put the view that the Government was completely neutral in relation to technology. The Government was not concerned about which technology would finally first introduce pay television into Australia. In fact, the Prime Minister was deeply concerned that the Government would be locked into television technology; that it would be locked into a technology based on plastic dishes and that the superior technology of microwave television would be locked out by the regulations that existed then. So the Prime Minister gave his directive: the Government should press ahead with the introduction of MDS microwave transmission for pay TV. He assured the Australian people that this was a superior technology.

Senator Collins, who has never entirely grasped the technology in this area, felt that the Prime Minister must know and so he went along with the Prime Minister. As the year went on, each succeeding month he told people that MDS technology was coming for pay TV. In November he assured the nation that microwave technology would be here first; that Australia would have pay TV by microwave technology before satellite transmission was available.

Of course, what does this Bill do? It makes absolutely clear the reversal of the decision which Senator Collins has had to go along with in such a humiliating way. This Bill makes clear that satellite transmission for pay television will be introduced before MDS transmission. That is an admission which has been wrung from Senator Collins in the Senate this evening. This is what the Bill does: it gives priority to satellite transmission. So much for all the statements that the Government made last year. The Bill is the final nail in the coffin of the whole process over which Senator Collins presided for months and months until the Prime Minister pulled the plug.

This Bill exemplifies the total chaos that has been wrought in this area by the Prime Minister and his mates. The Prime Minister intervened, first of all, to favour one approach; then, under pressure, to favour another approach; and, finally, the industry is in complete confusion as to what framework will be provided. The Government is humiliated. It has got off to the worst start after an election that I can remember. I cannot remember a government which has stumbled from pillar to post in the way that this Government has stumbled over the last three weeks. Now, as I said at the opening of my remarks, it is desperate. It is desperate to get this legislation through, it is desperate to stop the debates in the House and it is desperate to do anything—to agree to anything—so that it can move on to some other matters.

One aspect of this legislation is that it imposes a definite finite starting date for satellite transmission of pay television. This was imposed on the Government by way of amendments moved in the Senate and it is a matter with which we agree. Until this amendment was put forward, there was no obligation whatever on the licensees or on the Government to agree to a definite starting date for pay television. We have waited 13 years for pay television in this country; Australia is just about the last industrial country in the world to have pay television. Until tonight, until the amendments introduced into this House this evening as a result of the deal in the Senate, there was no finite, definite starting date for pay television in Australia.

The amendment that has been placed before the House this evening provides that by 1 March, the licensees for the satellite licences must agree on a standard for transmission, and must agree on a uniform standard. This is to be welcomed because it does give us the prospect that there will be pay TV in Australia. If the agreement is not settled between the licensees, if a standard is not agreed upon, then it is up to the Minister to establish the standard. Of course, there is no time limit within the legislation which specifies when the Minister must settle the standard for pay television. And then the legislation says that it is not until this standard is settled, and it is not until satellite transmission begins, that transmission by MDS—microwave technology—can begin. So a clear priority is given to satellite transmission. But what happens if, when this standard has been agreed upon, satellite transmission does not begin? What happens if there is a further delay? The amendments provide that if there is a further delay, by 1 December 1994 microwave transmission of pay television can begin.

Only two days ago, the Minister for Communications told this House, in answer to a question from me, that he believed that pay television would commence in Australia by mid-1994. Yet the legislation which was introduced here this evening holds out the possibility that we will not get microwave pay TV transmission or any pay TV until into 1995. So within two days, the possible timetable for the introduction of pay TV in Australia has been set back six months. The Minister comes before the House tonight and tells us that this legislation is to introduce certainty. Well, the consumers in Australia have absolutely no certainty from this legislation other than the fact that, by 1995, there is some possibility that they will have pay television.

There are a number of other amendments to this legislation which have been agreed upon by the Government and the Democrats. There is an amendment concerning cross-media ownership. Why this amendment is in this legislation, I do not know; Senator Collins does not know. When Senator Alston in the Senate raised the question as to why this provision was necessary and whether it was in fact just regulation for regulation's sake—which is something that the Democrats enjoy; they are probably the party most dedicated to regulation in this Parliament—Senator Collins said he could only agree that this seemed to be regulation for regulation's sake. But being so desperate to agree to anything, he agreed to it. So it has come before the Parliament tonight and the Government intends to force it through the House of Representatives this evening.

Then there is an amendment for an industry plan to cover all forms of pay television. It is provided that the Australian Broadcasting Authority must ensure the adequate involvement of Australian industry in program production. This provision has no tightness about it; it is a general provision. It seems to be meaningless because it is virtually certain that when microwave television, at least, gets going, because of the nature of that technology and because that technology is geared to transmission to particular communities and is particularly suited to allow communities the kind of pay television which suits their particular cultural or sporting interests, the production for pay television will have a significant Australian content. The generality of this provision is such that it appears to add nothing to the legislation.

When this was pointed out to Senator Collins in the Senate this evening, I understand that he agreed with it—that this provision adds virtually nothing to the legislation. Again, I emphasise that this shows that the Government was prepared to agree to anything to rush this issue through the Parliament.

There is a provision within the amendments for local content, and I understand there will be a review before 1 July 1997 concerning the possibility that some provision could be made to lift local content to 20 per cent. At some distance in the future it is a provision which certainly, if it were acted upon, would impose costs on the new infant industry. It is a provision placed in the legislation by the Australian Democrats because they are not interested in pay television which reflects consumer preferences. They have a view that they should impose a particular position on program content on the industry.

So we have before us tonight a piece of legislation to which it is very hard to give any respect. In only one amendment is there something to be welcomed—at least a date is specified which will encourage the early start of pay television. When I say early, I mean early in terms of what might otherwise have transpired because in this area Australia is, as in so many other areas as a result of ten years of Labor Government, at the back of the pack internationally. We are the last to come into this area.

We are the first with digital compression for satellite transmission. The Government has supported, and now given priority to, a technology which has been tried nowhere in the world. It may be a good technology for pay television. It will be the first, as the Prime Minister said. One of the major reasons for the delay in the introduction of pay television within the last year is that no equipment has been developed by which consumers can receive these digitally compressed transmissions. There has been a long period of delay—a very long period in which Australian consumers have been denied the opportunity which has been readily accessible to consumers throughout the rest of the western world.

Why is that so? Why has there been this extraordinary delay? Has it been a lack of interest on the part of the Government about the interests of the consumer? There has certainly been a general theme of neglect of the public interest in the way that this has been handled. Has it been that particular interests in television in Australia have not pushed for the introduction of pay television and have seen an advantage to themselves in the delay of pay television? These are questions that the public is asking about the Government's dilatory handling of this very important development in television which has come to the rest of the industrialised countries, but not to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, we have this piece of legislation before us tonight as a desperate attempt to clear this whole stinking fiasco off the Government's agenda and off the agenda of this Parliament. Hopefully, out of it there will come a system of pay television which Australians will be able to enjoy and through which they will be able to express their preferences. It is a piece of legislation which reverses the position that the Government has taken for some time but it is at least a piece of legislation which now has a starting date in it. Hopefully the presence of that date in the Bill will encourage the licensees to settle on a standard and to begin the transmission of services at the earliest possible date, which is in their commercial interest, so that Australians can have a fair go in an area where they have been treated with such contempt and where the Parliament has been treated with such contempt by this Government.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Beazley) read a third time.
